He helped her make the move to assisted living and he cleaned out the family home of 50+ years – no small task, indeed.On Thursday, January 17th, as his headaches grew stronger, Sam decided to go to the doctor. The doctor thought the pain might be sinus-related so he ordered a CT Scan. The scan revealed a mass on Sam’s brain. Within a day, he was in brain surgery. Unfortunately the tumor was too intertwined so the surgeons couldn’t remove it. By Sunday, Sam and Vanessa were informed that the cancer in his brain had metastasized from his lungs. Further scans showed the cancer was also in his liver, spine, and jaw.In the face of this devastating news, Sam and Vanessa have been incredibly strong and positive. Humor and laughter, which have been a huge part of Sam’s life, will undoubtedly help him with what lies ahead. Just hours after being diagnosed, Sam was cheering on his beloved New England Patriots in his hospital room. When the nurse asked him to “cheer quieter,” Sam politely nodded. When the nurse left the room, Sam turned to Vanessa and his friends and said, “What are they gonna do? Kill me?”Sam is, simply put, a sweet, kind, and generous soul. Through his music and acting, and most of all his friendship, he has blessed all of our lives immeasurably. Throughout his wonderful life, including his more than 30 years in Los Angeles, Sam has perfected the fine art of friendship. So many of those friends have reached out, wanting to know how they can help support him and his family during this difficult time. As Sam and Vanessa face the challenges ahead, they will both have to put working on hold. There will be a range of medical, childcare, and other expenses. We are asking for your help so our dear Sammy can use the time ahead to GET HEALTHY, spend time with his wife, his new son, and his wonderful friends – and to borrow the title of the new song Sam wrote for his show... “Make Music Along The Way.”Every prayer, every positive thought, every dollar, and every gesture of support is greatly appreciated.ANY AMOUNT WILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE.  Thank you and please check back here for updates!

name: Bec's Battle with Brain Cancer
text: PLEASE SHARE! Only 2 months ago my sister Bec Lancaster-Scully was a happy and healthy 36 year old woman living on the beautiful Gold Coast with her husband Joel & two beautiful boys Will, 5 and Kit, 1.Just before Christmas 2018 Bec suffered a series of migraines and doctors found 2 tumors. At the end of January 2019 Bec underwent brain surgery to remove one of the tumors, the other cannot be removed due to it being on her brain stem. She has since been diagnosed with Grade 4 - primary glioblastoma with a rhabdoid subtype AKA brain cancer.  The average survival time is 12-18 months with only 25% of glioblastoma patients survive more than one year, and only 5% of patients survive more than five years. What makes Bec’s story so incredibly sad and unique are the challenges her and Joel have faced over the past 6 years. Will was born in May 2013 with a heart condition that required heart surgery. He spent 7 weeks in hospital until he was strong enough to undergo the surgery. Then in February 2016 their little boy Jasper was born sleeping at 9 1/2 months. Bec and Joel welcomed Kit into the world in October 2017, born at 34 weeks which kept Bec and Kit in hospital for 6 weeks. Just when they thought all their struggles were over, they’re now faced with this horrible uncertain future. As Bec has family in different parts of Australia and friends all over the world wanting to help, we thought what better way to raise some money to help her, Joel and the boys. As everyone knows medical bills are costly and add up very quickly. Especially when you’re not able to work and trying to run a household all at the same time.Bec is the strongest woman we know & if we can make this fight a little bit easier, we’re going to do whatever we can for her and her boys' future.

name: Help Jon Turner Battle Cancer
text:
Friday night, February 1st Jon thought he was sick with a cold so he left work to get checked out. Within a few hours, he was moved by ambulance to a hospital. Words like a blood clot, lesions on the stomach, low hemoglobin level, possible internal bleeding, all came spilling out to his wife Jasmine and family members.After many of the test results came back we received the devastating news Jon was diagnosed with Stage 4 Stomach and Liver Cancer.  He also has numerous blood clots and internal bleeding. Because of the bleeding they cannot treat the blood clots at this time. The Turner family knows they are in God's hands and have asked for any and all to wrap their family in your prayers during this difficult time. Our Prairie Woods family is trying to help in any possible way right now. With setting up this GoFundMe we hope to help lessen their financial burden as much as possible.  


 


Jon is in his 14th season here at Prairie Woods Golf Course as our Director of Golf and Head PGA Professional.  We know he has played a huge role in everyone's experience at Prairie Woods, like so many other people in his life.  Jon is a husband to Jasmin and the father of seven wonderful children.Jasmine, his wife of 19 years says it best - "To know Jon is to love him, he can be quiet at first but if you watch him, he is always working behind the scenes, helping people any way they need help. He is kind with a heart for children that never stops. His faith in this has been amazing. He is my hero.  Times like this make you realize what a gift we have in each other and how blessed we really are. Jon has been God’s greatest gift to me and I am so grateful to be his wife." Jon has not only been the head of our Golf Department but also to many of us who have worked with him, has been a true leader.  His office door is always open for questions, concerns, golf advice or fantasy football discussions.  He has taken on the leadership role here at Prairie Woods to help so many people through work and individual concerns and needs.


We are asking you to please support this wonderful man.  He has a heart of gold and is a true family man whose kindness, selfless ways and compassion has touched so many of us.

name: Stage IV Breast Cancer has nothing on Jacquelyn
text: In June 2015, Jacquelyn Penrose found out she had breast cancer at the age of 26.  She was a young, hard-working mom of a 2-year-old and spent over a year completing all recommended treatments including chemotherapy, radiation, and a mastectomy.  Despite routine mammograms and completing the standard treatment for breast cancer, we learned in January 2019 that cancer has returned to her body.  Jacquelyn, now 29 years old, was given the devastating news that cancer has spread throughout her body.  Recent PET scans show lesions in her breast, liver, bones, and brain making it a metastatic Stage 4 diagnosis.  This has resulted in several doctors appointments, scans and biopsies, an unexpected ambulance ride and ICU hospital stay, an outpatient surgery, and cancer treatments all in the last three weeks.  Although we don't want Jacquelyn to have to go through this again and are crushed by the news, we choose to believe in miracles and have faith in God's ability to heal.Because of the recent events, Jacquelyn has had to take a leave of absence from work to focus on her health at this time.  Her husband Seth is trying to be with her as much as possible while they raise their 5-year-old daughter together.  Jacquelyn is currently undergoing treatments of chemotherapy and radiation and every donation will help to relieve the financial burden of these treatments. Please donate to financially support Jacquelyn and her family at this difficult time as she battles cancer again!

name: Help Ryker kick Brain Cancer’s Butt
text: ￼￼Sara and Drayton welcomed their first healthy, sweetest, angelic baby boy June of this year. On Tuesday, August 14th, almost 3 month old Ryker Jay was hospitalized due to some unforeseen medical issues. At this time there are still a great deal of unknowns ahead, but their family do know that the medical bills from this will be high. There will be a lot of uncovered medical expenses that need to be paid out of pocket, including extensive medical needs and nursing care. To help ease the burden of this, we have set a goal of $20,000 to help them.If you know either Sara or Drayton, you know how phenomenal, loving, compassionate, selflessness, amazing people they are. Our hearts are very heavy during these moments for them as first time parents and hope that we can help them every step of the way. At this time, The Doyle/Lutz family have all of the medical expertise they need. Please respect their privacy at this time until they are ready to speak out.￼￼￼￼Ryker Jay was diagnosed with a cancerous brain tumor a couple days before he was 3 months old. It was absolutely heart breaking for us as parents. They can not remove the mass and he is too young for radiation. He is undergoing Chemotherapy once a week.. the plan he is on will be for 52 weeks. He had a feeding tube placed to eat and is battling to gain weight. The tumor has caused Diencephalic Syndrome. This is going to be a battle of a lifetime for our little man. Please pray for him. ❤️

name: Lia's Fight Against Cancer
text: Last year our sister Lia had the opportunity to teach English in Korea. While she was there, she developed a persistent cough which prompted her to go in and get it checked out. The doctors broke the news that Lia had stage 4 colon cancer which had already spread to her liver and lungs. Lia was forced to end her adventure in Korea and returned home to Appleton and begin chemotherapy in June of 2018.Several months following Lia’s chemotherapy treatment, Lia reached out to Froedtert Hospital in Milwaukee for a second opinion. Though it was a difficult decision, she decided to continue treatment in Appleton as she felt that being closest to her support system--her family and friends -- would give her the encouragement she needed to fight this disease.Currently, Lia has been having difficulty breathing on her own.  She is relying heavily on oxygen and has been in and out of the hospital in the past month due to her breathing issues in addition to infections.  Because of these complications, her oncologist has stopped her chemotherapy treatments. It has been about two months since her treatments have been discontinued and her condition is not improving.  Her oncologist has recommended that she not undergo any further treatments, but per Lia’s wishes, she still has the will to fight! She has persuaded her oncologist to prescribe an alternative oral chemotherapy medication to trial. However, the process of actually receiving the medication has taken longer than expected and she has not started the medication yet.  As her immediate family, we feel that she would be better cared for at a larger facility with more experienced doctors.  We are scheduled to meet with Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN on March 20th for a consultation, but we are hoping to get Lia in sooner with Virginia Piper Cancer Institute in Minneapolis.Lia is just 25 years young. She still has so many things to look forward to, people to meet, and dreams to chase. For those of you who know Lia, she is an independent, free-spirited, humble, positive human being. She is an ambitious person who always pursued her goals and dreams regardless of what others said. Even as she is battling cancer, she is still the strongest, most positive person we know. Every day is an opportunity for her, and she will not back down from this fight.Until now, she has only opened up to close family and friends. She didn’t want to feel like a burden to anyone. All expenses for consultations and treatment out-of-state would have to be out of pocket. Unfortunately, Lia’s insurance only covers one consultation and it was already used when we consulted with Froedtert Hospital. As her family, we are burdening you for monetary donations which will be used towards all her medical expenses. Please keep her in your prayers and help share her story. We thank you for your time and support.

name: Estelle Breton 40 ans cancer incurable  4 enfants
text: Notre sœur Estelle est atteinte d'un cancer incurable, un mélanome métastatique de stade 4. Estelle est un des cas unique au Canada, concernant l'évolution de son cancer et la réception aux traitements. Elle est une mère de 4 jeunes enfants. Nous voulons ramasser des fonds pour l'aider ( à la fin du message les détails) Voici son histoire, notre histoire:Estelle, 38 ans, était une femme enjouée mère de 3 enfants Malyah 1 an, Emrys 3 ans et Nathaniel 5 ans, elle était enceinte de sa 4e quant à sa 27e semaine de grossesse en octobre 2017 elle a découvert sous son bras gauche une petite bosse. Elle est allée consulter, ils lui ont fait une biopsie pour lui apprendre que s'était une récidive à un mélanome qu'elle s'était fait enlever 3 ans plus tôt dans le dos, une simple grain de beauté qui avait changé de couleur. TOUT UN CHOC pour elle et toute notre famille!!! On lui dit que tant qu'elle n'aura pas accouché on ne pourra rien faire pour elle. La bosse grossit à vue d'œil alors son accouchement est provoquée à 37 semaines de grossesse. Félycia voit le jour le 5 janvier 2018. Son état va de mal en pire elle sera opérée le 11 janvier, pour lui retirer un tumeur rendu d'une grosseur d'un pamplemousse seulement 6 jours après son accouchement. Tout les espoirs sont permis nous la croyons sauvée. Elle continue malgré tout à prendre soins de ses 4 ENFANTS avec un drain sous le bras et des souffrances incommensurables. Après 1 mois sa plaie guérit et peu passer un TEP. Ils découvrent que le cancer s'est multiplié par le système lymphatique. C'est l'horreur son bébé à juste 1 mois et elle a ses 3 autres enfants. Un essai clinique non homologué par Santé Canada s'offre à elle l'Immunothérapie, la réponse des assurances est positive, les traitements débutent début mars à tout les 2 semaines pour prolonger sa vie et avoir la chance de voir ses enfants grandir. Son dermatologue est surpris des résultats, Estelle répond très bien aux traitements avec très peu d'effets secondaires, mise à part une très grande fatigue. Le printemps passe, les traitements continus elle reste forte, courageuse et présente pour les siens. À l'été les effets secondaires s'accentuent, elle continue de se battre même si elle a besoin de plus en plus d'aide. À l'automne elle repasse un TEP et tout est stable, nous voyons enfin une lumière au bout du tunnel! L'énergie revient elle semble de mieux en mieux, les traitements sont donc diminués au mois. On passe un beau noël ensemble comme avant. Début janvier 2019, Estelle se plaint de maux de ventre de plus en plus fréquent. Elle repasse un TEP le 4 février 2019 et BOUM le 5 février le ciel nous tombe sur la tête; son hématho-oncologue lui apprend la triste nouvelle une 3e récidive vient la happer. Une grosse tumeur à l'intestin  est apparue et la maladie est trop avancée pour l'enlever. Nous sommes dévastés!!! Une seule option s'offre à elle une autre sorte d'immunothérapie, un autre essai clinique, avec beaucoup plus d'effets secondaires cette fois-ci, la maladie doit arrêter de progresser, le temps presse.!!! Nous demandons votre aide afin que notre Estelle qui est âgée d'à peine 40 ans et ses 4 enfants de 1,3,5 et 7 ans puissent vivre dans un environnement adéquat et qu'Estelle puisse réaliser son rêve d'avoir une maison pour elle et sa petite famille. Présentement dans un petit 5 et demi avec la maladie et ses 4 enfants, l'un de ses rêves est de déménager dans une maison pour permettre à ses enfants d'avoir plus d'espace et pour elle d'avoir un milieu facilitant son quotiden et la gestion de sa maladie. Plus d'espace lui permettrait d'adapter son milieu de vie à sa réalité et d'accueillir l'aide nécessaire qu'elle aurait besoin au quotidien.Chaque petit geste et don compte. Nous vous en serons éternellement reconnaissant. MERCI de nous aider à prolonger la vie de notre sœur dans la quiétude et la sérénité. Estelle à tellement un grand cœur elle ne mérite pas ce qui lui arrive. Tout ce que nous voulons c'est un petit coup de pouce de votre part pour qu'Estelle puisse croire que dans la vie tout est possible et qu'ensemble nous pourrons apaiser son histoire. MERCIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIII pour votre grande générosité.Ses sœurs Christine, Isabelle et Sophie qui l'aiment tant et qui croient encore à l'humanité xxx Pour les dons par virement interac 581-985-3049 réponse Estelle ou par chèque au nom d'Estelle Breton envoyé au 300 Route 283 notre dame du rosaire qc G0r2h0 MERCI Les sous amassés serviront tout d'abord à:Entretien ménager , aide pour les repas, épicerie commissions. Une aide à la maison à tous les jours pourr les enfants le matin et le soir. Aider dans tâches quotidienne (lavage, etc.)Aide pour les différentes commissions ( services de livraison épicerie pharmacie, transport des enfants, aide pour les RV ( estelle ne peut pas toujours conduire, etc.). Merci infiniment ☺️￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼

name: Amanda's Cancer Fight
text: Amanda is in the fight for her life. After being misdiagnosed for months, she finally got the diagnosis of a life threatening Gastric Adenocarcinoma Stage 4.  With this diagnosis, she is not a candidate for the surgery needed to remove her stomach.She may be a candidate for a radical surgery called HIPEC, which is very extensive and costly, with an extremely long recovery period and many months of treatment to follow. During this time she will not be able to work to help support her family.  She just started a new job as a Para Educator at Columbus Community School in November, so she is not eligible for benefits. Matt works at Cooper Gutter Service in Letts, Iowa, and will have to take time off in order to take Amanda to her many appointments. Amanda and her fiance, Matt, are parents to 3 wonderful children, Mason, 16, Jillian, 15, and Cash, 11. Together they all enjoy spending time in the outdoors, trout fishing, and camping. Matt and Amanda are hardworking and loving people who are always willing to help anyone in need. We are now reaching out to our friends, family, and communities to ask for help so Amanda has a chance to fight this horrible disease. We want to see her grow old and have the opportunity to see her children graduate, marry, and have her grandchildren. We have such a sense of urgency and need your help, prayers, and recommendations or referrals to somewhere, anywhere that can help her. We are desperate. Thank you for any help you can give to her and her family. With all of you behind us, Amanda will beat this!God Bless.

name: Gilbert Rodriguez Cancer Battle
text: Gilbert Rodriguez was diagnosed with stage 3 testicular cancer in January 2019. He is a 22 year old senior at William Penn University in Oskaloosa, Iowa originally from Manassas, Virginia. He has had surgery to remove the tumor and chemotherapy treatment will start on February 18th for a 4 month duration. He has had to put his collegiate wresting career on hold as well as his Information Technology internship at this time. We are looking to raise money for him to offset the cost of his medical treatments as well as gas money to drive the 60 miles each way for his 5 day a week treatment schedule and money for food and rent. His mom has made the trek from Manassas to Iowa to be with him during this most difficult time and she is also unable to work due to the needs at hand. Gilbert is a 3.1 GPA student in his senior year of college with a bright future ahead of him. Please come together to help Gilbert and his family during this time of need. Any and all donations will be highly appreciated!! No amount is too small. Thank you in advance for helping this wonderful young man in this time of need.

name: Help Julie, a new mom, fight breast cancer.
text: This January, just a few months after her 40th birthday, Julie was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. The cancer is quite advanced and has spread to her lymph nodes, which means she has a gruelling 6 months of chemotherapy and surgery ahead of her.With her beautiful daughter, Cicely, just about to turn 2, Julie’s biggest anxiety is not being able to be the mom that her little girl needs. Nick and Julie need some financial help. This will allow Julie to stop working and Nick can reduce his long hours as a chef in order to care for both Julie and Cicely during and after her treatments. Julie's goal throughout her treatment process is to keep a positive healthy environment for her family and to make life as normal as it was for Cicely before her diagnosis. We know that Nick and Julie have a big worldwide network and there are lots of people wondering what they can do to help from many miles away. Here is what you can do. The money we raise here will enable the family to spend more time together during this fight. It will help with childcare, cover lost wages and allow Julie to focus her energy into beating cancer and being the amazing mother and wife that she has always been.It has taken some time to convince our dear friends that it’s ok to ask for help and sometimes all you need to do is put it out there and let the world show you its kindness. Thank you xJess and Bianca

name: Bras de fer contre le cancer / Soutenez Yvanns!
text: Bonjour à tous,C'est avec beaucoup d'émotions, d'espoir et d'amour que nous vous demandons votre aide pour le combat de notre courageux Yvanns, 24 ans, qui a récemment reçu un diagnostic d'un sarcome des tissus mous dans la main gauche, une forme de cancer très rare et malheureusement très agressive. Sa seule chance de survie? Première étape, l'amputation de la main gauche qui aura lieu dans les prochaines semaines. Ce n'est que suite à cette étape que nous saurons s'il doit passer par d'autres types de traitements en plus pour s'assurer que le cancer ne fasse pas d'autres dégâts. Yvanns est un battant et il est prêt à tout pour réaliser ses rêves : avoir des enfants avec sa blonde avec qui il est depuis 5 ans et une maison pour se créer de beaux moments avec ceux qu'ils aiment.  À seulement 24 ans, il sait que malgré la perte d'une main il a encore beaucoup à vivre et il veut mettre toutes les chances de son côté pour y arriver!Il sait toutefois qu'avec l'amputation de sa main gauche, il devra travailler plus fort que jamais pour y parvenir : - Achat et adaptation à sa prothèse : Yvanns travaille physiquement, une prothèse lui permettant de reprendre son travail par la suite coûte plus cher que des prothèses standards (prix à venir).- Frais de déplacements et d'hébergements, car tous les rendez-vous et les opérations ont lieu à l'Hôtel-Dieu de Québec (nous vivons à Sherbrooke).- Achat/Adaptation de son véhicule. - Soutien physique et psychologique (nous regardons déjà les Centres pour les amputés dans lesquels les personnes reçoivent de l'aide pour diminuer la fréquence des douleurs fantômes).- Comme Yvanns commence dans la vie, les économies de sa blonde et lui ne peuvent subvenir à tous ses besoins ni rencontrer leurs obligations financières sans stress. En l'aidant vous l'aider à se concentrer sur sa guérisson et à oublier les problèmes financiers engendrés par le cancer.- Grand sportif et amateur de jeux vidéos, du matériel adaptés sera nécessaires pour qu'Yvanns puisse continuer à jouer au hockey et s'amusersur la Xbox avec ses amis. Dans ce genre de combat, pouvoir continuer ses loisirs est un pas de plus vers la guérison. - Tout le nécessaire pour faciliter son entrée dans sa nouvelle vie et parer aux imprévus qu'engendre un diagnostic de cancer.Nous ne sommes qu'au début du processus, il est difficile pour le moment d'estimer totalement tous les coûts qu'engendreront la nouvelle situation d'Yvanns, mais nous savons que chaque dons est pour lui une raison de plus de se battre et de vous montrer de quoi il est capable! N'oubliez pas, tous les dons sont importants, des plus petits au plus gros, et seront un coup de main de plus dans le bras de fer d'Yvanns contre le cancer. Nous vous tiendrons au courant à chacune des étapes de son combat pour vous témoigner de la grande différence qu'apporte votre soutien dans la vie d'Yvanns et de ses proches.De sa part et de celle de ses proches, merci énormément de nous permettre de le soutenir dans cette épreuve et de lui donner espoir en une qualité de vie qui le soutiendra tout au long de sa vie.- Team Yvanns

name: Mandeep Singh- Cancer Treatment and Education Fund
text: We are trying to raise funds to help Mandeep Singh, 20 yr old student who came to America, from a village near Kharar, Punjab, India on Jan 4th 2019 to study Nursing at Missouri Western University in St Joseph Missouri and pursue his dreams. Unfortunately the culture shock, unfamiliar food and extreme weather resulted in him loosing weight and other complications and he ended up in emergency in St Jo, who then transferred him to KUMC hospital in Kansas City.During his stabilization and investigations, KUMC hospital medical team diagnosed Mandeep with advanced stage of Neuro-Endocrine Cancer with a prognosis of a few months lifespan. Mandeep's student friends reached out to Indian Association of Kansas City to request for help as he was lonely and craved Indian food. Who in turn reached out to the Sikh community, so that we could alleviate his cultural shock by sending visitors who could speak to Mandeep in Punjabi, his native language. Mandeep was getting ready to head back to India to be with his family, depressed and resigned to his fate, but he was lucky enough that Dr Jaswinder Singh an Oncologist who is a part of local Sikh/Indian community decided to intervene, review his case and suggested that a treatment for his cancer was available (PRRT Therapy) that can significantly prolong Mandeep's life. The treatment will last approx a year and as Mandeep does not have the resources, the local Sikh/Indian community is rallying around him to provide accommodation and raise funds to maintain his status at the university, fund out of pocket costs of treatment and medicines as well as offer travel back to India so that he can see his family which currently is his greatest wish. We are making an appeal to the wider Indian Community to help with whatever small amounts of donations you can to give this young man a chance at a new life and hope to fulfill his dreams that he came to America for. Our goal is to get the funding in place over the next two weeks to help support Mandeep's treatment and stay here.Also as you are donating and believe in the worthy cause please share this campaign on your social networks, so that we can reach the widest list of donors possible and every small additional donation helps.Some folks have expressed concern about high 'tips' suggestion from GoFundMe page when they try to donate, I think it defaults to 10%, click on the dropdown arrow and you should see option of 'Other' choose this and you can decide what tip you wish to give to GoFundMe.Note: For those who wish to visit with Mandeep Singh and wish him well in person, the address is "Gurudwara Nanak Darbar Sahib, 126 S Cherry St, Olathe, KS 66061". Please be mindful that we will be restricting visits after he starts his treatment on 2/13, for 3-4 days, for Mandeep's and visitors safety reasons. Also please avoid visits if you have cough, cold or any type of flu symptoms, Mandeep's reserves to fight of infections are low.

name: Whippy Cake (Becki Crosby) Cancer Treatment Fund
text: Whip is a beautiful single mother of four small children who is handling breast cancer with grace and confidence.  She has used her platform as a public speaker and influencer to share her story and struggles. Even when she's been sick from chemo or recovering from surgery she still find a way to use her situation as a way to help others. She has had such a positive impact on many people who are also going through cancer treatment. Whip handled the double mastectomy and lymph node removal unbelievably well. She has been in treatment for 8 months and still has at least a year ahead of her. The multiple surgeries, chemo, radiation and daily hyperbaric treatments have impacted her ability to work. This go fund me is to help with her growing medical bills. Any amount is greatly appreciated.

name: Kali’s Cancer Treatment
text: First off, thank you for taking the time to visit this gofundme page. Your contribution and support for Kali during this difficult time is deeply appreciated. On December 27th Kali was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. This completely changed her life. In order to focus on what has become the biggest challenge she has ever faced, she is taking time off from work and essentially putting her life on hold. Coming to terms with breast cancer at the age of 32 is challenging to say the least. Minnesota has a great health care system, and Kali is confident in her treatment plan. She enrolled in an immunotherapy clinical study, which has given her access to cutting edge treatments and further testing. These tests include MRIs, CTs, and PET scans. The results from the first set of scans confirmed that the cancer is stage 2b. While still an aggressive form of cancer, it thankfully has not spread to any other areas of her body.Kali had her first chemotherapy infusion on January 28th, and these treatments will continue for 22 weeks. Following chemo, she will have surgery in August to remove the tumor and breast tissue. This surgery will likely be a full or partial mastectomy to reduce any chance of recurrence. There will be a recovery period after surgery, which may be followed by radiation therapy depending on further test results. Hormonal treatment is the last step and will continue for an undetermined length of time. Kali is fortunate to have health insurance to help pay for most of the medical costs associated with treatment; however, her monthly health insurance costs have increased. She has medical and pharmaceutical deductibles to pay, and other parts of this process that are not covered by insurance. These include fertility treatments, genetic counseling, and unforeseen additional costs. As there was no immediate family history of breast cancer until now, genetic counseling is especially important. It will help doctors determine which surgery will be most appropriate, and provide invaluable information to the other women in Kali’s family. Facing these financial burdens while battling cancer feels overwhelming. The money from this fund will provide financial relief in a challenging time. Kali’s friends can attest: Kali is one of the most caring, adventurous, supportive, and wise people you’ll ever meet. We have no doubt she’ll win this battle, but your help would mean a lot as she navigates this challenge. She can’t wait to return to happier times of hiking, traveling, and spending quality time with her friends and family. Any donation amount helps. Kali is so grateful for all the amazing people in her life. Thank you all, and we love you!

name: Mother of 4 diagnosed with stage 4 cancer
text: On Friday, February 1st, 2019 we were informed that my mother was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer of her liver, lung, and colon. She had been having stomach pains for quite awhile and after a few failed attempts with her doctor, she decided to go to the emergency room. It was then that we found out about the possibility of having cancer. They ran some tests and did a biopsy only to find out the tests came back positive. We are all extremely devastated and heartbroken to find out that our hero, our mother, our best friend has been diagnosed with cancer. You never think it will happen to you until it does. She is a wife. She is a best friend. She is a mother to my three sisters and I. She is my whole world and my younger sisters being two and six can’t really comprehend the severity of what is going on. Not only the treatments, but also the studies can be quite costly. My dad has taken off work to be there for my mom and be the greatest father to my sisters. That’s why I am here asking for support.

name: Help Dulce Fight Cancer
text: UPDATE: I have changed the goal to $100,000. Because my mother is now in an out-of-network hospital, our insurance will not cover most of the expenses. My father is not working right now; he stays with my mom day and night, only coming back home to shower. He sleeps on a chair in the room with her. Even after my mom wakes up from intubation, he still won't return to work for a couple of months so he can be my mom's caregiver at home. We have no other relatives here as they are in the Philippines. It is just my dad, mom, my sister, and me here in the USA. The $100,000 will be used for the hospital bills and future treatment at UCSF and Stanford if the chemotherapy does not work.Near the end of 2018, my mom wasn’t feeling well. She had a hard time breathing and was cold all the time. She went to urgent care—no x-ray was taken.  They given antibiotics and a nebulizer. After weeks went by, she continued to get worse. We went to urgent care again. They took an x-ray. Then we got a call from her doctor saying that she needed to go to the ER because he said she had pneumonia and there was a dark shadow on her lungs. At the hospital, they realized she had fluid in her lungs and pericardial cavity. She also had multiple nodules throughout her lungs. After a thoracentesis in which they extracted 600 mL from her lungs, the results from the fluid came back. On January 31st, 6 weeks after my mom first fell ill, she was diagnosed with stage IV lung cancer. Her right upper lobe has already collapsed. My maternal grandmother was a heavy chain smoker, but my mom has never smoked a cigarette in her life.  She was at her healthiest in 2018—she went to the gym daily, ate healthily, lost weight, gained muscle. She had so much energy until now. My entire family is in shock. Despite the weeks that have passed by, she STILL has not received any treatment for her cancer. It has been over a week since genetic testing was done to see if she had certain mutations that would allow for targeted therapy. We are STILL waiting for those results.She was sent home on February 1st on an oxygen tank. At 3 AM on February 3rd, she was gasping for air. We called for an ambulance. My dad went with her. At 5 AM, my dad called me to get to the hospital ASAP because he was scared she wasn't going to make it. She couldn't breathe. The ER doctor wanted to place her on an incubator. Once we arrived, the doctor finally put her on a BiPAP which significantly helped her with breathing. She was finally able to get a bed after 12 hours of being in the ER.The doctors wanted her to get an airway stent in her lungs. The hospital she is currently at does not provide this surgery. We have been waiting almost a week now for surrounding hospitals that can do the surgery to open up a bed for her. We thought she was getting better the last 2 days. Her breathing was slower and her voice was stronger. But last night, her breathing worsened. Her doctors now no longer want to do the surgery. I am frustrated because if the surgery was done earlier this week when she was better, we would not be having this issue. But now she is in serious, critical condition. She can't breathe.We have been told by others in the healthcare field to take her to UCSF to get proper and immediate care, instead of waiting weeks for something to be done. However, our insurance refuses to cover us if we do transfer her to UCSF. The purpose of this GoFundMe is to help pay for the treatments that my mom desperately needs. She is 51 years old. Just last Christmas she was talking about how she was excited to get presents for her future grandchildren. The doctors told her she had at least 1 year and at most 5 years to live. Yet every single day that we wait for her results to come back, beds to open up, and insurance to approve of her medications, her condition continues to worsen.If you cannot donate, please keep my mom in your thoughts and prayers.Thank you in advance,Reeva

name: Help Sarah Beat Breast Cancer
text: My name is Sarah Harling, I am 26 years old and was just diagnosed on January 21st with grade 3 Invasive Mammary Carcinoma. I recently accepted a promotion at a nonprofit organization called Epilepsy Pralid as a Fiscal Intermediary. Because I was so recently employed by this organization, I do not yet qualify for FMLA benefits. As a first time insurance buyer and previously healthy individual, I have an exceptionaly high deductible (upwards of $20,000). I start chemotherapy Friday, February 7th and will continue for a 16 week regimen, along with several other expensive cancer related medications. After I finish chemotherapy I will be undergoing two surgeries and radiation therapy. As you can imagine, the bills are already piling up. It is for this reason that I am asking for your help in making my transition into recovery as smooth as possible. At such a young age it is extremely rare to have such an aggressive form of breast cancer, and this has been an incredibly emotional time for both myself and my family. Any donation would truly be a blessing, and I want you all to know that I appreciate your thoughts and prayers during this immensely difficult time.

name: Titus's journey to fight cancer
text: At 2.5 years old Titus is already in the fight of his life. As happy and rambunctious little boy, he is a champion who has all the love in the world ready to combat this situation. However, this is going to be a tough journey. He can always use the love, kindness, and support of family, friends, and those who care to see him have all the greatest success in his life. Titus was diagnosed with Neuroblastoma. Although diagnosed early, the cancer has progressed quickly, He has some of the best care available at Children's Hospital of The King's Daughters in Norfolk Virginia and they are all going to help him in his care and treatment to look forward to one day being cancer free.Having said all that, there will be some obstacles for those immediate family members supporting him in this fight. Time off of work and specialized care are in everyone's future.If you can find it in your heart to help a wonderful little boy go through this journey, he and his family will be forever grateful.Thank youFromVictoria, Paul, Grandma's, Grandpa's and extended family.

name: Josh's Army: A Cancer Fundraiser for Josh Schwarz
text: Days after Thanksgiving 2017, Josh Schwarz, 37, was given the devastating news...It’s Cancer… Squamous Cell Carcinoma to be exact. Three weeks later, he was in an operating room for fifteen hours at St. Luke’s Hospital, as surgeons removed the malignant tumor, 1/3 of his tongue, and lymph nodes at the back of his mouth, and neck; followed by extensive reconstruction. After an extremely tough week in surgical ICU, he was able to go home, just in time for Christmas, to prepare for the next phase of recovery. With speech therapy and proactive measures planned – including radiation and chemotherapy - to prevent the cancer from returning, he knew he had a long road ahead of him. After weeks of healing, post-surgery, Josh endured another 9 weeks of outpatient treatment to kill the cancer cells in his body. There was joy all around when he rang the victory bell on his last day; as these were truly some of the hardest weeks of his life. As the Josh we all know and love, he kept his unwavering positive outlook on life; spending time with his family, friends, co-workers and guiding students to be the best version of themselves at the junior high school, where he works as an Assistant Principal. He regained his strength, and abilities that we may easily take for granted every day. After some time, Josh found his new normal. Life was good! Fast forward to January 2019: Josh met with his doctors for a routine post-Cancer checkup. Unfortunately, the results weren’t what we hoped for. The Squamous Cell Carcinoma is back, with a vengeance. Josh is now quickly preparing for a second surgery to remove the tumor on his lung. And, we are all ready to fight with him. However, he's still paying back the medical debt from the first round of care received during surgery, chemotherapy and radiation. So, this is where we PRAY HARD, and ASK FOR YOUR HELP. Josh’s surgery and post-op chemotherapy are going to be very expensive, over the next six months. We really, really, need your support. Please donate anything you can, today, to help Josh #DestroyCancer Thank you, so, so much for all of your love, support, and prayers. They are always welcome!

name: Sergeant Simonds Cancer Treatment
text:
Recently, Brian was diagnosed with cancer. Like many people who are met with this sobering diagnosis, it came as a surprise and a host of emotions. Brian wears many hats. He is a husband, a father of 6 children, including 15 month old twins, and a Sergeant with the Dallas Police Department. It is safe to say many people at home and in the community rely on him. 

Surgery is scheduled to happen within the next few weeks, at which time they will learn more about his prognosis and whether the cancer has spread, which is a concern at the moment. With any surgery and cancer diagnosis, there are a few certainties. First being a loss of wages. Like most police officers, he works a steady schedule of "extra jobs"  and overtime to make additional money for his family. Secondly, the accumulation of medical bills. Even with insurance, the costs will add up quickly and all money raised will go toward offsetting these expenses. Brian is the Captain and founder of the Dallas Police Hockey team which has raised tens of thousands of dollars since its creation helping officers in need. Now it is time to help someone who has helped so many himself. As always, any little bit helps. Thank you for your time and your help.

name: Breast Cancer Sucks
text: Hey everyone, it's Marica Hase. At the end of last year, I found out that I had breast cancer. We went to many doctors and finally made a decision of what to do. This month, I will get a bi-lateral mastectomy and reconstruction at the same time--it will be performed at the City of Hope Facility/Providence Hospital. I want to work in the industry again, so this seemed like the best option.I will be out of work for 4 months plus the insurance doesn't cover everything. The $50k will cover all my related expenses, post-op, treatment and medicines.  Plus, I might need chemo and radiation.  If anything is left over, I will donate it to the City of Hope, who have helped save my life.Please give what you can no matter how small. I love everyone in the industry and I feel like you're family. And, family helps family. Buusan says thank you.

name: Help Seth Kick Cancer's Butt
text: Please help my niece Erika and her husband Antonio be able to be with their 7 year old son Seth as much as possible while he battles T Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  My goal is to help them enough financially so that they can spend more time with Seth.  This is their story:Last Tuesday night we noticed swelling in his neck, swollen lymph nodes. He had had a cold for a long time and was very congested. His tonsils were swollen and red. We brought him to the doctor Wednesday morning. The did a strep test which came back negative. He had an ear infection in his right ear. The doctor suspected he had some sort of virus which can cause swelling of the lymph nodes. They did some blood work. His mono test came back negative. His white blood count was only slightly elevated at 16,000. Normal range is between 5,000 and 10,000. Since it was only slightly elevated they thought the ear infection explained the elevation. We were sent home with antibiotics and scheduled to come back for a follow up. The following Tuesday we brought him in for his follow up appointment where the doctor noticed a rash around his neck and on his lower abdomen, it looked like lots of tiny broken blood vessels. She voiced her concern about the rash and called the hospital. We were sent to the ER. After waiting for hours we were finally seen by a doctor who ordered blood work. His white count was 245,000. We were admitted to the pediatric ICU that night. He received lots of fluids through IV. The next morning he was brought to the OR for procedures under general anesthesia. He had a lumbar puncture to ensure there was no leukemia in his central nervous system and the fluid they took out was replaced was an equal dose of chemo. A PICC (peripherally inserted central catheter) line was placed for easier long term access for treatment, this will later be replaced with a port in his chest, surgically placed. And he had a bone marrow biopsy where a needle was put into his hip bone to extract bone marrow and fluid from within the bone. The procedures went well and he handled anesthesia like a champ. The bone marrow sample confirmed that he has T cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. The plan for phase one is to receive steroids and chemotherapy for 4 weeks. At the end of the 4 weeks he will need another bone marrow biopsy to reevaluate the levels of leukemia in the bone marrow which will determine the steps for phase two. Right now the oncologist says we're looking at a 6 month process with hope of remission where leukemia levels are undetectable. Unfortunately this is a lifelong diagnosis that we will have to keep monitoring for the rest of his life.

name: Soula Pavlakos cancer treatments
text: Soula’s story Soula Pavlakos is a mother of two young children, Katerina 13 and Steven 11 years of age. She was diagnosed with breast cancer 7 years ago at the age of 40 years old. After doing many rounds of chemotherapy and radiation she had a double mastectomy to help reduce the chances of the cancer ever coming back. However, just over 2 years ago her mother passed away unexpectedly and tragically after having been ill herself for many years. In the midst of all this stress her worst fears had become reality again as the cancer returned even more aggressively and had metastasized to her major organs and bones. The impact of this news has been devastating to her family especially to her 2 young children who have known nothing in their short lives but knowing their dearest mom has cancer. They live in daily fear about her illness. She again began traditional chemotherapy and radiation in Canada but also to explore alternative cancer treatments in other countries as she was not getting any better. In January of 2018 she went to a world-renowned clinic in Mexico and spent 21 days there receiving treatments which started working well and she was feeling a lot better and stronger after that. Before going down to Mexico she could not even walk a few steps to the mailbox without feeling exhausted. After that initial treatment, she was walking briskly around the block. However this treatment requires constant trips to continue the healing and so she made an additional 3 trips there last year receiving treatments that are not offered in Canada. So not only has she been spending precious time away from her young family but they have spent tens of thousands of dollars doing everything they can to get Soula to beat this disease. Unfortunately, OHIP and medical aid do not cover any costs for these crucial treatments. She will now need to go back to a hospital in Mexico where she will need to stay for a month to receive innovative treatments for 6 hrs a day 7 days a week including a stem cell bone marrow transplant which is not offered as a treatment regimen in Canada for breast cancer. This will cost them another $55,000 CDN but as you can see they want to do everything they possibly can to keep their loving mother and wife alive and well for as long as they can.This disease has been a tremendous financial and emotional burden on this family and I reach out to all to help Soula get the necessary medical treatment to help her in her battle to defeat this dreadful disease. Thank you all for your support to Jack and Soula.

name: Help Vanessa fight cancer
text: Vanessa is our friend, aunt, daughter, niece, cousin, sister, grand-daughter, sister-in-law and co-worker.  As many of you know, she is a tenacious person.  She has been this way from childhood on.  So cancer may be unprepared for the tough contender who will be fighting back with all her strength.  Vanessa has blood clots in her lungs and a rare form of cancer in the biliary ducts of her liver (Cholangiocarcinoma).  She is on blood thinners for the clots in her lungs and has started chemotherapy treatments for the cancer in her liver.  The chemotherapy sessions happen for two weeks followed by a week of rest.  This routine will be repeated for the next several months, so keep Vanessa in your prayers and thoughts.While Vanessa is undergoing chemotherapy she will need support and assistance from loved ones.  In this, Vanessa is blessed with a loving family, friends and supportive people from her church.  However, in order for Jake and Lorraine to assist their daughter, Vanessa, they will be making trips to, and stays in, Calgary, Alberta while leaving their farm in Saskatchewan behind.  The cost of these trips, away from work and home, will accumulate over time.  As for Vanessa, the blood thinners are needed for the rest of her life at $1,000.00 a month.  The cost of the thinners are covered till the end of June.  After that, it is unknown how these prescriptions will be paid for.  The prescriptions, parents' travel costs, and other expenses will add up fast, while Vanessa's income on disability is only 65%.In making this gofundme page it is our hope to lighten the financial burden so Vanessa can take on this battle with all her strength and mind without added distractions, worries and financial woes placed upon her and her family.  Please consider donating to help Vanessa as she takes on the biggest battle she has ever faced.  If you can, donate whatever possible, a one time donation, a monthly donation or a small donation every payday.  Help Vanessa fight and give cancer a knockout punch!campaign created on behalf of my niece, Vanessa.

name: Help George Kick Cancer's Ass
text: Cancer sucks! Whether you know George or not, you likely know someone who has had the unfortunate run-in with cancer.  You also likely know how incredibly difficult it can be without help from people who care about you.  Now, if you KNOW George, you know he bends over backwards for anyone, any time. He's the first one to offer a helping hand, but he's the last one to ask for it.  As his friends, we decided to ask for him.To give you a little background on George.  He was born and raised in a tight community in northern WI. Everyone knows George and if you ask, they will likely have a funny story about a great memory with "Little Georgie Gunderson."  George raised 2 wonderful sons, is a volunteer fireman and has a long history of helping everyone and anyone. George is a respected Realtor and member of the community, serving on various boards and committees.  But most of all, George is known for just being a heck of a guy and genuine person.  George was recently diagnosed with a very rare cancer called Chordoma.  It's a rare type of cancer that occurs along the spine and extends into the surrounding tissue.  In George's case, the cancer is in his spine and throat and has begun to affect his breathing, which is how he found out he has cancer.  This is not an easy surgery, nor is it an easy recovery.  After the invasive surgery, George will spend months recovering.  In George's line of work as a Realtor, there is no sick pay, disability coverage or paid time off.  He relies solely on commission, so you can imagine the financial stress and worry this causes.  We want George to be focusing on his health and recovery and not how he is going to pay bills.  Every little bit helps.  Please consider a donation to help George in these next few months.

name: Cilla's Alternative Cancer Treatment
text: I'm on a transformative healing journey of my own. I'm reaching out to share it with you. For the last decade I've poured my heart and soul into my healing practice. I have also used all my spiritual and material resources to produce and direct the Real Immunity film series. With each person touched or energized by my work, I have felt uplifted and motivated to go forward. Last December I began to feel drained. I felt encumbered with trying to stem the tide of human suffering. It seemed an impossible task.  It was then that I found a suspicious lump in my breast. My first impulse was not to engage in the conventional medical industry -- an industry based on fear, worst case scenarios, and despair over "sickness."  So I reached out to colleagues to assist in ordering my own testing, while I also met with a functional doctor, my psychic friends, a master herbalist, and wise associates.  I underwent Dark Field Microscopy, cinched up my diet, added supplements, and began the process to remove my ever suspicious root canals. I scheduled surgery, cancelled surgery, buried my beloved 14 year old Golden doodle, and have been humbled and sustained by the outpouring of love and support from the people in whom I confided. As I assembled my own care plan, I continued to read and seek and question everything. I've felt remorse over preaching in my films and to my clients about avoiding fear, when now it was my constant companion.Then I made a decision. I have decided to go to this healing program;  www.Hope4Cancer.com, and I feel light, clear, and excited. I'm filled with gratitude that I have this opportunity to learn more, change more, and evolve. I see it as a sacred calling to understand what "healing" really is, through a deeply personal experience. The program starts on Feb 27 with 3 weeks of intensive therapies outside of the U.S. for 8 hours daily.  I'm followed closely for 3 months after returning home. Then 2 more on-site follow-ups are included with additional support for an entire year.  My deepest desire is to share it all with you in detail so you can have questions answered, learn, and understand what true healing of real immunity looks and feels like.  I appreciate any donation you feel able to contribute to the financial cost of my healing journey. In return, I pledge my commitment to keeping you informed, and to acknowledging the love and light you are providing to sustain me on the journey.  ❤️

name: Help Léandre's family beat cancer together
text: (Version française ci-après)My nephew-in-love Léandre was diagnosed with a brain tumour on December 27, 2018. Four days later, on New Year's Eve, he underwent 10 hours of surgery to remove it. Although the surgery was a success and nearly all of the mass was removed, the tumour was malignant, so the next steps for Léandre’s treatment are radiation therapy and chemotherapy.￼The past weeks have been devastating. We are all reeling from the shock of his quick diagnosis: his mom Anne, his dad Denis, his little brother Audrick, his Oma Rosemarie and Opa Andreas, grand-maman Germaine, uncles Georg and Benoit, aunt Catherine (my sister) and cousin David (my son). Though we are not related by blood, I've known Léandre his whole life, and love him as a nephew.Léandre is ten years old. He is an extremely gifted violinist, who has been playing since he was 3 1/2 and competing since he was 4. He has won two silver medals at the Canadian Music Competition and has performed twice at Carnegie Hall! Here is a link to hear him play at the CMC competition in 2017. And here is a link to his very first performance, at 4 years old.￼Léandre also swims, dives, rides horses and loves to read. He particularly enjoys books on ancient mythology; he raced right through all of Rick Riordan’ books, and read the Iliad and the Odyssey. He is bursting with life - kind, enthusiastic and passionate about everything he does.￼The Schwab-Gaucher household is filled with warmth. Birthday parties are marked by Anne's incredible homemade cakes, in the shape of planets, or sea creatures, and by elaborate treasure hunts and activities for the kids, animated by Anne and Denis and decorated by Oma's beautiful artwork. ￼Léandre and his brother Audrick, 7, are very close. Audrick looks up to his big brother, and plays the violin as well. When they are at Oma and Opa's house, they practice violin at the same time. Léandre plays for Catherine, and Opa accompanies Audrick on the piano. At home, Toxo the cat listens - of their four cats, he has the best musical ear.This past December, David and I went to Léandre's house to spend Christmas together with the family, as we do every year. Anne baked up a storm - I think she had 20 varieties of Christmas cookies this year. Léandre and Audrick had practiced some Christmas carols to play for the family, as duets on the violin. David had just started learning the flute, and had brought it with him. When Léandre learned this, he didn't skip a beat: he transposed his own harmony in his head, so David could play along in the key of C. It was one of those small but great moments that showed Léandre's generosity and irrepressibly positive energy. That was three days before his diagnosis. ￼It's hard to believe that was only five weeks ago. Though Léandre had been having some mild headaches and nausea for a few months, he was otherwise in perfect health. Today, he is struggling to talk, and his walking is unsteady as he recovers from the effects of the surgery. Every day is better, but there is a long road ahead.￼Léandre's tumour was a medulloblastoma. Despite its near-total removal, six weeks of radiation therapy will be needed to target the remaining cancerous cells and keep the tumour from growing back. Since the treatment he needs (proton therapy) is not available in Canada, the Montreal Children's Hospital has helped arrange for the family to go to the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, where they have the specialized equipment and expertise required. After that, Léandre will go through four to six months of chemotherapy administered at the Children’s Hospital in Montreal. He may also need other therapies, due to the strong side effects of the cancer treatments.In order to be at Léandre's side during his battle, and to take care of little brother Audrick, his dad Denis has stopped working, and will not be able to return to work for the better part of this year. There is a government relief program for caregivers, but this will only cover about half of his salary, which they depend on. Without more help, their family will be in serious financial difficulty.￼That's why this GoFundMe campaign was created. All the money raised will go straight to Léandre's family, to cover their loss of income and inevitable extra expenses, so they can focus their energy on what matters: Léandre’s treatment and rehabilitation. They will be deeply grateful for any contributions. ￼With love, luck and support, Léandre will be back on his violin playing concertos well before next Christmas! Love,Aunt-in-love Jenny Aidez la famille de Léandre à combattre le cancer ensemble Mon neveu Léandre a été diagnostiqué d’une tumeur cérébrale le 27 décembre 2018. Quelques jours plus tard, la veille du jour de l'an, il a subi 10 heures de chirurgie pour qu’on la lui enlève. Bien que la chirurgie fût un succès et que presque toute la tumeur ait été enlevée, elle s'est avérée cancéreuse. Les prochaines étapes pour Léandre sont donc la radiothérapie et la chimiothérapie.￼Les dernières semaines ont été dévastatrices. Nous sommes tous sous le choc de son diagnostic : Anne, la mère de Léandre, son père Denis, son petit frère Audrick, sa Oma Rosemarie, son Opa Andreas, sa grand-maman Germaine, ses oncles Georg et Benoit, sa tante Catherine (ma sœur) et son cousin David (mon fils). Bien que Léandre et moi ne sommes pas liés par le sang, nous sommes liés par l'amour : Léandre est comme un neveu pour moi.Léandre a dix ans. Il est un violoniste extrêmement doué : il joue depuis l'âge de 3 ans et demi, et fait des compétitions de musique depuis qu'il a 4 ans. Il a gagné deux médailles d'argent au Concours de musique du Canada. Il a même joué deux fois à Carnegie Hall à New York!Voici un lien où vous pouvez écouter une de ses compétitions en 2017. Et voici un lien vers sa première performance, à 4 ans. Il fait de la natation, du plongeon et de l'équitation, et il adore lire. Il aime particulièrement les livres sur la mythologie antique, et il a lu l'œuvre complète de Rick Riordan, ainsi que l'Iliade et l'Odyssée. Il est aimable, enthousiaste et passionné dans tout ce qu'il entreprend.￼La résidence Schwab-Gaucher est bien chaleureuse. À chaque fête d'enfant, Anne fait des gâteaux personnalisés incroyables, en forme des planètes ou de créatures marines. Il y a des chasses au trésor élaborées et d'autres activités divertissantes pour les enfants, animées par Anne et Denis et décorées par les œuvres d'art magnifiques d'Oma.￼Léandre et son petit frère Audrick, 7 ans, sont très proches. Audrick admire beaucoup son frère ainé, et joue également le violon. Quand ils sont chez Oma et Opa, ils pratiquent le violon en même temps. Léandre joue pour Catherine, et Opa accompagne Audrick au piano. Chez eux, Toxo le chat écoute en ronronnant – de leurs quatre chats, c’est lui qui a l'oreille la plus musicale.En décembre, David et moi sommes allés chez Léandre pour fêter Noël avec la famille, comme on le fait à chaque année. Comme d'habitude, Anne s’est surpassée dans la cuisine; je crois qu'elle a préparé 20 variétés de biscuits de Noël cette année. Léandre et Audrick avaient préparé des chansons de Noël au violon. David venait de commencer à apprendre la flûte traversière, et l'avait emmenée avec lui. Quand Léandre l'a su, il n'a pas hésité : il a transposé l'harmonie qu'il avait appris, dans sa tête, pour que David puisse jouer avec eux. C'était un petit moment, mais qui démontrait la générosité de Léandre et son énergie positive. C'était trois jours avant qu'on apprenne son diagnostic.￼Il est difficile de croire que cela fait seulement cinq semaines. Bien que Léandre avait parfois des maux de tête légers ou un peu de nausée ces derniers mois, il était autrement en parfaite santé. Aujourd'hui, il a encore de la difficulté à parler, et sa démarche est incertaine, dû aux effets de la chirurgie. Il s’améliore à chaque jour, mais il y a encore un long chemin à parcourir.￼La tumeur de Léandre était un médulloblastome. Bien qu'on l'ait presque complètement enlevée, Léandre devra subir six semaines de radiothérapie pour détruire les cellules cancéreuses restantes et pour empêcher la tumeur de revenir. Comme le traitement requis (la protonthérapie) n'est pas disponible au Canada, l'Hôpital de Montréal pour enfants a arrangé pour que Léandre puisse le suivre à l'Hôpital général du Massachusetts, à Boston, où ils ont les appareils et l'expertise requis. Léandre subira ensuite quatre à six mois de chimiothérapie, administrée par l'Hôpital de Montréal pour enfants. Il aura aussi probablement besoin d'autres thérapies, dû aux effets secondaires puissants des traitements contre le cancer. Afin de rester aux côtés de Léandre pendant sa lutte, et afin de prendre soin de son petit frère Audrick, son père Denis a dû arrêter de travailler, et devra arrêter le travail pour la majeure partie de l’année. Bien qu'il y ait un crédit d'impôt du gouvernement pour les aidants familiaux, celui-ci ne couvrira que la moitié de son salaire, qui est la principale source de revenu de sa famille. Sans aide supplémentaire, ils seront en grande difficulté financière.￼Voilà pourquoi cette campagne GoFundMe a été créée. Tous les fonds reçus iront directement à la famille de Léandre, afin de couvrir leur perte de revenu et leurs dépenses inévitables. Ils pourront ainsi se concentrer sur ce qui importe le plus : les traitements et la réadaptation de Léandre. Ils seront très reconnaissants pour toute contribution.￼Avec de l'amour, de la chance et le support de ses proches, Léandre sera de retour sur scène avec son violon, bien avant Noël prochain!Merci de tout coeur,« Tante » Jenny

name: Love for Keagan  - Fight Cancer
text: This week, Keagan Evans received news that no child should every have to receive.In Nov 2018 Keagan started having some weird neurological symptoms, like rt hand weakness.  An initial MRI was done at the beginning of December and it was discovered then that there was a growth of some sort in his brain.The symptoms got worse and  Keagan had brain surgery on Monday Jan 25th to remove a growth/tumor from his brain. Heartbreakingly, the pathology came back on the tumor as a Grade 4 Glioblastoma. (brain cancer)Keagan is in for one hell of a fight which starts asap with radiation and chemo.His mom Shannon has had to leave work in order to be with Keagan, and with limited benefits, will need all the help she can get to be able to be at his side while not having to worry about day to day expenses and to also help Keagan start checking off things on his bucket list. His brother Logan is at his side helping him rally.Any donations will be truly appreciated. Sincerely,Shannon's Hospice Family <3

name: Help Josie and her family kick cancers butt!
text: I’ve known this beautiful, caring, giving and sensitive young lady since she was a bubba! She is now 11 years old ♥️..... I introduce Josie to you all. ￼She has such a passion for life! She brings so much light and love to her community, the environment, friends, sporting teams, dance teams and family. Her love for life goes beyond herself and extends to so many others both human and animal. She truly is an inspiration and at such a young age!￼￼￼￼￼Today I found out Josie has bone cancer in her lower leg. This news was truly heart breaking. Josie loves being active and enjoys dance, netball, swimming, camping, practicing gymnastics with friends, going skating and so, so much more. Whilst everyone around her was devastated with today’s news, Josie’s one concern was that her mum was alright ♥️.Josie’s mum (Nic) is one of my dearest friends (adopted family over here in OZ and amazing god parent to my twins). Nic is a single mother of three fabulous children (Ben, Josie and Charlotte) who have all learned how to be beautiful inside and out from her. Nicole is a high school teacher and for as long as I have known her has always given 150% to her children and students. It’s so hard bringing up children on one wage and Nic is no stranger to making huge sacrifices for her children. This news has shattered Nic, Josie, Ben and Charlotte’s sense of life’s predictability and safety. Whilst surgery and treatment in hospital is covered, Nic and her family will have a tough journey ahead of them. This truly beautiful family will need financial support just to keep life going and to pay for Josie and the rest of the children’s support needs in months that follow. I ask you to dig deep and pledge as much as you can to support this gorgeous family manage bills, transport costs, therapy costs etc over the next several months. Nic and her family live within the constraints of a very tight (sometimes too tight) budget. They need our support. I could not think of a more deserving family.￼Josie will have to learn to adapt to a new way of living. The type of surgery will be invasive and will have significant impact on her ability to do what she loves at best and may result in some more significant surgery / impact on her mobility depending on what we find out next week - fingers crossed this is not the case.I will keep you posted as to how she is doing.A truly beautiful young lady inside and out♥️.￼Life long friends ♥️. Please help this beautiful family in their true time of need.

name: Help Mustafa Beat Skin Cancer
text: Prosle su skoro dvije godine teske borbe sa ovom opakom bolescu i jos uvijek traje borba moga oca sa ovom opakom bolescu koja ga je dovela u ovu tesku situaciju u kojoj je sada aza koju se ja nadam da ce izdrzatii pobijediti sve ovo i biti jak i cvrst kao sto je uvijek bio. Nadam se i vjerujem da ce izdrzati sve ovo i da ce se uskoro oporaviti ako bogda,postovani prijatelji rodjaci i svi dobri ljudi nadam se da cete razumjeti ovu situaciju i pomoci da se izbore sa ovom situacijom i bolnickim racunimasvaka i najmanja pomoc je dobro dosla. hvala svima od sveg srca.

name: HELP Madison Fight Brain Cancer
text:
URGENT: On behalf of the Jeff Domin Realty group at Coldwell Banker SCA, we are asking if you could help us save 3yr old Madison's life and support our team-mate Debbie Williams and her husband while they undergo this painful journey of doing whatever they can to keep their little girl in this world. It has just been announced that Madison is battling a rare, life-threatening brain cancer, called a High Grade Neuroepithelial Tumor.


It all started in February, when Madison was in and out of the doctors office because she was not feeling well, had a loss of appetite, and sleeping so much that it just did not seem right. Like many of us this winter, we had our children to the doctor for sicknesses that have been going around; but for little Madison, it turned out it wasn't what she was dealing with.On Thursday, March 1st, Debbie and John Williams were informed that Madison needed a CT scan. This CT scan revealed what no parent wanted to hear. . . . that their little girl had a brain tumor.  Upon the news, they were immediately transferred to the Childrens Hospital in Chapel Hill, NC.  Debbie and John were told that Madison needed to undergo brain surgery to remove this tumor and gather tissue. Tissue results would reveal if the tumor was cancerous or not.On Saturday, March 3rd, Madison spent the majority of the day in surgery. Her parents Debbie and John anxiously awaited for their little girl to awake. It was a joyous moment when the surgeon notified them that the tumor looked to be completely removed and Madison did an amazing job. Unfortunately an MRI later that night revealed that there may be remnants of the tumor still there that they could not see....     While in recovery, Madison had her appetite back and she only wanted to eat pink donuts. She was quickly nicknamed by hospital staff as the donut girl! Two days later Madison was on her way home, snacking on salami and pink donuts, and excelling at recovery from brain surgery. Within those couple of weeks after, she was back to her old self enjoying time with her brother Andrew, grandparents, family and many fun play-dates with friends.


On March 20th, the results came back and revealed disheartening news. That Madison has a rare cancer called a High Grade Neuroepithelial Tumor and her surgeons are diligently reaching out all over the country to find clinical trials and the best treatment plan to battle this. While waiting, she starts daily aggressive chemotherapy on March 26th.Debbie and John are determined to do whatever it takes to save Madison's life and be with her to help her get through these aggressive chemotherapy treatments. Travel will be abundant and expensive. Medical bills are already starting to come in at astronomical amounts.  We have started this fundraising campaign to help the Williams family cover the traveling and medical expenses of Madisons treatments. Let's help sweet Madison get through this!!! A donation of any kind would be amazing, along with your prayers and words of encouragement. Together we can take some of the burden off their shoulders. 


Please share and tag with #TeamMadison.We will be updating regularly on her progress and a HUGE THANK YOU from the bottom of our hearts and God Bless. Your support means the world.- The Jeff Domin Realty Group

name: Help Nancy Conquer Cancer
text: Nancy Guimond was diagnosed with Anaplastic Astrocytoma, a rare form of malignant brain cancer in October 2017. A few days later she traveled to Yale New Haven Hospital to have surgery to remove the tumor. Recovery from the surgery alone would be a long road, but her treatment was just getting started.She began radiation treatment in December followed by 12 cycles of chemotherapy and physical therapy. After many months, she started to show signs of improvement.Unfortunately this was short lived and her condition began to decline in late 2018, prompting her doctors to start running new tests. They discovered several masses in her brain near the area where they removed her tumor in 2017, diagnosing them as potential remnants of the cancer, scar tissue or radiation-damaged tissue. She is scheduled for surgery this Wednesday to have the tissue removed, and we are hopeful this will help improve her condition.The treatments, procedures and medicines Nancy relies on to help her battle cancer are very expensive. She has been unable to work during her treatment and her family has had to adapt to life on a single income. Fighting through cancer is tough enough, but the added financial burden they face makes a bad situation worse.We Need Your Help!There is something that we can do for Nancy and Kelly that could have a major impact - raise some money to help offset these bills! The Guimond family have been active and supportive members of our community, and among friends and family. It’s time we repay the favor and help them in their time of need.Please consider donating (every little bit helps) and help us spread the word by sharing this campaign.This fundraiser is being organized and run by her niece Jillian Ferguson and Jillian’s husband, Jeremy Szechenyi. Her children Evan Guimond, Tyler Guimond and Meghan Guimond, and sisters Laura Sycz and Darlene Bensen are also part of the support team. All funds will be delivered directly to Kelly Guimond, Nancy’s husband and primary caretaker.The BackstoryBorn and raised in Plainville, Connecticut by John and Audrey Bergenty, Nancy Guimond is a lifelong area resident. She is a teacher who dedicated her life to helping children with special needs get the support and attention they deserve to succeed.￼￼As passionate as she was about her career, Nancy loved nothing more than her family.￼She met her lifelong love, Kelly Guimond, in 1975 as freshman in high school. They married in 1983. A true testament to love, they’ve been inseparable ever since and continue to inspire others with their amazing relationship.￼￼￼They have three children, Evan, Tyler and Meghan. Evan is a plumber living in Plainville with his girlfriend and their dog Benji. Tyler followed in Nancy’s footsteps and is working with special needs children in Plainville. Meghan is a Freshman at Westfield State University where she’s studying Nursing.Thank you for taking the time to visit our fundraiser. We hope you'll consider donating and please help us spread the word!

name: The Tracy Watkins Cancer and Memorial Fund
text: Two weeks ago my Wife Tracy Watkins went in for a checkup because of pain near her stomach. We were all devastated to learn that Tracy has Stage 4 Cancer that spread to 50% of her liver. There are still many unknowns but we know that Tracy is facing chemotherapy as well as possible Hospice. Above all else, we are certain of our faith and God’s healing hand. Tracy is 51 years old, a Clemson University Engineering graduate 89’ and a member of Forest Hills Church. She is head designer at Cosmic Cookie Bakery  formerly Kai’s Kookies and More. Which is a family run full small business that we operate together.She is the primary caregiver of Kai, our 21 year old daughter who was diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy at birth and who is our Miracle child. And she is the Mother of Aiden our 15 year old Son who is a IB student and rising Junior at Myers Park High School.Tracy is also an Advocate of Children with special needs in the Charlotte, NC region. And has served on regional Boards and on various committees such as Easterseals/UCP and Misty Meadows Mighty Riders to advance our Daughters chances in life.She has also served on our neighborhood board and local school committees. My Wife has the deepest desire to be in her Children’s lives and to continue serving our community. They will shortly begin procedures to preserve her life. It is our hope to help Tracy recover fully and to lessen the financial burden that this sudden illness causes our family. We are starting a fund to help offset the expenses that are not covered by insurance. Please consider donating if you can and most of all please keep Tracy, Patrick, Kai and Aiden in your prayers.

name: HELP Detlev Hanschke Fight Cancer
text: As many of you may already know, Detlev was diagnosed just 6 months ago with multiple myeloma (a very rare form of Plasma Cancer). At only 58 years old, this aggressive cancer has reached a very serious stage and is very much threatening his life. After much effort in trying to beat this alone, it’s time for us to reach out to all of you for help.For all of those who know Detlev, you know better than anyone what a kind, generous, and helpful person he is. He has helped so many of you in different ways, and over the years you could always depend on him. Whether you are a family member or one of many friends he is thankful to have in his life, now is the time that he needs you most.If you haven’t had the pleasure of knowing Detlev, he originally moved from Germany in 1997 to begin a new life for his family. He has 2 sons, 4 grandchildren, and so many friends who are like family to him in the Bay Area and all over the world. Always doing the right thing for others and going out of his way to educate people all around him at every single opportunity, is how most would describe him. Plus he has a pretty amazing sense of humor and always has a smile to share! Detlev is such a special man to so many, we hope to lengthen his life for as long as possible. He is facing a very serious and difficult road ahead and simply put, needs your support at this time. He is focusing on treatments that combine the best of conventional and alternative medicine, with a focus on building up the body’s health and innate positive immune response. This however, requires a substantial amount of investment, both physically and monetarily.We are reaching out to those of you who know Detlev, and those who support such a strong presence in our community. Every contribution makes a difference in the fight.  All funds will be used to directly benefit in Detlev’s survival. Prayers and positive thoughts are also greatly appreciated!Please consider sharing this with your friends and family.The goal for this fund is quite significant, but that is what is needed to actually fund Detlev’s treatment.Funding Goal:  $145,000It is important to note as gofundme rules state that I Dunia Hanschke, am Detlev Hanschke's wife and will be monitoring and withdrawing funds in my name on Detlev's behalf. The funds are being deposited into our joint account. Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions!

name: Kevin "KC" Klett's Fight Against Cancer
text: Kevin "KC" Klett, a 14-year veteran and ladder driver with the New Britain Fire Department, was recently diagnosed with Non-Hodgkins B-Cell Lymphoma - just before his 40th birthday.  KC is a devoted husband and father of two beautiful girls.  Please help us in our efforts to support our brother and his fight against cancer.

name: Donate for Gloribelle Ortiz Tongue Cancer
text: Gloribelle Ortiz is a 28 year old who has dedicated her last years to guide and care for children in different carecenters around the west side of Puerto Rico. She is suffering from the rare condition of Squamous Cell Carcinoma ( Tongue Cancer). The condition was diagnosed a month ago, right now is in a stage 2 and needs surgery immediately.
