text: https://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/local/columnists/andreatta/2018/10/05/burhanuddin-shamsuddin-afghan-refugee-battles-cancer-dying-wish-see-mom-golisano-childrens-hospital/1521055002/

name: Help Jack fight cancer!
text: On Friday, October 19th, 2018 our sweet and healthy 16-year-old son Jack had unbearable pain in his hips. A trip to the pediatrician lead to lots of questions and the suggestion of a trip to Children’s Hospital for some blood work. After hours of waiting, we received the diagnosis- leukemia.  We were floored. Jack is a healthy kid who is always looking out for the well being of others.  He doesn't like or need to be taken care of. We are now faced with a life challenge.  Jack is a fighter but what has been explained to us is that we are embarking on a 3+ year journey with the hopes of a recovery.  Jack will have intense chemo followed by many more years of additional chemo and other treatments.  Doing what is right and best for Jack won't be easy. It isn't something we saved up for and are scared of what it will mean to our family.  His health is our priority.  The facility he will be treated at is 30 miles from our house so that adds to the costs and stress. Any help provided will be used to offset the enormous bills we have been told are coming. We were told the first bills are just weeks away.  We are optimistic and hopeful that Jack will recover and are appreciative of any support we will receive. Jack (on the left) spends his free time volunteering with Expand, Boulder's program to help special needs kids. He is a partner with the Special Olympics helping out wherever he can. Jack has a HUGE heart and is a wonderful kid.  Thank you,Daniel & Tricia

name: Jaime’s Cancer Fight
text: Jaime has unexpectedly and painfully been diagnosed with colon cancer.  As the burdens of such a diagnosis pile up, I will also be having to balance all the medical bills and treatment required since i will need to take unpaid time off from work to care for him after surgery.  I have been asked by friends and family wanting to help, to create a donation fund so they can do so... Anything and everything is welcomed and i deeply appreciate the love and support shown to us during these hard times. God bless.

name: Help Stephanie Fight Cancer
text: Stephanie Grimes has been working as a group fitness instructor for the past 30 years.  She has been courageously fighting cancer for many years.  This incredibly strong and beautiful woman, mother and dear friend has asked us to help her NOW because the fight is getting much harder.   She needs money for medical & living expenses... Stephanie has always given more than she's received and NOW is the time she needs our help.  She has run out of sick & vacation time and is unable to continue teaching.  This fight has taken all of her energy & financial resources ... Without your help, the situation is very bleak.  Please give what you can.  No amount is too small.

name: Olivia vs. Cancer
text: Meet Olivia; a happy-go-lucky, sweet, almost 3 year old with a huge problem. On Monday, 6/18/18, Livy was diagnosed with a Wilm’s Tumor, a type of nephroblastoma (kidney cancer) often seen in children under 5. Until recently, she was perfectly healthy. The past few weeks, she has had some intermittent fevers & was seen by her primary doctor but nothing serious was suspected. This past weekend, her parents noticed some bloating in her belly & a hardened area. The massive tumor was noted on her CT scan & her parents, Kendra & Austin Lewis, were given the news that would turn their worlds upside down. Olivia, who will turn 3 on July 10th, will undergo a major abdominal surgery to remove the tumor as well has her left kidney, which is completely engulfed by the cancer. Following surgery, she will have several months of chemo & radiation. Olivia has a 4 year old brother, Isaac, & a 10 year old sister, Emma. Kendra & Austin, who live in Aaronsburg, will be juggling Olivia’s treatments in Hershey as well as working full time & caring for their other children. I’ve started this page to ask for donations for this family as they embark on what is sure to be the most difficult thing they have ever faced. They will need extra money for gas, hotel rooms, childcare, & various medical expenses. Olivia is expected to make a full recovery but the journey to get there will be long, trying, & scary. Please consider donating, sharing this page, & praying for this family & their sweet, sick little girl.

name: Pancreatic cancer
text: Hello. My name is Dmitry, I'm 38 years old. I live in Brooklyn, New York. I have a wonderful family, a wife, two daughters, 3 and 6 years old, good job. Life was going great until suddenly in August of 2017, a terrible diagnosis of Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma Stage 3 cancer was made which they deemed inoperable. Here also began, various medical tests, sleepless nights, bad thoughts which simply can’t get rid of. I think I am understood by those who have ever faced this ailment.Doctors at first said that I needed an operation to remove the pancreas that would prolong life, but needed to go through a couple of chemotherapy courses to reduce size of the tumors. At that point there were two of them. Two months of chemotherapy and the prognosis was positive in which the tumors reduced in size. After the prior session the Doctors recommended another two months of continuous chemotherapy which after unfortunately proved to not end up working.  The original size of the tumors returned and the physicians once again recommended further radiation and treatment. Even before I made it to my appointment I ended up in the ER with an abundance of pain. Tests, CT Scans were done in which they found that the tumors grew and spread into the liver attributing to Stage 4 Liver cancer as well. In my gut I felt that due to the intense radiation and chemotherapy instead of it helping in actuality it only increased the size of the tumors and helped them to spread. Until this point the doctors and I had hope that a surgery would be an option but at this given time that is no longer an option. The doctors pretty much gave up on my case and told me nothing else can be done and to wait it out. No one can really imagine how difficult it was the next step I had to go through when I had to inform my family of this prognosis, pretty much telling them I have limited amount of time to live. There are other treatments that give hope to patients like myself but of course require additional funding. In life, every person at one moment reaches a point in which they have to ask for help. I hoped that I had enough strength and money to fight this battle by myself but unfortunately my health is disintegrating and further funds are needed for new treatment that provided more hope for recovery. I have my wife and kids to live for and can’t imagine giving up on them. Thank you very much.Dmitry.

name: "Mel's" Stage 4 Cancer Fund
text: My sister Melissa, was recently diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer that has metastasized to the Liver. She has never been the type to ask for any help, but she is in need of the support. We as a family have always been on the supporting end, helping friends, family, and co-workers in their times of crisis. Melissa has two young boys ages 7 and 10 and a daughter, age 24 along with two grandchildren. She will be having surgery on Monday and will be starting the chemotherapy treatments shortly after. As of now, Melissa is unable to work.  My sister does have medical insurance but it will not cover all the expenses that involve the treatment of cancer. The bills that she currently has unfortunately do not go away. These are stresses that a person needs not to worry about in a time of crises, but can weigh heavily on them. Our prayers will be answered and Melissa will pull through this. Any support is grateful. Thank you.Psalm 18.6 In my distress I called to the Lord;    I cried to my God for help.From his temple he heard my voice;    my cry came before him, into his ears.

name: Beat Cancer Like A Boss
text: As many of you know, Jami was diagnosed with Osteosarcoma in late October.  She quickly began chemo treatments that started in November.  The next big phase to come is a surgery schedule for 2/26.  She will have a portion of her femur removed and complete a hip replacement. Post-surgery she’ll resume chemo treatment for several more months.  Through it all, she still remains the positive, upbeat girl we all love!Jami is on extended medical leave from Tyson through September 2018.  Through the treatment process, there are significant out of pocket expenses Jami is incurring.  Some of the monthly shots alone cost her $1,250 per month.  If we’re able meet our goal of $7,500, Jami will be relieved for 6 months of this expense!  What a blessing to offer this stress relief while she’s building strength to kick this disease’s A$$! We appreciate everyone’s support  for Jami during this difficult time!

name: HELP BECKI BEAT CANCER
text: Hello,My name is Rebecca Ottusch.  At the age of 27, on September 18, 2018 I was diagnosed with Stage III Breast Cancer with tumors in the right breast and the auxiliary lymphoma nodes above and a mammoru gland under the ribcage.  I tried alternative treatment for about a month, water fasting and eating a purely raw green alkaline diet but the tumors when from 35 mm and 19 mm to double in size. I opted for a double mastectomy surgery in October of 2018, in which they found the entire right side compromised with cancerous cells, and removed tumors in the right armpit as well, and removed the left breast as well because of my high risk of reoccurrence. The doctors found through genetic testing that I carry a variant of the PALB2 and BRAC2 gene, both which of positive for, are indicators of high risk of breast, ovarian and other cancer. My doctors concluded that since I am so young with a very aggressive cancer and genetic indicators toward reoccurring risk, that it is in my best interest, medically, to perform a double mastectomy, chemotherapy, and radiation with follow-up treatment. For an aggressive cancer, aggressive treatment is needed and I want to be here, create a beautiful life in which I can continue sharing my talents with others, helping serve others, continuing to heal myself and the planet, and making this world a better place. Of course, I have more personal goals too like to raise a family, it would be simply amazing to have a family. I am currently just over half way through chemotherapy, of 6 sessions total spanning from December 2018 through March 2019, and after, I have scheduled radiation and a final reconstructive surgery. As an independent contractor for all my paid positions - as a yoga and meditation instructor, occasional model, and assistant to a screenwriter, I do not have the money and funds to do this alone.  I cannot afford to pay for all the supplements and alternative therapies in conjunction with conventional. Your generosity and kindness is deeply appreciated.  Thank you! Bless you <3

name: Help Firefighter/EMT  Gary Batista Fight Cancer!
text: Support for Firefighter Gary Batista  January 1st, New Year’s Day, is a day that is usually filled with warm wishes for a safe, happy, and healthy new year. For Gary Batista, January 1st 2019, wouldn’t be a New Year’s Day like all of the others. Gary’s day started the same as the previous New Year’s had, prepping a brunch for the swearing in of new fire officers at the Keasbey Fire Department, where he has been a volunteer firefighter for over a decade.  He would leave just before the ceremony began so he could get ready to work his shift at the East Brunswick Rescue Squad as a Tour Chief. A few hours later Gary would be rushed from work to the hospital by his fellow EMTs after passing out. He was placed in isolation after a battery of tests would show his white blood cell count was very low, and he started running a fever. A few days later, Gary would receive the news that he was diagnosed with a form of bone marrow cancer. Gary Batista is a valued member of so many communities: from central Jersey, to Jersey City and beyond. What makes Gary so special, is that he has dedicated almost his whole life to serving others.  He entered the field of emergency services as a young cadet with the Hopelawn Rescue Squad in 1973. In 1976 Gary enlisted in the United States Marine Corps where he served his country for 3 years. He returned home in 1979, and again served his community by joining the Perth Amboy Fire Department as a volunteer fire fighter and Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) with the Perth Amboy Rescue Squad.  He would work as a New Jersey State Corrections officer for many years, as well as an EMT with Jersey City Emergency Medical Services. He returned home to Middlesex County in 2001 to work for Perth Amboy EMS (later Raritan Bay EMS), and join as a volunteer with the Keasbey Fire Department to serve with his brother Joseph Batista. After years of helping others, Gary is in need of OUR help. The treatment for his cancer, and his medical bills are a huge burden. In his time of need we are asking that you open your heart to helping Gary and his family. Gary has been instrumental in helping others and is the type of man who never asks for help. He will give 110% to any task he is confronted with even now at the age of 61. Let’s help Gary fight, and BEAT his cancer.

name: Battle Against Cancer
text: As some of you may know, I was recently diagnosed with esophageal cancer. This is curable, and I am optimistic and as hard a fighter as you’ll ever meet. While I have insurance, I’m already getting bills for things that insurance didn’t cover 100%. Also, I’ll need to take some unpaid time off from work. During this ordeal, people keep telling me to not be afraid to ask for help, so here I am. Look, if you’re having a hard time financially, don’t sweat it. Send a good thought my way or post a funny meme on my wall. Thanks to everybody who has already helped me and to those who do in the future.

name: Support Taylor in Her Fight Against Breast Cancer
text: Hello friends of Taylor,I’ve made this gofundme fundraiser on behalf of Taylor Nairn in hopes that we can collectively help ease the financial burden of her battle with breast cancer. On 12/22/2019, Taylor felt a lump in her left breast and five weeks later, she was in her first chemotherapy session. She's been diagnosed with Stage 2A invasive ductal carcinoma, a very common, yet aggressive breast cancer. She is early stage, with a ER+, PR+, HER2- pathology (a favorable treatment profile). The doctors and Taylor have a good outlook, and she is looking forward to being on the other side of this, with new eyes full of wisdom! She does have a tough road ahead. She will begin with 5 months of ACT chemotherapy (the hard stuff) to shrink the tumor, then on to surgery, and 5-10 years of hormone therapy. She is a full-time biologist for our nearby coast and ocean, and while she will continue working part time, she will have to give up a lot of field work during treatment, as it requires handling dead animals. Taylor has been on the Bay Area hustle of also bartending at the Rite Spot, and has to let that source of income go to focus one healing and recovery. During the next year, she won't be able to work the 50 hours/week she's accustomed to. She is incredibly grateful to have good health insurance, but the costs of care and recovery in the Bay Area are tough when your hustle has been put on hold. Taylor says, “I know many of you out there also need a hand just as much, if not more. Smiles, hugs, prayers, and jokes are also warmly accepted!"And if you feel moved to give, it is with deep gratitude and humbleness that she accepts your kindness. It really helps to have another weight lifted through this journey.  Deepest thanks and blessings to all of you!

name: Help Laura Sharp Beat Cancer with New Methods
text: My sister, Laura Sharp, was recently given the challenging news that her breast cancer has metastasized into three brain tumors just five months following her double mastectomy.She has discovered some great alternative methods of treatment to explore that her medical insurance will not cover. I, her brother Dann, along with her family and friends, am asking for your prayers and any donations you can give. Thank you for coming alongside us during this challenging season. We are remaining hopeful.Blessings,Dann and familyBackground and Message from Laura:“Ending my twenty-year career at Warner Bros. with a layoff and loss of insurance coverage, my life became all about the caretaking of my parents, more specifically my mother through 8 years of Alzheimer’s. My hopes of getting back to employment were short lived as I became caretaker to my 100% PTSD disabled Vietnam Combat Infantry Veteran husband. The V.A. missed his Agent Orange induced Stage 4 stomach and esophageal cancer thinking it was the flu.Now three years out and he’s doing great, but I was diagnosed this summer with Stage III Negative BRAC 1 positive breast cancer.Began fighting back immediately and had a Bi-lateral Mastectomy in June.For stress relief after recovering from surgery, I drove my newly married daughter 3,000 miles to her new home in North Carolina.When I returned in November, my left arm went mysteriously lame.After much testing and a PET scan on Wednesday, I have been told that my cancer has metastasized into my brain where at least three (3) tumors are pushing on my motor chords. Steroids are currently helping sensation try to come back to my arm.In order to have hope and explore the many new therapies, protocols and drug studies, I need to raise funding for important testing and diagnostics.Hope comes in many forms.If there are any of you who would come alongside me as Spirit Warriors as I battle this on all fronts, I and my family would be very appreciative.Love & LightLaura Sharp”

name: Together for Theresa. Help her kick cancer.
text: There are those moments in life when you get a small glimpse of someone and just know they are going to be someone so big in your life. Maybe it's their infectious smile. Maybe it's their confidence and no holds barred realness. Maybe it's because she shared her lunch with you and gave you the special olives on her first day of work.From the first hello Theresa was the bomb. An amazingly strong woman and mother to her beautiful daughter Kayla, she inspires me to be my best and to have fun doing it. A comedian, for real, she used to tour the country and make people laugh, pull issues to the forefront and live life out loud. And she still does, live out loud. Every moment you spend with her you will learn something not only about her but about life and yourself.You see, Theresa has been such a survivor. After suddenly losing her husband, she and her daughter sold their family home. They packed up, including their little furry family member Fiddle, and moved to Manhattan. Taking care to make the transition to their new life as seamless as possible, this was no easy task and I watched her tackle it like a champ. Prior to all of that, she had battled cervical cancer. She was just about to pass the ten-year mark as a survivor. We were so elated and thought she was in the clear. But that, unfortunately, is not the case.This fall (2018) Theresa was at work and experienced a pulmonary embolism and was rushed to the hospital. After running tests, something bigger was going on. She was sent to specialists and diagnosed with stage 3 uterine cancer and stage 3 osteogenic sarcoma bone cancer. She is now going through the biggest challenge of her life. Battling two cancers at once and keeping her home and family together during it all. Her team of rockstar doctors has pulled together a treatment plan which consists of two rounds of aggressive chemotherapy and major surgeries. All of which are daunting to even imagine let alone the costs and not being able to work for most likely 12 months. She is going to need our help to lick this thing because cancer is not cheap. Your love, prayers and support are all greatly appreciated. This warrior is in it to win it. And I believe she will! She is such a selfless and generous human being. While she focuses on getting well, I ask all of you to do what you can to make this difficult time financially easier. Any funds not utilized during her recovery will be donated to cancer-related causes to help others tackling similar challenges.Please donate now! Many many thanks to you!

name: Alonso's Cancer Funds
text: Jose Alonso Lopez was just like any other young man in his early 20’s going about his day-to-day life, when early one morning as he was getting ready for work, he had a headache and began vomiting. His diagnosis was Stage 4 Medulloblastoma. This is most common central nervous system embryonal tumor and the most common high-grade childhood tumor.  Alonso has been hospitalized in Seattle’s Children's Hospital for the last seven months undergoing a dozen surgeries. He cannot move or talk and communicates through subtle hand gestures and facial expressions.Alonso does not receive much financial support for his medical bills and will soon need to leave the hospital. Too weak to be transferred, he is unable to return to his family in Santa Ana, CA. His parents live in Mexico and are low income.Please consider donating to Alonso’s fund to help him with medical and living expenses.

name: Help Richard Beat Cancer
text: Where do I begin? … It’s hasn’t been an easy journey! Many days have its challenges! But we’re believing that in the midst of chaos, God is in complete control! No one ever wants to hear that their cancer has returned. In December 2013, my husband, Richard Pyfrom was diagnosed with Colorectal Cancer. With no family history and too young to imagine such a diagnosis (just 37 years of age), we were dealt this devastating news. Nevertheless, he underwent surgery which removed a large portion of his large intestine and cycles of chemotherapy with high doses of radiation that took a toll on his body and ultimately, affected his quality of life daily. Consequently, this was a battle he wished to never undergo again.To our dismay in October 2018, after experiencing severe itching, abdominal bloating and jaundice of the skin and eyes, he was admitted to the local hospital. After numerous tests, the CT scan had revealed that his cancer had returned and had spread aggressively to his liver. At age 41 - the youngest of all his siblings, Advanced Liver Metastasis: Stage 4 is his diagnosis. His liver is severely diseased and covered in tumors. The tumors have blocked his bile duct and gall bladder preventing drainage from his liver into the gall bladder and intestine. This has caused the liver to become enlarged and caused leakage of bile and bilirubin into his abdominal cavity and bloodstream, hence his intense systematic itching and jaundice. Lack of medical insurance and reliance on public healthcare system, led to weeks to schedule appointment dates for any sort of treatment. Surgery is NOT recommended because of the vast quantity of tumors. Radiation is also NOT a viable option because of the dosage given during his initial cancer treatment sessions. In the first week of December 2018, he was scheduled to do chemotherapy only to be told that his bilirubin levels were too high with no proposed advice or solution on how to lower those levels. Thus, if chemotherapy was given it would have poisoned his body. It was then recommended that he only be given two of the three intended drugs that would bypass his liver. However, this left doubt on the drugs’ effectiveness. Additionally, with his previous and ongoing experiences from chemotherapy, Richard has opted out of such treatments, leaving them as a last resort.With that being said, he has decided to adopt a non-toxic, holistic alternative treatment, All-Natural Alkaline Herbal Detox Cleansing Therapy. We, his family fully support this decision and hope that this method will ultimately heal him. Thus, improving his quality of life as the disease has caused jaundice, excessive fatigue and itching, extreme weight loss and bloating coupled with physical, emotional/mental, spiritual, and financial distress. Since he has begun this method we have already began to see promising results. He’s been more active and energized, feeling less bloating with reduced itching. Consequently, he had developed a refreshed and hopeful frame of mind. However, the treatments are costly! Alkaline herbal therapy medicines, Alkaline organic diet (food/drinks), miscellaneous supplies, ointments, pills totals approximately $2,500.00 of monthly expenses.However, to our dismay, his abdomen and lower extremities ballooned about a month ago. This posed great concern. Consequently, oncologists were contacted once again. He is scheduled to have an appointment on February 7th, 2019. This consultation may result in chemotherapy being the method of treatment, as his only option. However, we are unsure if he may be eligible for such treatment as previously mentioned. Additionally, the cost of the treatment is also unknown as it is based on the type of chemotherapy as well as the dosage. As this disease has prevented him from working and he was the breadwinner of our home, our family has been doing our endeavor best to cover costs, amongst other daily expenses, on our own. But we are now in desperate need of help to continue his journey to health and wellness. For those who know Richard they are aware of the incredibly sweet, humble, hardworking, and devoted father he is. His commitment to his family and his love for bowling and his bowling family (whom we are forever grateful for) is immeasurable.  Today, we kindly ask you to search your hearts and assist us in whatever manner you can with this endeavor. Whether you’re able to make a small donation or not, we do need your prayers! So, we ask too, that you continue to pray for Richard as he continues to battle this disease in search of having a better quality of life that he can spend with his wife, kids, family and friends. We are truly grateful for your support, continued prayers and words of encouragement. PLEASE HELP RICHARD BEAT CANCER!

name: Amanda's Battle Against Cancer
text: When you move home to change your life around, to start fresh, to get healthy, to become closer to family, to leave all the bad and the ugly behind... you find out you have cancer. You get smacked in the face with the big “C” word. At 31 years old, you don’t expect to hear those words.. “You have cancer”. Yet, that is exactly what has happened to our daughter, our sister, our aunt, our friend.  Amanda  Dix has been diagnosed with Stage IV Colon Cancer.  A disease that she will have the rest of her life!  A disease she is determined to face head on and fight!  There are two major financial issues that are impacting Amanda's life which she needs help with.A little background how this all came about...Amanda started having stomach pains back in September. In October the pain got so bad that she took herself to the hospital.  They did a CT scan and noticed “scaring” in her colon and they concluded it was probably colitis, but she needed to see a GI specialist. Unfortunately, she was not able to see a doctor before her move back to California in November.  Once back home she had to find a primary physician first and then get a referral for a GI specialist.  She finally got scheduled for a colonoscopy on January 8th.  Amanda started the prep for procedure and instead of having bowel activity she got terrible stomach pains and started vomiting.  Called her doctor and she was told to go straight to the emergency room.  They did another CT scan and decided to do a “mini” colonoscopy.  However, they could not get the probe past the area where the scaring was, so they scheduled her for surgery.  We were told it was most likely scar tissue, though there was a less than 3% chance it could be cancer.After,  3 1/2 hours of surgery the doctor came out and told us she removed 8 inches of Amanda’s colon and that she had stage IV colon cancer.  The cancer formed in her gland rather then from polyps, another rare form of cancer.  Additionally, the cancer had spread across her abdominal wall.  Needless to say, heartbreaking news!We are just starting to understand what’s all involved in fighting the beast! Lots of time, love, support and expense. And this is where we need your help.First,  Amanda took a leave of absence from her job in Seattle so she could move home to be close to her family.  Thankfully, she was able to enroll in her company's COBRA medical plan.The problem is she won't be able to work for several months, or longer and her insurance premium is about $550/month. In addition, she'll need to meet her max  medical out-of-pocket expense of $5,000 before insurance starts paying 100%.Second, because the Chemotherapy medicine will likely destroy or damage her ovaries, she has decided to have her eggs harvested and preserved in the hopes that she can carry a child someday in the future. This is an expensive process that will cost her approximately $15,000.If you are able to donate any money to help Amanda in her fight against cancer and help with her growing medical bills, it will be HUGELY appreciated!  Your generous donation will  help her on the road to beating her cancer.With that being said, the  most important thing you can do to help is keep Amanda in your prayer's and send her positive energy and thoughts.With our gratitude and appreciation,Amanda's Support Team

name: Kinsley's Kicking Cancer
text: 11 month old, Kinsley Green has just been diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Her parents, David and Megan knew something was wrong when their happy, smiley, giggly baby girl began to act sick. They knew in their hearts something was not right and continued to press the doctors to look further. This is when Kinsley was sent to the hospital for what was thought to be a blood infection, and hours later found out it was Leukemia. Megan (mom) is having to take leave from her job to stay with Kinsley while she receives 5 weeks of chemo, and will be in the hospital the majority of the next 6 months. David (dad) is driving back and forth from Birmingham to Huntsville, where he is a football coach at Jemison High School, to help take care of sweet Kinsley, while also providing for their family during these trials.      Megan, David, and Kinsley need YOUR help! They have medical expenses, gas expenses, and living expenses. All of this was very sudden and unplanned and any thing you can give will help!Megan wants you all to know that after Kinsley's treatment and stay in the hospital, all money left over will go to childhood cancer research!    Megan and David know that cancer is big, but they also know that the God they serve is BIGGER! They ask that you stand beside them and support them with your prayers over Kinsley and their family.      You can follow along with her story here... https://www.facebook.com/groups/1084188928426261/

name: Help Addie Mae fight DIPG
text: Adeline "Addie Mae" Underhill was diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumor called Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (or DIPG as its commonly known) after being Airlifted from Sweetwater TN all the way to Nashville Tn's Vanderbilt Children's hospital. We took her to our local ER initially due to a couple of headaches and then she had this sudden paralysis to half her face. We jumped in the right then and there and went. After a CT scan we were told she had a "mass" in her brain. That was 7/30/17. Once she got to Vanderbilt they ran their own tests and told us on 7/31/17 the unimaginable. She was terminal. There wasn't anything they could do except palliative radiation therapy (Addie completed 30 rounds of radiation) and to "go home and make memories". But we couldn't just do nothing so Addie mae started a medical trial in Michigan in June and we have to travel back and forth every 3 weeks at our own expense. If there is anything you could spare to get Addie back and forth for her trial, therapies, medical bills and everything else that comes with having a sick child, I would be forever grateful.Kiley (Addie's Mom)

name: Help Stacey Reed Kick Cancer's Butt
text: First off I wanted to extend a huge thank you to everyone reading this, it shows you care.  All of those who have called and offered help and donated, we have no words for how much that means to our family.  I wanted to share some more information and keep everyone updated.  Following along this journey with Stacey has been heartbreaking.  Stacey is still paying off bills from last year, plus those incurred just in the past 3 weeks, which has been over 7 doctors visits, plus several blood works, biopsies, and body scans.   She got the fertility and chemo and radiation consults, and I can tell you her heart was devastated, as was mine.  We all know that chemo and radiation are toxic, and so you pump and radiate someones body to where healthy cells are now damaged as well as the tumor.  This damage continues for months after treatment ends and continues for your entire life.  Medical research is finding far better ways to fight cancer, but they are not considered conventional or offered very freely or affordably.  Her radiologist told her if she didn't follow their exact regimen of chemo and radiation, she'd be dead in two years, if not sooner.  Her oncologist told her if she didn't follow it at all she would die in 6 months to a year.  Imagine what those words feel like at 35 yrs young.  Once she did the research on recurrence percentages and the immediate and life long growing effects of radiation, what is left of her heart was extremely uneasy, she found no comfort in that route. That route would also take having children away from her, her dream of having her own family.   Those of you who know Stacey know her heart and she is a healthy, athletic, happy, (dog)loving person.  Stacey has always believed in the strength of the human body and a more natural approach to life.  Stacey has decided to go a more nature-path way and work with a team  who believe in the science of your own body and healing it's biochemistry to fight the cancer and starve it out and then treat it with nutritional therapy, nutrients, antioxidants, and hyperbaric oxygen therapy.  A lot of research stands behind this approach and has had great success.  This would not damage her body long term, it would not harm her fertility, and it would leave a piece of her intact.  Going through cancer is a mental, emotional, and physical devastation.  You don't get a day off.  Day in and day out she is fighting and everyday she grows more and more fatigued.  Harsh fatigue is a major side effect of cancer, as you can imagine the fight her body has had for over a year, going from doctor to doctor.  Stacey needs your help to live.  The costs of this treatment aren't covered by insurance, and the fight to save her life will be major.  She needs to focus on herself and have a positive outlook, and stress free approach....see the irony there?  She has to be her biggest advocate.  And I'm sure you can imagine how hard that will be given the place she is in.  My sister is my best friend, and we have both generated a bond so strong, I need her in my life, we all need her.  Please share and share and share with all of your friends and family.  Thanks again everyone, it truly means the world to me! <3

name: Together we will beat cancer. One world, One hope
text: Rigo Asencio, who is loved by all, was diagnosed with stage 4 Squamous Cell Carcinoma on his tongue on November 21st, 2018 that has metastasized to the lymph nodes on his neck. Time is too slow for those who wait, too swift for those who fear, too long for those who grieve, too short for those who rejoice, but for those who love, time is the eternity. Love recognizes no barriers. It jumps hurdles, leaps fences, penetrates walls to arrive at its destination full of hope. We as a class love Rigo unconditionally, but I haven’t had the time to spend time with him as much as the other students did since the Fall of 2017. I transferred into the class on September 5th, 2018 of the fall semester. I can’t even begin to imagine how the others are feeling who have known him much longer than I have. Ever since I’ve enrolled in this class, nursing school has been much more fun and stress free. Whenever we need notes, help in class and need anyone to talk to on a personal and emotional level, he is always there for us. Rigo is the type of person that always puts on a smile and makes the classroom filled with joy and laughter. Surrounding ourselves around him always lifted our spirits high. Broken crayon’s still color, and no matter how heart broken he may be feeling right now, he never gives up without a fight. This fight isn’t easy, but he’s not alone in this because he has all of us and others that are deeply engraved within his heart. Life isn't about waiting for the storm to pass, it's about learning how to dance in the rain. All too often, we forget about the patient's emotional fight while they're physically fighting their diagnosis, but cancer is a disease of the body, mind, and soul. Cancer may be a part of Rigo, but it does not define him. Cancer cannot cripple Rigo’s love, shatter his hope, corrode his faith, destroy his peace, destroy his friendships, suppress his memories, silence his courage and invade his soul. Rigo has an appreciation, a sensitivity, and an understanding of life that fills him with compassion, gentleness, and a deep loving concern. Beautiful people like Rigo do not just happen overnight. His diagnosis comes with huge expenses that is not limited to diet, tests/procedures, consultants, medication, follow ups and etc. This is a shock to all of us, but we are asking with a heavy heart to donate whatever you have to this fund as soon as possible. You know, chance does favor the prepared mind, and the more you know about it the more you will be able to understand what’s going to happen to you. I don’t think anybody should leave the doctor’s office after an examination or after an interview with the doctor with questions still on their mind. We want Rigo to get all the help he can get, but it can only start from us and everyone else that surrounds him by making a single gesture that will impact his life forever in a positive and meaningful way. Thank you for taking the time to visit our page and we all appreciate for everyone’s effort to give up a little bit of their time to help our amazing friend Rigo Asencio. We love you all!

name: Daryn's battle with cancer
text: On January 30th, Daryn went to the hospital for pain, assuming it was kidney stones. Unfortunately a short time later he received a devastating diagnosis. Stage 4 Adenocarcinoma.  It has spread throughout his body, including his brain. This is going to be a very difficult time, with many unforeseen expenses. Please keep Daryn and Barb in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time. ANY donations will be greatly appreciated, every dollar helps! Thank you for your support and we will keep you updated.

name: Help India Reed Bowers Beat Breast Cancer
text: Last summer, India went back to her little village in northern Sweden with her dog Molly for a 2 week visit in August from Paris, only to find herself diagnosed with breast cancer in Sweden en-route during her return. From then on she has faced sudden and related whirlwinds of subsequent events, and she needs our help.Before the immediate surgery to remove the tumor, and while staying in a local hotel and managing family situations at the same time, she was told she would only need 5-6 weeks radiation as post-operative treatment. At that time, already that seemed like a long period to be away from her home and life in Paris. In Paris, India had waiting for her upon her return:*a pending job offer to teach human rights*making plans to move in with a partner* her apartment and belongings*important pro bono groundbreaking legal projects she oversaw and brainstormed*urgent personal legal matters to tend to*AND her long-time dream to transition into making and selling her art, writing and jewelry in Paris.However, while she was still in the hospital bed in Sweden post-surgery, the surgeon informed her that the cancer had been found during surgery to have spread beyond the breast and into her sentinel and axillary lymph nodes, and that she would need, in addition the the treatment of radiation, 5 months of chemotherapy to start, as well as 5-10 years of pills/injections (hormone blockers as her breast cancer is hormone receptive) and monitoring. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------India's home, with her dreams and foundations to realize them, is Paris, and her medical team in Sweden is willing to help her transition her care to Paris, but this takes funds, effort, time and support. Since she has in the past few years been working hard as a dedicated and almost solely pro-bono human rights lawyer (expert in indigenous rights and additionally focused on root causes of domestic violence faced by immigrant women), while also lawyering her own cases and situations as an immigrant victim herself abroad (in turn rendered controversial for her work to speak out and in restorative methods), and doing the majority her work and advocacy out of her own pocket while becoming undiagnosably - until now! - increasing ill, India finds herself now in a financial and circumstantial bind with her sudden diagnosed medical situation and surrounding circumstances, as she also is not eligible for sick benefits or government assistance.India feels stranded and scared for her future; she wants, and has wanted this entire time, to get back to Paris to continue with the life she was on track with and for, to both pursue her opportunities of paying work in the ways she can and to be home, settled and relaxed in familiarity, surrounded by more extensive urban resources for her cancer needs, and forward-moving in her life, whole health and love. India is an independent soul, and it is NOT easy for her to ask for help, but several of us have offered to rally her communities to help out!As she put it: "Breast cancer patients on treatments continue living their normal lives, but in this situation I'm stuck in a place I don't live and it's circumstantial, not medical. I am going to need everyone's help getting back, I can't do it alone. I'm used to being able to do everything alone, but I'm lost needing help gah!" ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Your donation can help India get herself back to her home in Paris and safely transitioned there with her ongoing medical needs. Examples of costs to get there and back on her feet and continuing healing are:* Translation of medical records in Sweden so that they can be sent to Paris for review prior and a return thus planned accordingly*Application fee for the Paris-based medical review and resulting ongoing treatment plan and care fees proposal *Fertility protection injections during chemotherapy*Genetic and blood tests not covered that aid in treatment decisions and analyses, including assessment of cancer status, potential for metabolizing (or not) of treatments including hormone blockers, assessment and monitoring of hormone levels, monitoring of treatment side effects (such as bone density/loss, uterine wall thickening, and other systems balance such as thyroid)*Costs to get India, her dog, and their things that are in Sweden from these months of medical urgency back to their home in Paris*Out-of-pocket medical expenses once in Paris in the months following return, especially while transitioning between national health care systems, for example: remaining treatments, both cancer- and treatment side-effects-related exams and scans and tests, check ups, monitoring of side effects of prescribed long term hormone blockers medicine, fertility checks and needs, providing of the long-term hormone blockers anti-cancer medicine, lymphedema aid- drainage massage, compression sleeves, natural remedies such as herbs, nutrition, essential oils, movement and manual body work, any urgent, sudden or ongoing care related to serious side effects of chemotherapy, radiation or hormone blockers *Emergencies and travel care coverage both en-route and for times when she is able to travel starting up work again*Trauma counseling and other reparative healing *Additional living costs and backlogged living costs from being unable to gainfully work during treatments in the town she is in in Sweden and receiving no government assistance or any other insurance aid*Sourcing key support and resources such as long-term financial and life security planning, especially in light of her cancerEvery little bit will help - please give if you can and share with your networks!

name: #WITHGOD. Cancer won't win.
text: IMPORTANT NOTE: this is a surprise! So we are doing our best to keep it from him right now! So if you see him don’t say anything! Thanks so so much everyone! Hi! My name is Courtney Fuller, Marks daughter. My brothers, Austen and Brice  and I have decided to start a GoFund me page to raise money for our dad on this difficult journey. For those who do not know, January 24th, 2019 our dad was diagnosed with cancer. His entire world was turned upside down. That next Tuesday, on January 29th we went to his first appointment, where they decided to admit him to the hospital. This was decided because his femur was at risk of breaking, and also they thought it would be easier to be in the hospital and get all the tests done instead of doing a ton of out patient appointments. So he was admitted on that Tuesday, and we are still here in the hospital as of today the 4th of February. They have done 2 biopsies and discovered that he has a very large Stage 4 Gastrointestinal Stromel tumor on his liver, that has spread to areas on his spine and other bones, including his femur. Once we found that out they went ahead and did another surgery and placed a rod into his femur to protect it from breaking. So right now he is just recovering and getting lots and lots of rest.The plan when he discharges from here is to start Chemotherapy and Radiation, and also go down to MD Anderson in Houston, TX! My brothers and I all know that our dad is a very loved guy!! And very well known. He has such a giving heart and will give his last penny to anyone he knows. He is the most selfless person I have ever met. And to see him going through this is very tough but the strength and hope he has is so inspiring. We have decided to create this GoFund me page to raise money for the hospital bills, the future medical bills wether that be more hospital stays, or just all of his appointments he will be going to. Also his medications he will be on. And raising money to get down to MD Anderson in Houston, TX so we can get the best treatment possible for him. Like I mentioned we know that our dad is loved by so many! So we thought this was a great way to spread the word, keep you guys updated and give anyone the chance to help if they felt called to!!The phrase we have chose is #WITHGOD. #WITHGOD he has strength during this journey#WITHGOD he has peace through this #WITHGOD he has hope in this #WITHGOD he has belief that God is a miracle worker and can get him through this.We are huge believers in prayer, so we ask if you can't give that you guys would join us in prayer for our dad, this is going to be a very long tough journey, but with prayer and #WITHGOD he can do this!!!! Thank you guys so much in advance.  We couldn't do it without you guys! There is no possible way to show you how grateful we are. So thank you!!!!

name: Chelsea's Fight with Stage IV Metastatic Cancer
text: I am heartbroken and devastated to share with all of you that after Chelsea beat breast cancer while pregnant in 2016, her cancer has returned as stage IV triple negative metastatic breast cancer in her lung and lymph-nodes.  There is no cure for this cancer. It is terminal. At this point her doctors have given her a best case scenario prognosis of 1 to 2 years. This is if she chooses to do what treatments and clinical trials may be available. It is important to her that her quality of life is prioritized over the quantity, especially given that she has three young children, Kennedy-5, Brayden-3, and Harper-22 months. Her number one priorty is to make as many memories with her children as she can during the time that she has left. My goal for her is to be able to focus on living her life, without having to worry about money. One of the things that she would like most is the opportunity to take her children to Disney World. Most of you know me, but on the chance that you do not, Chelsea and I have been best friends for nearly 25 years. I hope that all of you can donate what you can so that Chelsea is able to make the most of her time she has left with her children and family and friends. I will also be coordinating other fundraisers in the coming weeks and months. I will be regularly updating this Gofundme account, as well as as the facebook group we started during her original cancer battle. Please feel free to join the group, ChelseaStrong. I ask that you please keep Chelsea, her children, and all of us that love her in your thoughts and prayers as well. Thank you in advance for all of your love and support during this extremely difficult time.

name: Lynda Rodriguez Cancer Battle
text: I am helping Lynda Rodriguez who is a close friend of mine almost like a sister raise money to pay her medical expenses for her cancer treatment. Lynda has three kids two girls and one boy, she was diagnosed with breast cancer last year and has been a warrior fighting this battle. Her oldest is in college and has actually put her education on hold so she can work and help pay her mom pay some of the expenses. She was scheduled to have surgery today January 30th but it was put on hold because she needs to meet her full deductible before she can have her surgery. We need to have her beat cancer! She needs your help so she can pay her deductible and any medical expenses that she has to have this horrific monster removed from her body. Please help with anything that you can. Anything Will help! The sooner we can raise this money the sooner she can have this surgery procedure done.  I truly believe and know that God is standing behind her and will not let her down.

name: Help Melissa fight cancer "Like a Boss"!
text: My beautiful sister Melissa was recently diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer at the young age of 37. Melissa has made frequent trips to Iowa City for radiation treatments and will eventually be starting chemo therapy. For being such a tiny thing, Melissa is mighty and one of the strongest people I know. She has been handling everything “Like a BOSS”. It is not easy for Melissa to ask for help as she is very self sufficient. We are blessed to have such close extended family to help support Melissa but realize the expenses that are accruing along with loss of wages may become overwhelming. As with any mother, Melissa’s main concern are her three young children aged 5, 8, and 11. It is understandable that you may want to express your support when you see Melissa out in public and on social media, feel free to do so, but please use discretion out of respect for her privacy and her children’s young ears and eyes while she determines how best to navigate through this process. If you know Melissa, humor and positivity will be a key component while she embarks on this journey. We would appreciate any prayers, positive vibes, and support you are able to provide at this time. In addition to this Go Fund Me page a benefit fund has been set up at Fidelity Bank & Trust in Oelwein, Melissa Meyer Benefit Fund. Also, we will be hosting a benefit event on March 9th at the American Legion in Oelwein, that will include a free will donation dinner, silent auction, and raffle. Words cannot express how very thankful we are to each and every one of you who have reached out with so much love and support and continue to do so.Thank you so much! Amy

name: Cam Conley Conquers Cancer
text: Seeing a three-year-old hooked up to IV's and laying in a bed way too big for him wearing a toddler johnny in a hospital is something that'll make you tear up instantly.When that three-year-old is your son, grandson or nephew it's your worse nightmare. It's a fight we didn't choose, one we'll win, but we need some help getting there. Cameron ... "Cam" to most ... has a long road ahead of him.  He was diagnosed with leukemia this past week and is being treated at Children's Hospital in Boston for the foreseeable future.Many have asked what they can do to help ... which is why we set up this page for Val, Joe, Cam & Riley.Our goal is to raise money to help take away some of the unexpected financial obstacles they'll be facing in the coming years as they stay with Cam at Children's Hospital in Boston.“Cambam Cunningham, strongest man in the land!”Our little Cam is a strong and inspiring little guy. He's already making friends with all the nurses and doctors and is keeping us laughing and smiling during these difficult times. Let's try and make his time away from home as normal as possible.Thank you for your support and we appreciate all the prayers and positive vibes.Stay tuned while we show cancer what us Conleys are all about.Val & Joe will be providing updates on Cam’s treatment through a blog listed below.  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/cameronconley￼￼

name: Please Support Steve's  Brain Cancer Treatments
text: Steve Hibbert, age 56,  self employed for 35 years in the construction flooring trade, a loving husband of 32 years. A father of three and grandfather of one.  On January 28, 2018, Steven and his family's life changed forever when on a routine morning, Steve was struck down and incapacitated by a seizure that would later be identified as a Grand mal. Transported to CCH it was discovered through brain scans that Steve had a small mass in the right lobe of his Brain and needed to be transported to BWH in Boston for further testing. On January 31,2018  Steve underwent Brain surgery, the doctors were able to remove 90% of the tumor as removal of the other 10 percent would have paralyzed Steve’s left side of his body.  Two weeks later, on Valentine’s day, we learned the results of the pathology report that the tumor was cancerous — a very aggressive, high-grade three Anaplastic Astrocytoma,  This is a very aggressive Brain cancer.Stunned by the news, we were told by doctors to focus simply on making Steve as comfortable as possible while he healed from the grueling surgery.  Six weeks later a treatment regimen that involved radiation five times a week and chemotherapy seven days a week.  Steve suffered another seizure on March 25, 2018  one of the four more seizures in the weeks following —  Then on July 26,2018  Steve endured a full body seizure that made him unable to move at all, resulting in the most significant setback in his treatment. Steve continues with chemo and anti-seizure meds, as well as physical and occupational therapy.  Between the meds, seizures, hand tremors, tumor, and constant doctor visits, Steve has not been able to work.  My work on Cape Cod is seasonal and winter is setting in. We are struggling financially since we have lost two thirds of our income, with medical bills, medications, home improvements are required to make our home safe and accessible for Steve ( ramps, grab bars, smooth surface walkway and drive)  as he adjusts to his new disabilities. My family needs your help  and  It is thus with very heavy hearts that we seek support from others to help make Steve comfortable and safe while he lives with the effects of this tumor and resulting seizures.  With kindness, love and heartfelt appreciation, we  thank you for your consideration and any financial help you can provide.Tomorrow is not a promise. Live, Laugh, and Love.Hibbert FamilyA foot noteWe held off on a gofundme for Steven,  because  my Daughter Sammy wanted to raise money for the Dana Farber Cancer Half Marathon  Sam  writes below,"I never considered myself a runner, even after years of running track in middle and high school. I never had to run for very long and I wasn’t very fast. It was more just something to do. I did manage to almost complete a season of cross country where I amazed myself by running 3 miles nonstop, once. I have run a handful of 5K’s in the past just to say I have done them but I never particularly enjoyed them. It’s not that I don’t like running, I was just never good at it.Over the years I have transitioned myself into a body- building workout regiment where my occasional cardio is the stairmaster. I haven’t run in years!This past January, my entire world was flipped upside down when my dad had a seizure which was caused by a cancerous brain tumor that could not be fullyremoved. Post surgery was rough and I didn’t believepeople when they told me that would be the easiest part. Then came the chemo and radiation. Watchingone of the strongest people I know go through that was, and still is, devastating. It is heartbreaking to see someone get knocked down by this brutal illness and struggle to do certain tasks or activities. Especially someone like my dad who was always working on several projects at once. I did everything I could to help but it never felt like enough. I wanted to do more but I wanted to have to work for it. I wanted it to be hard and painful and something I would have to force myself to do. Just like my dad had to force himself to go through radiation or another round of chemo cycling.Fundraising for brain cancer is a lot of bike rides and walks, neither of which I felt was hard enough for me. That was when a good friend sent me the link for Dana Farber Run any Race Fundraiser. She explained if I started training right away that I would have enough time to get myself up to 13.1 miles and she would run the race with me. I signed up immediately and barely completed a one mile run.With the heat and humidity most days the last thing I want to do is go for a run, let alone a long one. I can assure you the last thing my dad wants to do is go through another round of chemo cycling or have another MRI. That is what gets me outside running. It pushes me to run a little further each day. Nothing is worse than going through cancer treatment, and for me to watch a loved one go through it first-hand has been the biggest motivation. I am running for every single person going through what my dad is, to help bring an end to the disease someday. I will run the miles that most people receiving cancer treatment cannot, so hopefully one day they can run again too.- Samantha Hibbert

name: Help Support Laura While She Battles Cancer
text: As Laura made her 34th trip around the sun this year, she received the devastating diagnosis of stage 3 invasive ductal carcinoma.  BREAST CANCER!  So as Laura gets ready to celebrate her 35th birthday on December 15 she prepares for the long journey of battling this disease.  Who is Laura?Laura is an amazing mother to her four year old son, Jake.  She is a devoted teacher who has spent over a decade helping to guide young minds (fifth grade-they can be seriously moody and stinky but she loves them all-the-same).  She is an athlete (basketball and running) and has made a commitment to healthy living.  She is also a dedicated friend.  She is the type of person that you can always count on for a good laugh, a dose of the truth, or just a shoulder to cry on.  Laura grew up in St. Paul and is very close with her parents and FIVE brothers!  Family gatherings are filled with nieces, nephews, and a competition of some sort between the Buri siblings!    Laura's Treatment PlanLaura received her diagnosis on November 27 and met with her surgeon a week later.  As her cancer has already spread to her lymph nodes, she will begin aggressive chemo treatments for the next five months and then undergo a double mastectomy.  Funding Laura's Treatment and RecoveryDiscussions with cancer survivors all have the same message: focusing on your health and recovery is the best way to beat cancer!    Laura has dedicated 11 years to her role as a teacher and leader at one of the best schools in the state of Minnesota.  Unfortunately, her teacher salary and leave options will not enable her to take the time she will desperately need to focus on her well being.  Her Paid Time Off (PTO) will be exhausted in a short time and her school does not allow faculty to donate their PTO directly to Laura.  Laura's partner, Adam, will also be unable to take time off to be with her through her treatments without tremendous financial burden for their family.  DonationsCancer is expensive.  All donations will go directly to Laura and Adam during her treatment so that she can take the necessary time to heal and recover and so he can be there to support her without the burden of losing their incomes during her treatments.  Laura is strong and determined to beat this disease and with your help, she will be able to focus on her health during this difficult time.  Thank you for reading her story and any support that you can provide.

name: Childs Family Cancer Battle, Pt 2
text: Let me tell you about the Childs family. Troy, Christina, Jack & Ryan are some of the sweetest people you'll ever meet. This family has been through so much in the past few years, starting with Christina's breast cancer diagnosis in 2015, subsequent chemotherapy and THIRTEEN surgeries (with another one on the way). Christina is finally in the clear from her cancer and starting to feel like her old feisty self after a hard recovery. Just when they thought things were getting back to normal, Troy was diagnosed with Oropharyngeal cancer. Troy will possibly require surgery and 7 weeks of daily radiation and 7 weeks of chemotherapy with 4 weeks of recovery for the anticipated radiation burns. To pile on, they've recently discovered their home needs some necessary updates due to it's age (a beautiful 1941 home in Seward Park). Don't get me wrong, they are a crafty couple, but could use some financial support in order to ensure their boys lives aren't impacted - more than they already have been. Please consider donating to help them pay some of their medical bills, their home repair costs or consider donating groceries or a grocery store gift card to just keep them moving through daily life.For information on how to donate groceries or gift cards, please send an email to tamielwin@gmail.com.

name: Help Mayz Beat Cancer!
text: https://www.playformayz.com/  Mayz is a funny, sweet, silly 6 year old boy.  He loves playing anything with a ball and having books read to him. He especially likes when he gets to snuggle with his daddy. He and Daddy have a special bond between them.  He always sleeps with three stuffed animals and one is always the same. It’s a dog called Bolt from the Disney movie. He will rotate the other animals around but he always has Bolt.  In fact, Bolt is here in the hospital with us and it’s getting pretty ragged. He will always share whatever he has without question whether it be food or toys or anything.  When he gets in trouble or does something he shouldn’t, he is always the first to want to say sorry and mean it. There is not a mean bone in this little boy’s body.  Mommy and  Mayz have  a special relationship too. He will pick flowers out of the front yard or anywhere to give to Mom almost every day. He tells Mom that she is beautiful and that he loves her all the time. He’s even says, "You are the best mommy in the whole world."   He always wants to help Mom bring in the groceries, make dinner or cleanup. He is the first person to give you a hug when you are feeling sad. He plays baseball and loves his video games. He is a huge fan of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Star Wars. Mayz also loves the Angels and his favorite player is Mike Trout. He even picked #27 for his jersey number this year.  Early in March 2018, Mayz had a simple headache and went to the Doctor. That simple headache turned out to be every parent's worst nightmare, a malignant brain tumor. On March 12th, he had surgery to remove his tumor, which Doctors were able to completely remove. Unfortunately during that surgery, it was found that he has small spots on the backside of his brain and spine. Mayz had another surgery a few days after to put in a small tube to let fluid be released more naturally. This is an alternative to getting a permanent shunt. We are hopeful that this procedure works so that we don’t have to have another one. Pathology came back with results on the tumor. It is Medulloblastoma “metastatic” meaning it’s trying to spread.  This explains the spots the doctor saw in his brain and on his spine. He is at high-risk and will most likely need radiation and chemo therapy, maybe even at the same time. We keep praying and staying positive for our little “ Warrior”. (Thanks to the Lozano family for this title!) Mayz misses his friends, family, and teammates and hopes to soon be able to run, jump and play with everyone. He is a fighter with a never give up attitude and we all believe in his ability to make a full recovery. In the meantime, the whole process has been extremely hard on not only him but his family. His Mom Heather, Dad AJ, and Brothers Johnny and Skyler have all been doing their best to be there for him and cope with the situation.  THE ONE THING THE GONZALEZ FAMILY NEEDS IS THE GIFT OF TIME WITH MAYZ. EVERY SINGLE DOLLAR DONATED WILL GIVE HIS FAMILY THAT TIME. This page is set up to help Mayz and his family in this difficult time. Any and all types of donations are considered a blessing. We thank you all so much for your love and support. Please support Mayz by keeping him in your thoughts and prayers! Your support will also lift his spirits and give him strength to continue the fight! #PlayForMayz #PrayforMayz#TeamMayz

name: Pegi’s Cancer journey take 2
text: As many of you know last year Pegi had to have an emergency surgery due to a rupture in her intestine  causing her to become almost septic. That surgery ended up finding a large tumor on her colon.  They removed 30% of her colon and gave her an ostomy bag while her colon had time to heal.  In May she had her ostomy reversal surgery. In between surgery’s she went through 7 months of chemo and came out on top.  All her bloodwork was coming back normal and everything looked good. For the the past couple months she has been having a lot of stomach pain.  The doctors thought that the pain was coming from all of her scar tissue from her pervious surgery’s. On Tuesday Oct 9th they went in to remove some of her scar tissue. Unfornately during surgery they found new tumors on her bowel and abdomen wall, along with some small spots on her liver that we were already watching. She will now have to heal from this surgery and start some sort chemo moving forward. We are not sure on exact plan yet. Although insurance covers a lot, it does not cover all. We all know how expensive medical bills are and how they can pile up.  If you feel like you can help in any way it would be much appreciated but in no way feel obligated. I just want Russell to be able to have time to take her to chemo without having to stress over missing some work. Thank you all for your continued love and prayers.  As always they are greatly appreciated. ❤️

name: Meghann Mealbach's Breast Cancer Treatment Fund
text: Meghann who is 32 was recently diagnosed with breast cancer stage 3A  and will be undergoing 5+ months of chemotherapy followed by surgery later this year.  She has been a dedicated employee at the City of Dearborn Television for 13 years and because she is part-time she does not have any sick time or health care benefits through work. During the months she is going through treatment she may not be able to work so this fund will help with her lost wages and her sizable medical bills.Meghann is not the type to ask for money so her friends are asking for her. Please donate if you can and help spread the word!

name: BJ Jones Cancer Assistance Medical
text: Bennie (BJ) Jones was diagnosed with S4 Nasopharyngeal cancer after CT and PET scans.  BJ will need more tests and 6-8 weeks of chemo.  The costs of testing are immediate and extreme and BJ and Brooke could use financial assistance from friends and family.  They appreciate your help.  The financial and emotional strain on families fighting cancer can be overwhelming.  This is your chance to help a wonderful family with 2 young boys.  Thanks or your assistance, any amount helps!

name: ALS & Cancer - Pauline's Hope
text: Pauline Cardillo Criollo dreamed her whole life of becoming a mother.  She combined her love of children and dedication to others by becoming a teacher, spending the majority of her career from 2001 forward at Hommocks Middle School, where she taught seventh grade science.  Within two years time, Pauline married the love of her life and gave birth to two beautiful children.  Everything in her life was perfect.  However, a few short months after the birth of her son, Pauline began to notice some unusual but unremarkable physical symptoms.  She couldn't snap closed her new baby's outfits, and she had difficulty opening her daughter's hair clips.  Unfortunately this was only the beginning.In April 2015 Pauline was diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, or ALS, better known as Lou Gehrig's disease.ALS is a progressive neurological disease without a treatment or cure.  The average life expectancy is two to five years from the time of diagnosis.  Its patients become paralyzed losing the ability to move, speak, eat, and eventually breathe on their own.  The cost of medical care and equipment needed to support an ALS patient is tremendous.  These expenses include: making modifications to her home and car to allow Pauline accessibility, a powerwheelchair for mobility, technology to allow her to communicate with her children when she is no longer able to speak, a ventilator to assist with breathing, a feeding tube to sustain her, as well as sessions with physical and occupational therapists.  Additional in-home care is also needed as the resulting condition of ALS leave its patients unable to manage their most basic needs.Pauline was a loving and dedicated Hommocks teacher who spent her career inspiring her students.  However, after months of quietly coping with her disease and continiuing to give 110% to her profession, the disease began to take its toll.  It became increasingly challenging for Pauline to teach her students all day and then care for her own children at home.  When the physical burden of teaching full-time began to compromise her health, Pauline reluctantly agreed under the immense pressure from her family and friends to take a medical leave of absence.  Pauline's students and colleagues miss her presence in the building every day.  With her ALS disgnosis almost three years ago, we could  never have imagined that it would get any worse .  Last February, doctors found an inoperable tumor near Pauline's pancreas.  The diagnosis of the metastasized ovarian cancer had already spread to her lymph nodes.  Surgeons could not remove the tumor without the risk of Pauline permanently remaining on a ventilator.  Pauline continues to bravely battle both ALS and cancer.  These two devastating diagnoses have greatly changed Pauline's life forever.  Over the past year, Pauline has gone to countless doctors appointments for ALS and endured months of chemotheraphy for cancer.  She meets with specialists regularly, all while continuing to care for her two young children, Pauline, 4 and Anthony, 3.  Both Pauline and Anthony are incredible kids who love preschool and playing with friends.  They are increasingly aware of their mother's condition, and their love for her is endless.Pauline is unable to use her left arm and is losing functionality in her right hand and arm.  She is no longer able to climb stairs and walks with assistance and requires a wheelchair.  Total mobility is limited and speaking has become difficult.  She cannot hug her children good night or read them their favorite stories.  Yet everyday she meets each challenge her illnesses bring with grace and hope - hope for remission, hope for a cure.Pauline is also doing her part to make sure that others will not have to live with this unfair disease.  She is participating in reasearch studies and clinical trials with no benefit to herself providing researchers with more data on how the disease progresses.  Even during her own medical crisis, Pauline continues to do and think of others.  With her support system of family, friends, and colleagues Pauline has taken part in three local ALS walks, raising thousands of dollars for ALS research and advocacy.  This past June, Pauline and her family, along with numerous Hommocks teachers and friends particiapted in the Westchester ALS walk at Manhattanville College, raising money for a cure.Pauline remains connected to her Hommocks family through the numerous friendships she has made over the years and the profound impact she's had on the Science department both as a seventh grade teacher and chairperson.  She visits when possible, and enjoys hearing from her former students.  Pauline is a fighter.  She continues to be optimistic about her condition.  She tries to live her life as normally as possible.  Pauline's children are the source of her strength.  They inspire her to keep going and provide her with the joys only toddlers can bring - giving hugs and smiles when they are needed the most!Officially retired from her teaching position at Hommocks Middle School as of last June, the financial road for Pauline and her family has become more difficult.  Pauline and her family are now focusing their efforts on finding a ranch-style home which is wheelchair accessible, where Pauline can continue to raise her children and provide them a nurturing environment close to family and friends.  She also requires private home health care which is not covered by health insurance.  Please keep your eyes and ears open for an affordable four bedroom ranch house in the area so her children can attend school with friends.  Pauline means so much to so many people.  As a daughter, sister, wife, teacher, and friend she has always been there to help and lend a hand.  Pauline is tremendously grateful for all of the love and support she's received since sharing her story.  Your generosity and warm wishes are truly appreciated, and she continues to fight for a better tomorrow.  Let's come together to do something wonderful for this incredible wife, daughter and mother.  Please donate to help ease her family's growing financial burden.

name: Trisha Needs Stem Cell Transplant
text: Update February 10, 2019:Trisha had a series of complications that led to delays in her transplant. But she is finally moving forward on February 18. We still need a little bit more to complete her transplant fund... WE NEED YOUR HELP. Trisha's 22nd birthday is on February 12. (Wow, it's been 2 years since she first felt the tumor.) She is almost done with the battle. Please help us make this the year that Trisha finally beat cancer. <3 THANK YOU!Please continue to pray for us, donate, and share our fundraising page.———Hello everyone!First of all, my family and I would like to thank everyone who donated to our previous fundraising (hosted on YouCaring) that successfully funded my sister Trisha's fight against Stage IVA Classic Hodgkin's Lymphoma Mixed Cellularity--12 sessions of ABVD chemotherapy, PET CT scans, laboratory tests, medications, etc. Her last ABVD chemotherapy session (aka graduation) was on July 2, 2018. We were so thankful and hopeful that the treatment was a complete success (based on her March scan done just after 4 sessions of chemotherapy that said she is almost free of cancer).Unfortunately, the battle is not over yet.She went for a PET CT Scan on September 24, just 12 weeks after her last chemo, and it showed that she has active recurrent lymphoma. Apparently, she had tumour/s resistant to chemotherapy and that there are new growths in the lymph nodes of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis areas. It has also now spread beyond the lymph nodes and they found tumours in the marrow of her pelvis and spleen.We are all taken aback and devastated with these recent results. We thought everything was okay now. That the cancer is gone, done, defeated.In those 3 months after her last chemo session, Trisha started her road to recovery. She still couldn't go back to school but at least she was gaining her strength back. Her hair started growing again. All the side effects of chemotherapy were slowly disappearing. She even started crocheting Amigurumi keychains and tops. She was starting to rebuild her life and feel great again.But now, we have to go for more aggressive chemotherapy and transplant. We are lost and scared. During the doctor's appointment on Thursday, Sep 27, while discussing the results, my mom saw huge drops of tears falling from my sister's eyes. She was bravely asking the doctor, "ano ano pa po ang mga pwedeng gawin para mapahaba ang buhay ko?" (What are the next steps that we should do to extend my life?) She was trying to put on a brave face and a smile while crying. My mom saw how really scared my sister was. :((Being given news that you have cancer is already scary... but after having gone through treatment and being told that you have refractory lymphoma is most definitely heartbreaking and devastating, like you feel the world is crashing down on you. **Refractory cancer means it did not respond to a previous attempted cancer treatment. The cancer was initially responsive to treatment but between March and September scan, somehow it developed resistance. So here I am, knocking on your hearts once more. We need your help now more than ever. #TrishaIsFighting and we will continue to support her in every possible way.As outlined by her team of doctors, she needs to go for insertion of port-a-cath, bone marrow biopsy, at least 3 cycles of ESHAP chemotherapy which involves staying in the hospital for 5 days, PET CT scan, stem cell harvesting, autologous stem cell transplant, and numerous laboratory tests. She also needs medications during and in-between treatments. The doctors estimated that we need at least PhP 3,000,000 (around C$ 75,000) for everything, including transplant. And if we proceed as soon as possible, she'll be done with the treatments early 2019.We had some leftover funds from the previous campaign, which we have started to use for her laboratory tests this Sunday, Sep 30, in preparation for a port-a-cath insertion surgery and bone marrow biopsy tomorrow (Monday, Oct 1).(This portacath is a device implanted under Trisha's skin which allows easy venous access so that it will be easier and less painful for her to go through frequent and continuous administration of chemotherapy.)But we have no money at all to start at least the first session of chemotherapy, which costs PhP 150,000 (around C$ 3,600). We are hoping to have her go for the first session this coming Tuesday to Saturday so at least the fight against these new tumours have already started.My sister Mariah and I are the only ones helping our father with all the family expenses. We barely have enough as it is. And now just as we were starting to recover, we have to go through more treatments.
