(Photo 4: Quelques semaines après la chirurgie cranio-faciale)La troisième phase du plan de traitement a commencé le jour d'Halloween. Elle était exposée quotidiennement à la radiation pendant 6 semaines d'affilé. Après deux semaines, elle n'était plus en mesure de manger, ni de marcher. En surmontant ses effets néfasts, elle a réussi à se rendre à la fin des traitements et elle a sonné la cloche symbolique pour le signaler, en me rendant très fier.Son équipe médicale était alors confiante que les traitements avaient été un succès. Alina commencait sa lente, mais graduelle et constante récupération. Pendait 9 mois, elle était libre de cancer.UN NOUVELLE EMBUCHE Malheureusement, à la fin de 2018, le cancer s'est pointé de nouveau. La nouvelle nous a dévastés. Après tout ce qu'Alina avait déjà traversé, l'idée de faire des nouveaux traitements semblait plus difficile à digérer que jamais.La bonne nouvelle, la deuxieme chirurgie était aussi un succès: la tumeur a été enlevée. La mauvaise, c'est que les chirurgiens ont  trouvé des cellules pré-cancereuses. Selon notre oncologue, avec ce type de cancer, la chance d'une nouvelle récidive serait de 100%.(Photo 5: Alina maintenant. En pleine récupération. Toujours souriante)Ayant épuisé le recours à la chimio et la radiothérapie, les options pour traiter le retour du cancer sont limitées. UN NOUVEL ESPOIRNotre espoir repose sur l'utilisation d'un test de genome qui localise les mutations de cellules causant la tumeur pour qu'un anti-corp sur mesure soit fabriqué pour détruire les gênes déffectueux. En somme, ceci aurait comme effet d'éliminer d'emblé les thérapies qui n'ont pas de chance de succès et pointeriat notre équipe vers les solutions les plus adapteés. Cette technologie est recente, elle date de moins d'un an et elle est disponible seulement aux États-Unis. La Régie de l'assurance maladie ne couvre pas les frais. Nos assurances santé privées non plus. Le test (FoundationOne Cdx) à lui seul coûte plus de 6 000 USD. (Photo 6: Nos enfants)CE QUE VOUS POUVEZ FAIREDepuis le début des traitements, les medecins d'Alina ne l'ont pas autorisée de retourner travailler. Je fais de mon mieux, mais étant l'aidant naturel d'Alina et parent à temps plein, j'ai du réduire de beaucoup mes heures de travail. La réalité est telle que nous avons utlisé toutes nos réserves financières et avons maintenant besoin de votre aide afin de pouvoir payer son test de genome. Nous vous demandons de donner ce que vous pouvez. La vie d'Alina en dépend. L'argent recueilli servira au test de génome et aux traitements subséquents.Deux moyens de donner:- en pesant sur le bouton à la droite de cet écran.ou- en faisant un transfert direct à notre compte PayPal à l'adresse suivante: PayPal.Me/AlinaHelpFundAllez-vous donner une chance à Alina ?(Photo 7: 1,000 grues) DERNIERS MOTSAlina est une spécialiste de santé et sécurité au travail. Elle est très appréciée par sa famille, ses amis et par ses collègues de travail. La veille de sa chirurgie, ils se sont mis ensemble pour plier 1000 grues pour montrer leur soutien et lui souhaiter un prompt rétablissement. Une légende japonaise ancienne promet que 1000 grues d'origami permettraient combler un voeux ou guérir d'une maladie. Nous espérons voir cette promesse se réaliser.                                                                                  &&&&&&&&&&&&&&&ENGLISH VERSION(Photo 1: Alina & Marcel)Alina, the love of my life, has few options left after a 2 year fight against an agressive Sinonasal Cancer (SNUC). My name is Marcel and I need your help to stop this cancer from taking Alina.Alina is currently recovering after her second surgery. This is only a short respite before the inevitable return of cancer and I ask for your help to prevent this terrible disease from killing Alina.She needs to have a Genomic Test, which is not yet covered by our Public Health Insurance, nor by our private insurance company. This test will help identify a treatment that could save Alina's life. We have very little time.(Photo 2: Summer 2017 : Days before learning she has a stage 4 Cancer)OUR STORYIt was July 2, 2017 and we had planned on leaving on a family trip. On the morning of departure, Alina complained that she was not feeling well. For some time, she had nasal congestion, frequent headaches and felt tired. Sometimes she was dizzy. She was trying to stay strong, telling us that there was nothing wrong. Being in a family with 4 children where both parents work full time makes that easy to believe.A few weeks prior, Alina consulted a general practitioner at a local clinic. Unfortunately, the doctor misdiagnosed the cancer, thinking she had sinusitis. He prescribed antibiotics without further follow-up.Time passed. I found it odd that her condition did not improve and the symptoms persisted, if they were not getting worse. I thought it would be good to consult before taking the road of holidays. We went to the emergency room.On July 2, 2017, our world was turned upside down. Despite all appearances of a person in excellent physical shape leading a healthy lifestyle, a massive tumor had invaded her sinuses and spread into the frontal lobe of her brain. The tumor was so advanced that 40% of his brain was in edema. Her blood tests were alarming: the sodium level was so low that she was at risk of sudden death.The emergency doctor was unequivocal, "I do not know how she can still be alive.". He then rushed her by ambulance to the Montreal Neurological Institute.Stress and a sleepless night aggravated Alina's condition. The next day Alina began to have language problems: confusingly pointing to a chair, she called it Kraft Dinner, although she understood that she was not using the right word. Then she started to confuse the 4 languages she speaks.After administering powerful doses of dexahematosone (steroids), she became herself again. But there was a price to pay! Side effects of this drug are anxiety, insomnia, weight gain. She could not sleep a single full night for the next several months. With the stopping of her natural hormonal system, she took 60 pounds in just a few weeks. Did I mention the mood swings in a person who receives a dose corresponding to 400 times the normal level of adrenaline!First week in the hospital, we were under total shock. We were not able to absorb the information ourselves, much less explain it to our children. At first, the doctors were not sure they could treat this cancer. The prognosis was very bad. But since Alina was young, otherwise physically fit and would be able to support a very aggressive treatment, it was decided that they would try to remove the tumor.What a relief ! We had hope, even as the ENT surgeon read the biopsy report and exclaimed, "It's a horrible, horrible, horrible cancer !!!" The pathology indicated a highly advanced form of Sinonasal Undifferentiated Carcinoma (SNUC) with 10% Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC). Malignant. Extremely aggressive. Metastasic. Worst of all, it was evaluated to be Stage 4, the last stage of cancer development. The normal path would have been towards palliative care.THE LONG AND WINDING ROADThe treatment plan was multi-modal and intensive: 3 cycles of two simultaneous chemotherapies over a period of 9 weeks, cranio-facial surgery, followed by 6 weeks of radiotherapy combined with more chemo.It was physically and emotionally gruelsome, but Alina kept a postive attitude and managed to get through it.(Photo 3: Chemotherapy in progress, but large doses of steroids cause intense hunger)On September 5, 2017, just days after her last chemotherapy, I faced the fear of my life. On our way to the West Island Cancer Center, Alina had a seizure in the car. Her heart and breathing stopped.I pulled her out of the car on the edge of the highway and did CPR while waiting for help. After a few minutes, her heart was beating and I heard her breathe, faintly. Nothing in the world could prepare me for a moment like this. I was afraid of losing Alina like never before. Once at the hospital, I collapsed. Several weeks of therapy were necessary before I could take this route again. I cried like a baby every time I crossed this place in my itinerary.Two weeks later, Alina underwent cranio-facial surgery. There could be no delay between treatments. The cancer was stunned, but would not miss any opportunity to start growing again as soon as the chemo would lose its effect.(Photo 4: A few weeks after craniofacial surgery)Dr. Petrecca and Dr. Richardson and their colleagues perofrmed an exceptionally difficult surgery, exceeding all expectations, even theirs. The dangers of such of a surgery were multiple: changes in personality, loss of language skills, motor problems, risk of losing the left eye, etc.The surgery was planned to last approximately 16 hours. When you're in a waiting room, that is an eternity! When I finally saw Alina in the recovery room, with her two eyes, her personality intact and no noticeable change in her language control, I was nothing short of ecstatic!The third phase of the treatment plan began on Halloween. For 6 weeks in a row, she was exposed daily to radiation. After two weeks, she was no longer able to eat or walk. Overcoming the pain and the side-effects, she made it to the end and rang the bell reserved for those who make it to the end of their treatment plan. I was very proud. Her medical team was confident that their interventions were successful. Alina began her slow, but gradual and steady recovery.For 9 months, she was free of cancer.IT'S BACKAt the end of 2018, the cancer came back. The news was devastating. Alina had already gone through so much. The idea of going through more medical interventions was much more difficult to accept.Good fortune and talented surgeons to blame, the second surgery was also a success: the tumor was removed. On the bad side, the surgeon found pre-cancer cells in the surrounding area. According to our oncologist, with this type of cancer, the chance of a new recurrence coming from those faulty cells is close to 100%.(Photo 5: Alina now in full recovery, always smiling)Having exhausted our recourse to chemo and radiotherapy, the modalities available for treating a new recurrence are limited.A NEW HOPEOur hope lies in using genomic testing, which can locate the mutation causing the tumor, so that an antibody can be created to match that mutation, to bind to the mutated gene and inactivate it, thus suffocating the tumor. This would have the effect of eliminating from the outset therapies that have no chance of success and point our team to the most appropriate solutions.This technology is recent, it is less than a year old and is available only in the United States. The Public Health Program in Quebec does not cover expenses. Our private health insurance has also declined paying for it. The test (FoundationOne Cdx) alone costs more than $ 6,000.(Photo 6: Our kids)WHAT YOU CAN DOAlina is no longer able to work and I am doing my best to keep things going, but being Alina's caregiver and full-time parent, I've also had to reduce my work hours. The reality is that we have used up all our financial reserves and now need your help to pay for the genome test.We ask you to give what you can. Alina's life depends on it.The money collected will be used for genome testing and subsequent treatments.Two ways to give:- by pressing the button to the right of this screen.                      or,- by making a direct transfer to our PayPal account at the following address: PayPal.Me/AlinaHelpFundWill you give Alina a chance?(Photo 7: 1,000 cranes)LAST WORDSAlina is an Occupational Health and Safety Specialist. She is very appreciated by her family, friends and work colleagues. Her colleagues got together to fold 1,000 origami cranes that were given to alina the day before her surgery. An ancient Japanese legend promises that if you fold 1,000 cranes, you will be cured. We hope to see this promise come true.

name: Stacee's Ovarian Cancer Fight, NT
text:
My sister would never ask anyone to help her so i'm asking for her.

 September last year my sister had two large tumours removed from her right ovary (12cm & 7cm). The tumours came back as borderline mucinous tumours (pre cancer). The best method to prevent it from turning to cancer was to remove the right ovary. Stacee and her husband were ready to take on 2019 and get everything back on track after all of the time taken off work unpaid. Then after receiving a call from the hospital to go in for an appointment with my husband they were told that she now has ovarian cancer stage 1c. 

As you can imagine, this has come as a devastating shock to us. Stacee will undergo a 3rd surgery on 14th March (date TBC) for a full hysterectomy, remaining ovary and omentum as ovarian cancer can spread without detection very quickly. 

Once the pathology reports comes back then it will be determined if chemotherapy if is required. To follow on from surgery, stacee will have to have 8 weeks or more of recovery from work (as well her husband a few weeks as a carer), hormone therapy due to surgical menopause and possibly chemo. 

With no children of her own before Stacee has surgery, she is considering freezing embryos (pending funds). This of course comes with some initial costs (Repromed pay for it due to the illness which is amazing but there will day surgery, anaesthetists and ongoing costs and everything is happening so fast it’s all very overwhelming. 

With your help, we are hoping to ease some of the financial stresses Stacee and her husband face over the coming months. Unfortunately, with a myriad of appointments and 2 surgeries already, Stacee has already exhausted her sick leave and annual leave left to see her through what will be a difficult few months ahead. 


All contributions, no matter how big or small are appreciated beyond any of us can ever put into words. All funds will go directly to Stacee so all medical and other personal costs can be taken care of as she will be out of work for quite some time post surgery. 


Any funds that are not utilised will also be donated to the Ovarian Cancer Organisation Australia. 

We pray stacee will fight this and come out on top, like most of her fights in the ring. She can not wait to get back into sport and her normal lifestyle. 

Thank you

name: Maria Herrera is dying from Cancer
text: Thursday, November 1st 2018, Maria Herrera, a wonderful person, was taken to the ER for yellowing skin, eyes and abdominal pain. On November 5th, on her daughter’s birthday, she was diagnosed with Stage IV Liver Cancer. Doctor’s did not give her any options for treatment and she was put under Hospice care by November 8th , 2018. Three months have passed and Maria Herrera is now at the last stage of her life and hopes you can help to make her last moments on Earth a memorable moment for her family. Maria is 61 years old and for the last 20 years she worked as a CNA/Caregiver for the eldery and incapacitated people. She was always happy and made her patients laugh and provided exceptional care for them as if they were her own family and stood with some of them until their last moments. Now, is time for Maria to join them in Heaven.Maria Herrera is a member of a small family. She has been a single mother of two. Marisabel Lopez and Jaziel Martinez, now grown. Maria has two grandchildren, Elizabeth “Lizzy” Rossana Lopez 5years old and Giovanni “Gio” Andre Lopez 1year old.Unfortunately, the event has caught everyone by surprised. Cancer is a deadly desease that has no limits. Maria lived a happy life doing what she did best, and that was taking care of the elderly. Due to the highly cost of funeral or any other choice, we are seeking funding from you for her funeral arrangements and we hope you can contribute with as little or as much as you can. We will be forever grateful for your kindness and will not forget about you. Thank you so much for your help and god bless you and your family. Marisabel, Jaziel, Lizzy and Gio.You can email at Herrerafme@gmail.com

name: Robyn's Breast Cancer Fund
text: Our beautiful Canadian  friend, Robyn, met and fell in love with her Australian husband, Ari, while sailing the high seas working on a cruise ship. Fast-forward many years later to January 2019, when they are settled in Grovedale with their two young sons, Chase and Jude, and Robyn is diagnosed with locally advanced breast cancer. The doctors are classing it as stage 4, because it has spread into the lymph nodes, but the spread is still within the breast/armpit area so they will attempt to treat with it the strongest chemotherapy available to see if it has any effect on the tumours. Within the space of few weeks, Robyn is now facing an uncertain future and due to start four rounds of chemotherapy in February. As anyone who is lucky enough to be part of Robyn's life would know, she is an incredibly kind, caring and generous person who would never hesitate to help anyone that needed it.This fund is to give those who would like to support Robyn and her family an opportunity to help ease the costs surrounding her medical treatment. The funds raised will be used to supplement Robyn's income while she is unable to work, as well as alternative therapies to ease the side-effects of chemotherapy, and any other expenses to help others care for her children while she is unable to.If you would prefer to give in another way it would also be appreciated, feel free to contact the family to see what might be needed. Any love, support, and well wishes you feel like offering would be accepted with much gratitude.May we never forget how precious life is.

name: Single Mom, fighting stage 4 cancer
text: This is my beautiful friend Angi and her two wonderful daughters.  Angi is a single Mom. She works so hard, to provide for her girls. She is an amazing person.  Fun, loving, tough and optimistic.  We are so blessed to call her our Friend.  Two weeks ago Angi wasn't feeling well. She went into the ER.  Thinking maybe she just pulled a muscle.    The Doctor's gave Angi news that no one, ever wants to hear! (stage 4 cancer) to far off to attempt chemotherapy.   Our beautiful friend was giving this diagnosis, with the expectancy of 2-8 weeks. Angi has not worked in 2 weeks.  She will not be able to return back to work . We are  reaching out to all our family and friends.  The one thing she doesn't need, is the stress of eviction, or power outages while she's trying to be with her girls.   All savings have depleted due to medical cost.  Anything would be a blessing.  We want nothing more, then for our friend to feel peace and love throughout this time.  Please if you are willing, share this page.  Again anything will help.  God bless you all.

name: Let’s Help Sherrie Beat Breast Cancer
text: Sherrie has a very aggressive Triple Negative Breast Cancer that will require extensive chemo and surgery over the next six months. This life saving treatment is expensive and bills are piling up.  She really needs help to stay afloat. Sherrie Jones has been at the Renaissance for over nine years, we all know and love her, even our dogs think she is their best friend. Let’s reach into our pockets and help her out. She is going through so much while still showing up for work with a smile on her face despite terrible chemotherapy side effects. Any donation no matter how small will be appreciated.

name: Fighting the Cancer battle
text: Ainda que eu ande pelo vale da sombra da morte o Senhor Deus comigo esta, obrigada por sua doação. Você é instrumento de Deus!—————————————————————————Thanks... You’ve come to my page and I hope you can help me, I began to feel a strange pain a year ago, when I moved from Florida to California seeking treatment. I was an active working women,  debilitated by pain and feeling tired. I consulted my doctor here in California and they detected a mass in my uterus, so January 2018 I had surgery to remove my entire uterus. It was a mixture of emotions for me, sad that I would lose something vital to my body but happy that I would return to my normal bustling self! But I was worng, I recuperated but continued to feel tired and in pain. I was then counseled by a friend to get a mammogram in November of 2018 and found that I have breast cancer. That is why I need your help! I’m currently doing my rounds of Chemo Treatment, and as a single mom who can’t work, money has been really tight. These funds will allow me to continue treatment, pay rent and buy supplements, without needing to sell any of my belongings. My situation is dire, and I’m more than great-full that you have partnershiped with me.

name: Help Ang get to Dana-Farber
text: This is my lovely sister, Angela.  She was diagnosed with Breast Cancer in 2014.  Since then, she has undergone a mastectomy, chemo, and radiation.  While they worked for a bit, these measures are no longer working.  Her cancer has metastasized.  Ang has been accepted into a clinical trial in Boston at the Yawkey Center at Dana-Farber.  This will mean she has to Boston 2-3 times a month starting later this month.  She doesn't drive and neither does her husband.  They will be taking the train down, but this will cost money.  We will be raising money for her to attend this clinical trial and also to supplement her income a bit while she is undergoing treatment.  We are asking for your help to give Ang the chance to be the warrior we know that she is, so she can tackle this disease.  We appreciate any way you can help, whether it is transportation or meal vouchers, a visit, or a kind word.  Thank you for your help!

name: Help Our Mom Fight Breast Cancer
text: Hi everyone, As you may or may not know, my mom was recently diagnosed with breast cancer. She is a mother of four working by herself in Dallas. And my dad is currently working in San Antonio, making things extremely hard for her mentally, physically, and emotionally. My parents have always worked extremely hard to make sure we live a comfortable life, even if it meant that they sacrifice their own health and well-being. Although I am the oldest, I’m still a college student, and I am unable to provide any financial stability for her at this moment and it breaks my heart. She received her injections today that cost $50,000 alone and she goes into surgery tomorrow and we are expecting the surgery to add on a significant amount to our medical bills. The insurance can only cover so much, so we are turning to the community to help raise money for her surgery and treatments. If you are able to donate, we would appreciate any amount, even if it’s $1. If you can’t, please share to raise awareness. Anything and everything is appreciated!Thank you.

name: Help 5 year old fight her cancer Neuroblastoma
text: Updates on 1/10/2019:Ruien relapsed last Aug. We had to go back to hospital again. Until now, she has done 4 cycles of Chemo, which caused her lungs very bad side effects-- Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis. This disease is not reversible and makes her breathing very hard, she has to use a machine to help her breath all the time. Her cough is really bad too, she can cough continuously for one hour or two, even she is not eating anything. Doctor told us her lungs are gonna fail eventually.  Even if we can do a lungs transplant, that requires her to be cancer free for 2 years, which is almost impossible for her to wait that long.Our Difficulties:Mom has been a full time caregiver for my little one, we still have to take care of our first daughter, I am not sure what she will deal with this since we will probably have to face to worst result -- losing our second daughter. The doctors are suggesting we talk to her school and give her some pre consultant in advance. I, had a full time job, working in a limo company, now had talked to my boss, I have to spend more time with my family, since she only has limited time, I can not come to work at all. All the family income will be from the two rooms rent we share on Airbnb. We still have a lot of bills to pay. We do want to spend some quality time with my daughters and give her whatever she wants. She has been fighting for so long, she does ask too much, but I want to give her the best she deserves. We need your help, for this little cute girl.Back in 2016I have two beautiful daughters, Joy (8)and Ruien (5), they are both my precious ones. Until the end of last month(Mar. 2016), my little one was diagnosed with a super rear cancer - neuroblastoma. I have never heard about this disease before, but after the doctor told me, the whole family was put in a great pain. The doctor said they would do their best, but from the past, the survival rate is about 50%-60%.I brought my wife and 2 daughters all the way from China at the end of 2014. We were just trying to settle down here. I believe our life is going to be better and better. But now I have to stop everything, being in the hospital with my cute daughter, I hope she will be cured and grow up healthy, there are a lot of things I want to do with her.According to the doctor, we have to do 5 cycles of chemo and then we are expecting to see the tumor going smaller, then the doctor would be able to remove it from her belly by an operation, then she has to do another cycle of chemo. After that, she would have to do 2 times of transfusion, if everything is going fine, she would do around 6 cycles of maintenance therapy, the whole treatment is gonna be over a year.We are now in Children's Hospital Oakland for 20 days. Me and mom are taking turns to care her. She is a strong girl, she was talking to me she wanted to go out and play, but her leg was having cast, because of her bone fracture, I was trying to comfort her, so I talked to her " we can go boating, or go climbing hills, or just go to the park when you get well", she was responding me with her cutest voice, and I can see my wife is wiping her tears.My parents and other relatives are still back in China. I am working on the paperwork for them so they can apply for a visa, so they can come to visit my daughter. This is not a easy job, but I still have to do it.My first daughter is a sports girl, she likes swimming, skating, climbing hills and playing monkey bars, she is really good at sports. I hope my second daughter will get well, and I will spend more time with them, playing games and doing sports with them, so they would be healthier.

name: Help single mom with stage 4 cancer
text: I am a 44 yr old single mom of 3 children whom I raise myself.  6 yrs ago I went from being a normal healthy woman who thought I had food poisoning to a woman who in 3 days was in congestive heart failure fighting for my life   After several hospitals & a few months I was diagnosed with a rare terminal illness called Cushing's Disease & told my case is so rare only 2-3 out of a million get. Doctors said I wouldnt live to see 38 & if I did I would be in a wheelchair.  I have fought so hard not to make that a reality. With this disease you usually have a tumor on your pituitary in the brain or adrenal glands. In my case they could not find the tumor and after 5 months in hospital dying & due to the excessive amount of cortisol my body was producing had to remove both adrenal glands in order to survive while searching for tumor. Currently I am enrolled in a government research program at The National Institue of Health in Bethesda MD where I go often for treatment. In between visits to the NIH I drive a 2hr trip to Nashville each direction every few weeks to  see my endocrinologist & a few other specialists. A few weeks ago while at a 2 week stay at NIH they  not only found the tumor but several of them in the lymph nodes around the trachea & in the lungs. A biopsy has turned up 2 different types of cancer. One metastatic & the other neuro ectopic cancer . After researching several oncologist I found one at NY Presbyterian willing to treat me so now being treated at NY Presbyterian in hopes to be able to remove cancerous tumors & beat this horrific diagnosis. Currently I just underwent my first serious of surgery at NY Presbyterian removing all cancerous lymph nodes in right side of lungs. They are hopeful it was sucessful.  In a few  weeks i will undergo same procedure in left side in hopes to remove all cAncer. Unfortunately after removing 52 lymph nodes and 28 positive tumors from lungs and aorta the cancer spread back within 6 months. I continue to search for treatments in mutilple states so I can live and be a mom to my kids but at this point totally unsuccessful. without adrenal glands my life is at risk daily. I underwent 7 months of chemo which nearly killed me and this was only in hopes to slow the cancer as it is not curable. This  illness has disabled me & I have not been able to work in over 6 yrs.  However, I am grateful to still be alive & to have learned how to walk again, my health keeps deteriorating & Expenses to travel for treatments have become overwhelming & making it difficult to maintain household expenses & take care of my children while living off social security.  The past 6 yrs  has exhausted my savings,credit cards, 401k, sold all valuables & even designed my own shirts to bring awareness to this rare cancer and help raise money for the continued overwhelming treatment expenses . I have never been a person to ask for help from anyone but at th point I cannot continue to fight my battle without help.  I am forever grateful to any & all who support me as I continue to fight to win this ongoing battle which we know is incurable and help me continue to be a mom to my kids while I’m still able.

name: Help Meghan Kick Cancer's Ass
text: Dear Family, Friends, (and friends we haven’t met yet),I want to introduce you to my loving, vivacious, spirited, niece, Meghan Miller.  Meghan is a 33-year-old Canadian/American actor, writer, dancer, filmmaker, director (and bartender in between gigs) who has lived in New York City for several years in pursuit of her creative work.At a very early age, and after losing her precious dad, Meghan, true to her fearless nature, set out on her own to her now beloved NYC to pursue her dream of acting and writing (and hasn’t looked back). She’s had successful times, followed by lean times. But throughout, Meghan has thrived on being around other artists and contributing to the performing arts, her true passion.In mid-October, 2018, Meghan suffered odd, sporadic symptoms, including swelling in her face and fainting spells. Many tests and E.R. visits later and suddenly Meghan was given the diagnosis:  Mediastinal B-cell Lymphoma, in the form of a 9cm tumour in her chest cavity.The good news is that this is absolutely treatable, but not without a “helluva” fight ahead of her. That’s why we’re asking for your help.With barely time to process or make plans, Meghan has remained in hospital and has had to start treatment immediately. This includes six rounds of strong chemo drugs for five or six days in a row with only a couple of weeks' break in between sessions. Her immune system will be highly compromised. The doctors have said that due to the intensive treatment schedule and expected side-effects, she will not be able to work or travel for up to a year, impacting  her ability to pay rent, utilities and groceries, in addition to transport for her many doctor and hospital appointments... Therefore, we are asking you to contribute what you can so that Meghan can get better and return to work as soon as possible. Meghan has a loving and supportive network of friends and family both in Canada and New York including siblings Matthew, Valerie, Laura and Edward and her step-father, Mike, along with Meghan’s mother Rhona who has temporarily relocated to NYC.  Meg’s step-mom Janice will also travel from Canada to be there whenever she can to help in Meghan’s recovery.  She is surrounded by so much love from so many, including that of her extended (and extensive)  Rochefort family.Meghan is a strong and feisty young woman, which is why we know that she will kick ass and come out of this ordeal an even stronger individual and  back to normal life without the added stress of an insurmountable financial burden awaiting her. We want to help her get there, healthy and whole.She will do it!  She just needs your help to get her through this really hard part!  We humbly and gratefully invite you to donate to Meghan's Go-Fund-Me.  All donations will go directly to Meghan to help with medical bills, treatment costs and basic living expenses. We thank everyone who has been there to offer their love and support and for the many acts and words of kindness Meghan has received. We ask you to donate whatever you can to help her get through this difficult time and on behalf of Meghan and her family, we send our heartfelt love, gratitude and appreciation.

name: Moreno Sensei Cancer Treatement
text: - For the ENGLISH TRANSLATION scroll below the text in Spanish - Desde muy joven he dedicado mi vida a aprender y enseñar el maravilloso arte del Aikido.   Esta disciplina me ha dejado maravillosos logros, pero dentro de los mas importantes ha sido, junto con mi padre (que en paz descanse), la fundación del Aikido en México a inicios de los años 70s, así como la promoción del Aikido en otros países del mundo incluyendo Guatemala, Estados Unidos, y Australia.Desde hace mas de 46 años he dedicado 100% de mi vida a estudiar y enseñar este maravilloso arte sin pensar en el beneficio económico.  Mi familia me han apoyando siempre en mi misión de compartir Aikido con el mundo, aunque esto haya significado muchos sacrificios económicos dada la inestabilidad económica de esta actividad.   Desafortunadamente en el año 2015 los médicos me informaron de una condición acelerada de cáncer el cual he estado combatiendo incesantemente desde entonces.  En este caso, aunque el tratamiento de quimioterapia localizada que necesito para continuar con mi lucha contra el cáncer ha sido efectivo también ha sido extremadamente costos; demasiado para ser solventado únicamente con las contribuciones que recibo por los seminarios anuales que son mi única fuente de ingreso para mantener mi salud y los gastos familiares.Este tratamiento es urgente debido a que requiero su continuación inmediata para asegurar su efectividad contra el cáncer.  100% de los fondos recaudados a través de esta campaña serán destinados para el pago de las quimioterapias locales que necesito dando con esto la mejor oportunidad de recuperar mi salud, apoyar a mi familia y continuar con mi misión de compartir y diseminar Aikido en el mundo. Les agradezco de todo corazón sus amables contribuciones (no hay contribución demasiado pequeña) así como su apoyo en la difusión y promoción de esta campaña.  Sinceramente,Michael MorenoACTUALIZACION, 7 de Febrero 2018.Los doctores han requerido que tenga una operación urgente el miércoles 13 de Febrero.   Para poder cubrir los costos requeridos para esta operación esta campaña debe de alcanzar la meta de USD10,000 en los próximos días.    Muchas gracias de todo corazón por toda su ayuda en donar y difundir esta campaña.  Michael Moreno------------------------------------English TranslationFrom a very young age I have dedicated my life to learn and teach the wonderful art of Aikido. This discipline has given me many wonderful achievements.  Amongst the most important has been, along with my father (may he rest in peace), the foundation of Aikido in Mexico in the early 70s, as well as the promotion of Aikido around the world in countries such as Guatemala, the United States, and Australia. For more than 46 years I have dedicated 100% of my life to study and teach this wonderful art without thinking about the economic benefits or rewards.  My family has always supported me in my mission to share Aikido with the world, although this has meant many economic sacrifices given the financial instability of this activity.  Unfortunately, in the year 2015 the doctors informed me of an accelerated cancer condition which I have been fighting incessantly ever since. In this particular case, although the localised chemotherapy treatment that I need to continue my fight against cancer has been effective it has also been extremely costly; Too much to be covered solely with the contributions I receive from my annual Aikido seminars that are my only source of income.  Income that I use to maintain my health and to cover my family expenses.  The chemotherapy is urgent because I require this ongoing treatment to ensure its effectiveness against cancer.  100% of the funds raised through this campaign will be used to pay for the local chemotherapies that I need, giving me the best opportunity to recover my health, support my family and continue my mission of sharing and disseminating Aikido in the world. I thank you with all my heart for your kind contributions (there is no contribution too small) as well as your support in the dissemination and promotion of this campaign.  Sincerely, Michael MorenoUPDATE,  7th February 2018My doctors have instructed me to have an urgent operation on Wednesday 13th of February.   To be able to cover the expenses of such surgery, this campaign has to reach the target of USD10,000 en the coming days.  Thank you very much from the bottom of my heart for all your donations and for sharing this campaign.Michael Moreno.

name: Help Hank Battle Cancer
text: MY DAD, HANK LYLE, NEEDS YOUR HELP TO PAY FOR CANCER TREATMENT AND BILLS.In late June I took my dad, Hank Lyle, to the ER for severe abdominal pain and blood in his urine. The doctor came back with the terrible news that he had severe kidney cancer, stage 4. He had to have surgery immediately to remove the tumor (which took up his entire kidney) as well as the thrombus (blood clot) that grew from his kidney up into his heart.Since then, the road to recovery has been more like an obstacle course—he’s been to the ER twice, had abdominal swelling from fluid buildup that needs to be drained, which is costly, and because he’s been unable to work, the bills have been piling up. He has some potentially cancerous nodules in his lungs that spread from the kidney cancer, which require costly treatments.Yesterday (11/23), I took him to the ER because he was barely able to move and had trouble breathing. He’s stable now, and all we know is that he’s been bleeding internally. He only had 4.5 pints of blood in his body, while the average person should have 11.My dad is the strongest person I know. Before he got sick, I used to tell people that he was the youngest person I know, despite becoming a father (to me) at 45. He would go to the gym twice a week and work out. He designs and builds furniture and cabinets, but has been unable to work.He’s one of the people I love most in the world; I grew up with a love for art, nature, and milkshakes because of him. He used to braid my hair because he had long hair in the 70s. I’ve lived with him for the past 2 ½ years and most nights were spent cooking, watching TV, and laughing together. Everyone he knows loves him for his sense of humor, lightheartedness, and open-mindedness.The point of saying all this is that he’s hurting and needs help, and he is so deserving of help. The doctors are doing what they can to treat him, but besides that, the help he needs is financial. He needs to pay for tests, medications, treatment, debt from the surgery, rent, food, etc. Please donate to help.If you can’t afford to donate right now, please share this link or keep him in your thoughts and prayers. My dad is a big advocate for the power of prayer, and I know it would make him feel so happy to know that people out there are caring about him and thinking about him. THANK YOU to everyone that has supported him during this difficult time—you’ve made such a positive impact.

name: Laura's Fight Against Cancer
text: Anyone who knows Laura knows what an incredibly strong woman she is. Just in the past couple years, as her husband Roger has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's, Laura has stepped up as both his caretaker and full-time provider for their family. She is also a great mom to their sixteen year old daughter, Amy, as she navigates the high school years. Despite the time, love, and effort she commits to Roger and Amy, Laura still manages to fit in meaningful time with her adult children and grandkids. She loves Jesus, intentional connection with friends, and time spent in Creation on horseback… she’s always been an example servant and makes the most of her life. As if her plate was not full enough, we all watched in awe as she gracefully overcame a terrifying diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer (squamous cell) in the fall of 2017. After a successful surgery to remove the cancer, Laura picked up right where she left off— caring for Roger, working, being a mom & grandma, and spending time in nature. A clean cancer scan in April 2018 confirmed that she should indeed keep living her life as usual.However, everything came crashing down this holiday season. After navigating some mysterious leg pain for many months over the fall, Laura learned on December 30th that her cancer is back in her lung and has metastasized to her leg; the flip from “Remission” to “Stage IV” felt almost instantaneous.Laura and her family are now living on disability, which ends in October. Instead of being able to care for her dependents and earning a living, much of her time is now devoted to getting scans, sitting in waiting rooms, and receiving bleak news at every turn.At this point, Laura has a drain in her left calf to address the fluids that the cancer is creating (which was part of the mysterious pain and causing the leg to swell). The only course of treatment offered for her cancer is the drug Crizotinib, which, despite the optimism with which it was presented, has been accompanied by a shocking 1-3 year survival rate. Every other treatment and option discussed with her doctors has either been taken off the table or was not considered an option to begin with.Laura’s “Hail Mary” lies in pursuing the cutting-edge treatment offered through Issels Medical Center. While some of the diagnostics may be covered by insurance, the heft of the cost is not. Laura has felt that God is starting to open doors to this treatment in spite of others having closed. We are praying that we can bless her with the opportunity to receive this treatment, and that miraculous healing will be seen through the experience...and your love, prayers, and support! Please donate as you feel led, and join us in fighting for the life of our mother, wife, sister, and friend.Thank you for your generosity!Laura is posting updates on her battle at CaringBridge.org. You are invited to learn more about her journey and course of treatment (and details about the process with Issels) at that site.

name: Neal the Real Deals Fight With Bone Cancer
text: Our brother Neal has and still is fighting stage 4 bone cancer. He is now in his home with his family and has been placed on Hospice. Any help is greatly needed and appreciated. This man would and has asked for nothing from anybody during his battle with cancer.... Please step up and help his family with this upcoming final expense.L&R

name: Jerry's Journey to Knockout Cancer
text: I created this page to try to help my sister, Debbie, my brother-in-law Jerry and their 4 children.  Two weeks before Christmas, the McGovern family was given some devastating news. Jerry, 55, was diagnosed with stage 4 poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The primary site was in the lung, with metastasis to the lymph nodes and then doctors also found 11 lesions on the brain. Immediately, Jerry could no longer work. He is a driver by trade and now he has found himself out of work & needing to apply for disability (which is half of what he normally brings in). Almost overnight, this young family’s world has just been turned upside down. The diagnosis is devastating enough, but now they also find themselves in dire need financially. Jerry is the breadwinner in the family. In addition to stressing about how they will pay for the cancer care, they have bills & a mortgage to pay and have no idea how they are going to make ends meet. They have been told that a single dose of chemo is $30,000. Although Jerry has insurance, they still have deductibles to meet and still have to pay a huge portion of that. The thought of that, is completely overwhelming for a family that has barely any income coming in now.Jerry began his cancer battle with radiation to first address the brain lesions before doctors could even begin to address his inoperable lung tumor. There is a ray of hope in all of this. Jerry was tested for and found out that he is a candidate for a new cutting edge procedure called immunotherapy. Only 1 in 5 are eligible to try it and he was lucky enough to qualify as a candidate. This treatment could potentially help him fight the cancer from the inside out and hopefully will give him the shot he needs to fight this cancer and God willing, eventually go into remission. After a battle with his insurance company who at first refused to assist in paying for said treatment, Jerry began the immunotherapy treatments and has been diligent with these treatments every few weeks for the last few months. It has been tough the last few months with bouts of nausea, diarrhea and weakness and multiple medications. After two pet scans, it appears the immunotherapy is working! The original brain lesions are shrinking. Unfortunately however, this past Monday, Jerry had an emergency MRI after suffering a  new bout of dizziness, disorientation & headaches. Although the immunotherapy is  shrinking the original brain lesions, two new lesions have now appeared. Jerry needs to continue the immunotherapy & now address additional medication & alternate treatment for the new lesions. To top this all off, the insurance company will no longer cover Jerry (or his family) after July unless they purchase the insurance through COBRA. The insurance company will require Jerry to pay $600 a month just for his insurance (COBRA) & that doesn’t even include the rest of the family! Jerry & Debbie are beside themselves. They are in no position financially to do this. The bills are pouring in & they are falling behind quickly. In addition to insurance & new treatment, they also need to continue the immunotherapy which is extremely expensive ($15,000 each round). This treatment is Jerry’s greatest chance to prolong his prognosis & potentially save his life. Without it, he might not survive.They have 4 children aged 12-22. Their two oldest sons are attending college. They also have two young daughters, one in high school and the youngest just in 7th grade. All are still living at home and depend heavily on Mom & Dad. If any of you could find it in your heart to contribute to this cause, or help in any way, you would be making a huge difference in the life of this family. They would be eternally grateful. Their future depends on the kindness of others who can help alleviate some of the worry & stress of this crippling diagnosis as well as its financial repercussions. Thank you so very much.

name: Support Ryan's Fight Against Cancer
text: My little cousin Ryan (34) got married to his beautiful and talented wife Ashlee just last year.  Since then, he was misdiagnosed by his primary with IBS.  A recent severe illness, initially thought to be food poisoning, led to the discovery of a tumor on his Pancreas that proved to be cancerous, specifically Adenocarcinoma.  This type of Pancreatic cancer is fast growing (he's lost 25 pounds over the last three weeks), and he needs to battle this as pro-actively as possible.  A stint was placed in his Common Bile Duct to assist with the blockage caused by the tumor, but insurance has been a challenge and he was initially stuck on an HMO with a deductible of $6500 (that he has already maxed out)!Through some incredible blessings and a strong network of family/friends, he was finally able to change insurance and get into UCLA's cancer program.  UCLA's top Pancreatic surgeon miraculously had a cancellation in his schedule, and they already have surgery planned for Monday, Dec 10th.  The type of surgery Ryan needs is called a "Whipple Procedure", an extensive 6+ hour surgery, but necessary first step in his treatment.  However this is just the beginning of the road, and he will likely continue with Chemotherapy in the new year for an additional 5-6 months.  While they feel truly blessed to be in the UCLA system, this poses other financial challenges.  His new insurance carries higher premiums and he will now have to max out his second Out of Pocket within a week.  Unfortunately he couldn't afford to wait and delays in treatment could affect his survival rate. We are coming together as Ryan's family and friends to help lift him up both financially and through prayer.  Let's show Ryan and Ashlee they aren't alone in this fight, now and into the coming year!  Anything you can do to help would be appreciated.*If you’d feel more comfortable or would prefer to donate more directly, please contact Ashlee, or send a message to any family member for PayPal/Venmo information.

name: Help my mom beat cancer
text: They say "when you become a mother, you are no longer the center of your own universe. You relinquish that position to your children." These words describe no one better than our Mom, Usha. This woman lived by her values, taught her children how to be good people, how to trust god, and never do any harm to others. She was our rock, the person who held the family together, and fought others like a mama bear that she was when someone spoke ill of her cubs. She worked days, cooked and took care of her kids at night, and never questioned her faith. We grew up watching her go at full speed from sun up to sun down...and now, she can no longer do that. Over a year ago, we received the worst news, our mom was diagnosed with Stage 4 liver cancer. She didn't care, she organized and danced the night away at our brother's wedding, watched her second grand daughter come into this world and put up a fight against cancer. She continues to live by her faith and values but she is no longer the person she used to be. The cancer is spreading to her stomach, causing a lot of pain. She can no longer get out of bed, go to work, clean (her favorite part of the day), or cook for herself. She never asked anyone for help and now she is at the mercy of others. We, her 3 kids, are trying to raise money to assist with her medical bills. She would never do it herself but we have no family around to support us. Our father does what he can to meet the needs of the home and day to day bills. We appreciate any assistance, whether its financial or in heart felt prayers. Thank you.

name: Mallon Family Battles Against Cancer
text: Cancer is an unforeseen, destructive illness that takes so much from so many people every day. Physically, emotionally, and financially families suffer.  In late 2017, our Dad, Doug, was very ill and underwent multiple surgeries and testing before he was diagnosed with terminal cancer called Multiple Myeloma.First a little about Doug:  Born and raised in Chicago, Illinois he moved to Florida with our mom in 1978 when they went on their honeymoon and never returned to the cold.  He is a father of four and grandfather of three.   He loves his family, Turner Classic Films, The God Father, Notre Dame football, The Blackhawks, The White Sox and The Tampa Bay Buccaneers (one for FL! ) On May 29, 2018 he received his terminal diagnosis.  Multiple Myeloma causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow where they crowd out healthy blood cells.   This eliminates the ability to create healthy antibodies and for the body to self-cure causing infection in the entire bloodstream. Multiple Myeloma cannot be cured, and he will live out the rest of his life with this illness. He started chemotherapy on June 15th and has been undergoing strenuous treatments weekly since diagnosis. These treatments have taken its toll on his body and mind.  Unfortunately, the treatments were not working as the Doctors and Oncologist had predicted.On February 8 he will undergo a Bone Marrow Transplant that will leave him hospitalized for at the minimum 30 days if all things go perfectly with zero complications. At this time Doug will need to have 24-hour care under his primary caregiver, our mom, Laura resulting in both of them being unable to work. All in all, there is a long hard road ahead of all of us but our Dad is a fighter and he has a strong team of family and friends behind him every step of the way. That said, the financial burden is daunting as insurance can only cover so much. These debts weigh heavy on his heart and mind making the ability for him to concentrate on getting well and beating this cancer difficult and he is instead plagued by thoughts of financial responsibility. Doug is not one to ask for any assistance. He is a very proud man who has always paid his own way and took care of those around him. We are very thankful for all of the help and support we have received thus far and we are asking for any assistance from anyone who can offer to help him win his battle and keep his head above water financially.

name: Mookie Needs Our Help To Fight Cancer
text: We got results back for Mookie this evening. Mookie does in fact have cancer. She had a tumor growing in the bone. Osteosarcoma. For now we are keeping her comfortable. We will keep everyone posted. Thank you all for your love and kind words! We are so heart broken, Mookie means the world to me and I don’t think I’ve ever loved another being so much! A surgeon told us that there is another option to remove the leg, and treat her accordingly. I am not sure that we will make it this far, but I am willing to try at this point. I was not going too, but I can’t quit her just yet. Anything helps us get to surgery, where she will then have her leg removed and tufts medical pays for the rest of her needs. Anything helps at all to try to see what we can do!

name: Joey image cancer fund
text: Last year, Joey was diagnosed with liver cancer.  He’s seeking treatment at the University of Miami, and is possibly a candidate for liver transplant, but these procedures are incredibly expensive and often have devastating side effects.  Joey is currently driving for a living, but is uncertain whether or not he’ll be able to continue this line of work once his treatment begins. With this campaign, we’re hoping to raise funds to cover his medical expenses, and a portion of his living costs, including rent, food, and transportation. It’s not often we are able to give back to the artists who’ve shaped our lives, but this is an opportunity to help someone truly in need. If you’ve ever listened to Misfits records on repeat, or met a friend/spouse at a horror punk show, or were inspired to start your own band because of ‘Horror Business’ – please consider even a small donation. Everything helps.

name: Kilos & Kokoda Over Cancer
text: Kilos and Kokoda Over Cancer is the 1st fundraiser I am creating and doing to raise funds to help go towards cancer research and also help me get to Kokoda in late 2019  .  From the 1st of October 2018 until the end of January 2019 I will lift 1,000,000 KG of weights .  In 123 days that is 8,130KG per day. More than an African Elephant every single day.  I am doing this to show my support to my parents, to feel extremely uncomfortable and sore to somewhat empathize with the pain they feel daily.  The mental battle of the challenge will be a major focus and having to keep going no matter pain or problems that will arise within the challenge.Cancer is such a shit and horrendous disease  and everyone most likely knows someone who has been impacted by it directly or indirectly. My Parents are both currently suffering from this awful disease and have had to change a lot of the things they would normally do to better accommodate their appointments and also depending on how they feel on the day. My Mother in law also has had several battles with cancer including one recenlty that she came out victorious against.  Her husband as well has had major family losses to the disease. Cancer is something that always makes you wish you could do something more for your loved ones when you hear that this has happened to them. You want to take that pain away from them and show them you'll always be there for them!The money raised over the course of this challenge will go  towards cancer research at Curtin University so i know that all the money that is donated will go directly into the hands of the people trying to fight this disease.The challenge will also be helping me to get over to do the Kokoda track in PNG. Kokoda is something that my dad had always wanted to do but is unable to do so now  (although he would tell you he's fine and could do it anyway ). The full track is 96KM of grueling mountain ranges and dense jungle and is a major part of Australia's WW2 history in the defense against the advancing Japanese army in 1942. The physical and mental nature of the track will be a massively grueling challenge but something i look forward to.Any donations you guys make will be greatly appreciated and i would really appreciate anything you can help with.

name: Jason's Fight Against Rare Cancer
text: The Journey BeginsJason and Stephanie Le Shana have three children: Elijah (5), Micah (4), and a new addition, baby Jude (infant).  In May of 2018, Jason began to experience extreme pain in his left hip and leg. Doctors diagnosed his condition as inflammation of the hip socket, and prescribed a regimen of exercises to improve his condition. However, Jason’s pain escalated through July, leading to an MRI (at his request). On August 3, Jason and Stephanie received the startling MRI results: a large, 10cm x 10cm x 9cm tumor resided in the left side of Jason’s pelvis. This discovery launched several weeks of tests to determine the exact nature of the tumor. Those weeks were a whirlwind of activity, even as Jason’s pain began to spike to excruciating and debilitating levels. There were Emergency Room visits, doctor appointments, and more tests. While Jason suffered, Stephanie was due to give birth to their third child on August 13 via C-section! Despite his pain and difficulty walking, Jason was determined to accompany Stephanie to the hospital to witness the birth of baby Jude. On the morning of the C-Section, as Stephanie and Jason sat in the prep room, Jason’s pain spiked to an extreme level, forcing them to make a truly gut-wrenching decision: Jason was not fit to be in the operating room with Stephanie and their new son. Instead, hospital personnel rushed him on a gurney to the Emergency Room to receive several rounds of IV pain-killers to bring him out of agony. Both Stephanie and Jason mourn the fact that he spent the birth of their third son alone in the ER.The “C” WordOn Monday, August 20 (one week after Jude’s birth), the Le Shana family received more devastating news: Jason’s tumor was a rare and aggressive form of cancer, called sarcoma. Only about 1% of all cancer cases are classified as sarcomas, and there are dozens of sub-types. Moreover, the large tumor presented significant, life-altering consequences if simply removed through surgery.  An aggressive treatment program of chemotherapy and radiation, both to shrink the tumor and to address any other malignancies in the body, would be critical for Jason’s quality of life. Following consultations with some of the most highly respected sarcoma doctors and centers in the nation, Jason and Stephanie have identified the Houston, Texas-based cancer hospital MD Anderson as their preferred hospital for treatment. MD Anderson features a prominent and comprehensive sarcoma treatment center with experienced specialists and, most significantly, a proven track record of success in treating sarcoma.Next Steps: A Major MoveThe road ahead will be difficult. The current plan is for Jason to receive approximately six intense rounds of chemotherapy over the course of four months, followed by five weeks of radiation treatment. Approximately one month after the conclusion of radiation, the doctors expect to attempt to remove the tumor (which we earnestly pray will be much smaller by that time!).The treatments (chemotherapy and radiation) will be lengthy, intense, and challenging. In addition, significant financial, emotional, and spiritual costs loom on the horizon. At this time, the Le Shanas plan to temporarily relocate their entire family to Houston while Jason receives chemotherapy and radiation (i.e., about 5-6 months), leaving a significant emotional and spiritual support system behind in Southern California. Although some extended family members live in the Houston area, the financial costs associated with pursuing this treatment are daunting.We need YOU to continue to support Jason, Stephanie, Elijah, Micah, and baby Jude through prayer and giving financially as you are able!  Thank you!This GoFundMe account has been created to ask for your support in as few as one, and as many as three ways:1. Pray: This battle is spiritual as much as it is physical. We invite you to commit to praying for the Le Shana family in this season. Specific request for the boys are for their overall adjustment to the move and for good school options for Elijah (Kindergarten) and Micah (Pre-K). Jason and Stephanie request prayer for peace and trust in God in this season of the unknown, for strength physically, emotionally, and spiritually during Jason’s treatments, and that Jason will be HEALED!2. Give: Jason’s cancer diagnosis has led to significant, unplanned expenses. Money donated to them through this site will help to offset these costs, including but not limited to the following: increased health insurance premiums, medical costs (specialist appointments, scans/tests, prescriptions, chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, etc), housing costs in Houston, travel to and from treatment (both car and airfare), and to supplement lower than usual income.3. Share with your networks: We won’t be able to reach these goals without the help of a large village. Please consider sharing this with your friends and family, either via social networks, email, or word of mouth.Note from the campaign organizer: Angela Rickey is the cousin of Jason Le Shana. She has partnered with Alison Westerlind (also cousin of Jason Le Shana) as the campaign team from Arizona representing all Family Members supporting The Le Shanas. Due to the overwhelming response to this site, a withdrawl plan has been established for Jason Le Shana as the beneficiary of all donations. Updates are forthcoming to share with you details behind how withdrawls are immediately going to be used for all aspects outlined in point #2 described above. Thank you all!

name: Adam Dreeszen’s Cancer Fund
text: Earlier in May Adam was diagnosed with esophageal cancer. This was discovered by accident. It all started with difficulty swallowing and then He eventually got a piece of chicken stuck in his throat. When they removed the chicken, they took samples that came back positive for cancer. From that point He went in several times for different tests and biopsies. The cancer had spread to a couple of surrounding lymph nodes.Because it has spread the doctor is calling it stage 4 but he is confident that with time it can be taken care of. He will start chemo treatment on June 7th and after a few months, they'll reevaluate a treatment plan from the progress. We’re asking for prayers and financial assistance to help with medical expenses and other expenses to get him through this time. Thank you for anything you can provide. We love Adam very much and know he’ll fight his way through this!

name: Help Sheklun Defeat Brain Cancer!
text: URGENT!!! Everyone, my family and I need your help to save my little 14 year old brother! He has a tumour on his brain stem. Anything helps! A donation, telling your friends and family, sharing on social media, and of course your prayers.I will tell u more info below My older brother Brett, my mother Carmen, and my Stepdad Vingo are asking for your help!   Sheklun is a great brother with an amazing heart. He is loving and caring. He always makes sure you are good before he is! He has such a kind soul and is very down to earth. He is always looking out for his family and friends. Always asks me to take pictures and capture the good times! He deserves a better life!  On Jan 2, Sheklun passed out at home and was rushed via ambulance to the Stollery Children’s Hospital. We thought nothing of it and just thought he passed out from choking on a smoothie he was drinking. It turns out he passed out from a hypoxic event (shortage of oxygen). During our visit to the ER on January 2nd our world was turned upside down. We found out he had a tumour on his brain stem. Near the end of October 2018 Sheklun’s symptoms began; he had minor balance issues and slurred speech. We thought nothing of it. Surgery was planned for January 9th to allow him to be stabilized. We were fortunate enough to have the best neurosurgeon in Canada, Dr. V. Mehta. Also fortunate for his team and neurosurgery nurse practitioner Wendy.   On January 9th the exophytic (outside) part of the tumour was removed. However his brain stem is still infilterated with the tumour. The tumour is glioblastoma grade IV, aka GBM. The location of the tumour and the type of the tumour with the mutations is very very rare. The tumour was affecting his auto drive to breathe. Due to the removal of the exophytic part of the tumour, the pressure on his brain went down. His breathing and voice improved.   On January 11 Sheklun was extubated and it was successful. Sheklun began walking again on January 13 around the hospital and even to the healing garden. He did these walks from the 13th-18th. Things were looking really good! Then on January 19th we noticed he had a weaker voice and couldn’t stand. On January 23 things got really scary as his Co2 levels greatly elevated. He was placed on a ventilator. January 24th his Co2 levels elevated even more. On January 25th Sheklun was intubated and radiation treatments began in hopes to slow down the growth of the tumour. We are 3 radiation treatments down and things are looking good.  We are buying Sheklun more time so he can leave Canada and get the treatments he needs to defeat this rare tumour!Anything helps right now! Please share, donate and of course pray for Sheklun! If if you would like to make it easier to share, please check out my post, stories and tweet regarding Sheklun on Instagram, Twitter and Snapchat. Also help us get the help of celebrities on my instagram and Twitter! My social media handles are.instagram:  www.instagram.com/tfrunchy twitter:  www.twitter.com/TFrunchak snapchat: @t_frunchakThank you all!

name: Help Brian Beat Cancer
text: On November 7, 2018, our family found out that Brian Hubbs was diagnosed with stage 4 stomach cancer. As a young and healthy man at the age of 37, this came as quite a shock to everyone. He is a son to Janis and Gary, brother to Jennifer and Jonathan, husband to Stella, a father to his son Dylan, and a relative and friend to countless others. His daughter is due to be born in December. Brian recently started a new job in the Bay Area, and the medical insurance for him between his jobs puts him in a precarious position. As such, the insurance and medical bills are expected to be very expensive as he begins treatment.We are setting this GoFundMe page up to help with the costs of his treatment. The road ahead is scary, but we all remain hopeful that Brian will succeed in beating this awful disease. Any donation amount is appreciated and tax deductible, and we highly encourage everyone to please share this page with your friends and family. Brian is committed to his family, community, and country. He proudly served in the United States Marine Corps for 5 years. He went on to earn a Master of Arts in Nonproliferation and Terrorism Studies from the Middlebury Institute for International Studies at Monterey. Your donation will go a long way to help ensure Brian lives a long life where he can continue to contribute his love to his family. We thank you so much for your support in this difficult time.A message from Stella, Brian's wife:Brian is a loving husband and father that always puts his family first. No matter how long his work day he makes quality time for me and our baby everyday. Brian is a big animal lover especially to our dogs, one who has passed and one who is still with us and does her happy dance every time he comes home. This diagnosis came as a shock to everyone as he is one of the healthiest people we know. He eats healthy and exercises and encourages the same for his loved ones. As a busy mom it was very hard for me to eat healthy at times as I would just grab what was fast and easy and not always healthy. He would take the time everyday to cook for me and make sure I’m eating healthy. He would always come home from a long day at work and cook, clean, and take care of our baby to help me get a break. On weekends he did yard work among other things that needed to be done. He always had so much energy and drive and it is very difficult for me to see him so weak. He has some very bad symptoms from the cancer which has affected his stomach and liver. His energy levels are so low. It is very hard on him as well, feeling that he can’t do all the things he use to. We have just moved back to the Bay Area which has been a difficult transition and we are grateful for the help we received during this difficult time. We are excited for our daughter to arrive who is due in December. We are looking forward to starting his chemo and recovery. We are very grateful for your help and donation during this difficult time. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

name: Mike Gorman’s cancer/stroke fund
text: In April 2018 Mike was diagnosed with Stage 4 oral cancer.  In June he underwent an extensive 18 hour cancer removal surgery.  The day after surgery it was discovered that Mike had suffered a significant left sided stroke sometime during surgery.  The stroke has effected the right side of his body and the speech and communication centers of his brain.  Mike has been in the hospital for over 4 months.  Even though he has made significant progress in this therapy  the road to recovery is long.   Mike will have life long limitations and will need extensive therapy once he is released from transitional care.  Mike will also require 24 hour home care for a while until it is deemed safe to leave him alone.  As you can imagine the medical bills and expenses are mounting.  Home care and the extensive speech, occupational and physical therapy that will be required will exceed our insurance coverage.  Any money raised from this campaign and the upcoming benefit will be used to fund Mike's therapy, medical bills and modifications to our home to make it more accessible.   Thank you for taking the time to read this and for any help that you can provide.  It is greatly appreciated!

name: Elizabeth Sagers Cancer Treatment
text: Liz was diagnosed with Pancreatic Cancer last year, it has since spread to her liver and there are concerning blood clots.  Surgery isn't possible for a couple of reasons.   She has done chemo and radiation and is on medicine to help with her blood clot. The insurance plan does not have a max out of pocket on pharmacy. The medications for her treatments are very expensive. Liz is also trying alternative medicine and treatments that are helping with the pain and side affects of the cancer, which are not covered by insurance.   We are asking for help as this is financially devastating their sweet family.   Any amount will help alleviate the financial burden on their family. We are praying for a quick recovery for Liz so she can spend many years with her husband Stephen and her 6 year old daughter Megan. Donations can be received through the following methods:This GoFundMe AccountMountain America Credit Union - Elizabeth Sagers and Stephen Sagers Account In person to Liz or Stephen

name: Caleb's Medical Fund (Brain Cancer)
text: The stroy is in both languages English and Spanish! La historia está en los dos idiomas ingles y español. English Caleb is a handsome 10 years old boy which parents are Nancy Morales and Pedro Morales. Caleb has always been very happy, he makes friends everywhere, he is very mature, intelligent, cooperative, thoughtful, sweet and stills very innocent. One of the things he enjoys doing is helping the homeless, baking cookies and biscuits. This past September 2017 he began to suffer from headaches and vomiting. The doctors discovered that he suffered from a stage 4 cancerous tumor called glioblastoma multiforme, lodged in his brain. In three weeks he suffered three surgeries in his brain. He already had 6 weeks of radiotherapies and chemotherapies have just begun. Currently they have a lot of medical deductibles to pay. Aid for these costs is being managed with the faith that they will be covered but there are other expenses like medical appointments that must be covered, medicines, natural treatment, in addition to the preparation of the home for the Hospital Homebound, therapies, etc. His mother had to stop working to take care of him at all times due that she has to take him almost every day to  the oncology clinic, rehabilitation therapies and specialty doctors which has complicated the family economy even more. We really appreciate your help, no matter the amount of it because among all the contributions, Caleb will overcome this cruel disease and the whole family can stay together. Español Caleb es un niño hermoso de 10 años cuyos padres son Nancy Morales y Pedro Morales. Caleb siempre ha sido muy alegre, hace amigos en todas partes, es muy maduro, inteligente, cooperador, detallista, dulce y aún muy inocente. Una de las cosas que disfruta hacer es ayudar a los deambulantes, hornear galletas y bizcochos. En septiembre 2017 comenzó a sufrir dolores de cabeza y vómitos. Los doctores descubrieron que sufría de un tumor canceroso clase 4 llamado glioblastoma multiforme, alojado en su cerebro. En tres semanas sufrió tres operaciones. El tratamiento recomendado es radioterapias y quimioterapias, las cuales ya comenzó. Actualmente tenemos muchos deducibles médicos que tenemos que cubrir. Se están gestionando ayudas para estos costos con la fe de que serán cubiertos pero hay otros gastos como citas médicas que hay que cubrir, medicamentos, tratamiento natural además de la preparación de la casa para el Hospital Homebound, terapias, entre otros. Su mamá tuvo que dejar de trabajar para cuidarlo en todo momento, ya que casi diariamente tienen que ir a la clínica oncológica, terapias de rehabilitacion y doctores especialistas, lo que ha complicado aún más la economía familiar. Agradecemos de todo corazón su ayuda, no importa la cantidad porque entre todas las aportaciones, Caleb logrará vencer esta cruel enfermedad y toda la familia podrá mantenerse unida.

name: Michele Proietto's Cancer Battle
text: The close friends of Michele Proietto have chosen to reach out and ask friends, co-workers, and any other individuals in the community to help support Michele’s battle against Stage 4 Uterine Cancer at age 49.  In the last 2 weeks, Michele was blindsided with the devastating news of her diagnosis after being admitted to the emergency room after experiencing severe pelvic pain.  After several days in the hospital, two surgeons were able to operate simultaneously and remove multiple tumors from her pelvis and other surrounding areas where the cancer had spread.  Other affected tissues/parts of her body were removed as well.  The situation is especially emotional for Michele since her mother died earlier in her life of the exact same cancer, while Michele attended her in Hospice.  Getting through the tumor-removal surgery was the easy part of this process.  The next steps will require Michele to undergo 6 months of chemotherapy with doctors monitoring her progress closely.  During these past 2 weeks, Michele has only been able to focus on survival. The road ahead requires much more extensive medical care with numerous doctors and continuous monitoring.  We all know someone who has been affected by this horrendous disease and how it takes an emotional toll on the patient. We all hope and pray for her full recovery. Michele’s friends and family can provide emotional support and get her to doctor appointments, but we desperately need financial help.  Michele needs all her energy focused on healing rather than worrying.  Being that she lives alone and is the sole income provider, the mounting medical bills and basic living expenses are overwhelming in the face of everything else.  Helping Michele now is a minor way in which we all can assist in alleviating the burden that this devastating medical diagnosis bears on her shoulders. Please support Michele’s recovery with a gift – whatever you can spare, no gift is too small.  Many small things can amount to something big, and make a world of difference for Michele.   The money raised from this GoFundMe will be used to help pay for Michele’s further treatment and ongoing expenses until she can get back to living and working again as a flight attendant. With your love and support, there is always hope.

name: Help Milo Sanchez Defeat Cancer
text: In October 2017, 3 month old Milo was diagnosed with Bilateral Retinoblastoma, a rare form of eye cancer. His mommy and daddy found the best doctors at Wills Eye Hospital and the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. From October-March 2018, Milo's doctors had him undergoing chemotherapy treatments every four weeks. Milo also had EUA's (examination under anesthesia) to monitor the tumors located in both eyes.  During the EUAs Milo receives cyrotherapy and laser treatments to stabilize tumor growth. When not in Philadelphia, he receives weekly blood draws to monitor is blood counts. Furthermore Milo sees a Pediatric Ophthalmologist on a monthly basis to provide patching treatment to strengthen his vision.An EUA in May 2018 uncovered 6 recurrences of the tumors. Unfortunately treatment requires a risky procedure known as Intral Arterial Chemotherapy (IAC).  A catheter is inserted through his groin, and travels to an artery to administer the chemotherapy directly to the eye. We are hopeful the IAC proves to be successful, however, it isi costly, and  has prolonged Erin's inability to go back to work as she must provide constant care for Milo and her family. Traveling to Pennsylvania on a monthly basis, along with the mounting medical bills have put an added strain on the Sanchez family. Please show your love and support by providing the family with a monetary donation. All donations are greatly appreciated, and will help cover both travel and medical expenses.

name: Help a mom beat Stage 4 cancer
text: I am a mom of 5 with 4 kids still at home. And granny to 3 grandsons.  Im asking you to be part of the miracle of saving me please?I am coming here today to ask for help to save my life. I was diagnosed on friday the 13th of july with liver cancer. But come to find out its not liver cancer......its cancer of an unknown source that spread to my liver.......so far i have had 2 biopsies and 3 ct scans . I go to the university of michigan cancer center 2 hours away on the 18th to set my treatment plan. As of right now i am doing a alkaline diet. Which is very expensive and supplements because i am doing what i have researched that will help instead of just sitting here not fighting to live.
