I am only 40 years old and have so much life to live still. Not only for me but my children and grandchildren. They are what i live for. Anyone that has children and has had cancer knows that is all you worry about everyday. WHAT WILL MY KIDS DO IF SOMETHING HAPPENS....I need help with the medical bills that are already stacking up along with my copays and the things that are helping my stay alive  as of now. Tons of supplements and vitamins...Even everyday essentials, food...Because you take from one thing to get another thing. Robbing peter to pay paul. Its physically and emotionally draining. Cancer is expensive. If you have never known anyone with it or had it yourself its beyond financially draining.... Plus gas for treatments....I  have multiple tumors that metastasized to my liver. They say once they kill the root cause the tumors on my liver will go away as well.I am begging you if you have it in your heart to help a mom stay alive please help.... Pray or post some encouragement or advice.Thank you all for taking the time to read my post. Kind regards and many blessings Carol Biskner

name: Help Cynthia Cochran K.O. Cancer!
text: This is Cynthia’s story as told by her father, Todd Cochran: January 23, 2019 I received the phone call every parent prays they will never receive. It was 10:30pm and I received a call from my daughter, Cynthia’s boyfriend that she was having trouble speaking coherently and was disoriented. He told me he wanted to take her to the emergency room in Fayetteville, AR, where she attends college. I agreed and told him I would meet him at the hospital but we live in Tulsa, OK which is two hours away. On the drive to Fayetteville, we received another phone call telling us that the CT scan showed a mass on Cynthia’s brain. By the time we reached the hospital our worst fears were confirmed. Cynthia had a tumor in her brain the size of the surgeon’s fist and would require surgery. On January 25, Cynthia underwent a craniotomy to remove the tumor. The pathology report confirmed our next greatest fear. The tumor was a grade 4 glioblastoma, the most aggressive cancer that begins in the brain. Cynthia’s surgery went very well and the surgeon was confident he removed most all of the tumor that he could safely remove. The speed of Cynthia’s recovery from surgery amazed everyone who worked with her, from the nurses and doctors at the hospital and then at the rehabilitation hospital. Cynthia still has a long way to go. She will begin a regiment of radiation and chemotherapy at the same time followed by more chemotherapy after a resting period and possibly other procedures after that. Many people who have been praying for my daughter don’t even really know her and don’t even realize that while yes, it was a significant event because she was a loved daughter, sister, granddaughter, niece, cousin, roommate, friend, etc... there was much more to her story. I wanted to take an opportunity to tell you about her and tell you why what she is going through is so significant and at the same time amazing. Cynthia is 20 years old and a Junior at the University of Arkansas. My daughter is smart. I mean SCARY smart. In Kindergarten her teacher held a competition to see which student could read the most books by the end of the school year. To add to her motivation, I told her that I would pay her $1 for every book she read. She won the competition and it cost me over $50. I have often said that $50 was the best investment I have EVER made. Her love for reading continued to bloom and her thirst for knowledge grew along with it. She was pretty much a straight A student. Her teachers will tell you she was the kind of student that would be upset with herself if an assignment received lower than an A. In 7th grade, her state testing scores qualified her to be invited to participate in the Duke TIP program that allowed her to take the ACT college readiness exam. Her score was high enough that the test indicated she was ready for college as a 7th grader!! When it came time to take the test in high school, she scored a 31 which is outstanding but she wasn’t satisfied with that and took the test again. This time she made a 34!!! That score along with an outstanding interview lead her to not only be offered a scholarship to the University of Arkansas, but one step higher. She would become a fellow, earning a Fellowship to attend the U of A in their Honors College. She entered college already having 29 college credits because of AP high school courses and concurrent college classes while still in high school. While growing up she had one career goal that never wavered since the 3rd grade. She wanted to be a pediatrician. She is a DOUBLE major of Pre-med Biology AND Psychology, but she wasn’t satisfied with just those two hard majors, she also is obtaining a minor in French! This is all incredible when you recognize this all had been accomplished while unknown to any of us there was this growing tumor in her brain. Only FIVE days earlier before she entered the hospital, this incredible young woman completed the MCAT (medical school entrance exam)!And then..... 5 days later that incredible future seemed to now be in question. I don’t know what exactly will happen. I know one thing and it is the most important thing..... my daughter is alive!! She has survived a 4 hour long surgery to remove the huge tumor and is getting stronger and better everyday since that surgery. College for now is on hold. We contacted the university and found out the procedure for withdrawing for this semester. We hope that she will only be out one semester and then be right back on track to return to college this coming fall. I know my daughter, she is stubborn and strong. If anyone can do this it is her! So, this is for who you are praying. Praying that not only does God heal her body but that He also keeps the world from being robbed of an incredible doctor that one day will have an impact on hundreds and thousands of lives. As always, my family cherishes your prayers and support and we love each and every one of you!

name: Help Us Cure Bonnie's Cancer!
text: Bonnie's Ewing's Sarcoma has metastasized in her lungs. FROM THE BEGINNINGWhen you are a young adult attending college, working full time, and chasing your rambunctious but highly intelligent son through a bedtime routine, the last thing you expect is to end up in the ER in terrible pain. You especially do not expect to hear that the pain isn’t something simple to remedy, but in fact, is a softball sized tumor growing on your ribs. That’s exactly the challenge life served Bonnie.So, the mass was removed in one of the most painful surgeries a person can undergo. The Dr. sat across from Bonnie’s mother and partner with news to deliver that makes time stand still and your breath stop. “It’s definitely CANCER.”  Soon thereafter Bonnie began a rigorous regimen of inpatient chemotherapy which included a 5 day hospital stay (due to the intensity of the chemo) every 4th week. Between her inpatient chemotherapy visits, she was also receiving outpatient infusions every other week. Throw in another rib resection surgery mid-year and several hospital admissions for neutropenic shock, and Bonnie spent more of 2017 in the hospital than she spent time at home with her family.Happy news came early 2018. She had finally completed her year of chemo treatments and was given the "all clear" when her scans came back free of any indication of cancer. Bonnie could finally move forward with plans they had to relocate to Oregon, continue school and work, meet new people and enjoy time with family. DISCOURAGING NEWSWhen Bonnie went to the oncologist this September for her first routine 6 month follow up, the CT scans showed spots on lungs that were not there in February. After a biopsy a week later, it was confirmed that her cancer has returned. The new prognosis was originally presented as a pretty bleak scenario. Bonnie was offered limited treatment options that typically only show benefit in 30%- 50% of patients treated. Bonnie's oncologist was optimistic that if they could find the right treatment it could possibly stop the cell regeneration and maybe even send the cancer into remission. This suggestion offered her hope, until it was coupled with the phrases ”to hope for 10 years would be optimistic" and that anything currently available would still result in "just biding time". We felt defeated, but did not give up. A SECOND OPINIONThis is where we would appreciate your help!We reached out to Cancer Treatment Center of America for a second opinion and their attitude from the very beginning was one of optimism. They assessed the situation and believe that all treatment should be designed to cure and not just bide time. They are ready to review her individual diagnosis and create a treatment plan tailored to her specific cancer. Although Bonnie's insurance does cover some of the costs of treatment, she is seeking funding  to compensate for loss of income she will suffer while unable to work, loss of income her loved ones and support team may experience when helping her to treatments, reoccurring insurance premiums to maintain her health care coverage, insurance co-pays, deductibles, travel expenses to the out-of-state treatment facilities, additional childcare costs for her 7 year old son so he can attend daycare while she receives treatments, and any of the many other unforeseeable costs associated with such a diagnosis.As with any cancer diagnosis, time is of the essence. Initial funding will be put to use as early as this week when Bonnie heads to her first consultation with Cancer Treatment Center of America. The need for funding will be a continuous one as we learned in 2017, and every cent or every "share" of this GoFundMe link,  and Bonnie's story, is appreciated more than you can imagine.We understand not everyone will be able to donate, and that is okay! If you are unable to donate, but would still like to help, here's some suggestions:- Spread the word! Share this story with everyone you know!- Shoot her a nice text and let her know she is in your thoughts- Post pictures and stories here of how you know Bonnie and how she has touched your life- Visit her website for stories of her journey-Join her Facebook Group for regular updates and uploads- Check back here often for updates

name: Help Cortney Kick Cancer!
text: Cortney is the quintessential middle child - loyal, compassionate and kind. Her life is full of examples where she placed the well-being of family, friends, animals and the earth above herself.•  She opened her home to her siblings and for a time helped raise her little niece•  She is the ever-present shoulder and listening ear for new and old friends alike•  She ran a farm, cared for animals as a zookeeper and is the Momma to a pair of loving pitbulls•  She joined protests at Standing Rock when her personal beliefs and the earth were threatenedCortney has stood up for so many of us, it's time we stand up for her.Cortney has breast cancer. But, breast cancer does NOT define who she is. Cortney is everything mentioned above and more. And, she needs our help. She needs the loyalty, compassion and kindness she has shown to so many others. Her siblings in Kalamazoo and I (her brother in Detroit) have put together this crowdfunding campaign to help with the medical and financial burdens associated with her treatment and recovery. Funds will go towards medical bills, prescription costs and any day-to-day expenses impacted by her diagnosis.Cortney will be treated in Ann Arbor,  Michigan. Her surgeries are scheduled for January 2018.Please give what you can and/or share. Funds will be dispersed to her periodically during and after her treatment.We thank you! And, Cortney thanks you :)

name: CANCER: MGUS/MULTIPLE MYELOMA
text: CANCER: MGUS/MULTIPLE MYELOMA To whom this may concern, I am battling a rare cancer called MGUS/MULTIPLE MYELOMA.  Please understand that I am not sharing this story for anyone to feel sorry for me or to earn some possible personal gain for recognition.  I am simply sharing what I have endured and what I am currently going through to encourage others and to seek prayer, financial help, or whatever God lays on your heart to give. In 2010, I was given a specific amount of time to live (less than a year), due to being diagnosed with various disorders; one being Congested Heart Failure with an ejection fraction of 5%. Based on the diagnosis of one of my ailments, my heart at the time was not able to continue pumping the blood around my body. This caused kidney failure, edema, and my organs were starting to shut down. My body started to retain fluid and swell, which caused a huge amount to remain in my lungs. It was so bad at the time, my doctors wanted to amputate one of my legs due to a hole that was created from the lack of proper blood flow down to my bone. I went through additional testing because my doctors believed that I had Lupus; which is rare in men. I found out in December 2013 that I don't have Lupus and my heart is better; however, I am not completely healed yet.  I am still having various issues with my heart and my Doctors want to perform other invasive surgeries on me.  After more testing, I have been diagnosed with a Rare Blood Cancer Called MGUS/Multiple Myeloma.  I am doing all that I can to learn about this disease that I am facing.  In addition, I am maintaining my doctor visits to a Bone Marrow clinic for my diagnosis. It has been a journey, and the healing process isn't over yet, but through faith, I am Claiming it in the name of Jesus. I can remember not being about to even walk 1/4 of a mile to take my dog out of my home. With the help of my amazing Team At Duke HealthCare (My PCP, Nutritionist, Cardiologist, and the Holy Spirit for guiding these wonderful people along with a few others that helped) I am able to get around a little better. I share this message to encouage someone not to give up. God isn't done writing your story. As long as I am alive, on this side of the world, I will share with as many as I can what HE HAS DONE FOR ME!! I am 170 pounds down and well on my way to recovery!! I still have more surgeries and continued treatment to undergo. I am reaching out asking many of you to sow a seed to help with my treatments, medicines/prescriptions, expensive medical copays, travel expenses to and from doctor visits that are sometimes out of state; and various other expenses that have been generated. I wanted to reach out to a few of my friends to see if you could donate. I am trying to raise as much money that I can before my next couple of surgeries.  If you desire to give, feel free to donate here on GofundMe. If you are not able to give financially, that is fine as well.  Your prayers mean alot also!!  Please keep your brother in prayer!! May God bless you! #GoBeyondGiving Dameian Battle, MBA

name: CANCER IS A B*TCH
text: Our brother, our kids uncle, our parents son and his spouse’s love, Evan has been hit with the worst news we could have imagined.  CANCER.  He’s 25, incredible healthy, successful and full of light, this should not be happening.Evan has been diagnosed with B Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia and it’s very aggressive.  He lives with his girlfriend, Cori, in Grande Prairie, Alberta but since the hospital there can’t treat with radiation he was sent right away to Edmonton.  Now, he was told that he would be staying at the hospital for a month and then he would have to stay in Edmonton for another month and finish Chemo in Grande Prairie. However, that isn’t the case anymore and that is why we are asking for anyone to help. Evan will continue to stay at the Edmonton hospital for a month but will need to stay in Edmonton for a YEAR! He has to stay in Edmonton because there’s no hematologist in GP, and they can’t treat his type of cancer in GP and when he gets out the only ALL specialist in Alberta is at the Cross Cancer Institute. Also, at that point he doesn’t have to have radiation. Only the chemo. Since he will be very susceptible to getting sick, they need him to stay close by. He has also been told he won’t be working for the next two years. Now, as you can imagine this situation would be very hard for anyone. His girlfriend, Cori, is put in a rather awful position as well because they have now been torn apart, she lives in GP where she has her job and her loved one will be 5 hours away in Edmonton.  This is going to cause a lot of financial stress, which is why we are hoping to raise something to help them out for the next year or two. Here is a ink to what he has been diagnosed with:     http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/non-hodgkin-lymphoma/non-hodgkin-lymphoma/more-types-of-nhl/lymphoblastic-lymphoma/?region=onI thank you in advance for any donations as well as simply sharing this page with everyone you know.  This is an extremely hard time for our family.

name: From Cancer Remission to Car Repossession
text: in 2013 I was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer. It was aggressive and had to go into immediate chemotherapy to shrink the tumor then I was able to have a mascetomy and radiation. I survived. Yet after 4 years of treatments my financial world crumbled. I lost my job and was finally able to start work again with a tremendous paycut. I have worked in hospice for over 20 years watching people take their last breaths and supporting those who cared for them. My cancer ordeal not only depleted me financially but mentally as well. Due to medical bills and garnishments it became increasingly harder and harder to keep my head above water. I have always been a single mother fighting for the security of my children but it is now that I need help. My car was repossessed which now threatens everything, even my sanity. I feel very close to the edge and friends fear I will harm myself. Instead I am reaching out into the universe for help. If you can donate it could save my life, if you cannot please share and say a prayer for me and for the many others in our world who need it.  Thank you.

name: Firefighting Family Pancreatic Cancer Battle Fund
text: After decades of dropping everything for my fellow Americans and communities to fight fire or respond to those in need at their darkest hour, I am asking for help to fight for my wife's life. She was just diagnosed with pancreatic cancer 10 days ago. Her name is Cassondra and she has stood beside me for the last 10 years fighting fire and helping people. I am putting everything on hold to fight for her. Pancreatic cancer "the silent killer" has a survival rate of less than 20%,after 5 years the rate is less than 7%. We are going to fight this like a war. On 2/12/19 we are flying to the cancer treatment center of America in Chicago to start the fight for her life. As you all know this is expensive and we live paycheck to paycheck. Two of our girls are in college and the youngest will be starting this fall, we hope and pray that Cassondra will be able to see them all graduate in the next 2 to 5 years as well as watch them walk down the aisle and see her grand babies. We have fought fires in most of the Western states at one time or another and know firsthand the financial hardship that those affected have faced. As a combat veteran of the Gulf War , I am asking that you help me fund the WAR ON CANCER for my wife and others. We will be in Chicago at the hospital for at least 1 to 2 weeks with no income. We know that his disease can be overcome but it is a long hard road. Any and all help is very greatly appreciated. May God Bless you, my prayers are with you just for taking the time to read this. Thank You, Gary.

name: Young Mom Battles Brain Cancer
text: Hello everyone, my name is Jessica and I would like to tell you about my very first best friend who could really use your help. Ashley is a 26-year-old single mother of a beautiful one-year-old girl, Natalie Ann. Shortly after Natalie's first birthday, Ashley suffered a seizure which led to the discovery of a tumor in the frontal lobe of her brain. Within a few days, Ashley underwent surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible. Due to the location of the tumor, only about 70% was successfully able to be removed. Shortly thereafter, a biopsy revealed a devastating diagnosis. The tumor was determined to be a Stage IV Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), the most aggressive type of cancer that can begin within the brain. There is no cure for GBM. In order to slow the growth of the tumor and maximize Ashley's time with her daughter, she is set to begin chemo and radiation this week.Ashley has always given of herself, family being her number one priority since childhood. Recently, she set aside her career to help care for her mother who suffers from a form of muscular dystrophy.  Having Natalie has brought a light to their lives that had been missing for so long. Everyone who knows Ashley knew that she would be a great mother, but since the day Natalie Ann was born, there has been a light in Ashley's eyes that I've never seen before.  She was  meant to be this little girls mommy and all Ashley wants to do right now is spend as much time as possible with her baby girl.I'm asking anyone and everyone to please consider donating whatever you can to help this family focus on what's most important, not wondering how they're going to afford the next medical bill that comes their way. No donation is too small, and every cent will be going directly to Ashley and her family. If you can't afford a donation right now, please consider sharing this campaign to gain as much support as humanly possible.It's going to take more than a village. It's going to take an army. So let's rally the troops and stand beside Ashley as she begins treatment this week.And to everyone reading, sharing, and donating....Thank You.You are making a difference.#AshleysWarriors#AshleysArmy

name: Please help me with my cancer costs
text:
"Hi, my name is Manda, and I've been diagnosed with stage 4 ovarian cancer. I was diagnosed in February, and since then, the doctors have told me that I now have six months. The cancer is inoperable, and metastasized to my lungs, stomach and lower intestine.  I am a single mom, and although my children are grown [my youngest son is 19 years old] I am still helping them out with bills, college, and basically getting their lives settled because first and foremost I am a mom and I always will be. I love my kids and put them first in all things, but now this cancer has me."* * * * *


This was the opening that my mother wrote last year when she started this campaign, after being diagnosed.  Thanks to the treatment given to her by doctors and the loving support of her friends and family, she exceeded the six month estimate.  We were all thankful for every extra minute we got to spend with her, even though seeing her struggle with the disease was so hard.Unfortunately, in late January she passed away.  Now my siblings and I are beset with costs we were never prepared for, such as for cremation and arrangements to be made for her remains.  This woman was an endless pillar of strength for us all our lives, and for her to be suddenly gone has been devastating.  We thought we were braced, but really you can never be braced for something like this.  There has been an outpouring of love and support from our friends and family, and we are truly grateful for any help offered to us in this difficult time.  Thank you.

name: Ray Esparza Brain Cancer Medical Fund
text: Hi, I am Nichol and Ray is my dad. I want to share a story with you about how our world has been turned upside down. In late June of 2018, while running on the treadmill, my dad noticed an uncoordinated feeling on his left side, particularly his arm and leg, of which he described as a flopping sensation. Later that day while loading his pickup truck, he stepped off a platform and fell between the bushes in the yard. A quick call to his dad (a former Vietnam corpsman) resulted in an urgent plea to go directly to the emergency room to check for signs of a stroke. After an initial exam and 15 minutes in an MRI tube, the emergency room doctor delivered the alarming news. He explained that sitting directly over the control center of his left arm and leg was a 2-centimeter tumor. The next few days were full of distraction and uncertainty. From running his business to preparing the lakehouse for his niece’s wedding reception, my dad exuded immense positivity and determination. Then on July 6th just one day after his 1 year wedding anniversary to his best friend, and, self-described angel Karen, my dad began phase two which included the 5-hour brain surgery to biopsy the tumor. The surgeons removed as much of the tumor as possible--any more would have left him with a significant loss of function. And, before I knew it he called me shortly after the procedure to reassure me that he was okay and to sprinkle some of his optimism on my worried heart. Two days later he was released home for rest and rehab. Several weeks past before doctors discovered precisely what he was up against. The results were what we feared the most. The big C word. Cancer. Stage 4 (inoperable) Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM). It is terminal with a prognosis of 14-16 months with treatment. This 57-year-old father, newlywed, son, brother, friend, business owner, 3-mile runner, boat driver, motorcycle rider, guitar player and the king of positivity and happiness has been humbled beyond comprehension. The months following the prognosis have included chemotherapy, radiation, occupational and physical therapy 4x/week, nurses visits, as well as wearing his Optune (a device creating wavelike electric fields to slow or stop GBM cells from dividing) for 18-24 hours a day. Despite the fact that these treatments have taken a toll on his mobility they are providing my dad with a priceless treasure and that is time. Spending time with family, friends, and his fur babies watching movies, laughing, convalescing by the lake, and reminiscing is immensely important at this stage. I have created this GoFundMe page with the intention of easing their financial challenges but most of all to provide my dad with the important medical devices he needs such as a wheelchair ramp and 24-hour in-home care to ensure that he is safe and comfortable. Please reach out to him via Facebook or DM me for his direct contact information. He would love calls, messages, letters, and visitors. The more the merrier! Thank you for your time and donations. xo-Nichol

name: Melissa Bishop Fight Against Stage IV lung cancer
text: On November 11, 2018 Melissa received the phone call confirming our worst fear, she has stage IV lung cancer.    If you've ever met Melissa you know how amazing she is.  Her life has always been dedicated to others.  Anyone who has been touched by her can tell you story upon story of her kindness.   Melissa has been SO reluctant to allow this GoFundMe because she STILL feels like others need help more than she does.  The bottom line is her medical expenses are in excess of  $1000 a month out of pocket per month.  Her insurance deductible is $6600.  She obviously can't work.  Her amazing husband Larry is self-employed.   He doesn't get paid time off to care for her.  This is our opportunity to give back, she needs us.  This is Melissa's story in her own words: *****************************************************************"About 7 years ago I got a very bad case of the flu. It affected my breathing my oxygen level and had me in bed for around 6 weeks. I developed pneumonia from it and saw a noticeable marked difference before and after the flu with my breathing. With no Health Insurance I did what many Moms do…put ourselves on the least priority list. I honestly thought I would just get better. My Dr. thought I had some damage to my lungs due to the pneumonia but it was manageable. I had a chronic cough but it really did not impact nor affect my daily life. I was told I had mild asthma and allergies which made sense. I used an inhaler when I had flare ups and everyone around me became numb to my cough. I am not a smoker nor ever have been. people who are smokers smoke outside when I am near by and my home is 100% smoke free. I cared for animals, lifted heavy bags of feed, exercised and despite coughing spells and frequent bronchitis I was impacted very minimally. It became my normal. In July during one of my coughing spells I started coughing up blood. Even us tried and true Martyr Moms know this is the time to get to a Dr. We recently acquired a high deductible Health Insurance policy so decided to use it. My Dr thought I had a sinus infection she decided to do a sinus ct scan and add on a chest ct in case. At the hospital the techs broke character and shockingly asked me if I worked at an asbestos factory. I knew the scan was abnormal but was not ready to hear that I had Chronic Interstitial Lung Disease with Pulmonary Fibrosis. My Pulmonary Dr. assured me while it is labeled as incurable many treatments including lung transplant can greatly increase quality of life and life span. We were devastated to hear this. 5 years? How is this possible for a nonsmoking very active female? This is something 90-year-old men get after heavy smoking for years, right? Upon further scans Dr's became concerned with a dark mass on my lower left lung. Upon several attempts at biopsy and a very painful open lung biopsy, I was told that the tumor is Non-small cell adenocarcinoma lung cancer.  A further Pet Scan found another active spot on my upper right lobe that is the same cancer type. Apparently, the bad condition of my lungs makes my cells reproduce as cancer cells instead of healthy cells. At my most recent visit Hopkins Dr's told me that due to my Lung Disease they cannot aggressively treat the cancer and due to the cancer, they cannot properly treat my Lung disease. They labeled me as incurable and said on average people in my situation live about 1 year. They are offering Chemotherapy to see if they can slow the progression of cancer growth and prolong my life. My first treatment was on November 28th. Thus far my body is handling the chemo well. I have faith and hope. I am also trying Chinese medicine and some alternative therapies. Now adding insult to injury when people like myself hear devastating news like this, many things happen. You see the sadness and horror in your friends and family’s eyes. You realize that all your plans for Grandkids, growing old with your kids and spouse and friends are all in jeopardy. You watch as income dwindles and expenses rise and see the immense impact your illness has on those you love. Agencies that are supposed to be your safety net treat you like you are trying to pull one over on them. So instead of enjoying every minute with your family you are visiting lawyers, getting loans on your house and signing papers to try to extend your life. It is devastating. My goal in life is and has always been to help others. My prayer is that if even 1 person goes to see their Dr for an annoying cough and gets early treatment and saves them and their families from going through what we are then it will be worth being open about our current struggles.

name: Patrick Languzzi AML Cancer Fund
text: Genentech friends and family,Patrick Languzzi, SCOS, Boston North-Hematology Franchise, was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). AML is a devastating type of blood cancer and treatments can be life-threatening. Within 48 hours of diagnosis Patrick was admitted to Mass General Hospital in Boston to begin intensive chemotherapy; he will remain hospitalized for a month and then may need to return for a bone marrow transplant. Patrick is a longtime member of the Genentech family. He joined the company in 2004 working in the HER2 Family as a Clinical Specialist for nearly 13 years before transitioning to the Hematology Franchise this past January.  Deeply passionate about his customers and patients, Patrick's giving nature and genuine concern for others has also touched many of us both personally and professionally over the years. His favorite quote is, "You need talent to be good and passion to be great."Knowing our dear friend and colleague has a long road ahead of him we wanted to offer the opportunity to provide support for Patrick and his family during this difficult time.   The HER2 and Hematology teams have joined together to help ease some of the burden for Patrick and his family.  He and his wife, Ezzy, son Patrick and two dogs, Albert and Oliver live in Maynard, MA, a suburb of Boston. The funds will be used for things like restaurant and grocery store gift card, rides to the hospital or his son's school, lawn service and snow plowing, etc.  Flowers and certain foods may increase the risk of infection and should not be sent to the hospital or his home, instead we ask that you please utilize the GoFundMe account if you are interested in helping the family.  Cards and notes are welcome anytime, but we ask that texts, emails and calls be limited so he is not inundated. Please reach out to Brad Zebra or Andrew Bellina if you have questions or concerns. Thank you all for your consideration in assisting Patrick and his family through this difficult time.

name: Isabella vs. Leukemia (A.L.L.)
text: Hi everyone, so last Monday Franka and I started to notice a change in our daughter thinking she was sick. We were seeing her with a fever, she was very lethargic to the point where she was peeing the bed 3-4 times a night opposed to her usual, once maybe twice a week. We ended up  keeping her from school Tuesday and Wednesday Franka received a phone call from Isabella’s school because she hadn’t stopped crying. So when Franka picked her up from school, Isabella’s grand mother, Jen had pointed out that Isabella’s skin was extremely yellow and that we should bring her to her pediatrician.Franka brought her to her pediatrician and got blood work done. Not even 10 minutes after they left, Franka received a phone call from the office and we were told that we had to bring her to Tufts floating hospital in Boston, but we decided to go to Children’s hospital instead. When we got to the ER, they immediately got us into a private room, took her blood, and had some pretty accurate answers within hours. They prepared us for what had looked like leukemia. In which after more blood work, they confirmed that Isabella had been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. (A.L.L.). This news has been hands down the worst news we’ve  ever received. But the children’s hospital staff has not only been extremely informative, but amazing with how they treat our daughter. They let us know that even though some children do pass away from her version of leukemia ( A.L.L.; higher risk due to a genetic mutation) the majority of children can be cured.  Being affiliated with Dana Farber, having our family and friends as our support system, and by faith in God,  she is in the best hands in the country to treat this. Which has made us very confident in the fact that our daughter WILL beat this and will kick cancers butt.The unfortunate side to this, is that she still has to undergo 25 months of chemotherapy. This has been taking a huge toll on us already. We are currently living in children’s hospital. We please ask that you keep us in your thoughts and prayers and we will keep you posted on her updates. With Franka and I being out of work now, we are asking that you could please help us out by donating in order to reach our financial goal, so that we can accomplish our main goal, and that’s to be there for our daughter at every moment for the next 25 months without having to worry about any finances. Thank you all so much.

name: Help Susan Flores Fight Leukemia (AML)
text: Dear Friends:Susan Flores is a 53 year old fighter, a mother, a wife and a friend. She is compassionate, nurturing, and religious. She helped others when they were in need but she is now fighting for her own life. Now, Susan needs OUR help!She was diagnosed with Thyroid Cancer 18 years ago. She fought hard and conquered that cancer’s betrayal; however, she is again determined to battle another type of cancer which wants to take her life. Susan was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) recently in the last week and has been undergoing Leukemia treatments. She will need round-the-clock care while fighting for this disease. She is in need of Type “O” blood until her immune system is strong enough for the next phase of recovery, which may take up to 5-6 months. Susan Flores is admitted at St. Luke’s Medical Center in Quezon City, Philippines.I have started this fund to help offset the financial burdens of being treated for this aggressive form of Leukemia. Her family needs your support. I cannot express how important this is. With these funds, she will be able to financially give to her family and friends, who are sacrificing their livelihoods to help and care for all her basic needs. The contributions you give will help pay the medical expenses while in the hospital. Witnessing her journey throughout these years has been nothing but miraculous. She had defeated cancer once before and was on her way to significant life changing accomplishments. Since battling this horrific and challenging disease, she has had to step back and humble herself by asking for any help. She is getting physically weaker and currently undergoes blood and platelet transfusions weekly. Susan’s driving force through this ordeal is her 3 children, husband, and sisters and are the backbone of organizing all the efforts towards her recovery. Her family will need OUR support through this time while continuing to taking care of normal life’s expenses. Together we can help so she will have a better chance of fighting this dreadful disease without the additional worries of daily life, but to focus on the hard and winding road before her.....We sincerely thank those who are helping support Susan Flores through this journey, financially and spiritually.

name: Help Support Mr. Minutoli's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Mr. Minutoli, who has been a P.E. teacher at Spring Hill Elementary for over 15 years, was recently diagnosed with an aggressive form of leukemia.  He and Mrs. Minutoli will be traveling to New York where they will be staying for 5 months as he undergoes bone marrow transplant treatment at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. The Minutoli family appreciates all of the prayers and good wishes that have already been pouring in from the Spring Hill community.  At this difficult time, they are in need of financial assistance as they face mounting costs related to the cancer treatment, lost wages, travel, temporary housing, special dietary items, meals, and other living expenses.  If you are able to help out, any amount would be greatly appreciated.Please share this message with any past or present Spring Hill families and friends. Your prayers and support are greatly appreciated by the Minutoli family.Sincerely,Pamela Fox & Tammy ThornsburySpring Hill Cares

name: Save 7-year old Sriyam suffering from leukemia
text: It is with a heavy heart that I write this message.  Our beloved Sriyam (son of Srujan & Shanti Sriadibhatla) has just been diagnosed with a very aggressive form of leukemia (B acute lymphoblastic leukemia).  Srujan planned to go back to India as his work permit was getting over. He is not able to work legally and is on leave without pay. One week before his planned travel to India, his son Shriyam was diagnosed with leukemia. He must undergo extensive therapy. He is currently undergoing treatment at St Mary's Children's Hospital in West Palm Beach.His white blood cells count is very low and needs blood transfusion twice a week so far. Chemotherapy treatment every Thursday. In case of any infections, he has to be rushed emergency in 1 hour. All funds raised will go toward his medical bills and living expenses. Please help us reach our goal.  Most importantly, please don't forget to pray for him.  God Bless!Thank you,Veda Rai & Friends

name: James' Fight Against Leukemia
text: One week before his 21st birthday, James Le was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. This aggressive form of cancer starts in the bone marrow and quickly spreads into the blood. Since his diagnosis, James has been admitted to St. Luke's Hospital in the Texas Medical Center, where doctors and nurses have been working non-stop to fight this cancer.  This GoFundMe was set up to help the family deal with the overwhelming costs associated with James's care and treatment. Your donation, whatever it may be, will help us give James a fighting chance at beating Leukemia!  Besides being a Junior at the University of Houston (Go Coogs!), James also frequently volunteers at the Tinh Luat Buddhist Temple and in the Houston Vietnamese community. He also has a passion for fashion, design, basketball, and shoes. Our hope is to be able to treat James as quickly as possible and back home with his family and community.   Thank you for your consideration!

name: Paul's Brawl with Leukemia
text: My friend Paul Parfitt, husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, neighbor, marine, was on October 25, 2018 diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukaemia. In 2017 Paul was downsized out of his position and had been in process of starting a new business when diagnosed.  He has continued to provide for his family  paying household expenses as well as medical insurance costs & his daughter's nursing school tuition. The chemotherapy's side effects have caused serious complications and taken a toll on Paul's heart & lungs. Which has greatly increased his need for medical care and delayed his cancer treatment. Paul and his family are in for a long haul in getting him healthy again and they need our love & support every step of the way. Despite these financial challenges as well as the physical, mental, and emotional toll chemotherapy takes Paul has been a true inspiration. His smile greats every visitor and member of the fantastic medical team working to cure him.  His positive attidude bouyes the hospital staff and  his floormates.Paul is a selfless man who has helped countless friends, neighbors, acquaintances, and even strangers. But now he is in need of OUR help. Please find it in your hearts to help Paul and his family offset the mountain of medical expenses he and his family are facing.Paul's chemotherapy will be followed by bone marrow transplant as soon as a donor is located.Paul will be on the hospital for 6 more weeks during the transplant and will return to the hospital for regular treatment and management of his complications for approximately 12 months.He will not be able to return to work until he has significant recovery from his symptoms.Paul's wife Tracy and their children, along with out patient nursing staff, will continue to be his caregivers at home between hospital stays. THANK YOU.

name: Manuel's Fight Against Leukemia
text: As most are aware, Meme was recently diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Philadelphia Positive. He is currently receiving treatment in MD Anderson Cancer Center and it will be a while until he can pursue his career and make a living. For this reason, we have come together to create this GoFundMe to serve as aid during this difficult time, and the money raised will be used to cover medical and living expenses. We believe no contribution is too small and we thank you for all the gestures of love, support, and countless prayers.Como muchos de ustedes saben, Meme fue diagnosticado con Leucemia Linfoblastica Aguda Philadelphia Positivia. Actualmente esta recibiendo tratamiento en MD Anderson Cancer Center. Debido a su estado de salud,  aun no podra ejercer su carrera. Por esta razon, decidimos crear este GoFundMe, para que le sirva de ayuda durante estos momentos dificiles, el  dinero sera para cubrir gastos medicos, entre otras cosas, y depositado en la cuenta de Carolina Balderas. Queremos agradecerles por poner su granito de arena, por todas las muestras de carino, apoyo, y mas que nada por todas sus oraciones, muchas gracias!

name: Tina Martin's Leukemia Expense Fund
text:
My name is Lou Montgomery. I am Tina's nephew. I figured the best way I can help this situation, is to help lessen her financial burden, other than prayer of course.
As you may know, Tina has been diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). While I believe her prognosis remains good, she obviously cannot work while she is hospitalized in Ruby Memorial. Travel expenses and food for her husband Tom and son Trent are adding up very quickly. Tom has to travel back and forth to work and has been staying with Tina on the weekend. My goal is to help provide money so they can concentrate on healing during the rough chemo-therapy and recovery. 
The funds raised will be used for medical bills, food, travel and whatever else Tina, Tom and Trent need during the fight. They need the money now, so I hope you can find, even a dollar, to help out. 
The fact that perfect strangers often give money to different causes is not lost on me. I have contributed to things that don't have the levity of what I am asking you to do. Just know that my family and I will be forever grateful for your donation and prayers for Tina.

name: Ava Tunheim Battling Leukemia
text: Ava's story, as told by her father who was by her side throughout the whole thing.Ava started having headaches around Christmas, it was right after she got done with basketball.   Allison took her to her regular doctor on January 3.  The doctor stated it was probably just migraines and it will subside.  January 11, we went to a ice fishing tournament in Mobridge.  She had been saying when she stood up, she would feel dizzy but it went away in a minute or so; but sometimes I would look at her and she would look like she was in space.  So I asked if she was ok and she would say "yes".   The next day (the 12th) she felt pretty good and we caught a lot of fish but she still had the occasional headache.  The day of the tournament she felt ok in the morning but the afternoon her stomach started hurting.  I told her to tell me if we needed to go to the ER, so about midnight we went.  They convinced me that it was puberty and the gave her Prontonix so she could sleep better, which makes no sense to me.  When we got home Sunday, she felt pretty bad and I told Allison that something is going on.  She agreed, so she stayed home from work that Monday, Jan 15.  Ava wanted to wait for Allison to take her to the doctor because she thought it was a "girl thing".  The doctor was going to send her home once again, but my wife said "I would like a blood test done before we leave".  Once they came back, she had tested positive for mono and her white blood count was 40,000 (regular is 4-10,000).  They had sent a sample to Sioux Falls they were pretty sure it was leukemia.  They wanted to take her by ambulance and I said "what does it matter if she has leukemia, it isn't going to hurt her to ride with me", plus I didn't want to believe it, I was telling myself it was mono, which was the other possibility.  They agreed to let her ride with us there.   Once we got there they knew it was leukemia but they had to figure out what we were dealing with.  By the time we got her in her bed and situated she couldn't move her neck - all of the cancer cells were pushing up from her shoulders to her neck, which we didn't know that at that time.  That was January 16.  January 17 they did a spinal tap, gave her chemo in her spine and confirmed it was Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  Of course, we all fell apart.  So they gave her IV chemo that day and we had to wait to see what cancer markers she had been showing, that way they could treat for exactly what she had.  On the 23rd, they came and said we don't have great news, the markers they had found were the Philadelphia chromosome PH+.  We stayed in the hospital for two weeks, everything was doing what it was supposed to in the beginning.  Her body was producing 90% cancer cells and they got it down to 0 before we left.   Right now Ava has had her second outpatient chemo treatment and she had to get a blood transfusion to boost her hemoglobin and platelets.  Next Thursday (March 15), they will do a spinal tap to give her chemo in her spine again, but once they find out how the chemo has been working (which they find out through the spinal tap), that will determine the next month of treatments.

name: Justin Graham Leukemia Battle
text: Justin Graham is a beloved member of the Morehead community, a West Virginia State baseball player and a decorated  alum of Rowan County High School.  He is battling Acute Myeloid Leukemia and will be in U.K. hospital at least 4 weeks.

name: Megan Gifford's Leukemia Battle
text: On September 19th 2017 at 2 1/2 years old, Megan was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Type B at Arnold Palmer Hospital for Children. Megan loves her family and friends, hide and seek while peeking around each corner saying "boo", Disney and seeing all her favorite characters and her stuffed animal monkey, named monkey who is her rock through all this. Her parents, Stacy and Barry have yet to leave her side. Megan is resilient and won't let this slow her down. Show your support in any way you can, and with your help we can beat cancer!

name: Emmitts battle against Leukemia
text: As some of you my know my Nephew Emmitt was diagnosed with Leukemia on November 15, 2018. This was devastating news and the last thing anybody want to hear. Emmitt is such a bright and cheerful AMAZING little boy. Please help support his family during this time.

name: Emma Crawford Leukemia Fund
text: On Monday July 16th we learned that the daughter of Adrienne Crawford has leukemia. Adrienne is a part of the ACERTUS family at the Alpharetta Campus, and we wanted to throw a fundraiser event to help the family out financially and show our support. All donations will go directly to the family. All T-Shirt orders need to go through acertusgear.com .

name: ANDREW’S LEUKEMIA SMACKDOWN
text: On Thursday 8/2/18 early morning Andrew had a sharp pain in his leg and after visiting the doctor, he recommended that his parents take him for blood work. There is nothing worse than being told to go straight to the hospital as parents. After a battery of tests, they were told what no parent wants to hear: Andrew had been diagnosed with Pre-B ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia)Andrew’s Treatment starts Monday 8/6/18 and the road to recovery is going to be really tough for an almost 4 year old. However, the good news is that this is treatable and curable. Chemo will be Administered for 3 years.  It’s going to be a long road and recovery for such a vibrant little boy.  Andrew needs all of the prayers and strength behind him and his family to get through this difficult time.  April and Mich have a VERY strong kid.....He has a lot of heart and is very strong willed, he will tackle this Leukemia without a doubt. Lots of prayers, positive vibes and love to the whole family!!

name: Marie's Leukemia Fund
text: In July of 2018 Marie Moody was diagnosed with Leukemia. She was immediately admitted into the hospital and began treatment. It happened so fast and was completely unexpected.  As we begin 2019 Marie remains hospitalized fighting the effects of this life-changing event. She has a long, tough road to recovery ahead of her and will still need a bone marrow transplant. Marie continues to maintain a strong, positive attitude throughout this unthinkable ordeal.Let's come together in support of our friend in her time of need. All donations will be used to ease any financial stress that may arise during this difficult time so Marie can focus all her energy on beating this devastating disease. Any donation will be appreciated. Updates will be posted!Thank You!

name: Ella Simone is fighting Leukemia
text: Four-year-old Ella Simone Newman was diagnosed with leukemia on January 31 at Kaiser Medical Center in Oakland, California. What began with occasional nosebleeds and random bruising was found to be something much more serious.Ella’s treatment going forward will consist of 8 to 9 months of chemotherapy to be administered at home by her parents Rosie and Ari.Ella will not be able to attend school during her treatment since the chemotherapy will likely weaken her immune system. Should she develop a cold or slight fever, she would need to be rushed to be the hospital for immediate care. Sadly, this will also mean that she and her twin brother Desmond will need to be kept apart so that she doesn’t contract anything from him. We have set up this GoFundMe page to help give the family a little breathing room as they adjust to this stressful situation and to allow Rosie and Ari time to focus on Ella’s recovery.Ella’s two favorite things in the world are the movie Frozen and Desmond. They both have a brilliant sense of humor and are full of loving smiles. Anything and everything helps. Please don't hesitate to reach out and offer your support. Thank you!

name: Kianas Leukemia Recovery Fund
text: ￼￼￼*My Bestfriend Kiana Ashley Evans was diagnosed with leukemia in the summer of 2014. These past couple weeks have made me sad, kiana was put on a new medication which caused her intestines to swell, a blood clot in her thighs and now she's blind in both eyes. Kiana is currently in the hospital at MedStar Georgetown and I'm trying to raise pmoney for her. She does have insurance to cover the medical expenses. However Im trying to raise money for Kiana & her Moms needs such as Transportation, Medical Supply Needs/ Medication, Personal Items, Household Bills & more. Her mom recently went back to work but unfortunately due to Kiana's sickness she hasn't been able to work .*Update: ￼￼Kiana Is currently in the hospital & Needs All of Your Support. Unfortunately she's not getting better & will be having Home Hospice Care. At this time we're asking For All Donations, Small to Big to support my bestfriend . Kiana doesn't have Life Insurance so we need all the help we can get. Every Little Bit Counts.*On 04/02/17 at 5:30PM Kiana fight was now over, she's has now Moved On with the lord .

name: Ava Sophia Leukemia Warrior Fund
text: Ava has suffered a 5th Leukemic relapse.  Her leukemia is a beast and has spread to her bone marrow which is now 76% full of cancer. Ava needs all of the prayers we can give. In fact, Ava needs a miracle! I have had so many people reach out to me to ask how they can help. Well here is how! Let us help Melissa and Chuck and their family enjoy this holiday season with Ava without any financial worries. They are spending multiple days a week at Hopkins now. The gas, the food, the parking, special treats for Ava, etc. all add up so quickly. Also, the new year is about to begin which means a new deductible will have to be met. Finances are the last thing they should have to think about right now. If you would like, please make a donation to the family that will go directly to them to help with all of their needs and medical bills. Every little bit helps and no donation is too small! Please feel free to share as well. Thank you in advance for your love, your support, and most of all your prayers!

name: Help Ramses and His Family Fight His Leukemia
text: (DIRÍJASE AL FINAL PARA LEER EN ESPAÑOL)Ramses is a sweet, mild-mannered, and spiritually-minded, 13-yr old. His parents, Carlos and Ruby Muñoz, are hardworking and responsible people who have always provided for their family. It’s hard for them to admit they need this kind of help, but they need our help as they tenaciously fight for Ramses’s life. Please read on to learn about his fight and about how you can help out.￼￼Ramses (far right) with his family last year￼￼Last year in a congregation clean-upRamses’s SituationOn December 20, 2018, he was diagnosed with a deadly and rare blood cancer- Early T-Cell Precursor Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ETP ALL).  For a month after diagnosis, Ramses stayed in the hospital to receive chemo treatments followed by a second bone marrow biopsy. Unfortunately, the results of the biopsy revealed that the treatments had not reduced the Leukemia cells as expected. This means a new course of treatment – a more aggressive form of chemo and a transplant.  The rare nature of his Leukemia makes treatment difficult. In addition, the treatment and the disease itself bring on complications like low hemoglobin, which only makes the situation more dire.Pretty much every day since his diagnosis, Ramses has been hospitalized.  While Carlos continues to work, Ruby stays with Ramses 24/7 at the hospital.  This means she hasn’t been able to report to work this entire time. Carlos and their other two sons make the 40-mile, one-way drive to the hospital to provide support.  This is all very demanding on the whole family physically, mentally and financially.How You Can HelpFinancially- All of the funds raised will go towards medical bills, uncovered medical expenses- (such as supplements helping Ramses during chemo), family bills, and costs related to their needs while staying at the hospital. Ruby and Carlos will be the only ones authorized to withdraw any funds. ANY amount will help!   Recommendations- If you know anyone who has fought this disease or know any information about doctors who treat it, please email us that information.  Ruby and Carlos continue to search for the best treatment options possible. Getting the word out- Please share this link and Ramses’s story with others (ex. social media, email, fliers, word-of-mouth). This will allow others the opportunity to help out as well and will make this campaign more successful! Last, but most importantly, we ask that you, please, keep Ramses and his family in your prayers.  Psalms 46:1 says, “God is our refuge and strength, a help that is readily found in times of distress”.  We’re confident He will be refuge and strength to them throughout this fight!   Thank you in advance for your loving support!  -Natalie Crumpler (family friend)¡AYUDEMOS A RAMSÉS Y A SU FAMILIA A COMBATIR SU LEUCEMIA!Ramsés es un joven de 13 años con hermosas cualidades- amoroso y bien espiritual.  Sus padres, Carlos y Ruby Muñoz, son personas responsables que siempre han cuidado y provisto para su familia. Es difícil para ellos admitir/aceptar este tipo de ayuda, pero definitivamente necesitan nuestra ayuda mientras batallan tenazmente por la vida de Ramsés.  Por favor lea a continuación para aprender sobre su situación y como podemos ayudar.LA SITUACION DE RAMSÉSEl 20 de diciembre del 2018 a Ramsés se le diagnosticó un tipo de leucemia que es raro y bien difícil de tratar- en inglés esta se llama Early T-Cell Precursor Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ETP ALL).  Durante un mes después de su diagnostico, Ramsés estuvo hospitalizado recibiendo tratamientos de quimioterapia seguidos por una segunda biopsia de medula.  Lamentablemente, los resultados de la biopsia revelaron que el tratamiento no había reducido las células de leucemia suficientemente. Esto significa que un nuevo tratamiento es necesario.  Este consiste en una quimioterapia mas agresiva seguido por un trasplante.  Adicionalmente, tanto la leucemia en sí, como el tratamiento tienen efectos secundarios peligrosos como baja hemoglobina. Esto pone a Ramsés en mas peligro.   Prácticamente casi todos los días desde su diagnostico, Ramsés ha estado hospitalizado.  Mientras Carlos continua su trabajo seglar, Ruby se queda en el hospital con Ramsés día y noche.  Esto significa que ella no ha podido reportarse a su trabajo todo este tiempo.  Carlos y sus dos hijos viajan seguido unas 40 millas hasta el hospital para ayudar.  Todo esto exige mucho de la familia entera en sentido físico, emocional y financiero.COMO PODEMOS AYUDAREconómicamente- Todo fondo recibido será destinado a pagar cuentas medicas, gastos médicos no cubiertos por seguro medico (ej. suplementos que le ayudan a Ramsés a tolerar el quimio), cuentas del hogar, y gastos relacionados con su estadía en el hospital (gas, alimentos, etc). Ruby y Carlos son los únicos autorizados para sacar fondos de esta cuenta. ¡CUALQUIER cantidad puede ayudar y es apreciada!Recomendaciones- Si usted conoce a alguien que tiene experiencia con esta enfermedad o conoce de algún medico que atienda pacientes con la misma, por favor envíenos un mensaje.  Ruby y Carlos continúan buscando el mejor tratamiento para Ramsés. Anunciando esta campaña- Por favor comparta la historia de Ramsés con otros (ej. Anuncios impresos, correo electrónico, cuentas sociales como Facebook y WhatsApp, etc).  ¡Esto contribuirá al éxito de la campaña!Finalmente- pero lo mas importante- suplicamos que mantengan a Ramsés y su familia en sus oraciones.  Salmos 46:1 dice, “Dios es para nosotros un refugio y fuerza, una ayuda que puede hallarse prontamente durante angustias.” ¡Estamos seguros de que El será tal refugio y fuerza para ellos mientras luchan!¡Gracias por su atención y amorosa ayuda!

name: Help Support Ann Marie's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Ann Marie Clark, a successful interior designer currently working at Forward Design Build located in Ann Arbor, MI was recently diagnosed with an aggressive form of Leukemia (Philadelphia Chromosome Positive Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia).  She is currently being treated at the University of Michigan hospital and has already started treatment including IV chemotherapy along with a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor.   Even at this early stage of recovery, she has overcome major life-threatening obstacles including a serious fight with both sepsis and bacterial meningitis.  Her doctors have stated she will be unable to return to work during the 2019 year while she receives and recovers from comprehensive chemotherapy treatments, antibiotics, bio-therapy, and a bone marrow transplant.   They also predicted that she will be receiving treatments at the hospital for 2+ years.  The Clark family appreciates all of the prayers and good wishes that have already been pouring in from all of those who Ann Marie has touched.  At this very difficult time, Ann Marie and the Clark family is in need of financial assistance as they face mounting costs related to the cancer treatment, lost wages, traveling, changing housing accommodations, special dietary items, and other living expenses.  If you are able to help out, any amount would be greatly appreciated.Please share this message with your family and friends.  Your prayers and support are very much appreciated!Sincerely,The Clark Family

name: iyalee's fight against leukemia
text: On May 24th 2017 my 7 year old niece iyalee was diagnosed with leukemia this was very unexpected, and tragic. For anyone who has met iyalee or lee lee as our family calls her you know how beautiful, smart, sweet, spirited, and funny she is. She's an amazing daughter, big sister, niece, and cousin she loves Pokémon, littlest pet shop, watching YouTube videos and playing video games. Lee lee's leg had been hurting her for a little over a month now she was taken to the hospital where an x-ray was done and nothing was found she was sent home with crutches and a cast and was told to be brought back if the pain did not improve on May 20th she woke up crying in pain and couldn't move her leg and couldn't get up she was taken back to the hospital after hours of testing (x-rays, blood tests, mri's) where they found something and moved her to a hospital which specializes more in this area It was the morning after when the devastating news came that Iyalee had leukemia This GoFundMe was set up to help my sister's family deal with the overwhelming costs associated with iyalee's care and treatment No donation is too small, we will keep you updated as Iyalee beats this terrible disease. Please keep Iyalee and her family in your thoughts and prayers

name: Beating leukemia with Brendon
text: On August 29th Brendon was told that He was disgnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia. It was just a couple weeks before he was admitted to St. Louis University hospital to begin treatment including Chemotherapy. Bills have already started coming in, all while he has a 4month old son at home. His initial treatment is to last 4-6 weeks where he will be in the hospital and then they will know more about what will happen from there but overall it will be a 3 year process of outpatient treatment. Anything will help his little family at this time.

name: Help Sean Fight Leukemia!
text: On January 14th, 2019, following an urgent visit to the emergency room due to a consistent nose bleed and agonizing body pain, completely out of the blue - Sean Harvey was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). This GoFundMe page has been created to help support Sean and his family as they start this fight against this aggressive cancer of the blood and bone marrow.Since his diagnosis, Sean has been admitted to the Princess Margaret Cancer Centre in Toronto, where doctors and nurses have been working to develop a strategy to fight this horrible disease. Sean is one of the most vivacious, hilarious, strong, resilient, FUN, and full of life people that you will ever meet. He is one of those people that you want to be best friends with – or at least be close to as soon as you meet him.  Always there to pick you up when you are down, always the first to be on your side and make you feel special… this is why he is so loved by many.He was just starting a new chapter in his life when he received this diagnosis. He was only in his second week of classes in the Arboriculture program at Humber College when he started feeling excruciating pain in his body.  On the advice of his parents he went to Michael Garron Hospital. After an initial blood test, within 24 hours they sent Sean by ambulance to Princess Margaret Hospital because the results were Acute (ALL) Leukemia!!!Sean is very fortunate that he lives in Toronto and has the Princess Margaret Hospital to help determine his course of action/treatment.It is still early days but he now knows it will be at least a two year long and painful treatment plan to counter this disease.We want to help Sean and his family deal with the upcoming, unforeseen costs associated with his care and treatment. Sean had decided to change his career aspirations and had given up his job in order to go back to school. Because of this fantastic aspiration he does not have any medical insurance to aid him with his treatment. Canada does not cover prescriptions, rehabilitation or physical therapy, or every day costs of living. It is going to be a long, hard road to recovery.Please help us help Sean through this terrible, unforeseen ordeal. We will do our best to update everyone on Sean’s fight on this GoFundMe page. Thank you in advance for all of your love, kind words and generosity.

name: Aaron Kipfmiller Leukemia Fight
text:
Hello friends, family and individuals that we may not even know.   This is not something that comes easy to myself and or my husband. We have been very private about his cancer as a whole.  Trying to deal with his treatments, and the business by ourselves while battling this debilitating disease.  If there is anything that I am learning from this is that you can not do it all by yourself. Its not physically or mentally possible.  

Our friends suggested we start a gofundme page to help with our accumulating financial responsibilties during this difficult time.   This past spring my husband Aaron and I had decided to take our business to the next level by Aaron quitting his full time job to persue our dream of building Tiny Homes for others.  Our business was taking off and we were so excited to see it our efforts coming to life. 

Then on May 3, 2018 we went to the hospital for what we thought to be a stroke or other health issue due to Aaron not feeling well.  After a CT Scan we were told that he had a very large mass in his chest.   This mass was biopsied and on May 7, 2018, we were then admitted to U of M Hospital and Aaron was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive leukemia called Acute T-cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  

Aaron is fighting hard to beat this cancer but as of late all the chemotherapy and prescription are getting the best of him. He was just readmitted for a short time at U of M for a blood clot in his lung. He is suffering daily from nausea and dizzy spells.  It's hard to see your loved one who was once so strong be debilitated by this decease.  He is currently in round two of his treatment and we are starting the process of preparing for a bone marrow transplant. 

￼
The expenses are getting beyond our means and are asking for help to cover our transportation, living expenses, and general needs during this time. 



Please consider helping get word out about this huge financial need by posting this link on Facebook, etc:


Next

￼

name: Help Teodora Fight Leukemia!!!
text: Imagine you have a beautiful family and a happy life! And imagine you have a gorgeous and happy 9 year old daughter. One day she gets sick, doctors inform you that your little girl is seriously sick and that she has - Acute Myeloid Leukemia. How would you feel, what would you do... And that is exactly what happened to our little Teodora. By the April 2016, Teodora was a healthy child, who spent time playing with her school friends and her little brother Djordje. But slowly she start becoming too tired and the pain in her legs were enabling her to play or attend school. She began to fade, the disease was taking over…And then the first analysis were completed, it was Acute Myeloid Leukemia. AML is a cancer of the myeloid line of blood cells, characterized by the rapid growth of abnormal white blood cells that build up in the bone marrow and interfere with the production of normal blood cells. Since May 2016, Teodora`s parents and doctors at the Institute "Dr Vukan Cupic" in Belgrade began the relentless battle for Teodora`s life. She is just a little girl with the severe disease that has undergone exhausting aggressive therapy - five cycles of chemotherapy, where many complications prevented the desired results.This type of cancer is difficult to cure and the only way Teodora could be saved is a Bone Marrow Transplantation. The only hospital that can complete this procedure, to replace damaged or destroyed bone marrow with healthy bone marrow stem cells is the Children’s Hospital in Frankfurt, Germany. The cost for this procedure is 350,000 euros.Teodora`s dad, Bogdan, says: "My wife and I work in the media and we wouldn`t be able to earn this amount of money if we were to live our three lives! That much money, we simply don`t have, not even close to that. But we have no rights to give up the fight for the life of our Teodora, as she struggles to win this battle like the greatest warrior. The boundless love for our child we have, as any other parent in this world, gives us the strength to push, hope and believe that with the help of good people, institutions, agencies, companies - we will be able to collect the necessary 350,000 euros” Teodora`s situation is getting worse every day. To save her life we must raise funds in the next 10 days!THANK YOU FOR DONATING as much or as little as you can! Every donation counts and Teodora will be thankful to you until the rest of her long and happy life:) THANK YOU FOR SHARING this campaign with your friends, colleagues, family and network around the world!To save her life we must raise funds in the next 10 days! Help Teodora win this battle!!!

name: Team DiPippo ❤️ Kick Leukemia’s Butt
text: ❤️ ‘‘Tis the season for giving! And as we approach this holiday season I would like to ask that everyone who has their health & a wonderful holiday season to look forward to take a moment to read my story well rather my friend Debbie’s story.  I first met Debbie in 2000 when I was hired by Novartis pharmaceuticals.  We quickly became friends which has turned into more like family over the last 20 years.  Debbie was a young widow & raising 2 small kids......  Jake & Brooke by herself.  Debbie is one of the most loving, caring, honest and best people I have ever been privelged to know.  Well Jake & Brooke are grown now, Debbie has since left pharmaceuticals & moved to Florida.  My friend Debbie loves angels, has a strong faith in God & would do anything for anyone if asked .... Debbie has come across some very scary health concerns after having her blood work done with some pretty severe bruising & fatigue.  Debbie is with her daughter Brooke in a hospital trying to figure out what is next now that she has been diagnosed with leukemia❤️ I am asking any & all of my family & friends as well as Brooke’s & Debbie’s to help me raise some money to help the burden of hospital costs over these next few weeks that Debbie will NOT be able to work ~ she is in retail now and clearly can’t work for th next few weeks as treatment begins..... I’m asking that u donate whatever is on your heart to help my dear friend Debbie out at her time in need... Debbie has done it all by herself without ever asking anyone for anything even while raising 2 small kids on her own ..... help  me make this season for Debbie a true blessing of giving I will match up to $2500.00  ❤️  Thank you all for reading this & hopefully you will find it in your hearts to help my good friend out ... skip that latte $5.00 or maybe that nail appointment and show me some LOVE ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️ Thank you all again ............ Dipippo ~ Jake ~ Brooke ........ you are not alone in this ... we got this

name: Dakota's Fight Against Leukemia-ALL
text: This November, the day after Dakota turned 16 months old, we headed to our Pediatrician for the third time in three weeks because he began to rapidly look and feel very unwell. In just a matter of weeks our sweet, energetic, smiley young baby boy could barely walk or sit up for very long and had begun to look very sick and very sad. Our daughter Zoe, age 3, didn’t understand why her brother wouldn’t play anymore.We were immediately being sent to the local ER for testing. They said something was very wrong with his blood, his hemoglobin was 2.5, the doctor said he had never seen any person that low, he was barely alive. He began transfusions immediately while waiting for transport to the nearest children’s hospital and a hematologist/oncologist who would meet us in the Pediatric ICU where Dakota would have to remain until stable.We were transferred to the PICU at Palm Beach Children’s Hospital where we remained for 4 days. By the end of our stay in PICU, he had received 6 blood transfusions, 2 platelet transfusions, had a bone marrow biopsy, 2 lumbar punctures and a port had to be surgically implanted in chest wall. Dakota was diagnosed that Thursday with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).  They said his bone marrow was 75% leukemia cells and that the pressure they cause on his bones from the inside out meant our little boy had been in unbearable pain.  He began receiving chemo and we remained in the hospital for the next two weeks.Our Doctors have told us that his treatment will be at least a three year full time treatment plan that will include chemotherapy at home and in clinic, inpatient hospital stays and a lot of changes to our home and to Dakota and our family’s every day lives.  While we are hoping that our  insurance will cover a good portion of Dakota’s medical expenses, the reality is we aren't sure how much will be covered and the bills are already starting to pile up less than a month into his treatment.  There are other uncovered costs like his daily medications, special dietary changes, and changes we have to make in our home during his three year long treatment.  As his main care provider I will also not be able to return to work. We love our son very much and just want him to get better and will do whatever it takes to make that happen. Please know that any amount given to help us with Dakota’s battle with Leukemia will be greatly appreciated. We will try to update you guys throughout his journey, please keep Dakota, his sister Zoe and our family in your thoughts and prayers.Love,The Cappel Family(Jennifer, Kyle, Zoe & Dakota)

name: My Fight with Leukemia & Healing  Journey to Ghana
text: Please Help me win this fight with Leukemia Or CLL . I am currently a patient at Methodist Hospital Sugarland Texas and I’m in need of financial assistance to help eliminate some of  the financial stress that comes  with an epic fight for my life & longevity. Im 68 years old and I’m in need of about  2000 generous People to donate $20.00 each or what ever you can afford to reach my goal    Of $40.000 . There is no price for the precious gift of Life. This is not easy for me to do I have work and maintain my professional life as a Sabaean Health Activist & Chef for the last 40 years . Life is unpredictable, I just retired last year after working for the last 12 years as a manager/chef  at the HEB Lake Colony Store Cooking Connection. and I’m living on a fixed income. And now I’m in a fight with Leukemia or CLL . Going public was very difficult for me to do . I have maintain CLL in Secret I kept it all to myself for 4 or 5 years . Now I asking your financial help because I can no longer fight alone. A Thousand Thanks To All My great Doctors . My courageous global fight will take me from The USA  Back to My Ancestral Homeland Mama Africa  Ghana West Africa  to continue a combination of  conventional Medication and Natural holistic lifestyle environment, for self healing would help to increase my life and longevity. My holistic lifestyle and treatment will last for six months or longer  at The One Africa Guest House  and Holistic Resort  On the Gulf Of Guinea   Ghana West Africa . They make you feel whole again. Just imagine a clay body rub on the beach on the Gulf of Guinea, baked lovingly in the sun before floating in a warm sea salt sauna with the soothing roar of the ocean in your ears for some time and then returned to your mat and oiled down in Shea butter. Oh my Goddess . . . What a treat which can't be beat anywhere except at One Africa Health Resort. Come and let us pamper you. Come and become a brand new you. Much Love & Respect, Mama IMAHKÜS (One Africa)

name: Team Jared's Leukemia Fund
text: Our cousin, Jared Chitwood, has recently been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  Jared is 15 years old and will be a sophomore in high school in Richmond, Kentucky.  We have come together to create this GoFundMe to raise money to help our Aunt Kim, Uncle Todd, and cousins Justin and Brandon during this extremely challenging time. The money raised will be used in any way the family sees best fit, whether it be medical expenses, living expenses, or donation to research or cancer related charities.
