Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow that causes the bone marrow to create too many immature lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell.  In a healthy child, the bone marrow creates immature cells (blood stem cells) that mature over time and can become one of two types of mature cell.  The first is a myeloid cell: red blood cells, platelets, or white blood cells, or the second is a lymphoid stem cell: natural killer cells, or lymphocytes that help fight infection.  As a child with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, Jared’s body is producing too many stem cells that become lymphoblasts and lymphocytes but they do not work like normal cells as they struggle to fight infection.  These cells are called leukemia cells.  As the leukemia cells increase in the blood and bone marrow, there is less room available for healthy white blood cells, platelets and red blood cells resulting in increases chance of infection (National Cancer Institute, 2017). Jared will be enduring a three year long treatment at the University of Kentucky Medical Center, with the most intense treatment occurring during the first 6 months. The chemotherapy and other medications he will endure are going to make him an extremely sick kid. But in the long run will help his body fight this cancer and get back to living his normal life that every child deserves! We will be standing behind Jared and our family throughout this entire process, as we are sure so many of you will be too. We hope that you will consider donating to help an amazing boy and an even more amazing family during this challenging time.  No donation is too small and we are extremely grateful for your support during this time. We have faith in God that Jared will be cancer free again!-Nathan, Lauren, Brian, Emily, Ashley, and Molly

name: Cam and his Army Fight Leukemia
text: For those of you who do not know, Cam Barnard, son of Patrick and Christy Barnard and Carlee Roy, was diagnosed with Leukemia on September 17th, 2018. Cam is 8 years old and in the 3rd grade and such a wonderful kid! As Cam and his family begin to fight this uphill battle, we have decided to rally the troops together and help them out! To ease the burden of the upcoming medical expenses, our army is ready to fight and contribute in any way possible. We can’t imagine what they must be going through and we are here to ask for help! Any and all donations will go directly to the family for payment of medical expenses. This will be the start to help cover as much additional expense as we can, so the family can focus on Cam and his treatment. The family thanks everyone for their support thus far and it is only just beginning! So, Please put your gear on and help this fight by donating now and sharing the link!

name: Tua's Leukemia Recovery Fund
text: Tua has been diagnosed with T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. This is a severe form of Leukemia, but we will remain hopeful for Tua as there are so many unknown factors at this point. This go fund me is being set up as a buffer to help with as many costs as we can. The price for treatment is unknown right now so the goal for this go fund me may change. But Tua's apartment and cats will need to be taken care of on top of other typical costs of living while he is in the hospital. I will update this page as soon I hear anything. For now send prayers, blessings and love to Tua. Thank you all so much for your support.

name: Help Matt Aiello during his battle with leukemia
text: As some of you might know Matt was just hit with a devastating diagnosis of Leukemia. At 32, Matt is in the prime of his life with his 2 young children, Abigail and Nathan and his wife, Cheryl. This is not news you expect! But Matt is taking it all in stride and is ready for the fight! The plan is to be very aggressive with treatment which means Matt has to do it as an inpatient.  Due to this, Matt will be unable to work and Cheryl will have to take time off from work as well for support.   As you can imagine this is a very stressful thing for a young family to go through.  We are trying to raise money to help get them through the next few months without the stress of how they are going to pay their mortgage, insurance, etc.  We want all of Matt’s focus to be on kicking cancer, not on how they are going to get by while he is out of work. Matt is starting treatment this week so the need is urgent!

name: April's Fight Againts Leukemia
text:
April has been a true fighter for the past year and a Half! She is one of four siblings, a sweet 12 years old girl. 


Last year on Memorial day she became ill and was taken to OU Children’s Hospital. At that moment her parents thought it was only a bad case of fever. The doctors came back with test result showing she had Leukemia. April has been through chemotherapy and bone marrow transplant spending months in the hospital. Unfortunately her health had a major setback the past few months. Her parents have done as much as transferring her from Oklahoma to Tennessee, and contacting St. Jude Hospital in Texas for a second opinion. Because of her condition Guinther, her dad, has put work aside to be with her during what seems to be the last moments of her life. Raquel, her mom has stayed strong at their side while taking care of Jeremy, Jonny and Audrey. This family is in dire need of help. 


Lates Update: Today Sep 2nd 2017, April has became another of God's angels. This campaign is still open and any future donations will be used for her funeral service this week. I will share date, time and place of service as soon as one is set. You are welcome to come support her family during difficult time.




Thank you for your donations!!

name: Angelica's battle against Acute Myeloid Leukemia
text: Nine year old Angelica Nicholas has been diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a rare form of cancer which progresses rapidly. She is presently in the care of The Children's Hospital at Albany Med. She will be undergoing an aggressive treatment plan, requiring six months of intense chemo therapy, a potential bone marrow transplant and extensive follow up visits. Angelica's Hematologist/Oncologist is very optimistic about her ability to survive this battle.Angelica will require her parents unwavering emotional support and love. Her parents are humble working class folks in need of assistance with her medical/logistical expenses and loss of income. I'm sure you can understand how the sudden nature of this progressive cancer demands immediate social outreach. Angelica has three sisters (Jasmine 13, Sophia 7,  and Genevieve 2) and each consider her their best friend in the world.  She's also beloved by her classmates and faculty at The Big Cross School.  She loves attending the Glens Falls Summer Camp and swimming in her Papa's pool. She has an inquisitive mind and aspires to be a professional writer/artist in the future.  Most of all she loves life, and she wants to be a part of other's lives. "We were completely blindsided by this." Her parents (George and Tanya Nicholas) are absolutely devastated right now as you can imagine.  They will need all the prayers and support you can muster.  Please anything helps.  A nickel;  a dime;  a prayer;  a social media share,  whatever you can afford will go a long way to help with the cost of battling Angelica's leukemia over the next six months.  Please keep in mind something as simple as a share on all of your social media platforms can be instrumental in helping Angelica and her family.  With your support they can focus on Angelica and the other children  and not worry how they will make ends meet.  I humbly ask for your support in my adorable little cousin Angelica's time of need.You may corroborate this account by visiting her father George Nicholas here facebook page,  in casethe  link does not work at this time copy/paste this link : https://www.facebook.com/UberGeorge?__tn__=%2CdlC-R-R&eid=ARA7aofBdF4UEhqFdGhJgx9r4R2cRQa1Vws60HLtm0dLyBitd4AAKS0L-MMqrtJf2dMFSe1hIh2HtQAz&hc_ref=ARSoaa6K31WHtun7NEi1szL27clZSN4By2ANeGmyhvn7cytslf2R_3qtpT4bLsBVe9M   Or his wife Tatyana Nicholas here , again you may copy/paste the link provided here:  https://www.facebook.com/tatyana.nicholas.3You may also send checks directly to the non profit P.O. box atAngelicas Hope Inc.  P.O. Box #4181 Queensbury NY12801EIN # 83-3275682

name: Madi's Fight against Leukemia
text: Over the past two weeks, my cousin Ashley Jewett and her ex Chris Hanson had their world turned upside down.  After much consideration and prayer about how best we can help her,  Ashley's sister Whitney Jewett and I have decided to launch a Go Fund Me account.Ashley is a single mom with two beautiful children, Madison age five and Preston age three.  Two weeks ago Madi was admitted to Phoenix Children's Hospital for an undiagnosed condition affecting her immune system.  After ten days in the hospital, Madi was released pending confirmation of test results. On Monday, October 29th, Madi’s 5th birthday, Ashley received the call from the doctors confirming what she feared most.  Madison’s second bone marrow biopsy was positive for Leukemia.The type of cancer Madi has is called Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).  It's an aggressive blood cancer. It is fast spreading and represents about twenty percent of all childhood forms of leukemia.  Madi's doctors have told Ashley and Chris that the five year prognosis is 50/50. A few children do not survive the treatment because of how stressful it is on their cardiovascular system and immune system.   They are asking for your thoughts and your prayers. Please do not feel sorry for them. Feel positive and optimistic that Madi makes it through this with as little difficulty as possible. Hug your kids, go donate blood, be kind to strangers in Madi’s honor.  Live your life fully and know in your hearts that Madi will be a part of our lives for a long time to come! Family and Friends, It is time to rally for Madi and Ashley!Ashley will be unable to work full time in her profession as a realtor because Madi's treatment requires that she be hospitalized for the better part of six to nine months.  Ashley will be in the hospital right beside her. Madi's doctors have said she can expect a short break away from the hospital every couple months but during these breaks, she will need to limit her exposure to other people including family members.  Madison will be severely neutropenic as a result of her extremely compromised immune system.   As Ashely and her  family live approximately 35 miles away from the hospital, Ashley will rent an apartment next to the hospital.   This will serve as a safe home space for Madi during her short breaks from treatment as well as respite for Ashley when she gets a break from fighting alongside Madi.  While we hope that most of the medical expenses will be covered by insurance, any procedures that are not covered will translate into greater financial burden since Ashely will be unable to work during Madi's treatment.   Our wish is to ease that hardship with any donations that we receive so that Ashley  may focus all of her energy and spirit towards Madi's healing.  We are dedicating this page to fund ongoing medical costs and everyday expenses for Madi’s treatment.  We are grateful for each contribution, as this page is not solely intended for financial reasons, but also to serve as support for Ashley and Chris while they navigate this difficult life challenge.  Share your stories of hope and words of encouragement as often as you feel moved to do so! Please continue to keep Madi and family in your prayers. Isaiah 41:10So do not fear, for I am with you;  do not be dismayed, for I am your God.I will strengthen you and help you; I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.

name: Christian's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Hello friends and family. Something that no mother, father, grandmother, aunt or family member ever wants to hear about a precious loved one is that they have been diagnosed with cancer. Yesterday we got the dreadful news that our precious little baby boy of our family, my 6 yr old grandson, has been diagnosed with Leukemia. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. While away on vacation visiting his grandmother in Minnesota he became ill and was taken to the emergency room. At first they thought it was his kidneys or liver and then found the swollen lymph nodes under his arms and thought it may be Leukemia. They ran bloodwork and his hemoglobin level was at an alarming 4 which is near fatal levels and they immediately transported him to children's hospital Minneapolis and began transfusions and confirmed in fact that it was Leukemia. Our family is devastated and I cannot begin to fathom how my daughter and Christian's father are feeling at this time. Our hearts break for them and for little Christian and the road that they are going to have before them in battling this cancer. I am asking that anyone and everyone please pray for my family and if you feel it upon your heart to donate to help the family pay for some of the costs that will be incurred and the loss of income that will happen because of the time needed for them to spend with their son, please donate. Any bit helps and you will be greatly appreciated. I know that I have amazing friends and family that at the least will be praying and offering well wishes and for that we are so very thankful. I love you all and pray that Gods will be done. Thank you so much.

name: Shelby's Fight Against Leukemia
text: On Sunday, November 5th 2017 the amazing Lane family received the shocking news that Shelby had been diagnosed with Leukemia. We know that she will be receiving intense medical treatment over the coming months and will be unable to work. Please contribute monetarily what you can to help this amazing family. We all love them and even the smallest amount will offset the financial struggle this will cause. Let's go above and beyond to blow this goal out of the water! You know the impact they have had on you and your life. Goodness deserves goodness. And please include them in your prayers. Added 11/8/17: We have decided to increase our goal amount due to the possible length of treatment needed and additional loss of income. Thank you for your support! #welovethelanes

name: Karina Graham's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Karina Graham is a loving wife and the mother of three beautiful children. She was recently diagnosed with Acute Leukemia.  She has been receiving treatment at Northside Hospital in Atlanta since February 6th but recently found out her insurance isn't accepted by the Hospital. She has since switched providers but the new coverage doesn't begin until the 1st of March. This means she will be absorbing the costs for the first month of cancer treatment which is likely going to be substantial. The overall cost is unknown but given the biopsies, drugs, pathology, chemotherapy,  and overnight stays, it could easily surpass $500,000 in just a few weeks.  Karina works as a Realtor with her husband Kevin who is now tasked with taking care of the kids and working as much as he can to support the family himself.  I have known Karina for only one year but already know she is a wonderful giving person who has had a positive effect on the lives of many others. I know from experience that suffering from Leukemia is a monumental challenge for any family. She will be bedridden for many months and likely unable to work for the rest of the year.This fund is being set up to help her family manage the financial costs it will be faced with once she overcomes this terrible disease.  If you or anyone you know has been blessed by knowing someone like Karina, please donate what you can and let's send Karina a message of appreciation and let her know that we all love her and appreciate the sweet spirit that she truly is. And if you or anyone you know is looking to buy or sell a home, referring Karina or her husband Kevin would also greatly benefit the family in this crucial time of need.Thank You!

name: Alex's Leukemia Fund
text: I'm Colin.  You may know me... you may not.  That really isn't very important.  What is important is the following information:My 5 year old daughter, Alex, was recently diagnosed with 'B cell Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia'.Most of the time it feels like I can't breathe... and it's scary, and I feel helpless.  It's horrible to watch as someone who is so special, and smart, and beautiful, and strong go through something that causes such fear, devistation, and pain. Whats worse is that my younger brother just spent the last 8 months battling T-Cell Leukemia and I have witnessed first hand the horrors that this devastating cancer and also treatment can do to destroy her little body. What's worse is that my brother just went through the same thing, only with T-Cell... which is even .The reality that my daughter is going to have to fight through the same treatment that nearly destroyed my brother is staggering...  The reality that she might understand that the same journey lies ahead for her is devastating.My wife and I don't know what financial struggles lie ahead, but we know that we probably don't have what it takes.  I work a full time job, my wife is almost 7 months pregnant (which brings it's own set of challenges), we have amazing families who will be as supportive as possible, but at the end of the day things are going to be hard.  People burn out... bills don't pay themselves... relations strain... and I just want my baby to live.  Not just to be alive... but to really live.We have done our best to estimate what it is going to cost, daily, for the basic necesseties involved alongside her hospital care.  Some of these expenses include- Meals (we hope to tailor Alex's diet to be supportive of many of the vitamins and minerals that the chemotherapy will strip from her body)- Extra travel expenses such as gasoline for the multiple trips to and from the hospital- Vitamin supplements, again to replenish some of the necessary components to withstand both the cancer, and the chemo- Miscellaneous expenses such as pajamas & socks to keep Alex comfortable while spending an initial 4 weeks in the hospital.  Coloring books, school workbooks/activity workbooks, crayons, soap, toiletries, laundry detergent, etc.I'm not someone who is ever eager to accept help from others.  Growing up with little of anything rooted a deep desire in me to become sucessfully self sufficient.  I have worked long and hard to get to a point in life where I could finally provide for my family without needing help from anyone else, and it's not easy to admit that I can no longer do that.My struggle is not yours.  You owe me nothing, nor do I you... but if you have the desire to help another person, my daughter is in need.  She is innocent and kind, and so special... and she has life to live.If you decide to give toward her livelihood, we would be grateful forever.  ...Like I said before; we want our baby to live.

name: Grandma Marshas fight with Leukemia
text: Our amazing mother Marsha Larsen was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia on 4/11/2018. She has 5 kids, and 12 grandchildren who she adores more than anything else in her life. Anyone who knows Marsha knows that she would sacrifice her own well being for that of any of her grandchildren. At this time, she is the one who is need of the sacrifice and love of others, as she faces an uphill battle with Leukemia and that begins tomorrow with 4 weeks of aggressive inpatient chemotherapy in Salt Lake LDS Hospital. Because of her ongoing treatments and the uncertainty of how long this battle will last, her doctors aren't sure when she will be healthy enough to return to work. Anyone who who knows Marsha, knows how much she loves working at her job at Sky View High School. And if there is anything she loves ALMOST as much as her family, it is her friends, co-workers, current students and past students.....and Diet Coke :)She is on a single income, and now facing a mountain of  bills. Without her income from the school district she needs all the help she can get to survive. PLEASE Help support our amazing mom and grandma, Grandma Marsha!!One thing is for sure, cancer picked on the wrong lady. Our mom is not only going to beat this but she is going to KICK its butt!!! Thank you for all the support #Pray for Marsha#Marshastrong#Grandma Marsha > Leukemia

name: LITTLE ANGEL WITH TERMINAL LEUKEMIA
text: This little Angel JASMINE MEDELLIN who is dying from cancer. Her family is very poor and They need our support. She’s only 19 and has been fighting with multiple medical problems through out her life. Unfortunately three weeks ago she got diagnosed with a severe form of leukemia and she only has a few days to live. Her family does not have a lot of resources and they need our help. They even don’t have money to pay for her funeral. They are having a hard time emotionally and financially. This is our chance to help a family in need and show them some compassion and support.Please help us with this humble cause.

name: Help Antonella Survive Leukemia
text: Please help us to save Antonella!We need to raise $7,000 by June 10th to take her to Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami#HelpAntonellaSurviveCancerAntonella, is a 3 years old Venezuelan girl, suffering Leukemia. She is the only daughter of one my closest friends Antonio y Zeudy. Less than a week ago she was diagnosed with cancer.She was born on 2013 perfectly healthy and enjoyed a life full of love and support, surrounded by her parents and family. But a few days ago she started feeling weaker and weaker, she developed an ear infection, reason why her parents took some tests and realized something was wrong.Antonella and her parents lives in Caracas, where healthcare is in a precarious condition. Public hospitals lack the essential materials to assist their patients, basics such as oxygen, gauze or alcohol are not available. Clean and sterilized spaces to treat patients are not part of their priorities. Private hospitals are very expensive for regular Venezuelan families, where average monthly income is less than a 1% of what they need to pay for the first phase of Antonella’s treatment. Medicine status is dramatic, nowdays we cannot find meds at pharmacies as the rest of the world do, we spread the word out and wait for a caring soul who have that medicine and is willing to give it to us, or we need to know someone with health connexion who might help. Is not easy at all.Our first goal is to deliver the first phase of quimio in Caracas, and strengthen her body to take her to Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami where she will receive all the medical attention she needs. Antonio and Zeudy, are trying to find support from Ronald McDonald House Charity to pay for the treatment needed.We are running out of precious time with this child, after the first phase in Caracas she needs to go to Miami to continue with her treatment. This will obviously cost a ridiculous amount of money, money we unfortunately don't have enough. Just for the first quimio phase here in Caracas we need to raise $4,000 to be paid by June 8th on top of that the flights and living cost for three months in Miami, for one of her parents and her is an additional $3,000.Every day count, every single penny is worthy! We need to give her an opportunity to live. We cannot just let Antonella die when there is something that might help her. She deserve a chance and she deserve a life as much as anyone else.If Antonella receives this treatment and it does work, she will return to the happy life she had, full of health, smiles, joy, experiences and life.

name: Tony White - Leukemia Fund
text: My name is Tony White, and I was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia M5 in September 2018.  The only risk factor I had was exposure to benzene and radiation at work.  I played basketball for UT from 1983-1987.  The leukemia completely changed my life, and I have not been able to work since my diagnosis.  I had two rounds of 30-day inpatient chemo, which put my cancer in remission, but my doctor says that the type of cancer I have will evolve and come back stronger if I only continue to take maintenance chemo, and ultimately take my life from me unless I have a bone marrow transplant.  I have already been to Nashville for preliminary testing.  I will have chemo again soon, and then in 4-6 weeks the bone marrow transplant.  Anything you can donate to help me would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you, and may Christ bless you!

name: Save a Life: Cure for Artem Mahno from Leukemia
text: Hello friends!My name is Artem, and I am 19 month old. I was diagnosed with Inborn Acute Lymphatic Leukemia. I want to live and I fight for my life very hard. Treatment in Ukraine had failed. At the moment my parents are searching for help from clinics abroad but the amount of money needed is enormous! To start we need about $50,000 for the tests and to put my condition into remission. I can't make it myself and asking for your kindness and help. If you want to donate any amount to give a chance to win this battle, you will find all information on this page or ask admin for assistance.Історія наша розпочалась з того, коли 9.03.2018р ми приїхали до лікарні ДМКЛ та Артемчика поклали до реанімації. Він був в тяжкому стані. На той момент було 99% ракових клітин в його крові... Було тяжко, страшно. Була паніка. Коли нам оголосили діагноз: "Вроджений Гострий Лімфобластний Лейкоз", світ рухнув з під ніг. Ми не знали що робити. Лікарі хорошого нічого не говорили. Але його витягли з реанімації та перевели до онкогематологічного відділення, де ми пролікувалися 4,5 місяці. За цей час ми пройшли Protokoll l, блок HR3, на фоні якого стався РЕЦИДИВ. Страшне слово... З 6,7% бластні клітини зросли до 72%. Реанжировка МLL гена в 80% нуклеїнових клітин. В Києві ми були 3 місяці, де пройшли блоки R2, R1 (Protokoll ALL-REZ BFM 2002); інтенсифікація терапії, блок MARMA ( Protokoll Interfant 2006). Після всього нас Київ направив на Полтаву на відновлення, обіцяючи взяти назад після результатів пункції. Та результати виявились невтішними. Київ вирішив, що ми безнадійні та відправив нас на паліативну хіміотерапію... Це означає, що поки Артем буде отримувати хімію, здержуються ракові клітини. Але наступає такий момент, що організм перестає реагувати на хімію, і все... Дитина помирає від раку. Дуже боляче. Я не можу передати, що коїться в мене в душі... Це жах... Знати, що твоя дитина невиліковно хвора і що в Україні ніхто її не вилікує. Є шанс тільки за кордоном. І, як не жахливо звучить, шанси мінімальні. Але поки є хоч один шанс, ми будемо боротися. Зараз для нас ціль - це РЕМІСІЯ. Вона необхідна для того, щоб зробити ТРАНСПЛАНТАЦІЮ КІСТКОВОГО МОЗКУ. Лікарня в Ізраїлі погодилась нас прийняти, на новітне лікування але воно дуже дороге. Рахунок на лікування ьа ткм біля 300 000$. В нас немає таких захмарних коштів. Тому звертаємося до всіх. ДОПОМОЖІТЬ ВРЯТУВАТИ СИНА!!! Ми не здамося!!! Ми обов'язково одужаємо!!!

name: Zach Hare 16 Year Old AML Leukemia
text: Zach Hare,  sophomore at St. Peter Marian High School in Worcester, Ma, has been apart of the North East Baseball Family for the past 3 years.  Life has not been easy for Zach.  At age 9 he was diagnosed with Lukemia and spent nearly a full year at Boston Children's Hospital.  He beat cancer at the age of 9 and has been a fighter ever since.Unfortunately, last week we received a call from Zach's father, Mike, informing us that Zach had a relapse and the cancer returned.  He has been diagnosed with AML Lukemia once again. "He will begin Chemo this week -  3 doses of very strong chemo starting on Sunday.  The 2nd dose will be Tuesday, and the last dose on Thursday.  This will attack the cancer cells along with his cells.  He will be getting blood transfusions and platelet transfusions they said soon after the chemo is done.  He will start to lose is hair around week 3. Once chemo is over, he will under go more surgeries for bone-marrow biopsies, cat-scans and MRIs to see how the chemo worked.  During this time, his body will recover. Once strong enough, they will do a 2nd round and will start the testing all over again."  Obviously Zach and his Family have a rough couple of months ahead of them.  Baseballl/NEB are a small family....and we are going to do anything we can to help Zach and his family through the next couple of months.  Any amount helps and we appreciate everyone's support.  NEB will start things off by donating $1000.00 to the campaign.

name: Maria's Fight Against Leukemia
text:
Hi There, My name is Tanya. This is My Wonderful Mom, Maria. She is Fun, Loving, Caring , Kind, Faith filled, Generous and so much more. 


She is a Loved Mother, Wife, Daughter, Grandmother, Mother in Law, Sister, Aunt, and Friend. 


She Loves God with All Her Heart! She is Young and Has the" Fight in Her" to Live! ( Her 55th Birthday is on May 31st) 


Everyone Who has Encountered My Mom, has been Blessed because She Loves with All She Has! 


My Mom has had a difficult 2 years fighting against Leukemia with numerous treatments of Chemotherapy, Blood Tranfusions, Medications, Bone Marrow Transplant , Tcell Infusion, and Sadly they have not been successful. The Drs have unfortunately run out of options and we are now relying solely on Faith. Per the Drs, Maria was given a few months of life here on earth. . . 


My Prayer is for her Total Complete Healing , but if the Good Lord decides to receive my "Earthly Angel" in His Arms, then My heart is to give her the Best Quality of Life, just by simply being By Her Side during the most difficult part of her life, by Loving her, Caring for Her, and spending as much time helping her through this process being that I am her only daughter and Our Bond is Unbreakable! (My younger Brother tragically passed away 6 years ago. Another difficult time in my mom's life. The beautiful part is that he left us with a Beautiful Boy who was 3 months in his wife's womb at the time, who is a Light of My Mom's Life. And Gives Her Another Reason To Live. You can find a Picture of Juniel attached) 


The reason I am doing this is because I Love My Mom! 


The situation is that I have been out on FMLA for 3 weeks since my mom was recently hospitalized and then sent home with No Hope from the Drs on her getting better. (We are Hoping/Praying for a Miracle)
So, recently I have completely run out of PTO due to caring for my mom. Travel expenses, medical bills and other expenses related to her care have increased. For a time, I've attempted other methods of income such as selling food but it is very time consuming and takes away time from my mom. 


Normally I Would NEVER Ask for financial assistance, yet due to My Desire to be there for My Mom, I have to Step Out in Faith, Humble Myself and make My Heart's desire known. 


The Lord says Ask and You Shall Receive, Knock and The Door Shall Open. . . So I Am Kindly and Humbly Knocking on Some Hearts in Hopes That God Would Opened Doors for My Mom to have me by her side. (Which I know is also her desire) 


❤ Please Pray With Me 
for Maria's Miracle!❤ 


May the Lord Bless and Keep You, May He Make Make His Face to Shine Upon You All The Days of Your Life!

name: Help Ricky beat Leukemia
text: For those who don’t know, Ricky was diagnosed with leukemia on Monday January 7th, 2019. He’s currently in Rhode Island Hospital undergoing treatment and battling the illness until further notice. Due to the leukemia Ricky had to step away from two great jobs he’s been juggling for a bit now. This also effects his family as well as their finances. All donations will go to Ricky and his family and will be greatly appreciated!! Let’s help the Oldrids in their time of need and get Ricky and his family on the road to great mental and physical health. #NoOneFightsAlone#PrayersForRicky

name: Bailey's Fight against Leukemia
text: Last night, my best friend Emilie and her fiancé Danny were given the worst news imaginable . Their daughter, Bailey Rose, Styffe, was diagnosed with Leukemia. Although this will be a long hard battle, Bailey is at the Children's hospital in Boston, receiving the best care in the world. Doctors are working fast and doing all they can to help this little angel. Leukaemia is a cancer which starts in blood-forming tissue, usually the bone marrow. It leads to the over-production of abnormal white blood cells, the part of the immune system which defends the body against infection.If you know Bailey, you know she is a ball of sunshine. She is spunky, sassy, and honestly the most hilarious three year old I've ever met. That little smile could light up a city and her laugh is contagious. I remember when they told me Emilie was pregnant ! We were scared and nervous and excited for the future... but we never knew just how much B would truly change our lives, along with all the lives of the people who are lucky enough to meet her. Emilie and Danny will need all the support they can get financially so I am reaching out to each and every one of you for help. Any amount will help! Thank you all from the bottom of my heart. I will keep everyone updates as we receive we receive more news. Please pray,  and send lots of love and positivity to this beautiful little family.Love, Auntie Alex

name: Rhiannon Lindley Leukemia Fund
text:
I am creating this Gofundme account for a very special friend of mine. She was just diagnosed with Acute b Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia. 
Rhiannon Hall Lindley is a mother of 4 ranging in ages from 5 to just a few months. Her and her husband is also caregivers to her brother. This family has endured so much over the past 2 years. They had a house fire, Her husband had lost his job, she was a student in nursing and graduated, all while being pregnant. She has only been back to work for about 2-3 months now and gets hit with this. She does not have ANY insurance. She is also the family's main source of income. 
As of today 1-27-18, she is being admitted to a hospital is St. Louis MO. She will be there for a several of weeks for chemo. 
Please help us help this young family in their time of need. Any help would be appreciated. 

￼
￼

name: Team KLA (Kick Leukemia's A**)
text: Thank you for visiting Karley's page! My name is Allie Sirrine -- I am Karley's girlfriend, and we are from West Hartford Connecticut. Most of our friends and family may know that Karley was diagnosed with Pre B cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia in July, 2017. She is currently receiving inpatient chemotherapy treatment at Smilow Cancer Center of Yale New Haven Hospital.  As her oncology team at Yale did genetic testing, Karley also learned that she is "Philadelphia chromosome positive," meaning she has a chromosomal translocation abnormality, found in some patients who have leukemia. As a result, once she beats this, she will need to take a tyrosine kinase inhibitor drug called Dasatinib for the rest of her life in order to suppress that abnormality from causing a relapse. This illness was completely unexpected for Karley and presented very aggressively, but she is the strongest girl we know, she is in the best place, and she will get through this!!!! Please consider donating to Karley's fund to help soften this financial blow. Karley will remain out of work throughout her entire inpatient treatment at Yale. We ask for your thoughts, prayers, well wishes, and any financial support you may be able to offer Karley so she can focus on her health as she starts this uphill battle. These funds will go toward Karley's medical bills and for any other costs she will accrue while being in the hospital. We appreciate any and all support you may be able to offer. #teamKLA

name: Luis Eduardo, you and I, defeating Leukemia
text: Luis Eduardo, el niño del alma grande, un regalo hermoso de la vida. Tiene apenas seis años. Es inteligente, tenaz y aguerrido en lo que se propone y para él  ha sido un don natural  “enamorar” a cuantos le conocen. El jueves 17 de Enero de 2019, se llevó a chequeo médico por una fiebre asintomática y el diagnóstico fue: Leucemia Linfoblástica aguda. Está hospitalizado en el Hospital de Clínicas Caracas, donde ayer, 22 de Enero comenzó a recibir quimioterapia.Luis Eduardo, es el sol que nutre a su madre Vanessa y a toda nuestra familia en Venezuela. Ahora yo tengo la oportunidad de ayudar a mi familia atravesar este camino doloroso. Nuestras familias se conocen desde los años 40, cuando mi abuela fue a Venezuela por primera vez. Desde entonces todas las generaciones siguientes han estado juntas de alguna manera u otra, especialmente en el amor que compartirmos hacia nuestro Dios y Salvador. Le doy gracias a Dios, que me ha permitido hacer posible esta campaña, porque Luis Eduardo, ya 5ta generación es como mi nieto, y tiene hermosos sueños, ilusiones y sobre todo, porque posee  un corazón que le hará convertirse en un maravilloso ser humano,  único y excepcional, como ha sido durante su corta niñez.  Pero para que su vida continúe y él pueda seguir iluminando nuestras vidas, necesita de tu ayuda, de la ayuda de todos, ya que su tratamiento implica una primera fase de quimioterapia diaria por un mes, durante el cual estará hospitalizado  y luego debe estar por 24 meses en un tratamiento ininterrumpido a fin de que la enfermedad desaparezca por completo. En Venezuela, el sistema de salud está completamente colapsado y los gastos clínicos y de medicamentos son muy costosos y difíciles de encontrar. En vista de que Luis Eduardo no cuenta con ningún seguro médico, todos los fondos recaudados con esta campaña serán usados en su totalidad para cubrir tanto los honorarios de la Clínica, que son muy elevados, como para la compra de los medicamentos que se requieren a fin de completar su tratamiento. Siendo aproximadamente $4000 para la fase inicial, del tratamiento, que incluye hospitalización y quimioterapia diaria por 1 mes, y luego $2000 mensuales durante 24 meses, que sería hospitalización por 1 semana y tramineto, dando un total aproximado de 52000 Dólares. Quisiera agregar que los fondos serán depositados o transferidos a la cuenta que el Hospital Clinicas Caracas tiene.en dólares igual que al médico tratantePor eso, mientras Luis Eduardo pelea la batalla por su vida, nosotros, junto a ustedes, quienes a partir de ahora, serán parte de nuestra familia, estaremos peleando la batalla económica que nos permita afrontar todo lo que viene por delante. Ayúdanos para que Luis Eduardo pueda levantar sus manos en agradecimiento a Dios por haberle enviado muchísimos ángeles, que como tú, se sumen a esta noble causa. Muchísimas gracias.Luis Eduardo…a little child with a big soul, he is a beautiful gift of life. He is only six years old. He is intelligent, tenacious and brave in what he sets his mind to do and for him is a natural gift to make all those who get to know him "fall in love" with him. On Thursday, January 17, 2019, he underwent a medical checkup for asymptomatic fever and the diagnosis was: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia. He is hospitalized at Hospital de Clinicas Caracas, where yesterday, January 22, he began receiving chemotherapy.Luis Eduardo, is the sun that nourishes his mother Vanessa and our whole family in Venezuela. And now I have the opportunity to help my family make it through this difficult and painful path. My name is Karen and I thank God he has allowed me to make this campaign possible. Our families have known each other ever since my grandmother went to Venezuela during the 40's.  Five generations of families together helping each other and know Luis Eduardo, Vanessa's son, I feel he is like my own grandson, I have to see him grow because Luis Eduardo has beautiful dreams, illusions and above all, because he has a heart that will make him become a wonderful human being, unique and exceptional, as he has been during his short childhood.But for his life to continue, and he can continue illuminating our lives, he needs your help, the help of all, because his treatment involves a first phase of daily chemotherapy for a month  in which he will be hospitalized, and then he must be in an uninterrupted treatment for 24 months in order for the disease to disappear completely. I must ad the funds will be deposited or transferred to the hospital account in Commerce Bank in dollars and also to the.doctor's account.In Venezuela, the health system has completely collapsed, and medical and drug costs are very expensive and difficult to find. Given that Luis Eduardo does not have any medical insurance, all the funds raised with this campaign will be used in full to cover the Clinic's fees, which are very high, as well as for the purchase of the drugs for the treatment, food and other supplies needed for his recovery. So for the first month  the doctor said  the initial phase of the treatment is US$ 4000 and then US$ 2000 monthly for 24 months, giving a total of approximately $ 52,000. These numbers  seems so unreachable and the only way we can even get started is through this way of raising funds because the amount seems out of this world That is why, while Luis Eduardo fights the battle for his life, we, together with you, who from now on, will be part of our family, will be fighting the economic battle and many difficulties we may have to face from now on. Help us so that Luis Eduardo can raise his hands in gratitude to God for having sent him so many angels, who like you, will join this noble cause.Thank you so much!

name: Anthony Scafide Leukemia fund
text: Hello, my name is Giovanna and I am writing this with my husband. We have one daughter, Jianna, and one son, 2 1/2-year-old Anthony Scafide, who was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) at the end of April 2017. He is undergoing Chemotherapy at Advocate Children's Hospital in Park Ridge, IL, and has already had 15 spinal taps, 3 bone marrow biopsies, and 3 blood transfusions. He is very weak right now with all of the Chemotherapy being done, it is very hard to watch our sweet little boy suffering, surely this is the worst feeling in the world. He will be undergoing Chemotherapy for 3 years. We are asking for prayers and donations to assist with his medical needs.  Anthony is a strong boy, together we will beat this cancer. We will keep everyone updated on Anthony's journey.  We cannot possibly thank those enough, who have offered prayers or financial donations. Please consider sharing this gofundme on Facebook to continue building awareness for Leukemia and all Cancers.

name: Kelly's fight with leukemia
text: Kelly went to the instacare on Thursday because she hasn't been feeling well since Christmas. They took her blood, did some testing and sent her to the UofU ER. Her white blood count was at 190 ( it should be at 10 or less). She has now been diagnosed with leukemia. She has started chemo therapy and blood transfusions. For all who know Kelly, you know what a sweet, caring and compassionate woman she is. She is a wife and a mother to three beautiful kids, Morgan 14, Ashlyn 11 and Mason 8.  Kelly is one of seven children with 5 sisters and 1 brother. Kelly is fighting this hard and staying so strong.  She is so loved by all who know her. We are asking for any help we can get with donations to go towards Kelly, Jeremy and the kids to help with medical costs. Please keep Kelly in your thoughts and prayers. Thank you!

name: Help with Jame's Leukaemia Battle
text: Hi this is James, my 16 year old nephewIn March 2017, James was diagnosed with T-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) after his mum Penny, noticed bruises on his arms and legs. James was admitted to Lady Cilento Children's hospital in Brisbane to undergo immediate and intense chemo over the next 6 months.Those six months have now blown out to 8 months(and still going), as despite best efforts from doctors at both Lady Cilento and the Sunshine Coast University Hospital, James has been incredibly sick and has not handled his treatment as expected.With challenges such as being allergic to one of the chemo drugs that caused pancreatitis with a 3 week stint in hospital, contracting an E-coli infection, and numerous transfusions, he has faced an uphill battle of epic proportions. Like that old saying “what can go wrong, in James' case, has gone wrong”.Whilst James has left his friends in Year 11 at Chancellor State College and they're all getting ready to enjoy the festive season, James' battle will continue, along with the financial hardship Adrian and Penny are now dealing with.My brother Adrian quit his full time electrical job months ago to be Jame's full time carer, while mum Penny still works, her wage barely covers the mortgage payments. With no assistance from the government, up to three trips to Brisbane hospital every week, car parking fees, fuel and general household bills, the financial situation is growing. They have already had two re-draws on the mortgage to pay bills and live day to day, and with Christmas around the corner, myself and my family are asking if you could spare anything to help them.Any donation would help, the monies raised will go on general bills, mortgage repayments, car maintenance, fuel, car parking costs at the hospitals and food.Thank you all in advance xx

name: Gray’s Fight against Leukemia - help Lois Gilbert
text: Gray was a healthy, active 6-year-old boy until this week his life was changed forever. On 12/18/2018 he was given the devastating diagnosis of B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  Gray is currently admitted to the University of Virginia Children’s Hospital, where he will continue to be treated for cancer. Gray faces a lengthy treatment plan with many different chemotherapies and various medications.Lois is doing her very best to cover a mortgage, bills, and the costs of living. She will not be able to work for the foreseeable future due to the complexity of the care needed to save his life. As taxing as the emotional toll is for her – and for us, her family and friends – there’s the economic reality of what is needed to give Gray the care that he needs in the coming years.  But we are not powerless here. While we will continue to pray and send our love, there is more that we can do. We – her nieces Grace Merchlinski and Chrissy Kozloski -- are creating this campaign despite her pride and aversion to asking for any kind of help. We are asking for your help to fight this economic battle so that Lois can focus on helping Gray with his battle.

name: Angelina Domenici Leukemia Fund
text: Dear Friends and Family,Today my brother and his wife received news no parent should have to hear. After noticing their daughter was pale and bruising easily, they took her to their doctor. Their 12 year old daughter was diagnosed with Leukemia. Angelina was immediately admitted to Hasbro Children's Hospital, and will undergo surgery for a chemo port to be inserted into her chest. She will start chemo right away. Angelina will have to be at Hasbro for a minimum of one month. This is called the 'induction phase' where aggressive chemo is performed to kill as much of the leukemia cells as possible so her bone marrow can start to produce healthy cells once again. If all goes well, Angelina can come home after one month and will visit the hospital once a week for additional chemo treatments. This is what they refer to as the 'consolidation phase', and usually lasts 4-6 months. Finally,  if all continues to go well, she will proceed into the maintenance phase of chemo treatments for an additional 2-3 years. I am asking for your help so that Michael and Mayra can take time from their jobs and be by Angelina's side at the hospital during this initial phase, as you can imagine how frightened she is. Mike and Mayra will be struggling enough emotionally, if I can help ease their financial struggles, I know it will help them a lot to focus on what's most important! It is my hope and prayer that through family and friends, we can help them navigate through this difficult time so they can be there for Angelina. Her first words to her Dad upon hearing her diagnosis were, "Am I going to die?" I can't imagine what it felt like to hear their little girl say those words! Please keep Angelina in your prayers! She is one tenacious little girl and I know through our prayers and her resilience, she is going to fight this!   Love and blessings to all!The Domenici Family

name: Bo Cooper Leukemia Treatment Fund
text: We are in need of support for one of our Brothers, a Fire Fighter who, unfortunately, has been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) for the 3rd time since 2011. Each time, he has been successfully treated and put in to remission, however, the treatment options are dwindling. His father is also a member and is a Captain with our department. Last year, Bo received a bone marrow transplant and was well on his way to recovery. In October 2015, while on a Father-Son "dream trip" to the Yukon, Bo received the bad news from the doctors that the ALL had returned for a 3rd time. The doctors say that if even only one of the leukemia cells didn't die after his last chemo, radiation and marrow transplant, it could have grown and multiplied and only become detectable now. Apparently, the bone marrow donor cells are supposed to fight off any remaining leukemia cells, but it's possible the donor cells weren't strong enough either. As the leukemia cells grow, they can block out the healthy donor cells as in any other patient. Bo is now in Calgary, and is undergoing treatment with an experimental drug called Blinatumomab. The Tom Baker Cancer Clinic needed to get special approval to use this drug. The hope was that the drug would put Bo into full remission in about 24-50 days, and then he could possibly have another bone marrow transplant from a different donor. Now, the doctors are reccomending preparation for travel to one of 3 potential locations in the USA to undergo treatment with more promissing experimental Car T Cell drugs.  The family needs to quickly come up with atleast $500 000.00 to recieve the treatment.  They are trying liquidate any assets, but the process is slow.   The doctors are being frank and honest at this point, they really do not know what his chances are. He has had his lifetime dose of Chemotherapy, so treatment options are becoming slim. Bo will remain in Calgary, until he is able to travel for  treatment. He exhausted his financial support to stay at the housing unit for the Tom Baker Cancer Clinic during his last treatment phase, so the cost of accommodation, transportation, etc are up to him. We are fundraising at the local level as well, but a greater influx of support would be more helpful. At this point and time, any financial support from the public would be greatly appreciated. Bo and his family are not people who have ever asked for support, and are deeply appreciative of the possible benefit of this campaign.  Bo is just 26 years old and newly married.  He worked as a volunteeer Fire Fighter until he was hired by the Fort McMurray Fire Department in 2009.  Please consider assisting this family in need.  We thank you in advance for your kindness.

name: Xaviers Relapse With Leukemia
text: Xavier is a handsome,creative, smart 13 yr old boy who is in 7th grade. He has been battling a rare blood cancer “Early T-Cell Precursor Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia”. (ETP ALL) Xavier received Chemotherapy, Radiation Therapy and even a Bone Marrow Transplant. and still relapsed twice. But did manage to go into remission for 18 months. As of June 5th, 2018 he was hospitalized for high fevers,septic shock, and pneumonia. Also with low blood count, where he received 2 blood transfusions. June 8th, 2018 we heard the devastating news that Leukemia has attacked his body for the 3rd time. With this relapse that means our family is going to need money for bills, transportation, and necessities for Xaviers treatment plan and for home necessities I am Single mother of 5 and going to need all the help and support I can get. It just seems Xavier and our family can not catch a break. Thank you in advance for your support and prayers. You can follow his 3rd battle on FB. “Xavier’s Battle”

name: Abigail's Leukemia Fund
text: Abigail was very recently diagnosed with Leukemia at only 4 months old. Her parents and big sister will need help, from us. I have started this GoFundMe to raise money for the Shannon family for help with gas food, medical bills, and whatever other expense may arise during their journey. Abigail is a strong little girl, with a long road ahead of her but we have no doubt the Lord will pull her through this and Abigail will beat this! If you can donate, please do. If you can't, please share. We will also be selling decals, bracelets, t-shirts, and hair bows to raise funds! If you are interested in any of this, my name is Heather Janie Davidson on Facebook, feel free to add me or message me to purchase!

name: Help Leukemia Positive Cats to Live
text: We provide vet care, food, shelter, and endless love to these delightful babies with more strikes against them then they deserve. Because all the cats in the room have leukemia, we provide a rare opportunity for leukemia positive cats to share companionship and emotional support with each other while roaming free. Leukemia positive cats have been living here for 13 years and during that time I have had the honor to observe and participate in their daily lives. They have shown me how to face a terrible disease with dignity and grace and I would not have missed this time with them for anything in the world. Over 400 cats of all ages and breeds have been helped by the kindness and compassion of our supporters. Please donate today and together we can provide a quality life to those who normally are euthanized immediately upon diagnosis as there is usually no place for them to live.  Our wish list includes K.d food from Science Diet, Scoop away litter, and K.d wet food.  A few of the kitties can also eat Friskies pate wet food.  Thank you for your kindness and support.

name: Help Vasil Fight Leukemia
text: English version below⬇️С сегодняшнего дня начинается новый этап в жизни моих близких и моей жизни.Последние полтора месяца я провёл между приёмами у разных врачей, в поиска ответа на вопрос: почему у меня на шее показались лимфоузлы?Развернутый анализ крови говорил что есть некие отклонения от нормы. Было много разных вариантов, которые исключались по мере сдачи того или иного анализа.Что же со мной всё таки не так, при том что чувствую я себя достаточно неплохо. И так проследовав всю пирамиду медицинской иерархии, я добрался на приём к врачу-гематологу, за пару дней до Нового Года. Показываю ему это «ожерелье» на шее,а он в ответ: «На 95% уверен что всё впорядке, это может быть реакция на инфекцию,давай для полной уверенности сделаем несколько анализов - маркеров определенных заболеваний». Я конечно хотел было согласиться с его 95 процентной частью, но внутренний голос давал понять что эта 5ка не даст мне спать спокойно.Да и узлы как были так и оставались. Так как врач этот был работником одной из частных клиник,да и позиция у него не самая популярная в том заведении,он принимает раз в неделю, плюс наложились на это ещё и новогодние дни, а там сразу посленовогодний проект. Вообщем не с пустыми же руками к нему было возвращаться, нужны доп обследования,требующие времени на сдачу. Прикинув перспективы по занятости, записался к нему на приём, через 10 дней. Стали эти дни тянуться страшно долго, так как ожидание моё было непередаваемым, очень хотелось поскорее исключить все предположения и наконец расслабиться,тем временем перебирая шею в поисках узлов каждый день по 100 раз, как охотник за золотом мутную глину в реке, только моя ежедневная цель была обратной, не найти их. И вот финишная прямая, забираю последние результаты обследований и направляюсь на встречу к врачу. Приехал на место немного заранее, примерно за час, ну чтобы не опоздать.Отсидел это время частично в машине, частично в дороговалютном коридоре, обрамлённом лепниной и картинами в позолоченных рамках. Зовут, захожу, выкладываю свои «карты» на стол, предварительно расположив их в нужном порядке. Он смотрит, один-второй лист, вот думаю сейчас скажет иди уже отсюда и не придумывай, больше спи, здоровее ешь и радуйся. В ответ на моё ожидание вопрос: «У тебя регистрация киевская?». Киваю, что да (про это отдельный разговор).И получаю напутствие на дообследование уже в специализированном гос учреждении, с комментарием,что есть патология костного мозга, делай пункцию, они точно скажут какая, намекая на то,что лекарства через гос учреждение дешевле.Загудело в ушах, киваю, спрашиваю насколько это страшно, понятное дело не получаю ответов, так как на то оно и дообследование.Вот ещё одна надежда на сбой в иммунитете (как решил мой внутренний врач) рухнула. Выхожу из клиники,не снимая бахил, иду к машине, набирая при этом Дашу, которая как и я все эти недели волнуется вместе со мной.На следующее утро, едем уже вдвоём в городскую поликлинику. Захожу в ещё один кабинет, получаю направление в гематологическое отделение больницы, со словами: «проблема серьёзная хлопчик». Следующий шаг - больница, показываю результаты, направление, слышу всё те же подозрения только с ещё более подробными деталями и в конце: «надо дообследоваться, ложись на стационар, как только будет свободное место, набери через пару часов, может освободится». Этот день была пятница, жаль что не 13го, потому как 13е моё счастливое число. Спустя несколько часов в трубке телефона говорят,что в понедельник в 8:30 меня ждут с вещами на заселение. Ну я же неплохо себя чувствую, что они говорят? - думаю я.И ещё миллион мыслей,от которых всё плывёт вокруг.Но отказать врачам в их рекомендациях не получается.И вот понедельник, мы с Дашей, в руках мои пожитки для больницы, кладу вещи в палату, жду каких то конкретных, точных действий, наступает ожидание, но уже больничное, начало знакомства с госпитальным бытом, зрачки расширяются.Делают пункцию, ощущение как будто шприцом тянут из груди душу, кто делал поймёт.Несёмся чтобы успеть до закрытия сдать полученный образец в 2 разных лаборатории, которые этим дерьмом занимаются на клеточном уровне. Денёк ещё тот, один из тех в конце которого хочется выпить.Но был и позитивный момент дня, что мне не надо возвращаться ночевать в больнице. Следующие 5ть дней были как это называется в режиме дневного стационара, в режиме спокойного обследования-наблюдения. Всю неделю продолжаю трогать эти узлы, в надежде изменений. И действительно они стали немного меньше, а моя вера в хороший результат пункции больше.Мыслей такое количество, что они не дают мне спать, поневоле прорабатываю все возможные сценарии развития, от которых бросает в пот-холод-пот-холод. Спустя несколько дней, на подсознании я готов ко всему, но волнуюсь за тех кто рядом, оно есть. В конце рабочей недели, по дороге из больницы домой, звонок на телефон: «результат готов, куда отправлять, кто ваш врач?». В режиме левитации направляюсь домой. С этого момента становится темно...Итак, перед Вами человек со сбоем работы формулы крови, который врачи называют лейкемия. Человек, который готов и морально и физически бороться и побеждать. Но я знаю точно, этот путь можно преодолеть только командой при правильной стратегии.Приняли решение не откладывать и ложиться как можно раньше на стационар для начала химиотерапии. Сейчас много всего сложного нового сыпется, и к сожалению не только на меня, а и на моих близких, они те, кому сейчас нужна моральная поддержка больше чем мне.Уверен многие из вас откликнутся помочь и это действительно понадобится совсем скоро. Первое скорее всего что будет нужно, это люди с 2+ кровью для сдачи. (Второй положительной). Пожалуйста пишите в личку кто не против поделиться.P.S. На фото я, после знакомства с первой химией. Познакомились,немного мутило, но ничего криминального.Будем обнулять систему и дальше.#bloodyresort////////////////////This day is the day when the new stage of my life and life of my close people starts.Last 1,5 months I’ve spent in between appointments with different doctors in searching answer for questions: why lymph nodes on my neck showed up? Full blood count said that there are some indexes out of normal. It was many different presumtions on this case which were excluded with different tests. So what is wrong with me? Btw I fell myself pretty normal. Just before the New Year after I’ve made a way trough a whole medical hierarchy I finally got an appointment with a doctor who’s named Hematologist. So I’m at his office showing him my “necklace” made of lymph nodes. He responds to this with words: “I’m 95% sure that this not a problem,it can be reaction onto some infection. But to be on 100% let’s do some more tests - markers to exclude anything completely”.I’ve almost agreed with his 95% presumption but this shitty 5% will not keep me calm. And lymph nodes still here I can feel them.As this doctor was from a private clinic and his position not really popular over there possibility for the next appointment was in a week but because of the New Years holidays and music video project that I had it wasn’t enough time for me to manage new tests before I met him again. So I decided to come back to him in 10 days.That were loooong days of waiting.I was dreaming about to finish this asap and relax meanwhile I’ve been checking bulbs on my neck as golddiger checking myddy water but my goal was an opposite just not to find them. Days were lasting and here is the finishing line comes closer.I take my latest results and take off to the clinic. Got there 1 hour before slightly earlier not to be late. Half of this time I spent in a car and the other half at the extremely poshy clinic’s lobby with the pictures in golden frames. I’m hearing my name, entering door and putting my cards on doctors table. Still believe that he is going to tell me that everything is fine just normalize your daily routine. In answer to my waiting I got question: “Do you have Kyiv registration or the other one?”My nod in respond which means yes.And following: “you need to pass some extra tests it can be some pathology of bone marrow, punction needed, better to go to govermental clinic it will be cheaper and they have some support there”.So my feeling about some immune disease broke apart ( that was diagnose from my inner doctor, i’m sure everyone has his own). I’m getting out from clinic in surgery boots heading to the car on a way calling to Dasha she has been living trough this with me.Next morning together with her going to city clinic. Entering office, receiving medical refer from doctor with words: “problem is serious boy”.Next step hospital, showing my results, same suspicions that I’ve heard before already but with more details and in the end: “ you need to stay stationary at the hospital for extra tests, call us in few hours maybe we will have bed for you”.But I feel myself ok, why hospital?That was a Friday, unfortunately not 13th because 13 is my lucky number.Later trough the cellphone I hear: “come in on Monday and we will start - that was a doctor.”Next Monday we getting back with Dasha to the hospital with all stuff that you possibly could need, first introduction with hospital’s life.Long waiting, then sternal punction, this feeling when someone trying to suck your soul out of the chest.Flying with material to 2 different laboratories for more tests, they make this shit on cellular level.That was a day one of these when in the end of it you want to drink some strong alcohol.Next 5 days in observing mode at the hospital, one good thing that you don’t need to do is to stay there overnight.Keep touching my nodes in hope. And they really became smaller and with this my expectations for punction results bigger.Many thoughts in my head: what? if?how? where? and etc. Can’t sleep at night keep thinking about possible future scenarios. In few days I’ve managed myself to be ready to face to any results but still thinking about people around me.To strong.In the end of the week I recieved a call: “your results ready, where i need to send it, who is your doctor?”In result after 1,5 months of research guy in front of you diagnosed with a bug of the blood’s system formula which doctors call leukemia.This guy physically and mentally ready for fight and win.But I know for sure you can made this way only with a strong team and a right strategy. We decided not to delay and start chemotherapy on the next day. Doctors said they knew diagnosis week ago so they ready to provide me with a program.Right now many things falling on top of the head, unfortunately not only mine’s head but my relatives also. They are the ones who need support more then me right now.I’m sure many of you ready to help and it’s definitely will be needed very soon. First what I would ask you, probably soon I will need 2+ blood for blood transfusion (Second Positive).Write me down in dm who are ready to share some (if you are in Kyiv).P.S. Here is me on photo after first meeting with chemistry. Feels good by now. Waiting for the next one.Keep working.Vasil from #bloodyresort Cheers!Money needs to go through a US bank account because GoFundMe doesn’t support Ukraine banks, so it’ll be transferred to Corey Steinhouse and then wired to Vasil’s bank account.

name: Matt Simpson- Leukemia Battle Family Support
text: A friend and colleague of ours, Matt Simpson could use our prayers and support right now. Matt, Monster Energy’s Director of Marketing for eSports & Gaming was hit with the devastating diagnosis of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia on Wednesday. He is undergoing tests and scans now so his doctors can better understand the situation to determine the best treatment plan. He is currently at UC San Diego Health Jacobs Medical Center in La Jolla and will be there for 3-4 weeks undergoing initial chemotherapy treatment. After this a bone marrow transplant or stem cell transplant may be required. His full treatment plan is not yet determined.Matt’s illness evaded doctors for the past 8-months as his energy was drained, he experienced out-of-control weight loss and faced excruciating pain in his bones & joints. While not the diagnosis we were all hoping for it does answer the mystery and allows him, his family and his doctors to build and execute a plan fight-through and beat this cancer.Matt’s wife Candace and their two boys Max & Gray could use some help from the village. While Matt is tied-up let’s pitch-in to help with the incremental costs they will have like hotel bills for the family to be near the hospital, extra take-out food expenses, babysitting as everything falls onto Candace’s shoulders, fund the inevitable home emergency that Matt would normally handle, get a maid to help with laundry & cleaning, you get the idea- the extra costs they will experience and offer some support so Matt’s family can be there for him.Feel free to spread the word to other’s who may want to help.Update 1/12 from Matt-I got the full diagnoses. I'm going to be here for at least 4 weeks with potentially another week added on for the first round. And I will need 2-3 rounds about a week long each before the bone marrow transplant. I have B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. It is pretty rare in the US but this hospital only deals with blood cancers so they have treated it before. I'm starting chemotherapy tomorrow, once they knock out the leukemia cells, they start looking to do a bone marrow transplant.

name: Help Mozlee Beat Leukemia!
text: My son Mozlee who is  three years old was diagnosed with leukemia on September 4th 2015. He will be in treatment for the next two years. We have had to be away from our home a lot since we got his diagnosis. I am a teacher and unfortunately had to be away from work most of the year on unpaid leave. Since his diagnosis, Mozlee has become a big brother which he loves! And he has shown such amazing strength through this whole ordeal!  We love our little superman! He amazes us everyday! Any support is very much appreciated. Please help us raise money to fight this ongoing battle!

name: Our boy has Leukemia!
text: ￼￼Hello, you all know my family is everything to me!!! I call them “my crazies” and I call my sister Tina’s sons, “my boys”, “Our boys” to the family.  Well, we have learned one of “my boys, our boys” Tina and Ricky Oldrid’s oldest son, Ricky has Leukemia. We are devastated to find out this news. He is 24 and strong and we know he can beat this horrible disease. Please keep him in your prayers.The family faces a long road ahead of them.  As you can imagine the medical bills will be piling up again. My sister Tina and Ricky will have to miss a lot of time out of work. They are still catching up on medical bills from a past family illness. This family has had their share of heartache and my sister Stephanie and I are asking our family and friends to help make things easier over the next two yrs of treatments. They would never ask for help and if you know my sister, she tries and help everyone! I am asking for help in lessening their worry through this difficult time. Any donation will be appreciated. Thank you!THERE ARE TWO GO FUND ME PAGES.Ricky’s caring friends have started on too! All is going to the same cause!

name: Tinnley’s Leukemia Battle
text: Tinnley is a sweet, goofy 2 year old who was diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia back on Thanksgiving Day 2017. She has been bravely fighting her battle since. Unfortunately, we have received the news that Tinnley does not have any other medical options to heal her. Her parents have made the incredibly difficult decision to have her come home for as long as possible to enjoy the rest of her time with her family - her parents and her sister. Tinnley’s favorite place to be is Disneyland. All her wildest dreams and favorite characters come to life every time she sets foot in the park. This fundraiser is to purchase a Disney pass for her family to be able to take her to Disney as much as possible in the upcoming days. Anything we raise above the amount necessary will be used to help with medical bills and maybe even a bowl of her favorite meal, Jinya Ramen ❤️

name: Baby Ellis & His Leukemia Fight
text: I apologize to friends & family just learning of this news—I realize posting on social media lacks elegance, but it’s the most efficient way for me to seek help & share news.My nephew (Tara & Roger’s son) Ellis, was diagnosed with Leukemia on 11-28-18.He is 4 months old.We feel Ellis is being treated by the best— I am asking for help to cover his medical costs, since care is out-of-network, and will likely be extensive.Ellis is Tara & Roger’s first baby, but they also serve as adoptive parents for my neice, Taryn. Much energy and consideration is being applied to maintain a cohesive family of four. To balance life both in and out of a hospital room.My sister Tara is my hero for many reasons—One of them is her huge heart and love for others. Her selflessness is endless; even now. Roger loves my babies as his own and is a humble father and husband.Please consider giving back.Prayer, positive vibes, and peaceful encouragement are greatly appreciated and also needed. We love you Baby Ellis!

name: Symington family fighting Leukemia
text: I will try to make this as short and sweet as possible but there is only one way to put this so that its understood. A good friend of mine Shawn Symington and her family are going through that one thing that we all fear, being told that someone that means the world to you may die much sooner than you thought due to CANCER. Many of you may know or recognize Shawn from being a long time resident of Plaquemine Parish and has been  working at Balestra's  for the past 11 years. Her husband James has worked as a diesel mechanic for quite some time now and has always been very good at what he does, even though work kept him away from home quite a bit he did what he had to do for his family. When James was home he would spend as much time with his wife and two young sons, Jaison 11, who attends Belle Chasse middle and Tristan 10, who attends Belle Chasse Primary, as possible. His boys are always so happy to see their daddy and both look up to him tremendously. James has always been a kind man doing what he can for anyone that is in need, family, friend or even a stranger. That’s why when he fell ill it was so hard on everyone that knows him. Initially James went to the Doctor to have his knee checked for unbearable pain, first he was told it was stemming from his back. Then came all the testing! Scans and poking and prodding and they found nothing. His Doctor decided to do a bone density scan on him, which required labs and basic surgery prep. Still waiting for the approval for the scan , one morning James woke up to his wife asking him if he maybe fell out of the bed or smacked his head during the night because he had a pretty big gash on his head and was bleeding. James didn’t recall falling or hurting himself, so it was assumed he just did it in his sleep. Well the days following James developed several more of these mysterious spots on his body which were painful and bleeding. Assuming it was a case of the shingles he headed to his Doctor to have it checked out. THAT DAY THEIR LIFE CHANGED! Once they arrived at the office the Doctor informed them that his bloodwork came back with some scary results and his white blood count was triple what it should be and that could only mean one thing, Leukemia. James was admitted that day into Tulane and put into isolation because at this point they were not sure what type of leukemia it was and if he did in fact have shingles or if it was a result of the cancer. It took about a week of being in the hospital before they knew for sur what type of Leukemia he has which is CML (Chronic myeloid leukemia), on a grading scale it’s one of the worst kind, not that any are a good kind but it’s a very rare and aggressive type of Leukemia. He was in what they call blast phase which is extremely bad, come to find out that sores he has all over his body were NOT shingles but a result of the leukemia. It was basically causing his blood platelets to burst which was causing bruising and sores all over his body. They instantly started Chemo and he had to say in the hospital for 37 days, which of course led to several more long stays. Time away from his children and work and Time his wife had to take off of work. Since being diagnosed James has tried his best to continue to work, be it from home or just lite duty in the office but now that is no longer an option. Starting in October he will no longer have his job and will lose his benefits as well as his insurance. He’s been in and out of the hospital so much I’ve lost count. Every time he’s gotten a chemo treatment he ends up in the hospital for one reason or another due to his depleted nonexistent immune system. His last treatment he ended up catching a nasty intestinal infection and that was yet another week in the hospital for antibiotics. He will be needing to go through a stem cell transplant very soon and when that happens his wife will need to be with him as much as possible. He will not be allowed to be around pets or children under the age of 14, which means he will not see his boys for 100 days if everything goes well. The little income Shawn will be bringing in will barley be enough to feed them let alone pay the bills to keep their home and vehicle.  This is a very humble family and I have seen both Shawn and James go above and beyond to help others in need and now it’s their turn to be the ones in need.  This has been a very rough year for this family with Shawn suddenly losing her brother T.J. last month and literally fighting for James’s life, trying to keep it together and raising 2 young boys I’m just not sure how she does it. I know that if we can ban together and give them one less thing to worry about, one less heart ache, make things go just a little bit smoother it may be just a little donation out of your pocket but it would make the world of difference for them.BELOW IS A LINK WITH A VIDEO, it explains they type of cancer they are dealing with http://www.cancercenter.com/leukemia/types/tab/chronic-myeloid-leukemia/

name: Jennifer's Leukemia Fight For CURE
text: My name is Richard Byrne and am starting gofundme on behalf of my sister.  Here is her story:"My name is Jennifer Byrne and I'm 41 years old. I was first diagnosed with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia 2 years ago in September 2015. A chemotherapy option was presented to me in pill form but would compromise my ability to ever have children naturally while on it. In order to get the leukemia in remission, I would have to take the pill for the rest of my life. Once off of it, the leukemia returns.  It is a very serious blood cancer that without treatment, expectancy for survival is 2 years after diagnosis. Although I've lived longer than expected without treatment, the time has come where it is necessary for survival. I went as long as I could without taking the pill.  I tried it on my own with organic food options but with medical bills of recurring blood tests, that's not always affordable option as a single woman that supports herself.  My blood test results a few weeks ago just past the 2 year mark, showed a dramatic rise in my white blood cell count into dangerous levels where I was hospitalized last week to start the chemotherapy treatment as an emergency to save my life.  I am right on the cusp of the only cure known in the states covered by insurance being a bone marrow donor along with aggressive chemotherapy that comes with many complications.  Hopefully, the chemotherapy treatment I am currently on will be effective. But even at it's most effective, is still NOT A CURE. The leukemia had hijacked my system so much that I needed a blood transfusion to bring up my red blood cell count while in the hospital.The way it's been explained to me is that once your body's immune system has been compromised for a period of time, it is very hard to recover. It's like a bear has been chasing you for a really long time and the body is tired and worn out. The toll cancer takes on you emotionally and physically is almost too much to bare sometimes. There is a known cure for my type of leukemia in Arizona at New Hope Unlimited where they use all natural procedures to clean the blood with ultraviolet rays and bring your body back to balance with your own T-cells to fight the disease without chemotherapy which causes further damage over time. It is a 12 day procedure with only a 4 month follow up locally where I live in South Florida. It is the CURE, not a band aid.  It has a very high success rate.The procedure is not covered by insurance and costs 28,000.  That along with flights, other travel expenses, time taken off work without pay and other medical bills- I'm looking to raise 35,000 as my goal.  I may not hit that, but any amount counts.  The longer I wait, the more damage is being done to my body in the long run.  Any amount that exceeds that, I would like to pay forward to another cause close to my heart on Gofundme. Although I have cancer, I refuse to be defined by it.  I am not Jennifer who has cancer.  I am Jennifer.  I have dreams, hopes, and desires that I refuse to let cancer have. I've been lucky to work with Carnival Cruise Line for the past 2 years and happy to share in the experiences of booking cruises for everything from Honeymoons to Anniversaries, Graduations and for many other cancer fighters and SURVIVORS celebrating their lives and I desire the same for my own life.  I would love the opportunity to be married and have my own children still even though some say it's getting harder to do at my age.
