It's my dream to sing one day also and although I'm doing that now, I want to do it CANCER FREE and with a testimony in my heart to sing about forever!  With a story to tell my children, that there are still wonderful people in this world who love. I also want to give others hope that have been fighting all kinds of cancers themselves, that they are not alone in the journey and that there are other options out there.  I want to take you along the journey and document the progress. I want to be the example of someone who has SURVIVED!I am asking that you join this fight with me.  With the strength of God, I wish you to help me in taking back my life…with a view to a wonderful future."

name: Kylie's battle with Leukemia
text: Kylie and her husband Kevin recently welcomed their sweet baby girl into the world on New Year's Eve. Just one short month later they recieved devistating news that would change their lives. Kylie has been diagnosed with leukemia and now has to fight for her own health while also raising a newborn. Her sister Lakin has been right by her side and will continue to be there to help and support her family.  They were blessed with an opportunity for Kylie to receive treatment at MD Anderson in Houston Tx. This is an amazing facility were Kylie will be able to receive the best possible treatment; however, being uprooted from their homes and jobs for an unknown amount of time will put a financial strain on all of them. These sisters have already faced so much heartache in their lives with the loss of both of their parents. I'm hoping to raise funds to take some of their worry away so they can focus on getting Kylie well and taking care of her sweet baby. As a good friend of Lakin's, I have seen her generosity over and over again. She is one of the most kind and caring people in existence and would literally give all she had to help  someone in need. Now it's our turn to help her and her family.

name: Andrew's Fight Against Leukemia
text: On January 19th 2018,  Andrew was diagnosed with B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B cell - A.L.L.). The doctors have shared that A.L.L. is extremely rare in adults (this is usually only seen in young children) and especially rare in those who are 28 years old and in top physical condition.  Andrew always stays in great shape so the diagnosis is even surprising to the doctors. The good news here, however, is that B cell - A.L.L. is supposed to be curable; so that’s our new goal.The plan of attack going forward makes a lot of sense: · Andrew’s bone marrow biopsy came back negative for the Philadelphia mutation. The doctors say that with the Philadelphia chromosome not being present Andrew may not need a stem cell transplant. Still too early to know for sure because we have to see how Andrew responds to the IV chemo. · Since Thursday (1/18/18) Andrew has been taking oral chemo and steroids. These medications have really been effective. His white blood cell count has dropped from 424,000 (normal is <10,000) to about 1 as of yesterday morning.  Again, this is a very good sign. His red blood cells and his platelets and many, many other tests are coming back strong.  More good signs.This past Tuesday, Andrew started with a spinal tap & direct chemotherapy treatment in his spinal cord. This is day one of what we are calling the 28-day war.· For the next ~28 days Andrew will be undergoing very aggressive chemotherapy treatments. This is our aggressive attack on his cancer cells using IV chemotherapy. The intent here is to kill off all cancerous white blood cells, red blood cells, stem cells and everything and anything in his body related to cancer. The end goal of this attack is 100% complete remission.· After we successfully achieve full remission, we enter into another phase whereby we want to maintain that full remission over time. Yes, this means more chemo, but perhaps we can get Andrew home during this ~9-week phase. Massachusetts General Hospital works right alongside the Karmanos Cancer Institute in Detroit.  Andrew’s doctors are starting to arrange treatments for him at Karmanos so he can come home for a while. Nothing like mom’s homemade cookies, Belgian sausage and cheesy potatoes to help him feel better! We’ll see if/when we can swing getting him home.· During that 9-week phase there will be some days where Andrew feels great and other days when Andrew feels very sick. We will play it day-to-day, keep asking God for His grace & blessings and thank Him for all we’ve already achieved.· Should we successfully achieve 9 weeks of maintained remission, then we enter the next, more prolonged phase. This is when Andrew should be able to get back to work while still maintaining a rather less taxing chemo treatment schedule.  Nothing 100% guaranteed but step by step. ·Andrew will be undergoing chemotherapy for the next 2.5 years. He will lose his hair. He will be physically and emotionally challenged by his cancer and the life-saving treatments he has ahead of him. It will not be easy. Although his insurance will help him cover a lot of the medical expenses (estimated to be around 1 million dollars in cost), the co-pay over the next 2.5 years is nearly $25,000 out of pocket. Unfortunately, Andrew will not be able to work until further notice making it difficult to cover these costs. Please help us help Andrew during this difficult time. We appreciate all the love and support. Andrew is strong and he will get through this, but he won't be able to do it without the support of his family, friends and God.  He will fight this fight, come out strong & beat this cancer. "Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go."

name: Sylvia's War Against Leukemia
text: Life changing events happen too fast. “Your daughter is very sick, she’ll get through today. But, the future, we just don’t know.” the doctor said looking at Sylvia’s blood counts. This was the first indication that her situation was not going to be simple.Sylvia is the 4-year-old daughter of Maxine, who has been preparing to enter nursing school, and Charles, a disabled war veteran of both the U.S. Navy and the U.S. Army. Last November, Sylvia had to be taken to multiple doctors for issues resembling different infections, and then finally anemia. A week and a half before Christmas 2018, she was diagnosed with Acute L Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) and emergency transported from St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, OK to St. Jude Medical Research Hospital in Memphis, TN to begin chemotherapy and other treatments. Both parents have had to completely put their careers on hold to be with their daughter in Memphis, leaving their family with no income, in order to insure that she has 24/7 care and attention. Sylvia’s older two siblings have had to move in with their grandmother in Oklahoma to continue school throughout this processThe St. Jude staff is amazing, and constantly saying that they are in love with Sylvia’s positive and playful attitude. Treatment has been rough on Sylvia due to the fact that her blood has a specific antibody that makes finding supplemental red cells harder, as well as discovering allergies to certain chemotherapy medications.It is nearly impossible to map out what lies ahead. Charles and Maxine were informed they will have to heavily modify the house, that they currently have on a rent to own contract, in order to keep infections and germs away, or forfeit everything that they have invested to relocate. They will have to maintain a near sterile environment, while attempting to accommodate a childhood that is as normal as possible.All donations received will be used as follows:1. Cover any medical situation or supplies outside of the scope of what’s covered by St. Jude.2. Either effect modifications and improvements to their current house, or relocate to a house where no modifications are necessary.3. Dependable transportation enabling Sylvia’s movement between their home, the Saint Francis Hospital in Tulsa where will be doing her chemo and regular checkups, and St. Jude in Memphis where she will be required to go monthly to assess herprogress over the next three years.4. Meals and fuel while going to and from Saint Francis and St. Jude throughout her treatment timeline.Thank you for reading! Thank you for your support.   Please share!***Sylvia Warren is our four-year old niece. She loves to dance, to sing. She loves to play with her sister and brother and all her pets. Sylvia has an amazingly sweet and happy smile that will warm anyone’s heart.  Just before Christmas of 2018,  she was diagnosed with Leukemia .  This is  Sylvia's story.

name: Team Aidan! Help him fight Leukemia.
text: Aidan is such a sweet, loving and energetic 5 year old.  He always brightens everyone’s day with his contagious laugh and smile. He loves his family, going to church, friends and especially school.  (He is the first to run through the gate to start the day.)  2 weeks ago, he was playing and celebrating the holidays with his family.  Aidan was diagnosed this week with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (BALL).  With the help of modern medical advances Aidan’s prognosis is good however because of the advanced stage of his leukemia the doctors will be starting him on chemotherapy right away.   Aidan is an inspiration and is facing this bravely. His parents Frank and Corrie are receiving lots of love and moral support from friends and family.  Aidan has 2 brothers and 4 sisters. As you can imagine this is a very difficult time for his parents and siblings. His family has already spent many nights at the hospital by Aidan’s side to love him and support him.   As friends and family, we are also supporting them.   As courageous as Aidan and his family are being at this difficult time there is a long road ahead for Aidan to reach full recovery.  One of the ways we are trying to support this amazing family is by relieving some of the financial burden so that they can focus on Aiden and his health.  There will be many expenses, medications and time lost at work and the last thing we want them to worry about at this time is how they will pay their bills and cover the normal life expenses.  We are asking for your support.  Any amount you can donate would be greatly appreciated!! Love and Light!

name: Help Megan Fight Leukemia
text: In 2016, I was diagnosed with second stage, HER2+ breast cancer. As a healthy, active person my entire life, it was a shocking diagnosis but through multiple rounds of chemo and surgeries, my breast cancer successfully went into remission. You can read more about that here . In June 2018,  however, my body began to feel strange. My bones ached and walking on my right leg became difficult. They told me I had a pulled muscle - I like to run miles, go on rigorous hikes in the Columbia River Gorge, climb mountains. But I pushed for more tests and my oncologist advocated for them, pressing for answers because very quickly it became apparent that it wasn't just an athletic injury. The tests were fine at first but then...they weren’t. Then I was diagnosed with something crushing. Leukemia feels like a loaded word. I can’t quite wrap my head around it. I think about all of the other ways I wanted life to look like and couldn’t have imagined this in a million years. They tell me it's incredibly rare, less than 1% of cases, but that it happens and that it's a direct result of the chemo they gave me for breast cancer and that there's nothing I could have done to prevent it. UPDATE 1: I was immediately admitted to the hospital following my diagnosis and in-patient for 4-6 weeks for 7 days of continuous chemo while we wait for the results of my bone marrow biopsy to find out if I'll need a bone marrow transplant. In the past ten years, I've been busy building my career by going to grad school and working full-time in advertising and social media. I'm also an artist . However, in light of this ongoing, rigorous treatment for leukemia I've chosen to pause work for the moment and most likely won't resume for at least a year. UPDATE 2: Maintenance chemo took me back into the hospital but we're still in remission! UPDATE 3: The support has been absolutely overwhelming and I can't thank everyone enough for your generosity! We have a fundraiser coming up later this year, but in the meantime, it looks like I'm most likely need to have a bone marrow transplant. If you're curious, here are links to the national bone marrow database below. Consider signing up for the registry and donating today!  https://bethematch.org  https://bethematch.org/patients-and-families/about-transplant/what-is-a-bone-marrow-transplant UPDATE 4 (12/15): I'm successfully out of my bone marrow transplant! My Day Zero, my new Re-brthday!, happened the day before Thanksgiving and I spent about three and a half weeks total but am home now. Day +24! We're keeping an eye out for any complications but so far so good - I'm up and about walking every day, staying active, visiting with friends here at my house, and making art. Next big milestones: Get to Day 100 without major incident (that's a super crucial window right after a transplant), celebrate my birthday on February 14 and one year anniversary with my love, and a California road trip in April. Until then, it's one day at a time, eyes on the prize. The funds I raise here will help cover my medical bills that could eventually be more than $100k along with the $15k I still have from my breast cancer treatment. They'll help cover my living expenses and bills while I'm out of work with the most immediate needs covering housing, medical bills, and my car. This was not planned and it hurts my heart in so many ways to go through it again, but I've fought like hell before to heal and I'll do it again. I want this to mean something not only to me but to inspire everyone that's on this journey with me. Thank you for everything! Love to you all always.Xo - Megan http://megankrzmarzickart.com  http://instagram.com/messengerbird

name: Kacey Sanfilippo Leukemia Fund
text: On the 31st of March, the Sanfilippo Family were given the most devistating of news.  Their beautiful little girl, Kacey has Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  Kacey has been rushed to Brisbane to undergo further examination and commence treatment.Her mummy, Kirsten and her daddy, Dave are by her side.  At this stage, we don't know anymore about her Leukemia but we will be updating this page regularly.The sooner we can begin to raise funds, the sooner we can start helping the Sanfillipo family by way of providing meals to them at the Leukemia Foundation Accommodation so they can spend every waking minute only having to worry about their little girl.  We want to be able to assist financially to help keep Kaceys mummy and daddy by her side in Brisbane for as long as possible.  Their mortgage and bills are still going to roll in and with both of them off work, any assistance we can all provide will help to relieve some of the stress that this family is currently undergoing.  Any amount you can afford will help to put a smile back on little Kaceys face by keeping mummy and daddy close by her side.Please help.

name: Help little Khloe beat Leukemia
text: Help little Khloe beat LeukemiaPlease join us in supporting little Khloe.  She is only six years old and is fighting Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).  Her father is a disabled combat veteran who served in Afghanistan and her mother had to stop working to be by her side.  The family is incurring enormous expenses every day while Khloe has to undergo Chemotherapy in the hospital away from home.  The cost to fight this terrible disease is unknown at this time.  Our Family and Friends are pulling together to help this Family and Khloe overcome this difficult challenge.  Any donation that you can provide will help this Family immensely.  On behalf of Khloe, the Family wants everyone to know their hearts are overwhelmed by your generosity that will help in the continued fight against this tremendously difficult diagnosis.  Thank you and together we will beat this.  We love you Khloe---#KHLOE STRONG!!!!

name: Donate to Help Big Rob Beat Leukemia
text: So much of what we become in life is a consequence of our circumstances and luck - "though but for the Grace of God go I". My best friend Rob has led a tumultuous life. Adopted as an infant to a loving family who struggled to raise him, his life was torn apart when his little brother, addled on drugs, murdered his mother in cold blood in his boyhood home just before his 18th birthday. His adoptive father financially, but more important emotionally, abandoned Robert a year later, forcing Robert to go through life on his own with the exception of his friends and his loving Aunt. His finances have always been a struggle, living hand to mouth but developing the independence to maintain a job and car. In the last three years (he is now 41), his prospects much improved when he obtained health insurance managing a bar. He's the kind of loving, gregarious guy that will give you the shirt off his back.Now he needs help, and I'm hoping this venue can come through for him. In October he underwent surgery for routine inguinal hernia; surgery was complicated but he never really felt the same after the surgery. He's been in and out of the hospital since, with fever, malaise and body aches. Because of missing work, he was let go from his job. Yesterday a lymph node biopsy was positive for lymphoma versus leukemia, and his most immediate stress is how to finance treatment. The money raised here will go towards maintaining his insurance through COBRA so that he can receive chemotherapy and also for living expenses. Thank you for any support you can provide, any amount will help.

name: Help Deni and Skip fight leukemia
text: Dear friends, We are kindly asking you to help our friends Deni and Skip Gordon in their battle with cancer. As some of you already know on January 31st, 2017 Skip was diagnosed with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)- a slowly progressing and rare type of blood-cell cancer that starts in the bone marrow. 18 months later after 3 bone marrow biopsies and 2 types of chemo medication, his oncologist have reached the conclusion that in his case the only thing that can save him is a bone marrow transplant done as soon as possible. The team of doctors at Northside Cancer institute is confident that if Skip goes through the transplant procedure in the next few weeks he has 60-70% chance of being cured within a year- if he doesn't the prognosis is that his blood cells will continue to mutate untill he reaches a blast phase when nothing can be done to prevent the cancer from taking his life. Fortinately for Skip, his son Tate is a match and is willing to become a donor. Unfortunatelly, the recovery from such a complicated procedure is 6-12 months. Even if everything goes well, Skip will not be able to work or be in public for at least 6 months because he will have no immune system to protect him. He will need a 24 hour care giver to take him daily to the hospital for blood transfussions for a period of at least 3 months. His wife Deni will have to care for him and their 4 year old son, while trying to work and pay all the bills- a task almost impossible without some help from family and friends. We are asking you kindly to help this family financially survive this hard period in their lives. Let us take part of the burden they are facing and let us give them the piece of mind that at the end of the day they will have a roof over their heads and their utility bills will be paid so they can focus on getting Skip better and winning the fight against cancer! Please donate as much as you can and keep them in your prayers for we all know that cancer is something nobody is insured against and a battle nobody can fight alone! Help us give them hope, help us spread the word so more people can get involved in this cause and accept our gratitude on behalf of the Gordon family for all your generosity, prayers and support!

name: Help Aiden's Journey With Leukemia
text:
Aiden was diagnosed with T-ALL Leukemia on August 7, 2017 and began chemotherapy 2 days later. His overall treatment will last up to three years. Aiden has a mass tumor in his chest due to the cancer, that will shrink over time with Chemo. The diagnosis came as a complete surprise. Aiden was just getting ready to celebrate his 14th birthday August 11th and starting his first day of high school the 14th. 


Aiden is a charming, affectionate, creative, and a loving brother to his 3 siblings. Aiden was always seen participating in choir, school plays, and getting great grades. He already misses home, and has been positive so far with this diagnosis. He says everyday that "God is with me, and will heal me from this disease." We’re hoping to raise funds that can go towards Aiden's medical expenses, and his needs during this journey. As it's only just beginning, our family needs all the support we can get. Any donation will help our family out, including your prayers. 


Thank you.

name: Sofija's Leukemia Treatment USA
text: The Micevic family is raising money for their three-year old daughter, Sofija, in order for her to be treated for relapsed Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland, USA. This is the only available treatment in the world and their source of hope.  The family is entirely reliant on the aid and support of others to make this treatment possible. The treatment consists of two stages, the first costing $270,000 and the second, $500,000 for a bone marrow transplant. This is the cost of the medical treatment alone. Sofija is a vibrant and cheerful little girl who has suffered from leukemia on and off since she was 6 months old.  Time is of the essence- and her travel and treatment cannot begin until the funding goal is reached. Please help dear Sofija!Apel za pomoc: Porodici Micevic iz Banje Luke su potrebna sredstva za lecenje njihove trogodisnje cerke Sofije koja boluje od akutne limfoblastne leukemije. Lecenje ce se obaviti u bolnici Dzons Hopkins (Johns Hopkins) u Baltimoru, SAD. Ovo je jedina institucija koja je u stanju da obezbedi ovu vrstu tretmana.Porodica je u potpunosti zavisna od donacija kako bi se Sofiji omogucilo lecenje. Ceo proces sastoji se iz dve faze, gde prva kosta 270 000 USD, dok je druga faza transplantacija kostane srzi i kosta 500 000 USD.Ovo pokriva samo medicinske troskove.Sofija je zivahna i nasmejana devojcica koja boluje od leukemije od sestog meseca zivota.Vreme je od krucijalne vaznosti - njen dolazak i lecenje ne mogu da pocnu dok se ne sakupi novac.Pomozimo Sofiji!

name: Bryce's Journey to Beating Leukemia
text: As some may know, (and many may not), a little over a week ago Bryce was taken to the Palmetto Health Children's Hospital because of severe pain and the inability to sit upright, stand, or walk. After numerous tests, and several days in the hospital, on March 13th, 2018 our baby boy Bryce was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL). Initially, it was devastating. Mind crippling. We could not fathom that our boy, our son, was diagnosed with such a thing at the age of 3yrs old.  Its something no parent ever wants to hear. But as Isaiah 53:5 says, "But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon Him; and with His stripes we are healed.". And I believe with all my heart he will be healed. In Jesus Name. As a result, Bryce has began chemotherapy treatments to treat the Leukemia and is scheduled to continue them for several months going forward. This diagnosis came 2 days before we were scheduled to relocate to the DMV area as his parents had accepted positions in Washington, DC. Of course this has put a hold on the move, as well as I, his mother, will be no longer able to work. I will be the primary caregiver for my son during this time. We have been contacted by several friends and family members wanting to help, so we have created this GoFundMe to help with expenses associated with his future care, as well as his transfer to the Washington National Children's Hospital in a couple weeks. It may not be an ideal situation, but we are ready to take this thing head on. #LeukemiaWillNotWin #BryceStrong #PrayersForBryce #TheMiracleofBryce

name: Team Carters Fight against Leukemia
text: ​     Hello my name is Carter Michael Wheeler and I am 10 months old, on 10/31/16 I was diagnosed with cancer. My mommy and daddy are Stephanie and Michael Wheeler of Dartmouth, MA. ​     As I am sure you have figured this out, I am much too young to have written this, but my friends at With All My Heart Daycare wanted to help.  ​Carter was not feeling well on Monday 10/31, when his parents took him his to pediatrician.  This is where a routine doctor visit took a turn no parent ever wants to hear and immediately off to Charlton hospital for blood work. The pediatrician called an hour later to have us go to the children’s hospital.  Tests were run, analyzed and result were AML: Acute Myeloid Leukemia , changing this young families life in a heartbeat.  This is where we, his daycare providers decided to step in and ask for your help with this young family.  As with every family they are not asking for help, they are focused on helping Carter fight and beat this disease, but with the extensive medical, travel expenses that inevitably add up quickly we asking for your help.  100% of the money collected will be donated to the family to assist with any hardships and expenses that may result from their battle, during Carters road to recovery. ​Thank you in advance for your donations and remember the amount doesn’t matter it all adds up and will help this courageous baby and his parents stay focused and fight.   We will continue to post updates as they are made available.

name: Griffin Slezewski - Beat Leukemia
text: Sunday January 27th, Griffin and family received news that no one ever wants to hear. Griffin was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.The Slezewski Family can’t thank everyone enough for the tremendous outpouring of love and support. God bless you all!Griffin's chemo is slated to begin today, Tuesday the 29th. While the chemo “should” kill all the bad blood cells, it will also kill his good white blood cells, which are the ones that fight off infection, so he will be extremely high risk for other issues. He is expected to be hospitalized for pretty much the entire course of treatments, which will take 5 months! The first 28 days will tell us a lot, because every patient responds a little bit different. We pray for the best.This will be a long hard road for Griffin and family. Prayers are most important, and good medical care which I'm sure he will recieve, but this will also incur substantial cost as insurance only covers a small portion of the costs for this extended treatment. Please join me in providing financial support as well as prayers and good wishes. The wrestling community is a brother and sisterhood, so I ask that family for support as well. We will also formulate an event in the coming months.

name: Hunter's Leukemia Battle
text: October 10, 2018 Hunter was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Acute Myeloid Leukemia is a cancer of the myeloid line of blood cells, characterized by the rapid growth of abnormal cells that build up in the bone marrow and blood and interfere with normal blood cells. Symptoms may include feeling tired, shortness of breath, easy bruising and bleeding, and increased risk of infection. AML progresses rapidly very rapidly. If it was not for an infection that brought him to the emergency room at Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville, Florida we would have never known. There is no genetic trend for Hunter's diagnosis, it was completely random. His first day being admitted he was having an internal breathing problem and was immediately put on oxygen. As of October 17, 2018 he was clear and was no longer dependent from an oxygen tank. He will be hospitalized for a month while starting chemotherapy which he is reacting well to. The treatment plan he is on is 7+3.  He will be receiving chemotherapy for seven days and the +3 is two rounds of chemotherapy for the first three days which leads to the four days of standard chemotherapy. The chemotherapy is continuous, twenty-four hours for the entire week. He was accepted in a clinical trial which is allowing him to receive the highest dose of stem cells starting October  23, 2018. After Hunter gets into remission he will be having to follow up monthly with chemotherapy. We would appreciate any donation to help assist the family with the financial burden. All funds raised will go directly to Hunter's medical costs and Hunter's family. On behalf of Hunter and his family, we appreciate and thank you for any support during this time of need.To help get the word out, please share the link to this campaign. Thank you!

name: Michaels Fight against Leukemia!
text: My 7 year old nephew Michael was diagnosed with Leukemia on August 7th after a fight with an infection that just wasn't getting any better. He has a long road ahead of him. Michael will undergo at least 6 months of chemotherapy & then the doctors will reevaluate his progress & decide where to go from there. During all of this, Michael will not be able to attend school this year, however his Mom will be "home schooling" him so he doesn't fall behind. Between doctors appointments & home schooling him & taking care of his 1 year old Sister, Michaels Mom Heather isn't going to be able to work much, if at all. My goal for this is to help them get by, to be able to keep their home & pay the bills until Michael BEATS this & my Sister is able to return to work! After already being off work for a few weeks things are already starting to fall behind! ☹️ Anyone who knows my Sister knows all of what she's been through with fighting breast cancer herself, just completing school with her Bachelors in Social Work & being a single Mom! She needs a break, and if I can do anything in the world it would be to help her make it through so they can live life happily again! I appreciate it, from the bottom of my heart anything & everything you all can do in donating & sharing! Much love ❤️

name: Help Luke Fight Leukemia
text: Luke Hayworth is an 8-year-old little boy whose energy, sweetness, and silliness bring joy and light to everyone he meets. On December 26th, his family's world was shattered when he was suddenly diagnosed with Leukemia. The road is going to be long and hard for our precious Luke. During this period he will be spending a lot of time in the hospital. We have created this page for the Hayworth family to allow them to focus on what's most important at this time--supporting Luke and being together as a family, not having to worry about anything else. This family has been uplifted and touched with the amount of support they have received from family and friends within the community. Please continue the positive thoughts, prayers, and love.  We sincerely thank those who are able to help support the Hayworth Family. If you are able, a donation in any amount would help their family tremendously.

name: Help Lockdown Leukemia
text: On April 13th 2018 I was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia or AML with Flt-3 mutation. I was immediately admitted into the hospital, it was a Friday. My world began to fall apart as they poked and proded. My body was suffocating and doctors didn't expect me to live through the night. The over population of white blood cells was preventing red blood cells from delivering oxygen to my organs so my body was shutting down. I didn't look ill and the only symptoms were like the flu or bronchitis until I was passing out and lethargic. The reality was the capillaries in my lungs were bleeding, I have damage to a valve in my heart from it overworking, my kidneys were shutting down and my spleen was enlarged. I lost my job and lost my home due to no longer being able to work. I stay with my young adult sons who struggle to make the ends meet. I've spent the last 8 months in and out of the hospital having high dose chemo, fighting fevers and infections from being neutropenic and fighting to live. I have good and bad days and I try to smile through the pain, nausea, fear and recently I began having tremors in my hands. I tire easily when out and about and it reminds me I'm not well when I try to forget. I need help since I've been unable to work it's not something I can manage alone. My best chance is a bone marrow transplant and there will be post operative living expenses to be able to stay near hospital.I lost my husband to a heart attack last year and my mom after 3 days in ICU so I have no outside financial support. So I'm reaching out to my friends and the kindness of strangers to meet my needs. I hope you can, every little bit helps. If you don't want to donate through gofundme you can find me on venmo app under @SabrinaWitherspoonif your unable to donate please share this fundraiser and help me that way. The more people that see it the better my chances and every dollar helps. thank you for all your love and support.

name: Morgan conquers leukemia
text: My Name is ciera Frison, and I’m writing this on behalf of my daughter Morgan Frison! Over the last 2 months, my husband and myself been back and forth to the doctor’s with concerns of something being terribly wrong with our daughter! It wasn’t until we were on our family vacation at Disney world that our life turned upside down with the phone call from an ER nurse stating we needed to get her to the children’s hospital because she has ACUTE MYELOID LEUKEMIA! We had just got off the ferry to enter into magical kingdom! We were devastated, with this leukemia comes a long stay in the hospital anywhere from 5 to 8 months! We are having to take leaves from our jobs and depend on family to help take care of our other kids!! We could use help with the daily expenses of traveling to see about our other children! Our son who’s 7, also has a blood disorder , hemophilia A which requires infusions 3x a week! We would appreciate your help, even if it’s just sharing this post!!! We would like the money to help with providing for our other kids, gas, food, remodeling of our home to be suitable for Morgan when’s she well enough to go home! Her cancer is acute, so it progresses fast, so they have to treat it aggressively! She has had 10 days of 3 different chemo medicines! Her body is resting now , so that her immune system can rise back up! When that happens, it’s gonna be a repetitive course of more chemo for the next couple of months! Thank you all in advance for your contributions!

name: Delaney's Fight with Leukemia
text: In each of our lives we grow accustomed to the concept of indefinite time, as few are born with a clock counting down the seconds. Maybe even to the point where we stop appreciating the seconds, minutes and hours that we are all afforded. Time gives us the ability to compile handfuls of instances over a lifetime that we are fortunate to reflect on. These memories sometimes bring smiles, some anger and some tears. We reflect on these memories and they help develop a timeline which we eventually call a life. Occasionally things happen that we cannot explain or justify and they tend to leave a lasting impression. We write to you with an appeal, an appeal for a little girl named Delaney Fate DeVerna born April 24, 2014. Those of you that are parents, grandparents and family members, can attest that the birth of a child is a moment in time, an instance, a memory that is everlasting. The anticipation of the many years that will follow can be nerve racking, challenging, but most of all rewarding. We all know that life can also bring the unexpected. On October 7, 2015 the unexpected happened, Delaney was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. During that year she went through multiple rounds of chemo and was flown to Denver Children's Hospital for a bone marrow transplant. Delaney is a fighter, Delaney never lost her smile, and nearly 10 months later Delaney was put into remission and was allowed to come home. On November 11, 2016 we found out that Delaney's Leukemia had returned. Since then Delaney was flown back to Denver Children's Hospital in hopes to get a 2nd bone marrow transplant. On March 23rd we received the most difficult news, the leukemia was no longer responding to treatment and under the advisement of her doctors, it was recommended that Delaney be allowed to return home. Our only goal now…. to provide Delaney with every smile, every hug, every kiss and as many precious memories that this little angel deserves. Life changes when time is no longer infinite, and as we begin to prepare we ask for your support. The upcoming expenses will be difficult, not only emotionally but financially and we ask that you please consider a donation. All donations will go directly to Delaney’s immediate care and eventually for her services. If you are not in a position to donate financially we only ask that you continue your prayers, continue your kindness, and continue your outpouring of love for this little girl!!

name: Help Cody's fight against leukemia
text: A few weeks ago 15 year old Cody Shutz was diagnosed with ALL acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Cody is a star player for the wunkar bulldogs football club and a student at the loxton high school. Cody and his mum Jo are now living down in Adelaide for the next 9 months maybe a year, Hopefully after his treatment finishes in Adelaide (around 9 months), the family might be able to go back to Riverland but Cody will still will be on tablet chemo they call maintenance with regular visits for another two years which will be a 3 year treatment plan all up.. I would like to help out Cody and his family get through the tough year ahead, any donation big or small would be much appreciated..

name: Help Landon's Fight Thru Leukemia
text: On Monday, January 16th, Landon spiked an extremely high fever. Typically we would let the fever play out over a few days with Tylenol and Motrin but this time Landon wasn't complaining of anything hurting or upsetting him. We took him to the Pediatricians office that afternoon and they ordered an Ultrasound which we completed on Tuesday and a Blood Test which was completed on Wednesday. The Pediatrician predicted that he had Mono (the kissing disease) which would cause his spleen and liver to be enlarged and cause him to spike a fever since his body was fighting a virus.After the blood work on Wednesday (January 18th), We received a call from the doctors office at 4:30PM saying his white blood cell count was a little high and his hemoglobin count was a little low which could indicate that he could be "anemic" but unfortunately we would need to go straight to the hospital as they were admitting him that night and a room would be waiting for us when we got there.As we sat in his hospital room waiting, it was becoming more and more clear that the staff around us knew more than we did. Landon was hooked up to IV’s and he would say repeatedly that he just wanted to go home but we could not confidently tell our son to not worry or that everything was going to be okay. As we sat there, the doctor came in and we could tell by the way that she was easing into the conversation that what we were about to hear was going to change our lives forever. That moment our entire world turned upside, medical words had no meaning to us, and we had to come to terms with the "C" word for our one and only 4 year old son.Landon had no idea that this meant no more school, hanging out with friends every weekend, sporadic Disney trips, or even trips to Target or Publix on a normal basis. He had no idea that every night or day was going to be a surprise and every moment after that would follow an on going doctors appointment which could be daily, weekly, or monthly, hospital trips at any moment, and chemo treatments frequently. How exactly do you tell a 4 year old this kind of news?The oncologist came in shortly after to confirm the diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). Landon's white cell count was as high as 71,000 (average children who get diagnosed are at 51,000) which made Landon in the high risk range. The following day we completed the port surgery, bone marrow, and our first spinal tap to start treatment. After constant prayer, we did hear a gleam on good news which was that there were no signs of Leukemia in his spinal fluid or organs. However, we will still face an going treatment plan for the next 3.5 years until we are in the maintenance zone.This was an unexpected shock for our Family and something that we will have to cope with on a daily basis. However we have to try our best to deal with what has been presented to us, God doesn't give you anything that he doesn't think you can handle. In only the short amount of days we have found out this tragic news, we can not express to you how many heart broken nights of trying to make sense of all this, or count how many buckets of tears that we have shed. We are done asking “why” or “how” we are now determined and focused on “when”. “When” he beats this and "When” he will look back and know that he made it through this. On that note, we want to make sure Landon does not go with out and to do whatever we can make sure this never comes back. This means on going medical bills, medications, time off work, or any other essentials that our Family may need to help Landon. Our insurance indicates that we will have to pay $10,000 for our out of pocket maximum annually which I am sure we met on our first night of 10 days at the hospital. (one of many trips to come, I am sure). Although we are prepared to face this we also know there will be many unknowns and more battles than there are victories. Landon is also not the only kid having to battle this disease and our goal is not to just fight for Landon but to also raise awareness and give whatever we can to also help others just like him. We truly believe that there was a reason that this happened and it’s god’s will to use Landon as a vehicle to create a community for families just like ours and to put a smile on every kids face as they battle this disease. We would like to thank all of our family, friends, co-workers, and strangers that have showed us such tremendous love and support through this entire process. It would be an understatement if we said that we were surprised by the amount of love that has been shown for Landon and for our family. Thank everyone for there prayers and whatever act kindness that can be done for our sweet boy. We expect to do another bone marrow test at the end of our first 29 day introduction phase to see what the next course of action may be.We will update everyone as we know more through our journey. #teamlandon

name: Help Kevin Beat Leukemia!
text: Help Kevin Beat Leukemia!For the past 2 years, Kevin has been studying communications and journalism at UNC Wilmington. He loves being at the beach and when he isn’t in school or working his part time job, he enjoys playing on intramural sports teams at school and hanging out with friends. In July, Kevin noticed some strange symptoms in his body. He had lip/jaw numbness, muscle pain in his arms and legs, heart palpitations, swollen lymph nodes and shortness of breath…. to name a few.He went to his primary care doctor, immediate care, an ENT, cardiologist, oral surgeon, and a neurosurgeon. No doctor could diagnose his symptoms. Each doctor had a different answer, and all seemed to think it was of little concern.Each sleepless night of worry and pain led him to continue in his pursuit for answers. As we prayed fervently for answers and healing, God stepped in right on time.Kevin would have been in Wilmington had the hurricane not evacuated his home and school. Thankfully, he was home on Monday, September 17, when he began hurting in his chest and was unable to catch his breath while lying on his right side. He and his parents went to the emergency room in Wilson to get help. FINALLY, a PA there found a mass near his lungs and noticed that his right lung was partially collapsed. He was immediately transferred to Wake Med. Many tests including a biopsy, CT scan, and extensive MRI were done. The results of these tests were alarming, and he was transferred to Chapel Hill to the NC Cancer Hospital. Based on a PET scan, bone marrow biopsy and lumbar puncture, he was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).As you can imagine, for any 20-year-old and his family, the news seemed unreal and devastating. He’s not suppose to have cancer, he’s suppose to be planning and preparing for the rest of his life--NOT fighting for it. Kevin began chemotherapy on Saturday September 26, his first round of many. He’ll be in the hospital for the next 4 weeks undergoing grueling treatments, as they aggressively try to cure him of this disease. After the 4 weeks, he’ll have 6-8 months of traveling back to Chapel Hill 2-3 times per week for more treatments and then he’ll enter a 3-5 year maintenance phase.This will be a long road to recovery! Day by day, God gives him and his family small miracles and so much strength. They are trusting in His plan and know He will work all of this for Kevin’s good.No one knows what all this will cost, but everyone can agree that he or his family should not struggle with the worry of the upcoming medical bills, lost wages, travel expenses and all the costs that come along with the road ahead. We should be the community of support for Kevin and his family during this journey. Let’s join together in uplifting them. We can do this in 3 ways:1) Support the “Help Kevin Beat Leukemia!” Go Fund Me2) Share the Go Fund Me page on your social media outlets.3) And Most Importantly, PRAY!!!Any support that you can give Kevin and his family will be much appreciated. Every thought, prayer, positive vibe and contribution (big or small) will help Kevin and his family stay strong! We serve a GREAT BIG GOD who, through us, can bless this family in their darkest hour!T-shirts are now available as another way to support Kevin. #weALLfighttogether Please follow the link to order!  https://kaa-weallfighttogether.itemorder.com/sale

name: Help *Nash Alkire* Make Leukemia Extinct
text: Nash Alkire is 2.5 years old and has been diagnosed with Leukemia. Even with health insurance, the cost for his treatment plan over the next 3 years, and maintenance after, is overwhelming. Your financial donation will enable Nash's parents to focus on loving and supporting him while he gets well, with less worry about the cost. Mason and Brandi are currently traveling between home and hospital, a one hour commute, to maintain caring and raising their 4 month old daughter, Walker, as well. Your generosity will help not only with medical expenses, but also all the incidentals from daily travel and being away from home.If you make a donation of $50 or more, please complete this survey:  https://goo.gl/forms/ShS8ft1o5IbcyBM42. You will receive a small token of our appreciation for your support.If you would prefer to make a monthly donation, please complete this survey:  https://goo.gl/forms/ShS8ft1o5IbcyBM42 and you will be emailed a monthly invitation. Thank you for your kindness and generosity! ￼￼

name: Johnny's 3rd Leukemia Battle
text: Hello,My name is Cathy Reid-Satchell and I am a close and personal friend of  Sharon, John & Johnny Van Kemp. I first met Sharon through our former pastor while Johnny was towards the end of his 1st battle with Leukemia. Sharon and I became  fast friends and since then, I have grown extremely close to the entire family.   I have written the story below as I have experienced this long journey to cure Johnny alongside the Van Kemp's. By starting this GoFundMe campaign...it is just one of the many ways that I can help my friends by donating myself and asking those with giving hearts to donate as well.  Please consider donating as you read Johnny's journey. Johnny’s cancer is back” are the words that  I truly did not expect to hear only just six months after Johnny completed his second fight for his life to beat ALL - Type B Leukemia.                                           Johnny was first diagnosed with leukemia in April of 2012. He ended treatment after  3+ years in June of 2015 and fought with such determination and faith. The Ironman of Summerfield knocked out Leukemia! Johnny’s parents, Sharon & John, could breath again. They all enjoyed 10 months of “normal life” before their lives came crashing down on them once again. In April of 2016 they received news that the cancer had relapsed and Johnny was thrown back into the fight for his life. After two years of harsh treatments, Johnny showed all who know him what a strong & faithful young man he was. By May of 2018, the Ironman of Summerfield's record was now 2-0 against his tough opponent & the Van Kemp’s were on top of the world. John & Sharon planned a summer of fun for Johnny who had spent the better of six years  in and out of Brenner’s Children Hospital. They wanted Johnny to enjoy every minute he could before he became a High School freshman in the fall and they succeeded - big time.  Refreshed and renewed - Johnny became a proud Northern High School NightHawk.  He completed the 1st portion of drivers training and enjoyed his first Homecoming.  Johnny became a "young man" before we knew it. His eyes were bright, his smile infectious, his faith even stronger.  Monthly check-ups are the norm for someone who completes cancer treatment...and appointment after appointment.  Johnny and his parents were told that his body was getting stronger and stronger.  During his 6th month check-up, October 23, 2018  - Johnny heard the news he never, ever, ever thought he would hear again. “The cancer is back.” Shock. Horror. Disbelief. Tears. Every emotion overtook Johnny and his parents. Their lives shattered in a million pieces...again. AGAIN! For the third time in Johnny’s short 14 years, they met devastation face to face. Pure devastation. From the outside, it may look to you like the VK’s have the best in life. Yet, if you were able to peek through a window of their life, you would see how broken beyond belief they are. John & Sharon have watched their only son, who began life on this earth fighting for his life as he was born pre-mature, endure once again intense harsh treatments - trying to kill the bad while not destroying all that is good inside of him. They have watched their son sit on the sidelines of life as others his age experienced the fullness of childhood & become teenagers. They have watched their son sit in the barbers chair to have his head shaved twice already and see Johnny’s self esteem fall on the floor along with locks of his hair. They have held Johnny’s head while sickness overcomes him and run to the “chemo closet” in their home to clean up the mess in the dead of night. They have seen their son look them in the eye and cry out to them - “I just want to survive” & “Save me.”  To say these past 6+ years have been magical - the farthest thing from it.  This new fight, his third, is going to be Johnny’s toughest yet. Your prayers along with words of hope & encouragement would be greatly appreciated as we walk along side Johnny.  Pray that God will give him the strength he will need to get through this next year(s)in order to reach the goal of healing. Pray that God will cradle Sharon & John with love and guide them as they make the best decisions for Johnny... as well as staying faithful as they endure the pain of witnessing their son fight through this battle once again.  As I mentioned, this is going to be the toughest of fights that Johnny & his parents have had to face. It is going to take all of their family, friends and community’s support to keep them lifted up.  The day he learned that his cancer had returned, October 23rd of this year (2018), he and his parents were told to go home immediately, pack some things and return to be admitted to the hospital. They were told that he would have to remain in the hospital for the next 26 days in which Johnny would receive his 3rd chest port in order to begin harsh chemotherapy. Johnny completed those 26 days but not easily. He experienced the expected side effects along with losing over 20 pounds, became extremely weak and frail, and lost a good amount of his hair. He contracted some type of infection in his sinus area which gave him extreme pain in the right side of his face. After many tests and medications, the infection subsided and non to soon. The day we brought him home, he could barely walk. Since he returned home he has begun to regain the weight he lost and is slowly building his strength. Of course his mother Sharon and father John are doing whatever they need to do to get him as strong as possible for the next phase of treatment. While in the hospital, the Van Kemp's learned that Johnny could be a candidate for  CAR - T Immunotherapy which would take place in Philadelphia. After many discussions and the meeting of certain requirements, Johnny was accepted at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP).  Thank You God!!!  On December 3rd, Johnny and his parents will travel to CHOP for the beginning phases of this new type of treatment for Johnny.  The entire treatment period will be separated into two sections. The first, Johnny will need to be in Philly for almost a week to extract his T-Cells. The cells will be sent away to be "harvested" and will take about 4-8 weeks to do so in which Johnny will continue with maintenance chemo at home while waiting to return back to CHOP for the actual treatment. Once back at CHOP, Johnny and his parents could possibly be required to stay there for 6-8weeks. As thankful as Johnny and his parents are for this amazing opportunity for a forever cure, the financial burden will be extreme. Hotel costs, meals, rental car, etc. will all be a factor during this process not to mention the stresses associated with the upcoming medical bills, the current medical bills still arriving from Johnny's 2nd battle with cancer. Your funds, so graciously donated to Johnny’s Leukemia Fund, will help ease this financial burden.   Showering them in love... especially in prayers and your funds, so graciously donated to Johnny's Leukemia Fund,  will help remove the added stress so that John & Sharon can focus soley on Johnny and winning this fight for his life.  If you would like to stay up-to-date on Johnny’s progress, you may join the “Prayers for Johnny Van Kemp” on Facebook or Johnny’s Caringbridge page at:   https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/johnnyvankemp. If you donate to Johnny’s Leukemia Fund on GoFundMe, you will receive regular updates directly as they are submitted.  Johnny’s Faith is strong and he knows God will see him through this.  In gratitude and love, Cathy SatchellFriend of Johnny, Sharon & John Van Kemp

name: Logan's Leukemia Fund
text: Monday morning Logan woke up and didn’t seem like he felt well. He was pale and we were concerned. We got him into the pediatrician to find out his liver and spleen were enlarged. The pediatrician sent us to smh for blood work and ultrasound. The blood work came back and wasn’t good. They immediately admitted us to All Children’s hospital in st Pete at that point we knew it wasn’t going to be good. Fast forward through MANY tears, heartbreak, long hours, no sleep, minimal food, tests, blood work, and boat loads of information..... Logan was diagnosed with a rare form of Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia. Our hearts sank and the tears didn’t stop. We were scared and could only think “why us.” Logan began treatment on Tuesday night and we are asking for prayers to heal our lil boy. We will eventually start a separate Facebook page to report Logan’s progress and updates. Please keep us in your thoughts and prayers as we begin this long journey.  #prayforlogan #teamlogan

name: Help Bella Beat Leukemia!
text: Bella Serino is my 4 year old niece, and was diagnosed with TCLL, or T-Cell Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia in December 2017. She immediately began treatment at Providence Hospital in Anchorage. Her parents are my brother Darryl and sister-in-law Laurie, and they have lived in Barrow, AK for 13 years. Darryl is the pastor of Calvary Bible Baptist Church and volunteers as coach, equipment and ice rink manager for the youth hockey team, the Barrow Blizzard. Laurie is the city's go-to cake decorator, day-care provider, and is always right beside Darryl helping with church ministries, hockey, and being a huge positive energy in the community. They homeschool their children Micah (16), Jeremiah (15) Joshua (13) and Bella. Bella has undergone treatment that included chemotherapy and steroids. The first chemo treatment had the goal of getting her white blood cell count to drop from 800,000 to 50,000. This happened so much faster than anticipated that the doctors were shocked and said they had never seen a child respond so quickly! But ever since we first heard Bella was sick we reached out for prayer, and received a huge outpouring of love and support in return as Bella was lifted up in prayer by so many of you. Bella and the family are now headed to OHSU Doernbecher Children's Hospital in Portland, Oregon for a bone marrow transplant, donated by her oldest brother Micah. They will stay about 3 months after the procedure so Bella can be watched closely for side effects from the transplant. Medicaid has covered the majority of medical expenses and they will be able to stay at a Ronald McDonald House in Portland, but there are many additional expenses that will occur in moving, feeding and caring for the entire family as well as little Bella. If you would consider donating any amount to help with the costs of travel, food, and the many other needs that will pop up throughout Bella's time in the hospital, it would be so greatly appreciated! We cannot say enough how much your thoughtfulness and prayers mean to all of us as we help support Bella and her family during this time!

name: Jasmine's Leukemia Journey
text: Jasmine has just been diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Doctors are not sure of the severity at this time but the first course of treatment will be chemotherapy which begins on Tuesday January 22nd.Let's support Jasmine, Christine, Brad, Eli, and family through our prayers, donations, love, and support. If you would like to follow Jasmine’s Journey, Jasmine’s aunt Jessie will be blogging, providing updates, photos, stories and encouragement.Please follow this link to Jasmine’s Journey: http://jasminesjourney.ca/ Please join Jasmine's Army facebook group The army of prayer warriors, encouragers, intercessors, friends and family, who are upholding Jasmine Adams and her family as she and Jesus battle her leukaemia!  https://www.facebook.com/groups/600448343724813/ If you are interested in helping with meals a meal train has been set up, please keep in mind Christine and Eli have food allergies so please make meals gluten and dairy free and if possible freezer friendly.  To sign up please see the link:  http://mealtrain.com/8dq151

name: Help Bella Battle Leukemia
text: This page was created for my daughter Isabella Ward, aka Bella. She was diagnosed with a rare type of cancer on December 9th, 2013 at the age of 3. Bella was diagnosed with Acute Promyeloctic Leukemia (APML). Please help as much as you can. Every penny counts and helps our family during this difficult time. It will help with medical care, living expenses, and anything Bella might need. Thank you!! <3

name: Alexander's fight against Leukemia
text: Meet Alexander. A sweet, kind hearted 7 year old full of love and positivity. He attends le Coeur du Nord school in Kapuskasing as a second grader. He is the son of Maxime Bélanger and Tori O'Hanley.Just a few days ago Alexander Belanger's world was completely changed. He was air lifted to CHEO in Ottawa where doctor's confirmed his diagnosis: acute lymphoblastic leukemia.He has already begun treatment. He received the news yesterday that he will call the hospital home for at least the next 6 months. He is unable to come back home until then. The battle has begun for this brave little soul. As his teacher, i am pleading with everyone out there to give out donations. A little goes a long way to help out this family. Especially with the holidays coming up, we need to come together as a community to help out this wonderful little boy. Please keep Alexander in your thoughts and prayers. He will need all of our support.

name: Isaac’s Battle Against Leukemia
text: On July 13th 2018 my 17 year old brother Isaac Buchanan was diagnosed with Acute T-Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia. This day of course came very unexpected and changed every aspect of his and our family’s lives as we had known it to be. Within hours of finding out this news he was admitted into the hospital and a treatment plan was in place within a couple days. So far Isaac has had bone marrow biopsies, lumbar punctures, chemotherapy, and blood transfusions. This week will be the beginning of cranial radiation. Isaac will not be able to attend school for at least 8 months, he is doing an independent study program from home to help him stay on course to be able to graduate with Class of 2019 at Poway High School. Isaac will be in treatment for his condition for the next 3 years. As one can imagine the expense of treatment can be very costly. I am setting up this gofundme account to help my family with medical expenses. Any donation is greatly appreciated. Please keep Isaac in your prayers.

name: Fulfill wishes of cancer patient
text: Update: Funeral Services were completed as planned. Suresh family convey their heartfelt thanks for all your prayers, wishes and support during this tough time. Please keep them in your Prayers. Update: I am deeply saddened to inform that Suresh  passed away this early morning May 15th 2018 at 01.17AM in Fairfax INOVA Hospital. Please keep him and his family in your prayers.Funeral Services will be held on Thursday May 17 2018, at Adams-Green Funeral Home 721 Elden Street, Herndon, VA 20170.  www.adamsgreen.com  • 12:00 Noon to 1:00 PM Visitation• 1 PM to 2:00 PM Eulogy and Tributes• 2:00 PM to 2:30 PM Religious Services • 2:30 PM to 3:00 PM CremationAs of May 09 2018, our friend Suresh Subramaniam has been given 4 to 8 weeks to live and his last wishes are to pay off his outstanding medical bills and to provide education and basic financial coverage for his two girls.#HelpSureshFamilyInVirginiaSuresh has been fighting with blood cancer (Acute Myeloid Leukemia along with Myelo dysplasia Syndrome) since August 2017. He has undergone several chemo therapies along with other treatments to fight this cancer. He was waiting for a stem-cell transplant in January 2018 and while waiting his condition worsened and unfortunately, he is not able to recover from the treatment and is no longer a good candidate. While under continued treatment at Inova Hospital, he contracted fungal pneumonia and his condition worsened rapidly which shattered all the hopes of his successful treatment and survival. At this point oncologists have run out of treatment options and Suresh has been given only few more weeks to live.  This is his second fight with cancer. He was diagnosed with throat cancer with acute Laryngitis in May 2012. After intense treatments for more than a year he won the battle and started his normal activities in 2013.  His family was hopeful they had overcome all the emotional and financial hardships they had faced but the relapse has shattered their hopes of recovery.   Suresh and his family are devastated and are in dire need of our help in this unfortunate situation. I’ve known Suresh and family for more than 20 years.  They are extremely nice people and it is heartbreaking to see Suresh in this condition. His wife Jothi has been forced to take the whole responsibility of taking care of Suresh, their daughters and her elderly mother. I have created this GoFundMe to help them with the medical bills and their children’s educational expenses. All funds collected will go directly to the Suresh family. Any help you are able to give them is greatly appreciated.  Anyone willing to send checks can reach out to me at 703-989-5321, Karthik Govind at 703-856-6754 or Kumar at 848-248-6735 for mailing address.  About Suresh Subramaniam & his family Suresh Subramaniam (54 years) was born and brought up in Pollachi, a small town in Coimbatore District of Tamil Nadu in India. He did his Master’s Degree at PSG College of Technology in Coimbatore. He is married to Jothi who is also from Coimbatore and is living in Virginia, USA. Their elder daughter is a sophomore at VCU and the younger daughter is a 9th grader at Chantilly High School. Jothi does not have a steady job now due to having to take care of Suresh. Jothi’s elderly mother lives with them. Please help this wonderful family. If you can make a monetary contribution, please do, and spread the word.  It is in these difficult times of sadness when you see people coming together to help one another make it through, to support the people we care for. We are thankful for any support you may be able to provide.

name: 4 leukemia
text: Our friend Josie has been diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia .  She has been in the hospital for weeks receiving chemo. It’s going to be a battle but she is a fighter and she will win. It will be a roller coaster ride but our Diva will hold on, she always does. Let’s fight AML together #cancersucks#leukemia#chemo

name: Jerry Garcia - Leukemia Warrior
text: My father, Jerry Garcia, was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) in May of 2017. Despite the countless burdens that came along with the chemotherapy and cancer, my father remained steadfast in his faith, hope, love and positive mindset until his final moments. My father was a kind-hearted, level-headed and full of life man. He was a Jack-of-All trades. He was a man of God, a family man, an exceptional bowler, singer/musician, artist, car lover, handyman, hard worker, adventurer, lover of the outdoors, jokester, husband, brother, father and friend. It was a rare moment if you ever found him NOT singing karaoke, polishing his bowling ball, working on house projects, having a cup of coffee with my mother and cracking jokes/telling stories with my brothers and I. Although my father has recently passed in his battle with cancer on October 4th, 2018, his love and selflessness will continue to flourish throughout our family and friends. His actions and character have positively impacted the lives of those around him.  He treated all those he encountered with respect and continually put others before himself. He was an angel to walk this Earth as he always lent a helping hand to those in need. To further honor his name and legacy, our family is asking for financial assistance to provide him with a proper burial and funeral service by October 26, 2018.  If you'd like to donate please feel free to, we would greatly appreciate it! If not, please send good energy, prayers and support for my family during this time, it is extremely welcomed. Much love and God Bless. Thank you.

name: Donovan diagnosed with Leukemia
text: On Thursday night, our 9 year old son Donovan was diagnosed with AML-Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  He came into the hospital with a white blood cell count of 138,000 which is over 10 times the amount of normal range.  He has developed an enlarged lymph node on his neck which has been causing him  severe pain and keeping him sedated most of time.I have been at my son's bedside day and night helping him stay strong during his aggressive chemo treatment and my husband has had to take time off of work to take care of the rest of our kids who include Donovan's twin sister Rhiannon, and his brothers Aidan age 8 and Dorian age 13.We haven't had much time to process everything but know that once Paul's leave benefit runs out we won't be able to pay for any type of childcare while Donovan and I are at the hospital or even begin to cover the medical bills for him to continue to receive treatment, especially once we begin to consider bone marrow transplant costs, hospital stays, and other expenses involved in our fight.We are asking for your help to ensure we are able to provide the best care for Donovan for the next few months while we work hard to fight against this ugly disease.  We have our prayer warriors supporting us and asking God to heal him and help him stay strong in his fight.The family is available and willing to answer any and all questions.We have created a Facebook page to keep everyone posted about how Donovan is doing.  You can follow us at: Donovan’s Facebook page  https://www.facebook.com/Donovans-Infinity-War-Against-Leukemia-338253636646594/Thanks again for your donations!The Bayze Family

name: Missy's Fight Against Leukemia Fund
text: To all of the #MissyStrong supporters - Missy's fight is not yet over and we are looking to rally behind her once again while she battles this recent relapse with Leukemia.Missy found out late last week that her cancer has returned.  On Monday her doctors revealed their treatment plan, which will include a trial treatment with two different oral chemotherapy medications.  Missy will need to make trips back and forth to Mass. General Hospital twice a week over the next 5 weeks as part of her plan.    We are hopeful and optimistic that this trial treatment will kick her Leukemia back into remission.  From what I have been told, these drugs have a 30% success rate.  This number may not sound as high as we would like but we have all witnessed Missy tackle tougher statistics then this!  Right now we are looking to raise some additional funds to offer financial support to Missy and her family during treatment and recovery.  Once again, Missy will be facing added expenses and a prolonged loss of income.  The amount of support we were able to provide thorough this campaign last year was instrumental in relieving some of the extra stress in her life.  I can only hope this small gesture can provide the same level of relief this time around, so her family can focus on the emotional and physical support Missy needs as they face tough times ahead.  Any amount of help is greatly appreciated no matter how small.  We are also looking for volunteers that can assist with bringing Missy to her appointments at Mass General in Boston, and/or anyone that can stay with her three children while Jose brings her.  Most importantly, please continue to send Missy encouragement and positive energy!            I will update again as I get more information Original Message:Melissa Smith is a funny, kind-hearted and loyal friend/sister/daughter/mother.  If you know Missy you would have to agree that she has a true passion for making everyone around her laugh.  She has devoted her time to caring for others and is the first one to help a person in need.  Unfortunately we received some unimaginable news yesterday.  Missy has been diagnosed with a cancer of the blood and bone marrow called Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  She began Chemotherapy this morning and will have a bone marrow biopsy to determine the exact type, etc.     We don't know much at this point, but we do know that Missy has a long journey in front of her.  Many of you have asked how you can help through this difficult time.  We have set up this GoFundMe account to help her and her family while she undergoes treatment.  Your kind donations will provide support with the care of her three small children, unexpected medical bills and lost wages so that Missy can receive the best possible treatments without worrying about the financial burdens. The love and support behind Missy is very strong.   Continue to keep her in your thoughts and prayers.  Keep sending her your love and positive energy.  Thank you so much for your generous donations.  Each little bit helps.  Together we can help her beat this.  #MissyStrong!

name: Please help Miles beat leukemia
text: This is my nephew Miles. He turned 2 years old 9 days ago and today was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and it has spread throughout his entire body so he is now fighting for his life. Yesterday he had a bone marrow biopsy and a platelet transfusion. Today he was diagnosed and had an echocardiogram done to see if his heart is strong enough to withstand the intense chemo treatments that he will need. Tomorrow he is having a port placed and a lumbar puncture so they can inject chemo into his spinal column. He then has to start daily chemo into his port which is going to make him very ill and he will likely be unable to eat and need a feeding tube. He will be in the hospital for 9 months in a private room where the air is filtered to hopefully prevent him from catching any illnesses as the chemo destroys his immune system, leaving him unable to fight off any illnesses. That is a lot for a 2 year old to have to endure so he will need his parents at his bedside to help him recover. In addition to all of those things, he will be needing many more tests, blood transfusions, procedures, etc. His parents, Jake and April, will be out of work for that time to care for him and in addition to a very large hospital bill they still have all of their expenses at home, gas money, food, etc. I ask that you please not contact them directly at this time as this is an extremely difficult time for them and they are needing to spend all of their time with Miles. Instead, I will be updating this site with any new information and we will also be starting a caring bridge website. Miles' parents would be humbled by anything you could donate on his behalf. Please keep them in your thoughts and prayers. Thank you!

name: Battle Against Leukemia
text: On Monday, November 26th, 2018 my sister took my 2 year old niece to the doctor for what she thought would be a routine appointment. After doing some blood work the doctor entered the room with a concerned look and stated my niece needed to be admitted to the Pediatric ICU immediately, as he suspected she may have leukemia. After rushing to the hospital, where they ran several additional tests it was confirmed that 2 year old, Mae did in fact have Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Mae will have to endure 8 months of what they consider intense chemotherapy treatments, each week, followed by 2 years of monthly maintenance chemotherapy treatments. She will also have to take several medications daily.As it was explained to us, as a family, we must look at this as a marathon and not a sprint. We appreciate all donations, no matter what size.  Please send prayers for our family, for strength and healing.

name: Help Cole Malone Battle Leukemia
text: Cole Malone is a very special 9 year old boy whose Leukmia has relapsed (returned) and again has a long, hard battle with this terrible illness. We are asking for your donations to help offset the staggering costs of hospital and specialist co-payments, medical treatments and prescriptions. Thank you for your support!!!Cole was originally diagnosed with Pre-B ALL Leukemia when he was 2 years old. After 3.5 years of chemotherapy treatment, Cole's Leukemia was gone and he and our family returned to a normal life. After nearly 5 years of being cancer free, Cole's Leukemia returned. Now 9 years old, Cole has started a new treatment plan that will either be another multi-year chemotherapy treatment plan or a bone marrow transplant.

name: Krew Anderson
text: ￼￼Our nephew, Krew Anderson, who is 5 months old, was diagnosed with AML - Acute Myeloid Leukemia on March 1.  He is going to have a tough road ahead of him with 4 months of chemotherapy.   Although, I know he will be incredibly strong, he and his family are going to need our help.  As you can imagine 4 months at the Children's Hospital fighting this terrible disease will come at a cost.  With your help we can eliminate some of the burden Richard and Stephanie's family is up against.  Let's help Krew Dog fight this!  Any donation will be greatly appreciated by the family!  KREW STRONG!If you would like to follow along with Krew’s journey, Richard and Stephanie have created a Facebook page to journal about his progress. http://facebook.com/thekrewdude

name: Kristi Longsworth Martin Leukemia Fund
text: Our friend Kristi has ben recently diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Luekemia (AML) and she is "lining up at the starting line of a marathon" (her doctor's words). She has just started aggressive chemo and will be in the hospital for a while as her body starts making new white blood cells. As everyone knows even with great insurance the bills for this type of treatment will be really expensive for her and Shane. Keith and I wanted to put together this funding page so that all of Kristi and Shane's friends can help support them during this difficult time. This way they can concentrate on the battle of beating cancer and not have to worry about all the cost associated with this fight.

name: Help Lexi fight against Leukemia!
text: Https://www.aplos.com/aws/give/AWSUMCommunitiesandSchools/ Use the link above instead of the go fund me link. We have created a non profit website so you can donate directly and it is tax deductible (IRS 501c3). Thank you!!! Lexi was recently diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. This sweet thoughtful 6 year old girl needs prayers and support so she can fight this! She will have chemotherapy for 3 years and will be homebound for the first 8 months. Let's help her parents with the enormous financial burden so they can concentrate on helping her get well. ￼ ￼ ￼

name: Logan’s Battle With Leukemia
text: How Logan became our Iron Man. My family and I’s life was recently turned upside down when we found out my nephew Logan, who is only 3 years old, was diagnosed with leukemia. It all started with an ER visit for a headache and stomach ache in the middle of the night. We were thinking Logan would be given medicine and be on his way home. If only it had been so simple. The doctors noticed bruises covering Logan’s legs and decided to do precautionary blood tests. The tests showed Logan’s blood was in bad shape. Never once did our family wake up thinking we would hear the awful words “Logan has leukemia” but unfortunately, that is our new reality. Hearing this news shattered our hearts in ways we could have never imagined. We were broken. Logan is the most kind hearted, easy going, lovable child I know and he is my life, as well as my family’s. All he needs is a mud puddle and his day is made. Unfortunately, the life he once knew of mud puddles, ATV riding, and monster truck jams will look more like hospital visits, chemo treatments, and not feeling well for at least the next few years. Logan is our new Iron Man because of the port they placed in his chest. As unfair as it is for a child to have to go through cancer, I wanted something good to come out of it. 100% of the proceeds raised through this account will go directly to supporting the financial burdens that come with this dreadful disease.

name: Laurens 3rd fight against leukemia
text: In July of 2015 our world fall apart. Our 13 month old babygirl was diagnosed with highrisk Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. When Lauren was first diagnosed we spent 40 days in the hospital recieving multiple blood and platelet transfusions also recieving her first INTENSE round of chemotherapy. Little did we know know our journey. with cancer had just began, as Lauren had 2.5 years of chemotherapy ahead of her. Which includes 1 year of INTENSE chemotherapy.
