So why do we ask for help?    Shamil has been diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia in the beginning of this year.  Three rounds of chemotherapy brought terrible side effects but no disease control.  There are incredibly dedicated oncologists in Kyrgyzstan who go above and beyond to save patients lives in spite of lack of access to the full range of diagnostic and treatment modalities.  A bone marrow transplant is often not a choice as it requires travel to a foreign country and is unaffordable for the most patients including physicians who happen to be amongst the lowest paid professionals.  You can feel the frustration and despair, as Shamil’s battle is unfair and odds are not in his favor.  In an attempt to change this, we are planning to have Shamil travel to the Ruhr University Hospital in Bochum, Germany for further work up and treatment as soon as we have the funds.  The funds are being collected simultaneously by the family and friends in different corners of the world to cover the expenses.  Please support this fundraiser if you can.  Thank you all very much, your help is greatly appreciated.  Let Love, Health and Peace be with you and your family! Sincerely, Team Kyrgyzstani Community Abroad on behalf of Shamil and his loving Family

name: Help Áine Fight Leukemia
text: On March 10th, 2016, Áine was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. She is 19 months old. While children with Down syndrome have a greater chance of developing leukemia than the general population, they respond very well to treatment. This information, as well as Áine's immense spirit, brings us all hope. In the short time since her diagnosis, Áine has begun chemotherapy and been the recipient of blood transfusions. Her treatment plan includes an extended hospital stay with chemotherapy. While the path ahead is being determined, we know that continuing care will be extensive and costly.We are supporting Áine, William, Alexandria and their family with this fundraising campaign. Like many of you, we want to help our dear friends. Donating through this page will alleviate some of the financial burden incurred from the hospital stay, chemotherapy treatments and whatever is to come. All donations go directly to the family. While the road ahead for Áine and her parents will be long, our love and support can sustain them. Please keep them in your heart.Thank you for your support of Áine and her family.

name: Linda's Battle with Leukemia 2018
text:
Linda was diagnosed with  Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia  known as "ALL"  in May of 2018, just a mere couple of weeks after loosing her Mother to cancer.  Her diagnosis was a stunning shock to this devoted and hard working wife and Mother, as well as all of us who know and love her.  With a courageous fervor she began a fight for her life & thanks to Penn medicine she began her course of chemo treatments. Linda has seen her world turned upside down this past year.  We thank everyone who has bared witness to Linda's brave fight and thank all who've shared her story, donated time and or money to her cause.  Thankfully Linda was blessed on 8/31/18 by receiving a stem cell transplant graciously from her amazing sister Sandra.  Since August,  Linda has been bravely battling to continue to fight and regain her health back. It has been a tremendous battle and struggle but there has not been one day she's thrown in the towel. Exhaustion, pain, weakness try to become her new normal & yet all of us who know her see how she still tries to make us smile and or share her dreams of regaining her health. We are hoping in 2019 Linda can be cleared of her cancer and the peace of mind knowing her nightmare is over.  In May Linda was a full time employed worker in the medical field & while her job has been amazing supportive..she simply was not in a program to receive short or long term disability.  The loss of her income has left this family reeling.It's been a struggle to maintain house and home...their son is in Catholic school and they don't want him to have to go elsewhere, there have been car repairs, home repairs needed...not to mention...the holiday season is upon us.This is why I've started this page. I'm asking for your help! Can you give up the cost of a latte, lunch, or more to join our Labor Of Love???

Can you send prayers, share Linda's story or indeed make a contribution so for the next six months we can all cover the cost for the Leach family's payment for their home (at a minimum)??? With your donation...imagine the relief to provide one less worry that household obligations and duties, medical expenses and medicines we all take for granted can be taken care of?! Recently Linda has finally begun to see small steps in regaining strength and slight lifting of restrictions.  I'm sending an urgent request to consider making a donation to close the year out in providing Linda, Tim and their son a Christmas to remember after a year of such struggle and pain. We literally won't know what the future will bring for up to one full year to come as the "after transplant" is intricate and a work in progress, BUT...we can all join together...support Linda and say #F*ckCancer #CareCreatesCure We love  you Linda and admire your courage and determination!!!

name: Help Grayson kick Leukemias butt!
text: Last Friday (7/27), My best friend and his soon-to-be wife received news that no parent wants to hear. Their baby boy, Grayson, was diagnosed with B-Cell Leukemia. Grayson is a bubbly little boy who has a smile that can brighten any room. These next few months are very crucial and will primarily be spent in the hospital as Grayson receives his chemo treatments. I know this family would never ask, but I am asking for anyone that could possibly help ease the financial burden of the treatments and to support this handsome boy's journey to kick Leukemia's butt! Any amount would be greatly appreciated! Thank you!

name: Help Beaudin's Battle Against Leukemia
text: On January 16th our dear friends, Josh and Betsy Larrabee, heard the news that no parent is prepared to receive.  It’s Leukemia. Later that day at Children’s Hospital Colorado, a bone marrow biopsy confirmed that their six-year old son, Beaudin, has acute lymphoblastic leukemia (A.L.L).  Beau has already started his first round of inpatient chemo, a regime which will span over the next 36 months.  Josh and Betsy have started this journey with all the faith, love, courage, grace, and fierceness as is humanly possible.  And dare I say, joy and humor?  Because this is them and this is life.  Their life, anyway, for the next 3 years.  And although we have no doubt that this undying commitment and vigor will remain the theme of their story, it will also be nothing less than hard and exhausting.  A journey that is not possible without the support of their loving village.  The most intense portion of Beau’s 3-year treatment is this initial 6-9 months.  During this time, a significant portion of “normal life” will be affected. He will not be able to attend school with any regularity, as he will have 2-3 full day appointments at Children’s Hospital in Aurora each week, plus the added potential of overnight stays depending on many variables. Beau’s one-year old sister, Selah, will not be able to attend the frequent hospital visits, adding the need for childcare to Josh and Betsy’s logistical list. So many friends of the Larrabees have been asking what they can do to help.   While we can’t take away the heavy burden of what this disease is and will be adding to their lives, we can lighten the load of the day-to-day with our financial support.  An answer to our “we love you, how can we help?!?!” cries.  A tangible and direct way to offer our love and support of this amazing family.  Funding will help support:·   the extreme cost of treatment that is estimated to exceed their    insurance’s cap·   tutoring for Beaudin to remain at grade level while unable to attend    school consistently·   house cleaning services (to help maintain the nearly-sterile    environment Beau will need to stay strong, postured to fight)·   childcare for Selah during Beau’s ongoing chemotherapy treatments    & hospital visits·   toll road fees from Longmont to Aurora multiple times/week    (doctors explained how shocked most parents are at this amount) Let’s shower them with our love in the form of financial support, in hopes of making this journey a little more bearable.  Thank you a million times over for your prayers and loving presence during this difficult road.  Each is strongly felt and cherished by this grateful crew of Larrabees. If you aren’t yet receiving updates and would like to, please visit Beau’s Caringbridge site at  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/beaudinlarrabee.  You can also follow Betsy’s blog (less medical speak, more heart speak) at  www.summerofsilence.com.￼

name: Destry Abbott Leukemia Fund
text: Destry hasn't been feeling good lately and was hurting pretty bad. It turns out he has Leukemia and will be starting treatment ASAP. Destry is going to be in the hospital for a couple of weeks while the bills pile up. His families main income comes from his riding schools and racing. We appreciate everyone's support, thank you.

name: Kirsten's Leukemia Fund
text:
Hi,


My daughter Kirsten was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia on Sept 14th.  We are currently at the UNC Hospital Oncology facility in Chapel Hill where Kirsten is undergoing treatment.


We do have great Insurance with Aetna, but there are many many costs outside of the medical costs that are acruing.  


The treatment is long term, and Kirsten will be in the hospital for 4 - 6 weeks and then ongoing trips until full remission.


Everyone has been really amazing in their support.  What we aren't sure of at this time, are the overall costs that insurance doesn't cover.


Some of these things are Kirstens bills - rent, utilities while she is unable to work, living expenses at the hospital and the big unknown - what does insurance not cover.


While we are doing well now, we would appreciate any small help that you could provide.  All of the money (100%) will go towards Kirstens recovery, deductibles, and things that insurance does not cover and then to help her once she completes her hospital stay with living expenses until she can get her life back to normal.


We appreciate all of your support, love and caring !

name: Drew's Battle Against Leukemia
text: Drew's battle with leukemia has take a turn. His leukemia, a very aggressive AML with a mutation that complicates his treatment, is not responsive to chemotherapy and he has failed 5 rounds of chemo - meaning he is no longer in remission. Drew's best chance is a new, special medication taken in conjunction with a form of specialized chemo as part of clinical trail at MD Anderson. However, his insurance, through Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas, is refusing the peer to peer review that could potentially authorize this treatment. As it stands, nothing Drew is currently receiving at MD Anderson is covered. Every transfusion, IV and Tylenol is completely on Drew and Noblet financially - and he cannot enter the clinical trial that will save his life without insurance approval.While Noblet continues to advocate for Drew, please consider supporting them. Their MD Anderson bill is already astronomical, and will only continue to climb. Thank you. Please share. And please do not hesitate to note how their healthcare coverage is refusing the treatment that will save Drew's life - and that without, could kill him.

name: Support Ansley in Her Fight Against Leukemia
text: On January 4, Ansley celebrated her 2nd birthday. January 20, she went to the doctor because she hadn’t been feeling well and by that night she had been admitted to the UNC Cancer Center. The next day she was officially diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. In the 12 hours to follow, she had surgery to place a port, do a bone marrow and spinal fluid biopsy, and had the first chemo treatment placed in her spinal fluid. During the next month, Ansley will receive 4 rounds of one chemo drug, 1 round of another chemo drug, 28 days of steroids, another spinal tap and spinal fluid biopsy, and chemo placed in her spinal fluid once more. Not only will Paige and Jake have mountains of medical bills, they will miss a significant amount of work. Please help them have one less thing to worry about, so they can focus on Ansley.  If you aren’t able to give, prayers and positive thoughts are appreciated as well!Ansley is a sassy, spunky little fighter. She’s got this. And her favorite person is already leading the way showing her how it’s done. ❤️

name: Eliza Cait's Fight Against Leukemia
text: On Monday, February 26, 2018, 10 year old Eliza Cait Millwood was diagnosed with T-Cell ALL Leukemia after a busy weekend celebrating her birthday party, preparing for a dance competition and watch her cousin get baptized. As you can imagine, the financial burden of treatment options, loss work time and continuing normal life for her siblings is a stress  that her parents, Erin and Joey, should not have to worry about at this time. Let's reassure them that God will provide as they are relying heavily on their faith.Update: We lost Eliza Cait due to an infection suddenly April 3, 2018. The family has a long road of expenses between funeral, medical, living etc.  Due to the outpouring of support, we hit out original goal and increased it. Thank you to everyone who has supported them and have prayed for them. Please continue!

name: Kendall's Fight Against Leukemia
text: On October 9th 2017, the Mathews Family lives changed when their 10 month old daughter Kendall was diagnosed with a rare form of Leukemia (JMML). And as of February 2018, and 2 bone marrow transplants later Kendall is still fighting for her life. She is currently in the intensive care unit with renal failure and septic shock. She is sedated, on a ventilator and on continuous dialysis. Her mother Marisha had to immediately quit her job to be with her in the hospital from day one and her Father Kevin has been the support at home with their other two children Kasey, 7 years old and Kori, 5 years old. Her sudden decline in health has put a financial strain on the family, with an increase in medical bills, household and travel expenses, food for mom at the hospital, etc. This page was created for anyone who is able to help my family in their time of need. Anything is appreciated, even if it's just a share or a prayer. God Bless and Thank you.

name: Help Support Crystal Fight Leukemia
text: Crystal is the wife of Kevin Stuart and is about to enter into the biggest fight of her life, Crystal was diagnosed with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia on October 3, 2015. Since then she has been on 3 different treatments with disappointing results, Crystal’s only option left is to have a bone marrow stem cell transplant in which a donor has been found for her through the world wide bone marrow data bank.Crystal will need to travel to Halifax, Nova Scotia to have the transplant,  this will be a 3 year recovery process for her with a 3 month hospital stay then she will need to live in Halifax close to the hospital away from her family and friends for several months due to complications and medical reasons that will arise after the transplant. When Crystal is able to come home she will then need to travel to Moncton on a regular basis for 2 years for medical treatments and check-ups. I have grown up with Crystal and consider her my sister and close family, she and Kevin are the first to help anyone in need, I am asking all of you to please donate to help Crystal with this financial burden of medical and living cost while she is away from home.Thank you all who donate and please say a prayer for her.

name: Help Arrow fight leukemia
text: As many of you may now be aware this beautiful families life has been turned upside down as Mark has been diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) which is a cancer of the bone marrow and the blood.Mark had been suffering with a bad cold for three weeks and after numerous tests got the bad blow that it was Leukemia and treatment was to commence immediately.Mark and Casey are an incredible couple who with their three children have lived in small communities making a huge impact with their involvement of teaching, sporting motorbike and generally anything to support growth of a town.They are a very humble family who are there to help anyone in need but now is an opportunity for us to support Mark and his family in their time of need.Given the high cost of living and limited ability to work , things will be very challenging for them.These funds will help with living expenses and any uncovered medical bills so Mark can KICK LEUKEMIA'S BUTT!Lets together reduce the financial burden and stresses slightly for this awesome family so they can concentrate on the bumpy road ahead.Please consider helping Mark in the following waysDonate to the Help Arrow fight Acute Myeloid Leukemia Go fund MeLeave messages of encouragement on the - Arrows Battle with AML Facebook PageShare the Go Fund Me Page on your social media pagesSend out strength , healing and peaceWith Deep GratitudeTeam MARK

name: Help kick Kramer’s leukemia in the ass
text: Hi friends. If you know me, there’s a really good chance that you know my very good friend Kramer Collins. He has been part of my family for more than a decade and I consider him to be my brother. He’s a loving partner to my sister, Aryana, and a devoted cat dad to the (probably immortal) Nancy. He’s a great brother, friend...my boss at one point...teacher, shuffle board player, sorbet maker cook, writer, devils advocate (kind of annoying, tbh), observer of people, and all around lovely human.If you’ve ever met Kramer, there’s a chance that you really like him. He’s stubborn, but extremely kind and generous. He can talk your ear off for hours or just listen when he needs to. He’s pretty great. Kramer was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia this week. Up until today, he’s been working between two to three jobs to make ends meet and is now facing the ugly reality of our American health care system. He’ll be undergoing intensive chemotherapy treatments for the next month and will be living at the hospital for the duration. We’re asking for your help to cover his medical copay of $6000 and really appreciate anything hat you can offer, even if it means bringing him some delicious vegan soup from ma me house every once in a while.Many thanks!

name: 5 year old diagnosed with leukemia
text: Hey everyone. My 5 year old cousin joao who lives in Portugal was recently diagnosed with leukemia. His family is from the Azores. He was flown to Lisbon as an emergency and will be there for a couple of months while he receives treatment . My family in Portugal is pretty poor. They barely have enough money for food on a regular basis. Any donation would help. Nothing is to small . Thank you

name: Alex's Fight Against Leukemia
text:
Alex is an 18 year-old high school senior from a family of volunteer firefighters. She has been a member of the Cambridge (VT) Fire Department since she was old enough to be a cadet. Both her father, brother, and several other family members are also firefighters. 

In September 2018, Alex wasn't feeling well and went to the doctors for what they thought was a cold. After regular meds didn't work, she began experiencing pain in her neck and face. Blood tests revealed she had leukemia and she began chemo immediately that day. We are unsure of what the future holds at this point, but we are certain their family could use help with care. Whether it's medical bills, or supporting her parents who must take constant time off from work to be with her in the hospital, we want to do everything we can. Please take the time to donate even $1 to help this young lady. She is still looking forward to beating this and getting back to the fire department, her varsity softball team, and prom!Thank you,

name: Help Ryan Battle Leukemia
text: On May 9th my brother and best friend, Ryan Bray, was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). He has begun chemo therapy at a great hospital in San Francisco. For the next 12+/- months Ryan’s life as a husband, son, brother, friend, food broker, and car enthusiast, will be put on hold. All while the medical bills pile up. Any support you can give will be appreciated.

name: Help Zainab Beat Leukemia
text: On the night of November 19, 2017, without any warning or a moment's notice, the Jafri family lost their light. At the age of 21, Ali Jafri had the highest of ambitions and the brightest of futures ahead of him. A joy for his friends and family, and a strong man of faith, Ali Jafri was bound to elevate those around him...until that fateful night. A car crash left him in a severe coma with minimal brain activity. A few days later, he succumbed to diffuse organ failure and was laid to rest. He was survived by his doting mother and father, Syed Jafri and Samina Jafri, and his younger siblings, Hasan and Zainab, who had never known a world without him.As the long days passed, the Jafri family held strong and endured the storm bravely. Zainab, now a junior in high school, knew her Ali Bhai would want nothing more than to see his sister achieve her dreams and continue to be the ace student that she was. She continued to excel in her classes with eyes set on the best colleges in the nation, all the while placating her healing family. In early June, just a few months after Ali’s passing, Zainab contracted the flu, except this was a flu like she had never had before. It lasted for days. Weeks. Zainab did not think much of it and continued to work towards excelling at her rigorous coursework. Her parents, however, decided it would be best to take her to the doctor. A day before she saw the doctor, Zainab became a finalist in a prestigious scholarship for her future college education.At the doctor’s office, Zainab and her family were greeted with looks of concern. They were told that there were some serious abnormalities within the lab work and that they would need to go downtown for further check up. On an ambulance, Zainab was taken immediately to Texas Children’s Hospital.There, she was taken to a very specialized ward, a ward for patients with leukemia. Zainab’s lab abnormalities were concerning for leukemia.After a prolonged hospitalization that required lumbar punctures and bone marrow biopsies, Zainab was officially diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). Thankfully, while being one of the forms of leukemia with the best long-term prognosis, it still carries a long treatment regimen and short-term complications. With the devastating events of November 2017, and now this long and arduous battle with cancer, the Jafri family has had no room to think about the rigors of normal life. There hasn’t been much time to leave the hospital, let alone go to work. Zainab has been out of school for the past year, putting her dreams on hold. However, being the fighter and optimist that she is, Zainab sees this experience as one that has given her strength and inspiration. She is now an aspiring oncologist. Let’s do what we can to ease this wonderful family’s burden. The proceeds are directly funded to Zainab’s brother and father, Mohammad Jafri and Syed Jafri.#resilientZainab

name: Liliana's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Our friend Jaimie's daughter was just recently diagnosed with Leukemia. Liliana is 19 months old. She is currently in recovery from having a port put in and having bone marrow scans done. She will receive her first treatment this afternoon. As  we all know the cost of medical treatment is very costly, Jaimie is a single mom raising Liliana on her own, anything will help them. Please keep Liliana in your prayers as we all hope for a quick and successful recovery ❤️❤️❤️

name: Bryan’s fight against Leukemia
text: Bryan L. Wallace Jr is an 8 year old smart, attentive, energetic little boy that enjoys drawing, working with his dad, and making everyone around him laugh. He’s well known for how well he’s able to drive the zero turn while cutting grass at a young age. He also enjoys being outside playing with his siblings and the other kids that lives in the neighborhood. He got a swollen lymph nodes under his chin, and then they started appearing in his arm pits and in his groin area as well. He was having blurred vision, a headache, and was running a fever, so I took him to the Emergency Room in Columbus, GA where he was immediately transported to The Egleston Children’s Hospital by ambulance on Saturday August 25, 2018. We got there and they did a CATScan, tons of blood work, a MRI, EKG, and diagnosed him with T Cell Leukemia. His White Blood Cells Count was over 50,000 when they should have been between 5-10,000 for his age. He had surgery so they could get bone marrow, a spinal tap to get fluid from around his spine and a port was installed in his chest, so he could start Chemotherapy right after surgery. He’s had 3 rounds of Chemotherapy and had his second surgery the morning of Tuesday September 4, 2018.His blood sugar reached a high of 426, so he had to get insulin shots to get it lowered fast. He was in a lot of pain, having nausea and a loss of appetite, but he’s a fighter, so is trying to tolerate the pain the best he can.We still do not have a definite day as to when we’re able to go home. He has a care plan in place that is intensed for the first 6-9 Months, and then continued treatment for the next 3 years. We’re trying to keep him comfortable and entertained as much as possibly, and he’s enjoyed everyone that stopped by to visit him so far. Bryan parents are Marctavious and LaTonya and he has 5 other siblings. Jada is 10, Brayden is 7, Layla is 5, Miracle is 3, and Marcta Jr will be 2 on October 29. I had to leave two different jobs, and my husband with our other 5 kids to be by Bryan’s bedside every step of the way. We live 2  hours from the hospital, so my husband has to drive back and forth trying to make sure our other kids get to school, work as much as he can before it’s time to get them, make sure they have dinner, get in bed, and still try to be to the hospital as well. The hospital does not feed the parents, so I have been buying all of my food since we got here, my husband has to have gas money to get to and from the hospital, and has to buy him and the kids food whenever they visit. We are asking for donations so we can continue to be by Bryan’s bedside, until he gets well, and still maintain our house back home, so any amount will be greatly appreciated. The money will be used for Bryan’s medical needs that his insurance does not cover, food, gas, and lodging in Atlanta whenever the kids visit on the weekends, etc.Thanks in advance for your prayers, your donations, and please don’t forget to take a couple of minutes to share.

name: Little Megans Leukemia Journey
text: On December 23, 2018 our friends Jeremy and Mellissa Patrick received devastating news any parent dreads to hear. Their two year old daughter Megan has been diagnosed with A.L.L. a specific type of Leukemia.  Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many immature lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).Megan began her journey with pains in her legs and hips that would continually worsen. After several tests later their nightmare began to unfold. Jeremy and Mellissa are normal working parents with a family of three. Wanting a family was no easy task for these caring parents.  Thinking they won the lottery when they heard the news they were expecting a daughter to complete their family of two boys. We are asking our communities to come together and help support this family as they endure 3 years of treatment for their daughter. When most kids are excited and happily awaiting Santa Claus on Christmas Eve, this little girl was receiving her first chemo treatment. Currently she is undergoing chemotherapy and has to stay at the London Sick Kids hospital for the next month with additional stays as needed throughout to continue her treatment plan. Jeremy and Mellissa are planning on staying by Megan’s side. Help us alleviate some of the financial burden on the Patrick family so they can focus on getting their little Megan well again. There will be travel expenses, food cost, child care for the children at home, utilities and home cost as they will be away from their employment while Megan is being treated. Any donation is welcomed. Please keep this family in your thoughts and prayers.

name: Khloe's Battle With leukemia
text: We are asking for your support with expenses for our precious daughter Khloe's battle with leukemia. She was recently diagnosed with AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) and needs your love and support. With your support and God's grace we will all get through this.A little background story:When Khloe started having pain we (my wife and I) initially thought that they were just your typical teething pains. As time went on (about a month and a half later) ... we started inquiring more about the pain and if it was normal to still have that LEVEL of pain for so long. We sought advice from her primary care physician who advised that we take her to a dentist to get their opinion. We saw two separate dental offices who advised that possibly the tooth was just a bit stubborn and to keep a close watch on it. One night, Khloe's temperature reached 102.7 and we took her to the emergency room to get checked out. It was determined there that she suffered from a UTI (Urinary Tract Infection) and we were prescribed antibiotics. A couple days went by and her symptoms were not improving so we decided to take her in to see her primary care physician. It was at this time that it was recommended that we admit her to the hospital. We still thought we were only dealing with a slight infection as they told us that the initial antibiotic was just not strong enough to treat the infection so they switched to a stronger antibiotic. After several test ... we finally received the news that we most dreaded ... Khloe was diagnosed with AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia). Our hearts dropped in disbelief as we immediately went into prayer. "This CAN'T be right" we declared as tears ran down both of our faces. The initial shock of this brought us down to our knees as we just could not understand WHY this was happening. A few days have past, and we are still holding up strong ... but are asking for your support with some of the expenses for our daughter Khloe. We love you and thank you all as we grow stronger during this time.And a side note for anyone else who is going through something ... no matter what you are going through or what you are faced with ... there is absolutely NOTHING that will happen to you today that both you and God cannot handle together.God can work INCREDIBLE GOOD out of unspeakable tragedies ... but that doesn't mean He orchestrates the tragedies. God is ... and always will be on the throne.

name: Leukemia Support Fund
text: My father is one who is too proud to ask for help, and when he is offered help, he is too stubborn to accept it.  I am reaching out for help on his behalf. On April 4th, 2018 my dad (Dennis Walsh) had routine blood work performed, which revealed startling results. After multiple other blood tests, a PET scan, and a bone marrow biopsy, it was revealed that Dennis had a rapid and aggressive form of leukemia known as Acute Myeloid Leukemia, or AML for short. During the interim of tests, he also contracted bilateral pneumonia due to his diminished white blood cell count. He met with the oncologist on April 11th, 2018 who immediately referred Dennis to a hospital 3 hours away at Duke University because they do not treat this specific form of cancer locally. He was advised to travel to Duke "immediately" and arrived the night of April 11th. Upon arrival, the first task was to combat the bilateral pneumonia, which took 5 days, prior to initiating a vigorous treatment of Chemotherapy to combat the leukemia.  His oncologist at Duke informed him without treatment, he would be lucky to make it 1 month. With that, Chemotherapy began on April 17, 2018, with all signs pointing to a recovery and remission at this point. Dennis is required to be treated in-patient for the next 30 days, for which his wife, Karin Walsh, is staying by his side through the entirety of. His four kids are helping physically, financially, and emotionally any and all ways they know how. The community support has been tremendous and has greatly helped Dennis keep his morale up. It was recently revealed that Dennis will not be able to work for the next 18-24 months at a minimum per his treating physician.A few years ago, both Dennis and Karin fell on financial hardship that nearly depleted their savings account.  Over the years they have began to replenish their account, however it is not where it needs to be during this hardship.Karin is staying in Durham for the length of inpatient stay with her husband Dennis, and is required to pay for local housing out of pocket. This does not include the bills that are currently piling up at the couples home town in Brunswick County. Dennis was also placed on uncompensated leave for the time being until he is fit and ready to return to work. Karin's current employment is not sufficient income to maintain all bills, and this is prior to receiving medical bills.My dad has been a supportive and prominent member of any area he has lived in. He has worked endless hours in order to support his family the best that he could. He has had hardships that he has overcome more frequently than anyone should ever have to. He has always been one to give, even if he has nothing to give.  Currently both Dennis and Karin are worried about finances when their sole focus should be on kicking leukemia's butt. And their children are trying to help alleviate their burden as much as possible, however we can not do it alone. We are asking for the support needed to help both Dennis and Karin through this hard time to reduce their financial stress. Any little bit helps, and we are beyond gracious for any generosity you are willing to give.

name: Charlie Peter's Leukemia Fund
text: Tyler and Brittney Peter are a wonderful and generous couple who have a daughter named Charlie who was just recently diagnosed with leukemia at just 1 and a half years old. The couple now has to manage Charlie's treatments and hospital visits while simultaneously taking care of Charlie's newborn brother, Cooper, who is only 1 month old. Please show your love and support for this incredible family by donating any amount to help make this tough time a little easier.

name: Lester's Leukemia
text: We first got the diagnosis for our then-2-year-old son Lester back in August of 2016. After a year of Chemotherapy and a Bone Marrow Transplant, Lester's leukemia has come back a 3rd time and unfortunately due to it's aggression, there is nothing further we can do. We are taking him home from the hosptial for End of Life and Hospice care. Our immediate goals are solely to spend as much time together as a family (Me, my wife Megan, Lester, and our youngest son Malcolm) and keep Lesters quality of life as high as possible. This GoFundMe will be to cover:$6000 - Monthly Expenses, including Rent, Bills, Groceries for being away from work for 2 months$10,000 - Various End of Life expenses that our insurance doesn't cover that we need to prepare for. If there is a significant overage in financial giving, we will be buying various Dinosaur toys for City of Hope to give to other cancer kids, and possibly general donations to Cancer Organizations.EDIT:We will also be using some of the funding we've raised for counseling services, as well as other End of Life costs that we previously did not account for.P.S. - The campaign is listed at 4 Months Old because we initially wanted to switch to this for our funding needs instead of the PayPal link we were previously using. We ended up not using it all until 10/7/2017.

name: Help A Mom of 3 ( Nancy Lopez Leukemia Fund )
text: Joshua 1:9. Be strong and courageous; do not be frightened or dismayed, for the Lord, your God is with you wherever you go."There are moments in life when we receive the devastating news that we aren't quite sure how to process. Sometimes we are left with the unknown.                                                                      This Family's  Story:                                                       We recently received devastating news of our close family friend, Nancy Lopez who is only 33 yrs of age and they are ready to share her story. Nancy is a loving, caring mother of 3 young boys, also a great daughter, sister, aunt and a longtime companion to Gabriel.                                                                                                              A few weeks ago, Nancy woke up not feeling very well. At first, she brushed it off as a cold or flu, going by her day to duties of a typical busy mom .Going to work, picking up her kids from school, homework, washing, cooking dinner, soccer ect.                                                          After a few days she became weaker and weaker but kept trying to continue strong and tending to her kids daily needs and tasks, consuming the fact she was sick. Until one day, her body had had enough. She continued being short of breathe, her struggle to walk became noticeable, and her eyes and skin began turning pale -yellow.                                                           When Gabriel returned home from work that evening, he found her lying on the floor, struggling to breathe.  He immediately picked her up and rushed her to the E.R., still against her will, as she didn't want to alarm and leave her kids behind.                                          After many tubes of blood and exams, including two bone marrow biopsies, Nancy was diagnosed with Acute Lymph Leukemia ( blood cancer) Due to the severity, it was suggested by the doctor she be transferred to a specialized cancer Center, City of Hope ( Duarte, CA)  This gut - wrenching news left her family saddened and confused.                                           As a mom, her heart broke not only for herself but now to tell her boys of this life-threating cancer and having to tell them she wasn't coming home anytime soon.         Nancy since has been living at City of Hope getting extensive treatments, and Chemo for her Leukemia. She has been experiencing pain, weakness and side effects.                    She has a hard time sleeping, worried about her 3 kids well being. Nancy's strength, courage, faith and prayers keep her fighting daily as she has a long road to recovery.                                                    This Go Fund Me is to put Nancy's mind at ease, by knowing her kids will continue to have a roof over their head, food, traveling expenses to and from hospital, sitter,and other expenses that arise during this difficult time. May God continue to give this family strength and traveling mercies to and from hospital.    Nancy and family would like to Thank You in advance for all your prayers and healing, and any contributions you can make to her family.  They also ask to please share their story.                                           Note: Ethan her youngest,will be 6 yrs on Feb 8th, he wanted to go to Disneyland for his birthday, now all he wants is his mom home.                                      Thank You again, from Nancy and Gabriel

name: #TeamTrenton Leukemia Fundraiser
text: Trenton Sebastian is a loving, energetic, and affectionate 11 year old boy with a contagious smile and laugh. He is adored by his mother Brandy, his father Sean, his younger sister Terra (8), and his older brother Tyler (16).This past week the Sebastian family received the news that Trenton has ALL Leukemia.  He is currently receiving treatment at McMaster Children's Hospital in Hamilton.  His chemotherapy treatment will take several weeks. The money raised by this campaign will help replace lost income and cover other costs incurred by the family staying in and/or travelling back and forth to Hamilton. This will allow both Sean and Brandy to focus their energy on Trenton's healing and reduce the financial stress that they must endure during this difficult time.Trenton's parents would never ask for help but anyone who knows them would agree that they are always first to offer help when someone else is in need.  For this reason, their closest family and friends have decided to create this ‘Go Fund Me’ Campaign on their behalf. Please find it within your heart to help them out with a small donation. Every little bit helps.

name: Team Juliet. Let’s Beat Leukemia
text: Dear Friends & Family,Just a few short days ago, little Juliet was acting like any other 2 year old girl at her age. She was having fun at a local petting zoo and playing on the playground. Sadly, just one day later a rash was apparent on her body. Before her parents could even process what was going on, she was diagnosed with AML leukemia. This is absolutely devastating news to the family. This is a family of 5 that just recently got married and only one day after Juliet's mom, Alyssa, graduated from medical school. This is a family that their life has been turned upside down.  It is hard to believe that this is even happening to this lovely girl and at such a young age. It is a tough road to recovery for little Juliet. Dennis and Alyssa have had to leave their jobs indefinitely to care for her. As we all know, their daily responsibilities still exist. We have created this GoFundMe page because we realize we can't take the stress and pain away from what everyone in that family is going through, but we can at least help in regards to their daily needs which include paying for bills,  food, and of course traveling costs to and from Boston Children's Hospital on a daily basis.  At this time, it is known that Juliet will be in the hospital until at least the end of 2018.If you would like to help in any other way other than donating money (gas cards, groceries, etc.) then go to "Team Juliet" FB page where you can reach out and offer support, get updates, and follow her milestones. Use the link below: https://fb.me/JulietValerieStrongFOR BENEFIT CONCERT TICKETS USE LINK BELOW; https://teamjuliet.myshopify.com/products/benefit-concert-ticket**I am Juliet's Uncle Justin and will be in charge of the oversight and monitoring of this page. All funds go directly to Alyssa and Dennis. A wealth manager will be involved to assist in the distribution of funds as needed.**

name: Jacks Medical Fund To Beat Leukemia
text: Help Jack stay strong on his journey to fight leukemia!Jack Quinlan is a remarkable young man. A member of the National Honors Society, a premier soccer player, a talented artist and photographer, an outdoor enthusiast, and a devoted son and brother. His is a loving and gentle soul that shines through and touches everyone he meets. In April, Jack started experiencing some back pain. It was bothersome, but not enough to be alarming until Jack went away on a fishing trip with his dad. What should have been a weekend of sporting fun ended up being one of continuous discomfort and worsening pain. The pain was excruciating, much different from the usual muscle soreness that comes from participating in competitive sports and outdoor activities. By the end of the trip, Jack knew something was seriously wrong. When he returned home, he asked that his parents take him in to an orthopedic specialist who had treated him in the past. The doctor took some X-rays, which showed a wedge compression in the T12 vertebrae of his spine-a rather unusual finding for a healthy 17 year old boy. Blood tests were performed. Results came back normal to borderline normal. Physical therapy was recommended, along with a follow up bone scan at the end of May. ￼￼￼￼￼￼Jack continued with his life, while his parents counted down the days until May 31st. This was the date for the bone scan, a day they hoped would deliver an answer that would bring an end to the nagging pain Jack was experiencing on a daily basis. Unfortunately, that day delivered more pain, although not of the physical variety. More fractures had developed in Jacks spine, and the scan showed yet another worrisome development, a thinning of the bones in his arms. New blood tests were performed. Bone marrow was extracted. On June 2, a diagnosis was confirmed. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.Jack, in typical Jack fashion, tackled his diagnosis like everything else in his life. First and foremost, was his concern for his family, and how this would affect them. Then he drew upon his strength. His determination. His humor. And he prepared himself for the fight of his life. He will need to hold on to all of those attributes in the long days ahead. Jacks journey on the road to eradicate his cancer has just begun. He has completed the first round of chemotherapy, but that is just a tiny step in the long, painful road to recovery. He will be traveling this highway from hell for at least 3 years. Your generosity will help Jack and his family with his medical costs and other care not covered by insurance, such as transportation to and from the hospital for treatments as well as helping Jack stay as comfortable as possible during this long and difficult journey back to health. Immediate needs are a new mattress with better support for his back. Donations may also be used for unforeseen costs including but not limited to lost wages by the family if and when the demands of caring for Jack make it necessary for one or both parents to take a leave of absence from their jobs. The Quinlan family is unendingly grateful and incredibly touched by the outpouring of love and support they have received from everyone in this difficult time since Jack has fallen ill. Your love and prayers are the glue that are keeping us all together. Thank you.

name: Leya’s Leukemia Medical Expenses
text: On October 16, 2018 Leya’s mother,  Jessica, received the news of every parents worst nightmare. Her perfect, beautiful  5 year old baby girl Leya was diagnosed with Leukemia (A.L.L). Since diagnosis, she has been in the ICU due to how agressive this type of cancer is. We are asking for help for her medical bills and other necessary expenses to take the financial burden off of her parents.  Leya will be at the hospital at least 6 months which means Mom and Dad will be taking at least that much time off of work to be with her every step of the way. Leya has 3 siblings  as well that mom and dad still need to support during this hard time. Leya’s mother is asking anyone with questions, concerns or even advise, to please feel free to contact her and she will get back you you ask soon as she has the time. We greatly appreciate any donation amount, and if you are not in a financial state to donate please pray for Leya!

name: Support Ellen As She Beats Leukemia
text: UPDATE: Ellen is courageously starting yet another round of aggressive invasive chemotherapy, her fifth since November. This round of chemo is in preparation for clinical trials that will combine an umbilical cord-blood transplant (provided by a matched umbilical cord-blood donor) and a subsequent half match transplant donation from Ellen's courageous and generous brother Richie, who matches 7 out of 12 markers. The hope would be to put Ellen in remission so she can enjoy another 15 to 20 years of life. Ellen's resolve is truly awe inspiring. We humbly thank you all for your continued prayers, support and generosity. In December 2014, shortly after her 50th birthday, Ellen Canderozzi was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia. After fighting through three debilitating rounds of chemotherapy, Ellen was ready to receive a bone marrow transplant, however, none of her three siblings were a match for her. So a worldwide search for a bone marrow donor was underway. Luckily, an anonymous and selfless man was a perfect match. Ellen underwent a successful bone marrow transplant on March 18, 2015. After six long months in the hospital, Ellen was released in June 2015 and began to continue her recovery at home. Her prognosis was very good and celebrated her re-birthday on the one year anniversary of her bone marrow transplant in March 2015. Ellen had now reached remission and would just need to do weekly, bi –weekly and monthly follow up visits.In November 2016, during her monthly follow up visit, Ellen received the devastating news that she had relapsed. The Acute Myeloid Leukemia had returned. This came as a shock since her checkup 3 weeks earlier revealed no signs or symptoms of cancer.Ellen has once again began a series of intense chemotherapy treatments to treat her Leukemia. Ellen will also be in need of another bone marrow transplant in the near future. Despite continued support from her family, Ellen’s financial obligations have significantly increased with her relapse. Travel expenses to and from New York Presbyterian Hospital in New York City, along with expensive medical and prescription co-payments, and average costs for food and other household bills have become a significant financial burden for Ellen.Ellen presently requires all of her strength to fight this horrible disease for the second time in less than two years.

name: Sam's beat leukemia campaign!
text: Hi all! I am starting a Go Fund Me campaign for my beautiful friend Samantha Kneisler who was diagnosed with leukemia this week. She is a member of the Junior League of San Angelo, a friend, and wife, and a mom to a precious 2 year old boy. She will be in San Antonio for an extended period of time and needs our prayers and support. If you feel called to donate financially, we greatly appreciate it!

name: Team Parker Fights Leukemia
text: Parker Watson (four year old son of Michelle and Michael Watson) was diagnosed with Pre Bcell Lymphoblastic Leukemia on July 27th, 2017. He has courageously begun his battle, including countless blood draws, a bone marrow biopsy, lumbar punctures and chemotherapy. He has faced it all with his ever-present cheerful disposition. In an effort to allow the family to continue focusing on Parker's treatment, consider contributing towards or sharing this cause. The funds will go directly towards Parker's medical costs, at home care and necessary supplies, plus offset some of the work leave expenses now that he will be unable to attend school for the next year. Parker's doctors have explained it will be a 3-year road ahead of chemo treatments, lumbar punctures, doctor's appointments, and everyday changes in Parker's life. Any amount will help support Parker in his fight against cancer. "There is no pain that will ever match that of being told your child has cancer ... but Parker has already made us so proud."#StandWithParker

name: Cami fighting leukemia
text: Camila is a little warrior who has been fighting against cancer. A year ago it seemed that this princess's nightmare ended but unfortunately Camilita is again in the grip of this monster called Leukemia fighting to live.My request is that all those who can help by sending them a little contribution since the parents have to be traveling back and forth to the hospitals where the little one receives the chemotherapies and for them it is difficult to cover all the expenses. Please look inside your hearts and find that compassion of giving to others.In advance, Thank you

name: Fighting Leukemia
text: Hello, I wanted to tell my mothers story. So my 12 year old baby sister (her daughter) was diagnosed with Leukemia. She went into chemotherapy to only figure it was not working, the doctors kept increasing the strength of the chemotherapy two months later she went into remission (cancers gone but still needs to be treated). Now Mayra Nuñez has a very bad lung infection, she is now on life support just to breath and be alive, Mayra also has a big pocket of air within her heart. My mother Mayra Ulloa is in a very hard and depressing situation, she had to quit her job just to stay by her daughters side she is not able to leave it is very hard for her to raise any money for food, gas, clothes and pay her phone bill to keep the family informed on the situation. I Gustavo Casillas would very much appreciate any donation to help the situation my mom is in. She will only use the money for good causes she will keep 50% to help her with her necessities since she is not allowed to leave and have a job, the other 50% will be donated to Loma Linda for being such a good hospital to my sister❤️ really anything is very much appreciated thank you so much please keep my sister in your prayers. We do not have a goal for money, any help we get is really appreciated god bless you all❣️

name: Vika's Recovery from Leukemia
text: 8 year old Viktoria Grigoryan was born on August 24, 2007 in Yerevan, Armenia. She has always been well behaved, full of energy, happy, and friendly. She brought so much joy to her family. Vikul has been a little ball of energy since she was a little girl. In May 2016, Vikul started complaining of striking pains in her legs. Our little ball of energy died down as she was constantly weak and tired. Tests were run on Vikul, where she was diagnosed with childrens Leukemia. Vika was immediately admited to the hospital to recieve treatments, and chemotherapy right away as her cancer was aggresive.Currently, Vika is being treated at R. Yolyan Cancer Center, and her condition is worsening. Her only single mother is at Vika's bedside day in and day out subsequently, has unfortunataly left her job to stay and care for her daughter and is now in need of our financial help and support. She needs our financial donations, in order to recieve the best care, medicines and chemo.  The road to recovery will be very long and strenuous, as Vikul will need continuous and extensive care in the months and years to come. A donation in ANY amount will help support Vika's treatment and recovery by covering medical and living expenses. Please help Vikul a chance at a long and healthy life, and give her the hope she needs to gain that fireball personality yet again. For more information you can call Viktoria's mother Hayarpi Babayan at +37496388886.Please donate via this site, or directly to the accounts listed below:163068076088 (AMD)163068076104 (RUR)163068076096 (USD)163068076112 (EUR) 8 ամյա Վիկտորյա Գրիգորյանը ծնվել է 2007 թվականի օգոստոսի 24-ին ,Երևանում:Միշտ եղել է խելացի, ժիր, ուրախ և ընկերասեր: 2016թվ.-ի մայիսից սկսել է բողոքել ոտքի սուր ցավերից, հետազոտությունից հետո նրա մոտ հայտնաբերել են արյան քաղցկեղ՝ սուր լիմֆոբլաստային լեյկոզ: Այժմ  նա բուժվում է Ռ.Յոլյանի անվան արյունաբանական կենտրոնում: Նրա միայնակ մայրը թողել է աշխատանքը՝ երեխայի կողքին լինելու համար և այժմ ունի մեր օգնության կարիքը: Բուժման համար հարկավոր են թանկարժեք դեղամիջոցներ և անհրաժեշտության դեպքում բուժում արտերկրում: Ձեր կողմից կատարված ցանկացած ներդրում կարող է փրկել նրա կյանքը: Օգնենք նրան լինելու այնպիսին ինչպիսին մինչ հիվանդանալը՝ ուրախ և մշտապես օգնություն ցուցաբերելու պատրաստակամությամբ: Փոխանցման համար նպատակ դաշտում խնդրում ենք նշել ՝ Վիկտորյա Գրիգորյանի բուժման համար: Հաշվեհամարները ստորև.163068076088 (AMD)163068076104 (RUR)163068076096 (USD)163068076112 (EUR)Լրացուցիչ տեղեկությունների համար կարող եք զանգահարել Վիկտորյայի մայրիկին՝ Հայարփի Բաբայանին +37496388886 հեռախոսահամարով:

name: Help Baby Frankie Fight Leukemia
text: Calling all lovers, fighters, and supporters to help Baby Frankie in her fight against Leukemia.On September 16th, 2017, Natalie and Rocco welcomed the newest addition to their family, Francesca Persephone Maren Hollenbeck. This tiny lady, "Frankie", who is not yet big enough to fill out her name, was brought into Urgent Care for cold-like symptoms on Sunday, November 12th. Instead of being sent home with an antibiotic to treat her small cold, Natalie and Frankie were rushed by ambulance to Golisano Children's Hospital, where Baby Frankie was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia  - just four days shy of her 2 Month Birthday.  What does that mean? AML is an aggressive form of cancer that replaces normal bone marrow with leukemic cells - you can learn more from an AML survivor here. The long and the short of it is that this sweet girl will go through more before her 1st Birthday than most do in a lifetime.  What does treatment look like?Over the next four-plus months, Frankie's immediate treatment plan will include a minimum of 7 rounds of chemotherapy to fight the existing cancer, along with extensive care and monitoring of her immune system. Depending on how her body responds to chemo, she may then be in need of a bone marrow transplant. Because she's such a wee little thing and her immune system is so weak, she'll be a permanent resident of Golisano Children's Hospital, to keep her as far from germs and infection as possible. Mom and Dad will be working to find a balance between keeping her big siblings' schedules as normal as possible, while making the 45 minute drive between the hospital and home. She's so little, how's she doing?She is already proving to be extremely strong-willed (she's got the mean-mug toward nurses administering her meds down pat), but she has a lot of fighting left to do. She continues to surprise her doctors with how well she is responding to treatment, and she's quickly stolen the hearts of everyone on the cancer wing (no surprise there, just look at her). The road to remission will be long , but her family is choosing to live every day in love and hope. How can you help?Frankie's family is asking your help to cover the enormous costs of her medical treatment, term of residency at Golisano Children's Hospital, and the sacrifices that Mom and Dad will make for her care and to keep her brother, Jackson, and sister, Brie's lives as normal as possible. Because Natalie will be full-time with Miss Frankie, their family income will effectively be cut in half.  We're asking your help to ease the financial burden that Frankie's diagnosis has and will continue to put on the family, so they can focus on loving their little girl through treatment. The best way you can help is in thoughts, prayers, and monetary donation to Frankie's GoFundMe. She is small, but with your help, we know her fight and triumph will be mighty. Team Frankie!I will be updating this page as Frankie progresses through treatment. Thank you for your generosity, love, and support! #FrankieisaFighter #SmallbutMighty #FrankieStrong #FrankTheTank

name: Rivkah’s journey with Leukemia
text: Our daughter Rivkah has been diagnosed with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. At first the news came like a punch to the stomach, but there is a bright side, it’s not a death sentence. The type of leukemia she has is one of the most common types, and it’s treatable with over a 90% success rate. Over the next two years she will be treated with chemotherapy, and the doctor is very confident that she will make a full recovery. Even though the doctors are confident that the treatment will be successful, it’s going to be hard on her, and she’s not quite three years old yet. It’s going to be hard for our entire family, so we would appreciate your prayers and positive thoughts for our small family and especially for Rivkah Avigayil bat Ahavah. Feel free to add her to any prayer lists you feel appropriate, and I’d like to ask you to give something to charity in her name, even if it’s just a dollar. HaShem has given the doctors the knowledge to know what’s wrong and how to treat it, so we are already part of the way there. Unfortunately, the chemo will have the same side effects for her that it does for everyone else, nausea, vomiting, hair falling out, etc. This is an incredibly difficult road ahead of us, especially for Rivkah, but we caught it early enough to beat it and we know that the Great Doctor is ultimately the One treating her. As I’m sure that you can imagine, this isn’t easy emotionally or financially for us, so if you’d like to help us shoulder the burden that would be great appreciated. Also, I’d like to ask you to share this post to reach more people who may be interested in helping, every share and every dollar helps.

name: Ollie's Leukemia Fund
text: Ollie is 7 years old - brother to Jack (10years old) and Charlie (2years old).  He dances to the beat of his own drum - he's wild and adventurous with an amazingly huge heart.On wednesday 12th of July Ollie was admitted to Monash Childrens Hospital as a very unwell boy with no colour to his skin and his cheeky grin absent ...  Blood tests followed, then blood transfusions, then surgery for lumbar puncture to confirm every parents nightmare.Ollie has ALL (Acute Lynhomblastic Leukemia).Chemotheorapy is the recommended treatment and will be given for 3 & 1/2 YEARS.  There will be a very intense first 6 months - then monthly lumbar puncture, numerous blood tests and scans to follow.We need to raise funds for Ollie ASAP - as you can imagine the financial strain this puts on a family when they need to focus on Ollie and his siblings.Its an extremely stressful time and a juggling act - any donations will help towards everyday living expenses while Robin (Ollies mum) is unable to work.  These are basic things like petrol , hospital parking, care for the other siblings, bills and  medical expenses.As a group we are also currenlty organising a fundraiser day for end of August with a silent auction to help raise funds - if you have something you would like to donate or know someone that could that would be an AMAZING support also!If we all help a little it will go a VERY long way!

name: TeamLolaCruz fights Leukemia
text: Dear Friends and Family, On January 1st, my niece Sabrina and her husband Michael received news that no parent should have to hear. Their sweet 15-month-old Lola was diagnosed with AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia)The back-story: Lola had been sick for the previous 4-5 weeks. Her parents had taken her to the Dr. and the ER a number of times. Lola was treated for bronchitis and an upper respiratory virus but she didn’t improve after antibiotics. On 01/01/18,when Lola was so sick she was not able to sit up, she was rushed to the hospital as she went into respiratory distress. Upon arriving at the ER she was surrounded by a number of determined OHSU staff. After hours of testing her parents learned that Lola's blood count was extremely low, she tested positive for influenza, and she was still suffering from bronchiolitis. Lola had lost all of her color, and all of her energy. It was here that the doctors brought up the likelihood of Leukemia. Baby Lola was immediately admitted Doernbecher Children’s Hospital in Portland Oregon.Fast Forward: In the past week Lola has been recovering from the flu and from bronchitis, has had a bone marrow biopsy, several spinal taps, blood transfusions throughout and she is receiving chemo twice a day.Baby Lola is a fighter and her little body is responding well to the chemo. She is out of bed for the first time and she is enjoying toys and books and offering smiles to anyone that doesn’t look like they are medical personnel. I watched her squeeze her eyes shut when a “masked” nurse approached, peeking only to see if she had gone away. This young family has made sacrifices and worked hard to recently fulfill some big dreams. Sabrina studied and trained to earn a great job in law enforcement. Michael was the primary parent for baby Lola and big brother Lando (almost 4) while Sabrina was away training. They recently purchased their first home. Life was treating them well. A new normal begins. Lola will continue to stay at the hospital for a month receiving chemo. Depending on how her body reacts, she will begin another round of chemo. Both parents have been staying with her around the clock. Doctors have told Sabrina to plan on a year of Family Medical Leave (FMLA) coverage at the minimum.Sabrina has paid family leave for 1-2 months, with some flexibility if needed. Sabrina has insurance. Michael does not. Michael does not have paid leave and he had to return to work today. He will inevitably have to miss work intermittently or for extended periods depending on Lola’s condition.Sabrina and Michael are independent, tough people and they would prefer to handle things on their own. However, they are a two-income family and they have already realized that they can’t get through this on their own financially or emotionally. This is what they are facing:·      Continued chemo for Lola either in the hospital or as an outpatient. Unknown at this time, depending on Lola’s response to chemo.·      Possible bone marrow transplant in the future, again unknown but this would mean an extended hospital stay.·      Treatment for years.·      Prescription medications that will eventually be their responsibility financially.·      Many, many trips to and from Doernbecher.·      Loss of income.·      A new day-to-day routine for Big Brother Lando.·      So many unknowns.How you can help and why:I am starting this campaign for my niece’s family so that they can have one less thing to worry about and focus all of their attention on healing sweet baby Lola while supporting big brother Lando. It is bound to be an overwhelming time for him as well. He is such a sweet big brother and I love him and baby Lola so dearly. Those of you who know me, know that I would trade places with that baby in a second and if I were wealthy I’d write a big fat check to cover everything and more. I can’t do either of those things but what I can do is reach out to you and ask you to donate to this family. If you are not able to donate, your prayers, wishes and good energy would be appreciated.  It would mean the world to me and I know it would mean the world to them.

name: John Bauman's Leukemia Fight
text: John Bauman was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) on February 14th, 2017 at Inova Fairfax Hospital. Needless to say this was shocking, life changing news for John and Meghan. In addition to it being very rare for a 28 year old to be diagnosed with AML, he also has a particularly difficult sub-type to treat. His AML has been resistant to all treatment thus far and will ultimately require a bone marrow transplant once he is in remission. John has undergone 2 rounds of chemotherapy at Inova which failed. In April John and Meghan picked up from their home in Virginia to move up to NJ so John could continue treatment at Memorial Sloan Kettering (MSK). At MSK he has now undergone two more rounds of high intensity chemo therapy inclusive of a clinical trial, which have both failed. During this time, the chemo treatment and 4 months of being in the hospital took it's toll on John and he underwent surgery to deal with complications. As of June, John will now be entering his fifth round of treatment and next steps are becoming more uncertain and they are going "off script" to fight the cancer. The ultimate goal is to get him to remission so he can receive a bone marrow transplant which is a year long process of chemo, radiation, transplant, and recovery. But John is more than this, he is a husband, dog parent, son, brother, and friend. He is a strong, positive, silly, light-hearted, stubborn guy who refuses to give up and continues to fight like hell. John is a pre-clinical researcher at MedStar Washington who just wants to get back to his daily commute and have some normalcy. He is a hockey playing, sports enthusiast who can put together a mean fantasy line up. He has remained a steady force to be wreckened with and has never let his faith in his doctors or himself waiver. John's wife and partner in crime Meghan, has been by his side every step of the way. Besides being his caregiver and advocate, her other job is at Vibrent Health where she is a Program Manager working directly on programs for cancer survivorship and precision medicine because she has always envisioned a future where no person or family should ever deal with cancer or the burden of a life-changing disease. To literally be in the same shoes as the patients she works with every day and their families has given her more drive and purpose than ever imaginable and she continues to fight like hell. At this point John and Meghan have been fortunate enough that their insurance has covered a majority of medical costs. And what costs have not been covered and additional burden they have been able to cover with some sacrifices. However, with each treatment failure the next steps become more uncertain, they also become more financially burdensome. Just to give you an example of what they are up against the drug he needs next is $13,000 a cycle (1 month) and they do not know how long he will be on it, it could be months. The cost coverage was denied by their insurance. They did however, receive coverage from the pharmaceutical company for this first round, but again there could be potentially more to come. Also, bone marrow transplants are not typically fully covered by insurance and costs can upwards of $900,000. With unpredictability comes unpredictable costs.Meghan and John want to thank everyone for their generosity and thoughtfulness that you all have shown. I know they are hesitant to ask for help but with John out of work indefinitely, uncertainty of future treatments, current bills, and specifically paying the out of pocket costs for the uncovered treatment and transplant we are hoping to raise funds to support them so they do not have to stress about financials and can solely focus on getting John healthy. Core to who they are, their promise is to ensure any funds not used to support John's treatment, transplant, and care will be directly donated to support other young adults battling cancer.Thank you for your support and generosity,Kirsten (Meghan's sister)If you would like to continue to follow John's story, follow his Caring Bridge site:  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/johnbauman18

name: Grandpas Battle against Leukemia
text: On January of this year my family received a horrible news, a news we were not expecting. My grandpa (Pedro Perez), a once healthy strong man never been sickly or weak was diagnosed with Leukemia (cancer in the blood). Since that day nothing has been the same my grandpa is constantly  in and out of the hospital. My grandpa only depends on the help of his two daughters and their families. It’s been a journey as a family fighting together through this. My grandpa gets hospitalized every month for 5 days to get his chemotherapy. Recently his doctors informed us that the chemotherpy isn’t sufficient anymore, that my grandpa will need a bone marrow transplant. This transplant may give my grandpa the opportunity to be with us a litte longer. Thankfully my grandpa has a donor and in the next month he will be need to get transported to Portland, Or. To get the transplant done. After that My grandpa will need to stay in Portland for 3 months. Since my grandpa got dignosed him and my grandma stopped working, so income is very limited and short. I’m making his page to help my grandpa with his medical and living expenses while he is in Portland. Anything helps and As many of you know or may not know my grandpa is a great man of faith, even a prayer will help. Thank you all & God bless! ❤️En Enero de este año mi abuelo (Pedro Perez), un hombre fuerte qué nunca había sido debil o enfermizo fue diagnosticado con Leucemia (cancer en la sangre). Desde ese día nada a sido igual. Mi abuelo está constantemente en el hospital. Mi abuelo solamente depende de la ayuda de sus dos hijas y sus familias. A sido una constante lucha como familia contra esta enfermedad. Mi abuelo es internado en el hospital cada mes por 5 día para recibirSu quimioterapia. Recientemente sus doctores nos informaron qué la quimoterapia ya no era suficiente, qué mi abuelo necesita un transplante de médula. Esté transplante puede darle a mi abuelo la oportunidad de estar con nosotros más tiempos. Gracias a Dios mi abuelo tiene un donador, y en un mes mi abuelo va tener qué ser transportado a Portland, Or. Para hacer el transplante. Despues de eso mi abuelo tendrá que quedarse en Portland por 3 meses. Desde qué mi abuelo due diagnósticado el y mi abuela dejaron de trabajar, el sueldo es corto y limitado. Esta pagina es para ayudar a mi abuelo con sus gastos medicos. Lo qué sea ayuda. Como todos saben mi abuelo es un hombre de gran fe, hasta su una horacion ayudaría. Gracias y que Dios los bendiga! ❤️

name: Baby Andrew's Leukemia Fund
text: Three-month old Andrew was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia 2 weeks ago at UF Shands. The tragic news was devastating to mom Jing Hu who is a post-doc at UF Soil and water Science Dept, and dad Like Li who gradauted from UF Dept of Mechanical & Aerospace Eng. and is a post-doc at University of Pittsburgh. Andrew is a brave and happy boy, with daily chemo therapy, he suffers unthinkable pains at his young age, the youngest leukemia patient . Unfortunately, his illness requires 2-3 years of chemo therapy with ~50% survival rate.The parents are not only under tremendous emotional stress but also dire financial situation.  Baby Andrew needs your help so he can grow up to see the world.  The family would greatly appreciate your financial help to establish baby Andrew's leukemia fund.  Let us all work together to help save baby Andrew who will be a miracle baby when he grows up.  You have three options to help: 1.     Make a transfer at Bank of America through Jing Hu’s mobile number 352-871-4612;2.     Send a check to Jing Hu at 299 diamond village Apt 3, Gainesville, FL 32603;3.  Donate via Gofundme, which charges 5% fee.  (Since the parents will be busy taking care of Andrew in the hospital most of the time, their good friend, Xiaolin Liao, will help them organize the fund transfer from Gofundme)Lena Ma, ProfessorSoil and Water Science DepartmentUniversity of Florida

name: Summah's Battle to beat Leukemia
text: My beautiful 9 year old niece Summah has recently been diagnosed with Leukemia.Her parents, family and friends are absolutely shattered. For anyone who knows Summah knows she is just the most amazing, beautiful loyal little girl and to see her going through this is heart breaking.Summah has a long battle ahead of her and needs as much support as possible.Her amazing parents Mel and Corey have been by her side since the diagnosis, but as this is going to be a long battle, the financial stress that comes with this battle is really going to add up.The aim of this page is to raise much needed funds for Summah and her family to help with all the growing expenses that will come with her illness and to relieve the financial stress on Mel and Corey so they can be there fully for Summah during this time.Any donation no matter how small will make a difference and help Mel and Corey get through this battle they are facing.One thing for sure is Summah WILL beat this, she is a strong willed little girl and together we can help their family get through this!Thanks for your support,Stacey

name: Ela's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Family & friends –How  do we even begin with this one … Manuela ‘Ela’ is our sister.She just turned 45 years old and has recently been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. She was admitted immediately to start treatment. Naturally we were all shocked and saddened by the news as all of this happened so suddenly. We started to read up on it online and the prognosis looks promising. It will be an aggressive 8 months of chemotherapy with the likelihood of a bone marrow transplant. The doctors confirmed that they found a chromosome abnormality called the Philadelphia chromosome & after the doctor explained the side effects of chemotherapy, platelet replacement and anti-nausea meds – I saw my sister’s face sink. There we were in a room full of doctors talking about her cancer and just like Ela (Manuela) … never thinking of herself – she says, “6 months of not working? I don’t have that type of paid leave. How am I going to pay my bills?”She wouldn’t like that we’re mentioning this because she’s such a private person – she’s married with 2 grown children, 23 & 26. Her husband had a kidney and pancreas transplant a few years ago she donated one of her kidneys to him – she was a perfect match! Her daughter is in remission from Retinoblastoma (yes – another type of cancer). You see – Ela is supposed to never get sick, she is their rock! Now this is what’s handed to her.We are a family of faith and believe in The Lord. We love God and we know that He has her in HIS hands. She is a strong person & we know she can beat this.We are thankful for everyone coming together to support our sister & her family. We understand if you can’t give financially but you can help by sharing this campaign and continue to keep them in your prayers. Many thanks in advance for your love, support & generosity!12/12/2018-Go Fund Me asked to update the story page. My sister Ela has been feeling well. Getting ready for her 2nd cycle of chemotherapy.  We want to thank everyone again for your generousity, thoughts and prayers.Ela has trusted me to oversee all the withdrawals. I will transfer funds to her account via PayPal, when she requests it.  It will be used towards house expense as needed and payment for her medications.Thank you again...

name: Aaron Russell Leukemia Fund
text: Short and sweet here... Aaron and I recently got some heavy news, he has been diagnosed with phase 2 CML leukemia. Just started chemo and things are starting to look up . I am so thankful for our amazing friends and family for all of the support and help getting through these past few weeks. Spatz will be having a fundraiser for Aaron July 28th and the Porch will be having one August 13th.  If you can't make it and would like to donate still you can do it here. Thank you all for all the love ❤️

name: Seth the Brave battles Leukemia fund
text: Seth was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia the day after Christmas 2018. It took us all by surprise especially since I just took him to the doctors for a rash. Seth has a wonderful team of medical professionals that are helping not only him but our whole family. For the next Thirty Nine months (until at least April 2022) Seth will be receiving chemotherapy and other medical treatments/procedures. We are in this journey for the long haul. We know Seth will make a full recovery! While we are lucky to have private medical insurance it will definitely not cover the entire cost of this lengthy treatment plan, medication and hospital stays.We are reaching out to our friends, family and community asking for financial help with this journey we are facing. The money raised will help pay for the medical costs and other necessities Seth and the family will need. We appreciate all of the support, prayers and love we have received thus far. From the individuals helping me sanitize our house weekly to the individuals bringing us meals to the individuals sending supportive messages and so many others that have done so much already for our family - we love you all!#SethTheBrave

name: Bennett's Fighting Leukemia
text: Life can change in the blink of an eye...Thursday night Sam was brushing Bennett's teeth for bed and noticed they would not stop bleeding.  He also had some bruising which is not abnormal for this rough and tumble 22month old. They called and were instructed to bring him to the ER. From lab draws and tests Bennett was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Type B Stage 2.
