text: On behalf of the Cortes/Gallegos family; I am humbling reaching out to to their family, friends, and community to surround them with love and support durning this difficult time.Last week, their one year old daughter, Ruby, was diagnosed with leukemia. This has been a extremely hard time for the family. Through their faith, strength, and love they will weather this storm together and see Ruby overcome cancer.Ruby has been receiving intense chemo since Sunday. Her Leukemia was growing very aggressively. She has reacted well and is being watched closely in ICU.We have set up this campaign to help ease any financial hardships that present themselves along the way. Please help if you can. No amount is too small. If you can not give financially please pass along Ruby's story and keep her in your prayers.

name: Tess McDowell Perry Vs. Leukemia
text: Tess has been diagnosed with Leukemia. No matter how much our insurance will help, there are going to be expenses, lost salary, and unforeseen circumstances. Tess is the sweetest girl ever and we could use all the help we can get in her battle.

name: Beat Hal’s Leukemia
text: On Christmas Eve, Hal Osborne was diagnosed with Acute Leukemia. He was medevaced to Seattle early Christmas morning and will need to stay in Seattle for the duration of his treatment, which could last more than 6 months. He will need chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant. This will be a very difficult time for Hal and our family, as he will need to undergo intense treatment. We are trying to alleviate as much stress as possible so that he may recover without the worry of financial burdens. We need as much help as we can get to cover the costs of both medical expenses and housing in Seattle. All donations that friends, family, and generous strangers are willing to give are greatly appreciated. All we want is for our Hal to come home healthy. Thank you.

name: Tionna's Fight Against Leukemia
text: This is little Miss Tionna. She is just 9 years old and was diagnosed with AML 1 week ago. AML is a rare, aggressive Leukemia. Tionna and her family will be in Shands for six months or longer, going through chemo treatments and possibly a bone marrow transplant. Tionna has such a sweet and strong spirit. She can't wait to get back home so she can aggravate her little brother and old sister. Please lift Tionna and her family up in your prayers. All donations will be used for Tionna's medical bills and anything needed during her long hospital stay.

name: Todd Marchand's Leukemia Fight Fund
text: My name is Conchetta Bonnet and I am setting up this fund to lessen the stress on my Son-in-Law Todd and his family. Todd is married to my daughter Tina and they have three children.In Feburary 2016, Todd was experiencing severe sinus issues. After several trips to his Primary Care Physician and a CT scan, he was referred to an ENT. During the ENT exam, the doctor noticed several lumps in Todd's neck which raised more concern then just his sinus issues. On April 21, 2016, Todd underwent surgrey to remove and biopsy a lymph node in his neck. On April 28, 2016, the Biopsy report stated it was Non-Hodgkins B-cell Lymphomia.Todd and Tina made 2 trips to MD Anderson in Houston,TX. Todd was diaignosed with Chronic Lumphocytic Leukemia (CLL) Stage 4 with cancer filled nodules throughout his body .  He also has an enlarged spleen with nodules on both his spleen and lungs that the doctors are  keeping a close eye on. Another complication recectly came up- Todd just learned he has a specific genetic mutation that makes him unresponsive to chemotherapy. Due to this, Todd is planning to participate in a new, 2-year clinical trial where treatment can only be received at MD Anderson in Houston.  Todd has and will continue to undergo many blood test, CT scans, and  bone marrow biopsies.   Althought he is allowed to participate in this clinical trial, Todd & Tina are partically financially responsible for all tests before, during and after the trial and one of the medications during the clinical trial. Todd is a retired Command Sergeants Major with 25 years of service with the Louisiana National Guard. Todd worked very hard in the Military but his retirement benefits will not kick in until another 10 years when he reaches age 60.  Todd is a well- respected Law Enforcement officer for the last 19 years, giving back to the community daily . With their current medical insurance,  they are responsible for a  $1,200 deductible and a $7,500 maximum out-of-pocket.  To add to that financial pressure, they anticipate extensive travel expenses back and forth to Houston once the clinical trial starts that will add up very quickly as well.    This has made such an impact on the family due to the fact that Todd is the sole provider for their family.   We are asking our family, friends and friends of friends to consider contributing to our fund. All monies donated will be used to pay for medical and travel expenses to ease this burden.  We will continue to stay strong and with family ,friends, and prayer we can do this!  Please keep Todd and his family in your prayers.Please Post and Share this GoFundMe page on FB . We are so grateful for your support.

name: Autumn Boothe Leukemia Fund
text: Fighting a life threatening disease isn't the only battle to be fought. This extremely close and loving family have always found a way to get by. Unfortunately it's a heartbreaking reality that sometimes things don't go as planned. Saturday January 7th, Autumn, their 8 month old daughter was diagnosed with Leukemia. Due to Autumns young age, Akron Children's hospital is keeping her through the entire treatment process which will make daily finances extremely difficult for the Boothe family. Please send your prayers and/or even the smallest donation to help support this family through this extremely tough time in the many months ahead.

name: Grace's Leukemia Fund
text: Grace Cline, 17 years young in her senior year at Niles McKinley recently fell ill and was diagnosed with Chroinic Myeloid Leukemia. "Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), also known as chronic myelogenous leukemia, is a type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. Only about 10% of leukemias are CML." ( https://www.cancer.org/cancer/chronic-myeloid-leukemia.html) CML is a rare Cancer in which typically the only cure is a Bone Marrow Transplant. Given the current condition of Grace, Dr's advise against the transplant because there is a 40% risk of the transplant attacking Grace's body, which is called graph vs. host. If this happens, Grace will have no way of rebuilding her bone marrow, which would consuquently be fatal. The only option is Chemotherapy (Sprycel) which is a daily pill & currently happens to average around 144,000usd per year (excluding hospital visits, bone marrow taps etc.) The insurance covers some of the medicine & medical bills, yet will still be very costly over the next forseable years.Grace is a loving, brave, copmpassionate individual who has her whole life ahead. We the family love Grace very much and ask for your assistance in helping keep her healthy as this is going to be a long, tiring, uncharted journey. Akron Children's Hospital has offered Grace and family support groups, but any extra support whether it be donations, prayers, information, etc. is greatly appreciated!!Thank you & please share.God Bless.

name: Help Bien Beat Cancer
text: Hi! I'm Magnolia (Nol) Espedido and I created this campaign to raise funds for the medical expenses of Bien Dimalanta who is battling cancer. I have known Bien since Bec Dimalanta (Bien's mother) and I have been friends since we worked together in Ford Motor Company in the Philippines. Now that my family and I are based in Toronto, Canada, we still keep in touch with Bec and the rest of our Ford and ex-Ford friends. From the time that we learned about the latest milestone of Bien's battle, all of us felt the urge to act and do something that will help the family with Bien's rising medical expenses. Since I'm miles away from the rest of our friends, I volunteered to start this gofundme campaign because it's not availabe yet in the Philippines. The rest of our friends in the Philippines are planning other fund-raising activities.All funds collected from this campaign will be initially withdrawn by myself and transferred to my CAD checking account. Once funds are received, I will directly transfer the money to Bec's bank account in the Philippines.Please read the story of Bien below . . . ========================================This is Bien!This is the story of Bien's battle with cancer . . .Bien is a typical kid - jolly and playful. At an early age, he showed interest and passion for sports. Bien knows every NBA player but he cheers for the Cavs especially Lebron.  He also likes to bowl and in fact he bagged the 1st place in one of his games. Bien is into tennis as well with Nadal as his favorite and the list doesn't end there. He keeps himself updated with FIFA cause he's interested with football too. On August 8, 2008 ( Bien was only 3 years old that time ), he started to have on and off fever for a few days. Initially, the family thought it was dengue.  But Bien started to complain of  body aches. They can't even touch Bien because it was so painful. Bien became weak that he can't even stand up.After initial tests were negative, a bone marrow biopsy was performed and it was confirmed that he has Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (also called ALL or acute lymphocytic leukemia) is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. This type of cancer usually gets worse quickly if it is not treated.Bien went through a series of chemotheraphy treatment in the Philippines. After 3 years, he was done with the chemo but still had to go for maintenance check-up for the next 2 years to be declared cancer-free. But after 1 year and 7 months the same symptoms occured and the doctor said he had a bone marrow relapse. Now they are back to zero - Bien have to do all the chemotheraphy all over again.On April 2015, the family has to relocate to Bangkok, Thailand because of Marivic's ( Bien's mom ) work.  Bien continued the treatment in Thailand which he completed on June 2016.In Nov 2016, during his scheduled off theraphy visit, Bien was noted to have an enlarged left testis. It was later confirmed, bone marrow and testicular relapsed. He went through radiation and back to chemo sessions. This time, cancer is too strong and his system is no longer cooperating. There were complications that he needed to be in ICU twice.The family has now decided to have a bone marrow transplant but he needs to be in remission (have less cancer throughout your body) to have it. The doctor said that given the resistant behavior of his leukemia cells, his chance to have a remission is very less therefore, the potential curative treatment option is CAR T-cell theraphy. It is a process of re-engineering the Tcell and when administered back to the patient will recognize and kill the cancer cells.This treatment is still on clinical trial stage but the family are lucky enough that Bien's doctor coordinated in the US and referred Bien to a hospital in China who later accepted Bien into the program.The insurance reviewed the case and confirmed that they will not cover the expenses. The estimated cost for the CAR T-cell theraphy is $30,000 and another $30,000 for the bone marrow transplant. This doesn't include travel costs, accommodation and living expenses for the family. IT IS EXPENSIVE!Bien's family needs help! And they need it right away. Bien's life depends on it. Their families and friends have been supporting them the best way they can. And now, Bien needs YOU more than ever.Every single dollar will give Bien a chance at life, a chance he truly deserves.All your prayers, support and donations are very much appreciated by the Dimalanta family.THANK YOU!For donations in the Philippines, you may directly deposit it to their bank account.  Details found below:BPI SavingsAccount Name: Joshua Bien L. DimalantaAccount Number: 3469-0783-01

name: Raising Riley (Battling Leukemia)
text: “It takes a village”. A phrase that has always rang true to my heart. Now, more fitting than ever, I call on the many villages of friends and family to help with Raising Riley. At 10 years old, Riley has begun a journey that no child should ever have to take. She has boldly started down her path to battle T-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Riley will receive weekly chemotherapy treatments in her new hometown of Kansas City, at Children’s Mercy Hospital. Riley has access to the uppermost quality of care and her team of doctors have the highest hopes that she WILL go in to remission. In order to maintain this quality of care, the Delles family will take on expenses from treatment, travel, unpaid time off of work and various unexpected expenditures. It is my hope that we can lighten that burden for them.  Riley is an inspiration to us all. She faces cancer with an intelligent mind, extreme vigor, and natural wit. Anyone who knows Riley knows of her kind soul and her ability to laugh in most uncomfortable situations. She can outthink you before you ever saw it coming. She asks questions that only a PHD student  would think of. I joke that next book in her extensive list should be the Illiad and the Odyssey, but its not really all that far fetched. To hear Riley laugh is to know hapiness, and to see her smile is to know the stuff that only fairytales are made of.Please join me in Raising Riley. Raising funds for her family. Raising her above all worry. Raising her body and her mind. And raising her spirit in your heart. Villages near and far, please unite! Riley believes in narwhals, magic and miracles, and we should too.￼

name: Ryleighs’s Fight Against Leukemia
text: Andrea and Dominic’s beautiful little girl Ryleigh was diagnosed with acute t cell leukemia two weeks ago. Ry has started treatment which will be over the course of 2 1/2 years. This will require both Andrea and Dom to miss time from work, as there is no where else they would be then helping to ensure that their baby girl gets better. In an effort to take away some of the stress of medical bills, especially with many trips, several times weekly, back and forth to the clinic etc., I wanted to start this gofund me page for us to help to show them support and let them know that they are not alone in this battle. I have no doubt that Ry will beat this! Thanks for your  help! Please continue to send up prayers for this sweet girl and her family!! Thanks so much!!#RyStrong #ThoughSheBeButLittleSheIsFierceAlso please like the facebook page Ry Strong where we will post updates on Ry’s  treatments and progress.

name: Help Cynthia recover from leukemia
text: This is Cynthia, she is my god child, she was diagnosed with leukemia in April of 2018, she has been battling hard and has completed her 4th round of chemo, she will be receiving a bone marrow transplant on August 2018, her mom will have to stop working to stay by her side for the next few months while she recovers  in the hospital, she has two brothers at home so they will need all the help we can give. Please give what you can and let’s share this with your friends and family. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.Jorge Silva

name: Eli's Leukemia Fund
text: Elijah Razor is a smart, silly, energetic 2 year old with a great sense of humor. He loves tools and working with his Papa, Mickey Mouse, and playing with his Cousins. He has a new baby brother, Shepard, who is 3 months old. Eli loves being a big brother.On November 5th, 2015 Elijah was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia. His mom, Shani, noticed some unusual bruising a couple of weeks before and had his blood tested for anemia. His lab came back abnormal, and his doctor later suggested a bone marrow biopsy. The results of the biopsy revealed that little Eli had leukemia. He was admitted to Doernbecher Children's Hospital the same day, and is undergoing chemotherapy. They will be there for the first phase of treatment which will be 30-70 days. The diagnosis has hit the Razor family hard, but they believe that God will remain faithful in their time of need. Eli's dad, Russ, being the only source of income for the family, is unsure when he will be able to return to work. We, as a family, are reaching out to find support for them during this time. They will be traveling between Eugene and Portland frequently and will have many monetary needs during their stay and when they return home. Some of those needs include gas, meals for Russ and Shani, snacks for Eli, diapers, wipes, formula for Shepard, etc. They are also hoping to stay current on their monthly living expenses like their mortgage, electricity, garbage service, and insurance. Please continue to pray for Eli and his family. They appreciate all of the prayers and support.

name: My 9th Birthday Wish: Beat Leukemia
text: Hello ,My name is Xhavier Isaiah and I am going to be 9 years old Dec. 30. You would say I am an All-star, I love sports, really I do ! I have played T-ball , Soccer, basketball and Football. You won’t believe me when I tell you, but I scored 11 baskets in one game and 6 touchdowns in another. But i don’t like to brag mommy tells me that’s not nice. I also love skateboarding! I am even growing out my hair to donate to sick kids. (But for now it makes me look totally cool!) But I was told I’d have to take a rest from all of this for a little while. The other day we went to the doctor and he had my mom bring me to the hospital. I am pretty brave but I don’t like hospitals, the nurses are very nice but they have to poke me with needles. I can tell my mommy is sad , so I try even harder to be brave. But they do hurt! Not sure how much longer we will have to be here but I hope I can go home soon!My name is Danitza and I am proudly the mother of this most amazing little boy ! He always displayed a love for life and being active but lately was not being himself, his color was pale and was napping excessively. We had to take him in to see his Doctor, something just wasn’t right . On December 21st, 2017 we go the news that our little boy had to be admitted to the hospital. We got there as quickly as possible, so many questions running through my mind. More blood work and medical jargon. Finally a diagnosis, Acute undifferentiated Leukemia. My 8 year old son, my Bub, would need to start blood transfusions and need a bone marrow transplant. As if that wasn’t enough “he has to start aggressive chemotherapy immediately”. It took all of me to not roll into a ball and give in to the incredible pain and emptiness I felt. His whole life, from the moment I felt his first kick, I kept him safe, I was his shelter, found ways to make him better, but now there is nothing I can do. I am powerless! I can be brave for him and I am trying. I hope he can’t see the worry in my eyes! Hello My name is Tuesday,I am the proud aunt and cousin to these two amazing human beings and I feel lost. You hear about families that have overcame such an illness but you just never think it will happen to you or your family. As a mother myself I can’t imagine this pain and despair. I am sure with everything going on there is no time to think of finances. This is the only way I can think to help, I am not a doctor, I don’t have what Xhavier needs. Doctors are predicting my nephew will have to spend the remainder of 3rd and 4th grade in the hospital. And I too don’t know what else to do, I just have Faith and this request for support ! Every dollar brings some sense of security to a family that is spending the holidays clinging to a reason to believe and be strong!

name: Myles' Battle Against Leukemia
text: Hello everyone,A very good friend of mine, Myles, received a sudden and shocking diagnosis of Acute Myeloid Leukemia this past week. For those of you who know him, you know that his nickname is “Myles above ordinary” or “Myles of smiles”. He is one of the most fun, outgoing and cheerful people that I know. He is a great person, with a huge heart. Myles and his family are going to need lots of love, support, and prayers to get through this extremely difficult time. Myles is currently at UNMH undergoing chemotherapy and blood transfusions for the next 4-6 weeks. If there are no set backs, the next stage will be outpatient chemotherapy for the next year, with a stem cell transplant in Phoenix lasting up to 6 months. Myles will also need around the clock care in a sterile setting. He has a long road ahead of him to fight this.The financial burden that a diagnosis like this has on a family is unfathomable. I have seen the power of medical fund contributions before, and am reaching out for any help that we can provide for Myles and his family. Please consider giving any amount to this beautiful family to help alleviate their financial burden during this difficult season in their life. Myles, his parents, Larry and Marilyn, and the rest of his family would like to express their sincere appreciation and gratitude for all of the prayers, support and donations to come. I will continue to give updates on his treatments and progress. Please help us spread the word and keep Myles in your prayers. Thanks and God bless.

name: Ryan McDonald battling  Leukemia
text: Leanne Kerin is a single mother of 6 amazing children, 2 girls and 4 sons.In October 2016 her 15 year old son (28/12/01) was diagnosed with Leukaemia.  Ryan has been diagnosed with the rare form of leukaemia which is biphenotypic leukaemia. Leading up to October 2016 Leanne and her son were not  aware he had the disease. Their lives were changed beyond comprehension. Everything she had dreamed of for her children has changed forever. Their hearts break every day for their son/brother watching him go through the treatment and pain every day.Each year in Australia more than 300 people are diagnosed with leukaemia however the form of leukaemia Ryan as is very rate and accounts for only 0/3% of all cancers diagnosed.Leanne relocated to Adelaide in October 2016 and flies her children back and forth from Alice Springs and Darwin to Adelaide to support Ryan.He is currently going through chemotherapy which had made him extremely ill.Because Ryan’s disease has progressed quickly he has had a number of chemotherapy treatments which are not workingTheir last hope  is a bone marrow transplant and his brother is the exact match.This major operation will be done in Sydney in April 2017 and Ryan is considered high risk.Should the operation be successful Ryan will need to be in Sydney for 3 months then go back to Adelaide for further treatment before coming back to Darwin.This is extremely stressful for Leanne and her family and has also placed a huge financial burden on her to pay for her children living in Alice Springs and Darwin as well as spend every day with her son in Adelaide. Due to being his full time carer she is unable to work.As a single mother she would be extremely grateful for any financial support.

name: Fighting Foster's Leukemia Battle
text: December 2013 at the age of 1, Alyssa was diagnosed with ALL Leukemia.  She has had her share of hospital visits and stays since then.  She takes chemo, gets LP's done and has battled keeping her ANC'S up at times.  She is a trooper and just seems to go with the flow of getting poked with needles, taking all her different medicines and long trips to Children's Hospital for her checkups and Chemo.                                                                                                                  If having your child have Leukemia isn't bad enough, try finding out that her daddy also has Leukemia one year after his daughter.  December 2014 we found out Chad has AML Leukemia.  He has already undergone Chemo, a bone marrow transplant and multiple test. Chad has spent Christmas and New Years and Easter in the hospital.  His stays are a month long if not more at times.                                                                                                                  He currently is not able to work do to his condition and all donations that are made will be used for medical bills, travel expenses to and from the hospital, as well his medicines.                                                                                                                  Thank you and many blessings to each of you!

name: Tim's Leukemia Fight
text: What is Thanksgiving? It means “Thanks-4-Giving” This week, this weekend, today, tomorrow we are blessed with each other’s call. The world is not in our hands (It’s in HIM). We can do what we can do for each-other when the call comes… Fellow friends, family & neighbors we’re being called, each and every one of us to “call out our support”. Remember “Let’s Roll”…? Team TES, “Let’s Roll”…! (Tim’s Eternal Strength) --------------------------------------------------------------My friend and brother, Tim Sioui needs our help. He currently being treated for leukimia. I'm doing this campaign to help pay for hefty expenses he'll incur.  Tim has always been there for me, or any other person who needed him.  He is wonderful husband, friend, and son.  He is a self employed honest business man who works very hard for his family.   I ask that all his friends and family pull together to help him in his time of need.Thank you so much,Ken Myers

name: Help Shayna beat Leukemia!
text:
On November 16th we received the news that Shayna has Leukemia. She received her first round of chemotherapy already, which required a 3 week hospital stay. She has her next round scheduled to start on new years eve. With the type of cancer she has (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) she will require a Bone Marrow Transplant, which will reboot her immune system and ultimately cure her. The transplant is being done at OHSU in mid-February and will take her up to a year to recover, with the need of a 24/7 caretaker for the first 100 days after she is released.


     The cost of the medical care needed along with missed work to provide whatever care is needed will quickly add up, so any contributions are greatly appreciated!


    We aren't really the type of people to ask for money, and I know a lot of you have helped us out already in so many ways, so don't feel pressured to donate. This is mostly made to coincide with the big event being hosted by Horse Brass Pub on January 16th, and offer another means for people to contribute, but feel free to help in any way you feel able to. We never could have imagined this outpouring of support that we've received already from our friends, families, and new friends we haven't met yet! Thank you!Link to Horse Brass Pub event: https://www.facebook.com/events/2216804651934203/?notif_t=plan_user_joined&notif_id=1545277288361030

name: Anthony's Leukemia fight
text: Anthony was diagnosed with ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia). He is currently in Sick Kids Hospital in Toronto for treatment.We are raising funds to help the family with the financial costs so they can focus on Anthony's battle ahead. Any amount you wish to donate is greatly appreciated. Please help spread the word!

name: Arianna's leukemia fight
text: I started this for my daughter. Her name is Arianna. She is a bright, loving charismatic 13 year old. This is her 3rd fight with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  We are told that treatment may not work. We are trying to raise money for various reasons.. to help her Father and Grandparents get to her, for her to hopefully spend, maybe fly her best friend to see her. We need help with many things and would appreciate anything you can donate and lot and lots of prayers. My baby needs a miracle.

name: Geneva's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Please consider supporting Geneva Gomez and her amazing family during this difficult time. Geneva was recently diagnosed with leukemia, and will be at CHOC Hospital for the next couple weeks while treatments begin. Geneva's path to healing will be long and hard, and the Gomez Family should not have to worry about finances while watching their daughter fight for her life.Geneva has impacted our family's life for the better, with her kindness and compassion for Josiah. We could never repay her or her family for the love they have shown us, but hopefully this will help them endure the journey. Below is a link to her Caring Bridge site, if you would like to follow and be updated. http://www.caringbridge.org/visit/genevagomez/mystory

name: Quinn's Fight Against Leukemia
text:
If you know the faces, hearts, and minds of these children and their parents, you know what it is to belly laugh, to be celebrated and cared for in the deepest way, what it is to be loved. And now, perhaps you know what it is to be heartbroken, to be shaken, to be on your knees in prayer.  On December 20th, after several weeks of a lingering cough and other common symptoms this time of year, Danielle took Quinn to the pediatrician. An exam and initial blood work were performed, which indicated something deeper was going on, beyond a mere cold or the flu. Danielle was advised to head straight to Lutheran General. Over the course of the past 48 hours Quinn has been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, which is the most common childhood cancer. Due to Quinn's age and blood cell count, she is in the standard range.  At the moment, doctors are working to get a port in and will then start chemo. The goal is for Quinn to be able to go home at some point next week, returning for treatments every Friday for a month. After that month the doctors will assess how the chemo worked by conducting another round of blood and bone marrow tests. Regardless of these results, Quinn is looking at a minimum of two years of treatment and dosages. As daunting as that sounds, the medical team has regularly expressed assurance that Quinn will overcome this and go on to live a healthy life. The future holds many unknowns, but what Joseph and Danielle are confident in is the character of God; that He is who He says He is and will do what He has promised. [Isaiah 43 ] “Fear not, for I have redeemed you;     I have called you by name, you are mine. 2 When you pass through the waters, I will be with you;     and through the rivers, they shall not overwhelm you; when you walk through fire you shall not be burned,     and the flame shall not consume you. 3 For I am the Lord your God,     the Holy One of Israel, your Savior... There has already been an outpouring of prayer, encouragement, and inquiry as to how to step in to help during this time. There will be many stages in the course of this journey. Currently Joseph and Danielle are rotating between permanent support at Quinn's bedside and being present and engaged in navigating this experience with the boys. As they continue in the day-to-day needs before them, there are several things you can do that will make a profound impact:1. Pray- Joseph shared the following: "We fully believe in the incredible power of prayer by God’s people. Please pray for our gentle, sweet, vibrant Quinn, for a path that would lead her to complete healing. Pray for Colt (6) and Kase (2.5), that they would understand what they need to and that the toll of these next months would be minimized for them. Dani and I also need prayer; we desire to make the wisest choices for Quinn’s treatment, and we want to be the best parents to all three of our kids through this. We also need prayer to not live in fear and worry. Please include our doctors in your prayers, as well. God has equipped very smart, compassionate people to help others, and we pray that our doctors and nurses have absolute clarity regarding treatment for Quinn."2. Persist- There will be moments in the weeks and months to come where the reality of what lies ahead will settle in. Let's resolve to be steadfast in support of this family, to listen to the Spirit's promptings to check-in, to pray, to listen, to speak words of truth. While Joseph and Danielle may not be able to respond to every communication, let's continue to secure and re-affirm our love for and loyalty to them, particularly in the long haul.3. Give- The last thing any parent in this situation should be thinking about is finances. And yet, it is a reality that even the most financially sound individuals will reckon with in time. The initial goal set here is a means to allow Joseph and Danielle the peace of mind to continue prioritizing what matters most during this season- their children. If you are able, a gift of any amount will help fill in the gaps as the bills start to accumulate and will continue to provide them a soft landing place as treatments stretch on.  We can't thank you enough for being the people Joseph and Danielle can lean on. May the echo of the days to come be an exhaustive example of what it means to love and to be loved in return.Warmly,Quinn's Family

 [Psalm 91]   He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High     will abide in the shadow of the Almighty. 2 I will say to the Lord, “My refuge and my fortress,     my God, in whom I trust.” 3 For he will deliver you from the snare of the fowler     and from the deadly pestilence. 4 He will cover you with his pinions,     and under his wings you will find refuge;     his faithfulness is a shield and buckler. 5 You will not fear the terror of the night,     nor the arrow that flies by day, 6 nor the pestilence that stalks in darkness,     nor the destruction that wastes at noonday. 7 A thousand may fall at your side,     ten thousand at your right hand,     but it will not come near you. 8 You will only look with your eyes     and see the recompense of the wicked. 9 Because you have made the Lord your dwelling place     —the Most High, who is my refuge— 10 no evil shall be allowed to befall you,     no plague come near your tent. 11 For he will command his angels concerning you     to guard you in all your ways. 12 On their hands they will bear you up,     lest you strike your foot against a stone. 13 You will tread on the lion and the adder;     the young lion and the serpent you will trample underfoot. 14 “Because he holds fast to me in love, I will deliver him;     I will protect him, because he knows my name. 15 When he calls to me, I will answer him;     I will be with him in trouble;     I will rescue him and honor him. 16 With long life I will satisfy him     and show him my salvation.”

name: Matthew’s Fight with Leukemia
text: My son Matthew Gama was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Lukemia a little over a week ago.  Since the diagnosis he has already started chemo treatments. And will continue to be in the hospital for the next 3-4 weeks depending on his progress. He and his girlfriend Amanda of 8 years  are both teachers and bought a beautiful home together last year. Mathew is 25 years old and is a math teacher at West Warwick High School and due to his diagnosis he will be out of work for at least a year. I have started this go fund me to help them financially with medical bills as well as the cost of living. Friends and family have asked if there is anything they can do. Making a donation of any amount would be helpful and very much appreciated.This is the time of year Damian and I usually fund raise and walk for JDRF to support Damian’s struggle with diabetes.  He and I decided that helping Matthew’s cause at this time is more important and would like to ask that people have donated to us in the past would consider donating to help Mathew through this very rough time in his life. Thank you❤️

name: #TeamLily fight against leukemia
text: Sweet Lily just turned 2!! She celebrated with all her cousins and friends. A week later she had a pretty serious cold. She just never really seemed to kick it. She'd spike periodic fevers and she started limping. Grabbing at her leg saying "hurt".After a few trips to the ped Dr. a blood test was done, then a rush to the hospital, a bone marrow biopsy confirmed that our poor baby had ALL  leukemia.  She's the sweetest little girl and doesn't understand why this is happening. Our hearts are broken but we will stay strong and fight as a team, doing for Lily what she cannot do for herself. Beginning last Tuesday, all who loved her had their lives turned upside down.  Her 7-month-old sister, Scarlett who has been staying with grandma and aunts, and her loving friends and cousins who want to see her but cannot due to the infection risks.   After one week in the hospital, she has had dozens of tests, two procedures, and two chemotherapy treatments. This disease requires a LONG battle. We are looking at 2.5 to 3 years of treatment. We are so grateful for any support you can give our little angel.

name: Devin's Leukemia Cure
text: Our dear friend, Judy Wanzie Miko's beautiful 11 year old granddaughter Devin Quinn Miko has been diagnosed with ALL Leukemia.  This GoFundMe has been created to support Devin and her family as they continue to walk the unknown journey of her treatment and healing from Acute Lymphoid Leukemia (ALL). The intention is to raise funds to cover expenses including costs associated with relocating (including travel expenses), medical, food, clothing, gas, and other costs so that Devin's family can focus on what's really important: Devin.To make matters worse Devin devloped a tear in her bowel and because of her low white blood cell count, her body is having trouble fighting the infection; so she is in intensive care.  We have been struck by the strength of this amazing, unselfish child. Devin is a hero and we must help in any way we can. Please consider donating to this amazing family and to our little hero, Devin.

name: Help Willow Fight Leukemia
text:
Today the Kreitz family received devastating news. Willow, 7 years old, has just been diagnosed with Leukemia. She has been admited to the ICU at Texas Children's Hospital where more intensive testing will be done. These tests will tell whether she is fighting ALL or AML, either way there is a long road ahead for the entire family. 
Please help me to relieve the emotional and financial burden for Amber, Robert and Raven as they support their daughter/sister during this difficult time. I am asking for your financial help to relieve the additional stress that meals away from home, travel costs, and parking fees cause . Additionally, they will need assistance for mounting medical bills.
If you are in a position to help Willow fight Leukemia monetarily please know we are truly grateful for your kindness. Please also add Willow, Raven, Amber and Robert to your prayers.

name: Mark's Celebration of Life
text: Our brother and friend lost his battle with Leukemia early Tuesday morning.  Mark touched the hearts of his family, friends and co workers from Texas to California, through his love of music, cheering on the Rangers and the Cowboys or planning and preparing a culinary delight.  Though Pearl Jam was one of his early favorites, Mark experienced insights and expressions of life through music, writing some of his own for the ear of only a few.  He had the ability to help bring himself or anyone out of a dark day with his humor, intricate stories…fiction or non…, and vibrant zest toward the next best thing.  He was most endeared to those who knew him by his tremendous compassion toward people, animals and situations."Heaven gained a great story teller and we all gained an angel."We are raising money to help pay for his memorial services.  Since Mark lived his life in both California and Texas, we are planning to have services in both locations.

name: Miles Kearbey Leukemia Fund
text: Miles Kearbey is a kind, energetic, 3rd grader at Rogers Adventist School. Miles has been diagnosed with leukemia. This news is already stressful enough for the family. Can we help shoulder the financial burden for Mike and Kim, Miles' parents?Thank you for what you can give, and please pray for healing for Miles.

name: Evan's Fight Against Leukemia Fund
text: This is the story of Evan Davies who is a very bright, fun-loving and athletic 12-year-old boy and my grandson.  Evan has a sincere love for sports, like his father, and vigorously participates in baseball and basketball.  He has a deep love for his family, enjoys playing with friends, riding his bike, and loves going to the lake with his family to camp, fish and go boating.On July 9, 2017, all that changed when Evan had to be rushed to the Emergency Room after finding numerous bruises all over his legs for no apparent reason.  After extensive tests were done, our family was given the devastating news that Evan has Leukemia.  His diagnosis is T-Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia.  He was rushed to a children's cancer hospital in Rochester, NY where he is currently undergoing chemotherapy for the next 22-30 days.  After completion of this treatment, Evan will need to make weekly visits to receive chemotherapy treatments for 3-4 months.  Those day visits could turn into hospital admissions depending on the results of his bloodwork.  After that stage of treatment is completed, Evan will require monthly visits for chemotherapy for 2-3 years.  This treatment plan is obviously based on everything going as planned.  We all know that life does not always work that way - especially with Cancer.  Evan is facing a very long road to recovery.Our very loving and caring family has been devastated by Evan's diagnosis.  Our focus right now is on getting Evan through this very trying time of getting established on his chemotherapy treatment.  It has been very rough on Evan and heartbreaking for our family to watch him go through.  We only want the best medical care for Evan so he can have a bright and happy future. I am hoping to raise $5,000 to cover the rising medical expenses that will not be covered by health insurance.  Any donations may also be used for travel expenses as the children's hospital is 200 miles from their home.  In addition, Evan has 2 siblings so there will be child care expenses to cover as well.  Any and all donations are considered to be a true blessing to our family.  They will help to ease the financial strain to provide Evan with these necessary medical treatments in his battle against Leukemia.  Our family will be eternally grateful for any financial support we receive.  Thank you in advance from the bottom of our hearts.  Team Davies

name: Wesley's Battle Against Leukemia
text: “Sometimes, real superheroes live in the hearts of small children fighting big battles.”Wesley is a sweet, energetic baby boy who just turned one year old. He has recently been  diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). We share this with everyone in hopes that you’ll add this beautiful little man and his family to your prayers.  As you can imagine, Wesley and his family will be facing a very difficult next 6 to 9 months as they begin their journey to beat this disease.From medical bills to missing work, this will become overwhelming for them. We are asking for support from all of our friends and extended family on behalf of the Craze Family. Your help will alleviate some of the financial burden that Ian and Nicole will be facing during and after Wesley's treatment.  Any amount of money can help. In addition, we ask for your continued prayers to help us all through this and to get Wesley healthy again.We are standing firm and believing for total healing! #WesleysWarriors #Hebrews4:12-13.       We love you so much Wesley!

name: Help Hayden beat Leukemia
text: Jessica (Onderko) Davis and Ryan Davis recently recieved the heartbreaking news that no parent ever wants to hear. Thier beautiful, 3 year old baby girl Hayden has Leukemia. Anyone who knows Hayden knows that she is an adorable little sweetheart, but she is also strong!She is currently ungoing testing, and will be staying at the hospital the entire time she is recieving her Chemotherapy treatments. Costs associated with Hayden's treatment are going to add up very quickly, and all donations are going directly to Jessica and Ryan to help with those costs.

name: Mikey Barratt - Leukemia
text: Mikey Barratt, 3 years old,  was diagnosed with AML Leukemia on January 22, 2018 and was immediately admitted into the Children's Hospital in Birmingham, AL.  Mikey's treatment is an intense, in-patient regimine over about the next 6 months.  Each round of chemo lasts for about a week, is then followed with about 2 weeks of recovery, both of these phases are in-patient.   Once his numbers are strong enough, he will be allowed to go home for a week!! What a celebration this will be!! His three sisters are really looking forward to having their little "Bubba" back home, as well as Mommy and Daddy! Mikey's family has set up this account because of the overwhelming response and request to establish some sort of account for him.  We all know how expensive medical services can be, and 6 months in-patient treatment will be costly.  Any funds will go towards paying for Mikey's medical treatment and expenses, parking, gas, caring for the three children at home, and the periodic unexpected expenses that come along.Our family asks for your continued thoughts and prayers.  We serve a Mighty God and he is showing us every day just how powerful He is!! Prayers are being felt by us all and they are being answered before our very eyes!If you would like to follow Mikey's story, please go to his facebook page.  Mikey Barratt - Prayers, Support and Updates.We are working on some fundraisers in the future...Leukemia Awareness products you can purchase to support a great cause and also support Mikey!

name: Roselynn's Fight Against Leukemia
text: After twelve days at home, we are heading back to the hospital to start round two of chemo tomorrow. Last week we had an MRD (minimal residual disease) test which tells us whether there are leukemia cells in the bone marrow. We got the call this morning that there are, making her "high risk." This means that we now have to plan for a bone marrow transplant and a different regimen of chemo. This is definitely not the news we were hoping to hear. We appreciate all of the love, support, prayers, and donations as we begin this new process of finding a bone marrow match for Roselynn. We aren't matches (which means our family members most likely aren't either), so the next step will be to find someone who is. If you're interested in joining the bone marrow registry, or to learn more about it, follow this link:  https://bethematch.org/Support-the-Cause/Donate-bone-marrow/Join-the-marrow-registry/ Baby girl is still smiling through it all, talking gibberish, and running around like a mad woman. Her strength and resilience are unmatched.

name: Help Captain fight Leukemia!
text: Recently, one of the strongest members of our Production Family, Cori Adkins son Captain was diagnosed with leukemia. Let's show her the love and support she has always given to us. Give what you can, if you can.    - Yolanda & Rizza _________________________________________Dear friends and family,Yolanda and Rizza started this fund on behalf of my little brother, Captain Wright.On September 9th, 2017, the day before Hurricane Irma hit Orlando, my 13-year-old brother, Captain Wright Jr. was found by his father, Captain Wright Sr.—yellow and semiconscious in his bedroom. Captain was rushed to the emergency room and immediately started on blood and platelet transfusions. When we got the phone call from his father, exclaiming he was at the hospital receiving blood and platelets, something just didn’t seem to add up. How could a healthy 13-year-old boy need emergency care like this? What had happened between now and the last time I saw him just a few weeks prior?Finally, the doctors sat my mother, Cori Adkins, and I down and old us that Captain has Leukemia. After many tears and demanding answers as to why, the doctor described this type of cancer hits hard and fast with almost no obvious signs. No matter what, no mother wants to hear the words “your son has cancer”. We as a family did not realize how sick my brother was in the few months leading up to his diagnosis. He is a VERY humble child and never complains, but that day he had the strength to tell us that he has been feeling very ill as well as collapsing due to feeling so weak. He was suffering through all of this alone and was extremely private about his symptoms.Throughout this past week, he has ONLY been positive and strong for the entire family. He has done nothing but show respect for his hospital staff, following directions, and listening closely to how he must go about his new life. My brother is an avid skateboarder. He loves outdoor activities—fishing, swimming, and paddle boarding to name a few. But currently, he is very vulnerable to illness and infections, forcing him to press pause on many of his favorite activities. Captain can be around friends if he wears a mask, sits far away, and doesn’t touch anyone; a hard fact for a very social and popular teenager. Everyone in close contact with Captain must have a flu shot and respect the boundaries the doctors set in place for him. Captain will be pulled out of school for the next few months due to the cancer treatments and his immune system. One of Cap’s favorite parts about his life is cooking with my mother and exploring new foods, but he will now have to adhere to a neutropenic diet so long as he is receiving chemotherapy over the next 3 years.Due to his immune system and new lifestyle, my mother must redo and rebuy many items in Captain’s room and throughout the rest of their home together. She must purchase washable covers and furniture that can be wiped down and disinfected daily for Cap. Not to mention purchasing new paint, rugs, mattress covers, better cleaning supplies, storage bins, air filters, toys for him that can be disinfected, new shower curtains, his own personal towels and items to be bleached… the list goes on and on and keeps adding up. My mother must also hire a cleaning service to help her disinfect the house and keep it dusted while she is still working full time. His immune system calls for a special diet where everything must be sterile, unopened, fresh, handled and cooked a certain way. He cannot eat leftovers at all.At minimum, Captain will be enduring a 3-year journey with Leukemia, receiving treatments and hospital visits weekly. Medicaid will only pay for so much during this entire process. Many other catastrophic medical and life-adjustment expenses will be coming out of his parent’s pockets. It does not feel good for our family to ask for financial support, but we cannot ignore the realities attached to my brother’s cancer diagnosis.The support and love from you all has been outstanding and he knows in his heart that he is not alone. Thank you to those who have reached out to us. A big thank you to those who have helped with the hurricane cleanup at my mother’s house, supplies, and food. The more support we receive, whether it is financial, physical, or emotional, the more time my family can spend focusing on getting Captain better. Words cannot describe how appreciative we are for ALL of you. Each doctor, nurse, family member, friend, acquaintance, and stranger has surrounded Captain with such an awesome shield of love and encouragement so powerful, I know for sure he will get through this.Thank you for your donations and taking the time to read our story,Andrea Adkins & Family

name: Lily's leukemia fund!
text: Lily Dana is the 4 year old daughter of Christopher Salinas and Taylor Ayers. On March 29th, 2018 she was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, and the very next day she began chemo. Lily brings a smile to everyone she meets and has been an inspiration to those around her.

name: Help Geo fight ALL-Leukemia
text: My name is Lisandra.  I'am Geo's mother and we live in West Palm Beach Fl. Carmen is Geo's grandmother and she is helping us with this fund. Funds will be use for bills and for other needs since i will not be able to go back to work at this time. This is Geo's story On Nov 8th, 2018 we entered the ER with abnormal blood work after not feeling well for a week. He was admitted to Palm West Hospital where more blood work was done. The next day a Bone Marrow was performed. His numbers from his blood results were not so great. On Nov 12, 2018 Geo, a star 14 year old soccer player was diagnosed with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic An aggressive (fast-growing) type of leukemia (blood cancer) in which too many B-cell lymphoblasts (immature white blood cells) are found in the bone marrow and blood. Since then he has multiple blood  and plateles transfussion  as well as Dialysis for his kidneys. Geo is a strong young man who wishes to be becomes a professional Soccer player and play for Barcelona or a Engineer in the future. He has started his first chemo treatment and will continue fighting this battle for a period of time. This has been a difficult time for him and for our family. Geo is strong and he will get through this but he won't be able to do it with out the support of our family, friends and God. He will fight  come out stronger and beat Leukemia. At this time any little help count we appreciate your help of any kind God bless you all.  His Favorite,"Be strong and courageous. For the lord your God will be with you.. Joshua 1:9

name: Help Leo beat cancer
text: My name is Leo. I'm diagnosed with one of the most aggressive blood cancer leukemia, which affects not only the blood but bone marrow as well. Due to my illness I lost my job and now I have already spent all my savings, this is why I desperately need your help. This is my second fight with cancer. About 9 years ago, I was diagnosed with testicular cancer in which I endured 6 cycles of grueling chemo plus 2 surgeries to stop the spread of the malignancy. One of the surgeries was especially complicated because of a very large tumor in my stomach ; my heart even stopped at one point. All in all, it took me roughly 3 years to fully recover. It wasn’t simply a matter of the physical side of the illness, but emotional as well: I was diagnosed with clinical depression. It was a long, difficult road to recovery from all aspects of that cancer, but I finally made it through.Therefore this recurrence of another form of this terrible cancer has hit me especially hard; again, physically and emotionally. In fact, with bad memories of the rough chemo I’d had to endure almost a decade ago, I almost gave up right then and there when I heard the diagnosis. I was thinking that I could not go through that again. But slowly I began to realize: my life is worth living. This fight is worth it, and I want to win. I truly feel that God wouldn’t have brought me this far, only to take my life away. I believe my odds at surviving will be better if I can put every ounce of my strength and energy - physical, spiritual, emotional - into fighting this Cancer. My hope for special treatment is in the USA. Unfortunately at this point there is no other place in the world that will save my life from this blood cancer, only chance i have is the States. I'm labeled by my doctor as terminally ill  and i have been given a limited life. I don't believe in limited live. We all live our lives as long as we want and no one can tell us the end. I'll fight until the edge of the world for my life. Please help me in my fight for life; I deeply appreciated. Thank you very much from the bottom of my heart

name: Jude fights relapsed leukemia
text: Imagine waking up one morning, getting ready for your son's 18-month check up, expecting to go to work afterward, thinking about what to make for dinner and looking forward to a trip to the pumpkin patch with family and friends on the weekend. Then imagine it all gone in an instant, replaced with plans for a spinal tap, bone marrow biopsy and chemotherapy for your small child. That happened to us - within hours, we went from being a happy family with an active child to being in the hospital with many scary new medical terms and diagnoses.Jude's official diagnosis is Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). The good news is that it is highly curable with survival rates as high as 85%. But it's going to be a long road before we get there--frequent spinal taps (he's already had two), hospitalizations, bone marrow biopsies, chemo, steroids and treatment expected to last at least three years.While we have quality medical insurance through Aidan's job, fighting childhood leukemia is an expensive battle. The co-pays, fees, prescriptions, equipment, etc all add up. Barb will be taking a leave of absence from full-time work for a while to manage Jude's care. Anything donated will be gratefully appreciated and used to help cover the cost of medical expenses and help provide a cushion while Barb isn't working.We set up this site to provide a way for people to help after several offers and inquiries about financial assistance. We know times are tough, especially for our friends with young children, so know that we don't expect everyone to give. We are eternally grateful for everyone's support, whether financial or a kind word, it will take a village to help Jude win this battle.Here's Jude with Mom and Dad on a family vacation in September.Jude with Dad in SeptemberJude in his younger days, at about 6 months.

name: Hani Marie's Leukemia Fight Fund
text: Hani has always been a healthy child. She didn’t get sick a lot. She wasn’t  a fussy baby. She is always smiling and laughing and very playful even now laying in the hospital bed , she laughing and trying to be brave. After the flu had gone through the entire family one weekend ( recently), she didn’t bounce back as quickly as her brother and sister did. Her dad ( my brother) took her to the emergency room, as she had begun to throw up, she looked pale and was visibly weak ( he was afraid she was too dehydrated from the flu .) After standard routine testing they discovered Hani had an extremely high count of white blood cells, and very low platelets. This was a concern, so they tested for more possibilities as to why she would be so ill.  The next day Hani was diagnosed with Acute Lymphocytic  Leukemia (ALL). Like any teenage girl ,  She is sassy and headstrong and only worried about when she can get back to school and hang with her friends. She cares about her hair not looking good in the pictures and she doesn’t want to spend a lot of time lying in bed. For her father ( Ryan), who is a single parent of 3 children, he has a lot on his plate, there are unforeseen cost that will most likely start to pile up, so I am making this page to ask people to donate to him for the many things that he may need for her journey. This is the beginning of their journey with Leukemia. I ask that you donate anything you can and that you keep my little niece in your prayers and that any chance you get to arm yourself with knowledge and compassion on this subject,  you pass that along to the next person . Thank you, Leah

name: Patti's Leukemia Fight! #PattiStrong
text: “Courage is not the absence of fear, but rather the judgment that something else is more important than fear.” – Ambrose RedmoonEveryone bares a silent battle, that they must fight alone.  For Patti, like any other six year old, her battles consisted of eating vegetables and getting along with her siblings.  Unfotunately on March 14th everything changed when this radiant child was diagnosed with cancer.  Please help us raise money for this beautiful, courageous little girl.  She has been diagnosed with Acute Lymphmblastic Leukemia (ALL) and faces a long road to recovery.No child should ever have cancer!  Please help us support this brave little girl and her family.  All donations will be greatly appreciated.May God Bless You Always!#PattiStrong #PattiTheLion

name: Help Audrey fight Leukemia
text: My 4 yr old daughter, Audrey was diagnosed with Leukemia on June 7, 2016. This fight will be a long one, but we will get through it together & with God on our side. We live two hours away from the clinic that we will be driving to every week for therapy, medicine & any procedures that she will need done. I must stay in the hospital with her until we are discharged & then home with her to properly care for her. Any support from family or friends or just people who care would be very much appreciated. Audrey also has six siblings & I can just see how hard our journey may get if I don't ask for & accept help. We would be so grateful to have your support in kicking cancers butt.

name: Our 2yr old Dylan fights Leukemia
text: Dylan is a miracle and has already become a super hero!  Dylan's first super hero battle - supported by his dynamic duo parents, Aaron and Larissa - was when he was born premature.  Dylan and his parents fought hard and he has grown up to be a happy, loving and smart kid.  It is with a sad but hopeful heart that we learned that Dylan James Duncan Galt was diagnosed with Leukemia on July 24th, 2018. Dylan is now at Sick Kids Hospital (the best hospital in the world with the best doctors, nurses and volunteers) to fight and beat cancer.  Tests have been thorough and he has already started his first round of Chemotherapy.  It's unthinkable that a child has to battle Leukemia but this is his and his parent's new reality.  Much time will be spent at Sick Kids Hospital, absences from / splitting time from work will be regular and there will be sleepless nights.  Remember though, Dylan and his parents are super heroes and they will fight and beat cancer!  We are raising money to help his parents cover some of their costs - now and into the future when they help Dylan get back to their new normal - and also plan a fun trip to Disney when he finishes his 3.5 years of treatment and recovery to celebrate their victory!  Some funds will also be directed to Sick Kids Hospital.Dylan's parents would never ask for help but anyone who knows them would agree that they would always be the first to help.  For this reason, their closest family and friends have decided to create this ‘Go Fund Me’ Campaign on their behalf. Every little bit helps.  Please consider donating to help Dylan fight and beat cancer.  You can donate online to this GoFundMe - please find it in your heart to support in any way you can. Love,The Galt Family's many family and friends.

name: Robert Pollon's Leukemia Treatments
text: Robert Pollon, known to most as Pat (my Papa), is a family man with a huge heart. On October 24th Pat was diagnosed with Acute myeloid leukemia (a fast moving form of leukemia) after rigorous testing. Then finding out this heartbreaking news the family was determined it would be treatable. A specialist preformed a bone marrow test which was then sent to an Oncologist in Prince George and Vancouver. Pat and Brenda (Pat's wife), were told on October 27th that this form was not treatable by the doctor. The tests determined it was terminal and deamed untreatable. Pat was given three to six months to live. Within the first month of knowing his white blood cells decreased tremendously which left his immune system depleted, leaving him highly vulnerable to infections. He started using natural immunity boosters which on his next blood tests appeared to sustain his white blood cell count. Pat and Brenda were informed of the CIPAG Clinic and of Dr. Castillo in Tijuana Mexico. Following up on this clinic via web, they began emailing back and forth with the clinic. They decided to follow through. Within a week (shortly before christmas) after emails and phone calls they set a cosultation date for January 3rd 2017. The family found comfort and hope with this decision. What a great Christmas gift! On January 1st 2017 they flew out of Grande Prairie AB with great anticipation on their way to Tijuana. January 3rd 2017: After meeting with the doctor for two hours they immediatley started treatment and accepted him into their 25 day program.  We will continue to post further updates !On the families behalf, we thank you for all donations as every dollar counts to help them through this difficult time. Sincerly, Adrianna Anderson (Grandaughter)Costs:Treatment: $9,000 USDRoom: $138 USD per night (Approximately one month) $4,278 USDShuttle: Included in roomFood:  breakfast included in room, Approximately $75 USD per day $2,325 USDAirfare: Approximately $1505.29 USD Approximate Estimation: $ 22730.54 CAD

name: Leukemia CML Financial Hardship
text: I was recently diagnosed with Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia on my 49th birthday, June 1st, 2018. This is a cancer that spawns within the bone marrow. I was provided a course of treatment which involves taking two pills daily for an undetermined amount of time. I have been told it will more than likely be indefinite. To my understanding one of the pills (Hydroxyurea) is to bring my white count back within a normal range, the other pill (Gleevec) is a chemo pill. I have been able to obtain the Hydroxyurea as the cost is $60 monthly, however I have not been able to obtain the prescription for the Gleevec, as the cost for this is a little over $10k monthly. My oncologists office has applied for assistance with the manufacturer for Gleevec on my behalf, in hopes to aid me in obtaining the medication at a discounted rate. However, we still have not been provided the status on this request. So I have not been able to begin my chemo treatment. I currently do not have insurance that covers prescriptions, as I had to drop my insurance through my employer this past December when their rates increased. Due to having temporary custody of five of my grandchildren I couldn't afford the additional cost. I have obtained insurance through a private company, however this does not cover prescriptions. I am already paying for asthma and other prescribed medications out of pocket.This is a very stressful situation, I do NOT like to ask for help, I am usually the person caring for others. But I have 4 adult son's, and 12 grandchildren,  and I am not ready to leave them!!! I am struggling financially, have filed for intermittent FMLA with my employer due to my current health issues, although I am trying to work as long as I am physically able. I am experiencing pain throughout my body, extreme fatigue,  and nausea currently. I am not sure what to expect once I begin taking the Gleevec.The purpose of this go fund me request, is to ask for some help, to assist me through all of this....I know the Lord will see me through, whatever the outcome, and I appreciate you taking time to consider my situation.... if you aren't able to assist me financially I covet your prayers!!!Warmest Regards,Tracey

name: Ruth's Leukemia Fund
text: Following a series of life-threatening infections, Ruth was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia on October 16th. On October 21st they left their home, jobs, family and friends to board a plane for Houston, Texas. For the next year Ruth will receive care at MD Anderson Cancer Center, a world leader in leukemia treatment. Under the guidance of Dr Hagop Kantarjian, she will receive a regimen of chemotherapy in conjunction with effective new therapies including inoruzumab and blinatumomab.Armed with ceaseless faith and compelled by revolutionary research, they are willing to lose everything in order to increase Ruth's odds of survival. Funding will help support medical expenses which fall outside the standard protocol paid for by insurance, cover housing and relocation costs for the family including little Naomi and Mama Wu, and supplement Roy’s income while he stays by Ruth’s side during the most critical phase of treatment.Timing is crucial. A recent biopsy revealed seventy-five percent of her bone marrow is already cancerous. Ruth has been fighting for her life since she was first diagnosed with systematic lupus at age 13. But this time is different. This time she is fighting with and for her family. Ruth and Roy are facing one of the hardest challenges imaginable and they need your support. The year ahead will have many trials, including financial. Let’s show them what an army of love looks like.

name: Team Kailyn Fights Leukemia
text: Just about four months after Kailyn turned 3, we took her in for a blood test, because her daily activity had changed drastically. Our once energetic, athletic and lively girl, was now lethargic, unable to walk more than a short distance, and constantly complaining that she didn't want to do anything. Immediately after the blood tests were complete, the urgent care doctor told me that things did not look good for Kailyn. She was below critically anemic, her white blood cell count was astronomically high, her platelets were dangerously low, and that she likely had lekemia. He insisted that we immediately make the drive to LAMC Kaiser to get her treatment started right away. Once there we were greeted with doctors explaining that she would be getting two blood transfusions and three platelet transfusions overnight and would have a procedure in the morning. The next day Kailyn underwent a bone marrow biopsy, a lumbar puncture, the placement of her PICC line and the first dose of chemo. Kailyn was then formally diagnosed with "High-Risk B-Cell  Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)." Soon after the procedure she began her first full chemo treatment. From what doctors and nurses have told us, this looks to be at least a three year journey full of treatment, doctor's appoinments, chemotherapy, and all around changes in Kailyn's everyday life. While we hope that the majority of her medical care should be covered by insurance, we will still have to find a way to pay the pharmacy charges for her daily cocktail of medication, the price of driving to and from Los Angeles at least on a weekly basis (if not more), and also making sure that Kailyn always has access to the freshest food at home (since we won't be able to go in public for a long while).  With these costs already beginning to pile up, we just hope that you understand that any amount given is sooo greatly appreciated on this fight to beat Leukemia!!   We also plan to do some updates through this platform!

name: Helping Holly fight Leukemia
text: Hello, my name is Lauren and I am the owner of Ellapointe Dance Studio.  About a month ago we were devastated to find out that one of our gorgeous students, Holly Anderson was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia.  Holly is just 7 years old.   Her parents Anna and Steve, big sister Chloe and extended family are absolutely shattered, as is her Ellapointe family.  For anyone who knows Holly knows she has a heart of gold and a cheeky sense of humour so  to see her going through this is heart breaking.Holly has a long battle ahead of her and needs as much support as possible.Her amazing parents Anna and Steve have been by her side since the diagnosis, but as this is going to be a long battle, the financial stress that comes with this battle is really going to add up.  Anna has given up work to be by Holly's side every step of the way. The aim of this page is to reach out to the Ellapointe Family and raise much needed funds for Holly and her family to help with all the growing expenses that will come with her illness and to relieve the financial stress on Anna and Steve so they can be there fully for Holly during this time.Any donation no matter how small will make a difference and help team Anderson get through this battle they are facing.One thing for sure is Holly WILL beat this, she is a strong willed little girl and together we can help their family get through this!

name: Ron's War Against Leukemia
text:
I've been approved to receive a stem cell transplant as soon as possible!
It's scheduled for October the 4th, 2018 as long as my WBC or White Blood Cell count can stay at a tolerable level.

 My daughter is a 1/2 match which actually still works... Those who know me, and my family know that the last 6 years have been pretty eventful from day to day, month to month and year to year! I have a very aggresive form of leukemia that's proven to be pretty resistant to the chemotherapy I've been on all of this time. My white cell count fluctuates between 20-230(when a normal white cell count is 6-11) that's pretty painful and makes me fatigued,  and susceptible to strokes, aneurysms, blood clots, which I've had 6 of and heart attacks ....... "But Ron. .... You dont look sick!!!!" "Ron you've been chemo nearly 6 years, but still have hair...?" "You're still a big Dude!" Trust me, you don't want to physically trade places with me. Imagine qualifying for the narcotics hydrocodone, and dilaudid which is 8 times stronger than morphine for the past nearly 6 years! My form of leukemia gives you gout as a side effect. Imagine not taking pain medications unless you're in the hospital under the supervision of medical personnel, so that when you're on the streets. You can help support your family, emotionally, spiritually, physically and financially..... Imagine doing everything that you can internally, mentally to not live up to stereotypes. I'm very grateful for all of the wonderful people we've met locally and internationally who can relate to our circumstances to a certain extent. I'm still a loving, husband, father and God-fearing man. That hasn't changed. I'm still fighting, still surviving, still living for now. I'm thankful for being married to a loving wife, who works her tail off to support our family by working to make sure our kids experience life to the fullest. I don't believe my wife's purchased a new article of clothing since 2013 for her or the kids. And if you pay any attention to me... it's all t-shirts and shorts....lol! Thrifty is our way of life. Why am I asking for help through Group funding? This transplant procedure is not a 1 day procedure.... It's a 4-6 week procedure on the minimum side. 2-6 months is highly probable.  With several months of recovery, coming in my very near future. (When I survive this ordeal). The procedure itself cost $1.6 million! It's 'mostly' covered by insurance, but not completely.  During that time on the transplant floor, my 3 youngest kids will not be permitted to see me in the flesh(because of high risk of infection for myself and the other patients on the floor). We'll be using daycare for my wife to support me in the flesh, overnight for children ages 7, 6 and 5. It's not going to be a easy journey, but so many have successfully proceeded before us, so we are encouraged. If you have it to financially support this effort, balls in your court. If you don't.... I completely understand. Times are hard! Praying in our behalf, would definitely be appreciated! I still believe it can be affective.  If you're atheist or agnostic, no worries! I'll take wishes in our behalf too! Trust and believe, I'm praying forward everyone daily! Thanks from my family to yours..... Yours Truly, Ron A Strickland

name: Dons Leukemia Recovery Fund
text: Praise God.  I am alive.My name is Don Martin, I am husband to my beautiful wife and father of three grown girls.  I've worked hard all my life, always had a job.  From my hospital room (57 days), I worked every single day, except maybe four days, two when I had fevers over a 103 degrees, another the day they took my appendix out, and the next recovering from extreme pain from the surgery having the appendix removed.The bills from all of this have been overwhelming.  It is not just the bills from the hospital, doctors and medications, but it is the loss of income from not having the stamina to work like I did before I was sick.   My blood counts continue to be lower than normal.  My Doctors tell me they may or may not recover, this just might be my new normal forever.  I have no savings, no retirement, no pension.  My prayer, my hope is that I will be able to continue to pay my health insurance and many other bills to be able to survive.  The cost of health insurance is overwhelming and continues to rise each year, with less and less being covered.  I know God will provide.   Money will be used to defray my costs and to be able to pay back many people I owe money too.  I am working 70 hours a week, which if I am lucky is about 40 hours worth of work.  Everything seems to take longer to do.I was diagnosed on September 25, 2014 with AML.  AML is acute myeloid leukemia.  On that day my life changed forever.  It was exactly 2 years to the day and I think the exact or almost exact time that my father had passed away.  It was also only about 15 months after my brother had been diagnosed with Multiple Myeloma.In October 2014, I spent 27 consecutive days in the hospital, days 3 thru 10 hooked up to chemo around the clock 24/7.  After about 2 1/2 weeks I still had my hair, then it seemed suddenly, I rapidly began losing my hair.  I had an infection with a fever during those days as well.A few weeks later I received my first of three rounds of "consolidation chemo."  Chemo on days 1, 3 and 5 while in the hospital.  The 1st consolidation round, I wound up with an abscess on my back and an abscess tooth.  They lanced the abscess and removed the tooth.Second round of consolidation much like the second, I got sick again and this time they took my appendix.Third round of consolidation, the chemo made me throw up. Sick again after chemo, I had a blood infection.After four rounds of chemo, with many follow up visits, I had 303 needle sticks, 38 blood transfusions, 13 platelet transfusions, about 57 days in the hospital from 7 hospital stays, 12 biopsies, including 10 of them that were bone biopsies.  I also had an endoscopy where they did a biopsy and a liver biopsy.  I have an enlarged liver and an enlarged spleen.I am now in a trial study called"Phase I Study of an Oncofetal Antigen ("OFA") Multi-Peptide Immunotherapy ("BB MPI 03") In Subjects with Hematologic Cancer.  I'm told I was the first human being to receive the vaccine.  Before me it was just the monkey's I'm told.  More than scary, a long list of what might go wrong.  The hope is that the vaccine will work on me and on many, many people that will benefit as a result of my decision and others that followed me into this trial study.  The vaccine they hope will stimulate the growth of "T Cells" to fight off cancer.  So far I have received 5 of the 6 injections for the vaccine. Then they will continue to check on me for intervals through the fall of 2016.  The pharmaceutical company backing the study will then decide if they want to extend the study and give me more vaccinations.I need to continue to raise money on an ongoing  basis until I can get caught up on my bills, I've always paid my bills on time my whole life and have no money saved.   Your help will mean the world to me.   I want to be able to function more and more to help my family, my church, my community and to continue to praise God for all he has done.  Through God, I know he will stregthen me to do all things.

name: Charlene's Medical Fund~Leukemia
text: Charlene’s Medical ReliefDover, NJHello. My name is Pauline and I am starting a gofundme campaign for my youngest sister Charlene. At the age of 25 Charlene was diagnosed with Acute Leukemia. She immediately began chemotherapy and to our pleasant surprise went into remission. Unfortunately our celebrating was short lived. 24 hours after discharge Charlene had 2 brain clots and had a stroke (one of the side effects of chemo is blood clotting). She immediately underwent surgery and was put into an induced coma. The doctors were preparing us for the worse. Thankfully two months into the coma Charlene slowly started waking up. We soon realized that the stroke mostly affected her motor skills. The progress Charlene has made over the months is truly remarkable.
