Sadly because of this disease, she will take some time off due to her condition. She has a loving family who are currently struggling with the fact that their daughter/sister is going through such a horrible disease at such a young age. Katie's father recently lost his job of nine years and are all struggling to keep up with the bills. Katie has medicaid but, unfortunately, there is a limit to the amount they can pay. The money we raise will specifically go to those cost and to Katie's family. I ask of you, sincerely, to help us out. Whether it’s with a share, prayer, or a small donation. We appreciate anything and are so grateful for all your help. We pray and hope that Katie makes a full recovery and is back to her normal routine.Thank you for taking the time to read this. Please share this story and help us make this turn into an amazing outcome. Sincerely,The Otero- Henriquez Family———————————————————Por favor tome el tiempo para leer la historia de Katie; El seis de agosto, Katie Otero-Henriquez tuvo que irse al hospital de emergencia. Katie, que solo tiene diez años la diagnosticaron con leucemia. El ocho de agosto, Katie comenzó su primer quimioterapia y la pusieron en un estado intensivo. Katie iba comenzar el cuarto grado con todos sus amigos. Tristemente no va poder regresar por un tiempo. Katy tiene una familia bella, que en el momento están luchando para su hija. El papa de Katie a perdido su trabajo y están buscando todo manera para pagar para el tratamiento de Katie. Katie tiene Medicaid, pero por desgracia hay un límite a la cantidad que pueden pagar. El dinero que recaudemos irá específicamente a los costos del tratamiento ya la familia de Katie.Con la ayuda de ustedes y de Dios podemos ayudar a Katie para que se sane. Le pido a usted que nos ayude. Nos puede ayudar simplemente con compartiendo esta pagina, con una oración, o con una donación. Le doy gracias por ayudarnos tanto. Ojalá que Katie pueda comenzar su vida normalmente otra vez con su familia y amigos. Gracias por tomando el tiempo para leer la historia de Katie Otero- Henriquez. Por favor comparten esta historia con sus amigos y familiares y ojalá juntos podríamos ayuda a la bella Katie. Sinceramente,La Familia Otero-Henriquez

name: Adrian's Battle Against Leukemia
text: Adrian's StoryOn July 25th 2009, my wife and I met for the first time and it was love at first sight. Soon after we got married we started planning to have a family. On July 29th 2011 our one and only son Adrian was born. Adrian brought so much life and joy into our lives and we couldn’t be happier. Adrian was a healthy little man full of life and energy.On July 24th 2015, after 5 days of fevers, we took Adrian to the doctor and requested blood work to be done on him. The very next day the doctor called us with the results. Adrian had an abnormal blood count and the doctor instructed us to rush him over to the emergency room for further testing.While at the hospital, only 2 days before Adrian’s 4th birthday, he was diagnosed with cancer in the blood (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia).After 2+ weeks at the Children's Hospital, Adrian’s condition has been stabilized through intensive sessions of chemotherapy and drug treatments. Unfortunately, Adrian is still very weak and in major discomfort due to the adverse reactions of the chemotherapy, not only that but he is also required to be in isolation due to his compromised immune system. A simple common cold can be life threatening to Adrian. Due to his current condition the doctors recommend treatment that will last approximately three and a half (3.5) years. How You Can Help Adrian?Leukemia is a stubborn and difficult disease, even with “great” medical insurance the cost of treatment is more than most families can manage.It requires a substantial amount of emotional strength and financial resources. An incredible amount of family, friends and even good Samaritans have reached out to us to give us a helping hand and shown their support.My wife and I are two hard working individuals, but for now we have to put work on hold to ensure that we can spend every possible minute that we can by Adrian's side. Words cannot explain the pain and stress that this tragedy has put us under, that’s why we have made a promise to help other families and children going throughthis long and painful battle.All we want for our son is to have a bright and healthy future. Please consider “paying it forward” to help us ease the financial burden for Adrian’s recovery.Sincerely,Adrian ParadaRamiro ParadaTeresa Espinoza

name: Breanna's Leukemia BATTLE
text: Hello Friends & Family -Kelly, Hollis & myself, BREANNA's parents & brother are asking for your help.  On Oct. 6, 2016, Brea was diagnosed with Acute Leukemia .  This is an aggressive cancer.  The costs of treatment current & ongoing will go far beyond what our insurance will cover.     Many of you know Breanna has had great Life struggles the past few years.  But, the year 2016 had been much better for her up until the recent devastating news.  Brea had been working 2-3 jobs this year, to pay her college loans, and save for moving into her own apartment in the summer of 2017.     Now, with the long recovery, she will not be able to work for at least 3-4 months, and thereafter it will be a an ongoing struggle.   We are so deeply saddened that Breanna was on-track with her goals after years of struggle, now only to have this monumental mountain to climb.  We want the best for her after her recovery, and would be extremely thankful for helping her restore her Life to normal in the next year.Kelly, Hollis, and I, AND her beloved Squeakers ALL THANK YOU so very much for helping out Brea!PLEASE share this with those who you feel may help!

name: Battling Leukemia with Yordis
text: ￼￼Hello family, friends & strangers! I have created this GoFundMe page on behalf of Yordis Rodriguez (32 years old), my fiancé’s cousin’s husband. Growing up in a Cuban family, you learn to love your cousins as siblings. My fiancé, Danny, is an only child, so Yordis is like a brother to him. He helped bring him & his wife from Cuba almost 7 years ago so they could live the American dream like the rest of us. Just last year they were finally able to save enough to buy their first home. Just over a month ago, we were all struck with the most unexpected & unimaginable news. On February 23, 2018 he went to the hospital with horrible abdominal pain, only to be diagnosed with a rare and aggressive kind of leukemia, adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. Under the care of an exceptional team of oncologists, within a few days he began the 6-week course of induction chemotherapy. After approximately 3-4 weeks, he developed a coagulation problem, medically termed D.I.C. (or disseminated intravascular coagulation). In short, the body enters a state of rapid coagulation, where blood clots form throughout the body’s small blood vessels and can damage multiple organs. As the body’s coagulation factors and platelets are used up, less of them are available throughout the body and serious bleeding can occur. Luckily with rapid and extensive treatment, doctors were able to stabilize him, with some complications along the way. Unfortunately, his white blood cell count did not respond to the first round of chemotherapy as anticipated, so a second protocol was attempted & fortunately his body responded! With heavy doses of chemotherapy, came significant weight loss, weakness, vomiting, etc. Nonetheless, he is a true champ and has endured the past few weeks and stayed strong. Currently he is undergoing continued chemotherapy and being prepped for a bone marrow transplant. A transplant is the only way to potentially cure the disease and save his life. The procedure is very expensive and his wife has been fortunate enough to be able to stay by his side throughout the process so far. However, they are in need of ongoing financial support to continue the battle and fight this! We need your help. Any little bit counts & I promise to keep all those who donate updated. Thanks on behalf of our entire family. We will not give up & with faith & hope we know we can fight this! Please share this page! —————Hola familia, amigos y extraños!Creé esta página de GoFundMe en nombre de Yordis Rodríguez (32 años), el esposo de la prima de mi prometido. Al crecer en una familia Cubana, aprendes a amar a tus primos como hermanos. Mi prometido, Danny, es único hijo, por lo cual Yordis es como un hermano para él. Él ayudó a traerlo a él y a su esposa de Cuba hace casi 7 años para que pudieran vivir el sueño americano como el resto de nosotros. El año pasado finalmente pudieron ahorrar suficiente para comprar su primera casa. Hace poco más de un mes, todos nos sorprendimos con la noticias más inesperada e inimaginable.El 23 de febrero del 2018 ingresó en el hospital con un horrible dolor abdominal, solo para ser diagnosticado con un tipo raro y agresivo de leucemia, leucemia / linfoma de células T adultas. Bajo el cuidado de un equipo excepcional de oncólogos, a los pocos días comenzó el curso de 6 semanas de quimioterapia de inducción. Después de aproximadamente 3-4 semanas, desarrolló un problema de coagulación, médicamente denominado D.I.C. (o coagulación intravascular diseminada). En resumen, el cuerpo entra en un estado de coagulación rápida, donde los coágulos sanguíneos se forman a través de los vasos sanguíneos pequeños del cuerpo y pueden dañar múltiples órganos. A medida que se agotan los factores de coagulación y las plaquetas del cuerpo, hay menos de ellos disponibles en todo el cuerpo y se puede presentar una hemorragia grave. Afortunadamente, con un tratamiento rápido y extenso, los médicos pudieron estabilizarlo, con algunas complicaciones en el camino. Desafortunadamente, su cuenta de glóbulos blancos no respondió a la primera ronda de quimioterapia como se esperaba, por lo cual se intentó un segundo protocolo y afortunadamente ¡su cuerpo respondió! Con grandes dosis de quimioterapia, hubo pérdida de peso, debilidad, vómitos, etcétera. Sin embargo, es un verdadero campeón y ha resistido las últimas semanas y se ha mantenido fuerte. Actualmente se somete a quimioterapia continua y se está preparando para un trasplante de médula ósea. Es la única manera de asegurar que se cure de esta enfermedad y lograr salvarle la vida. El procedimiento es muy costoso y su esposa ha tenido la suerte de poder permanecer a su lado durante todo el proceso hasta el momento. Sin embargo, necesitan apoyo financiero continuo para continuar la batalla y luchar contra esto. Necesitamos su ayuda. Cualquier cantidad ayuda y prometo mantener actualizados a todos los que donen. Gracias en nombre de toda nuestra familia. ¡No nos rendiremos y con fe y esperanza sabemos que podemos luchar contra esto! Por favor comparte esta página!

name: Louis Alegrias' Battle with Leukemia
text: Louis found out he had Leukemia on Memorial Day he was diagnosed with bone marrow cancer or Leukemia and was given only a few days to live without treatment. He was immediately transferred to the oncology unit at the Methodist Hospital in San Antonio, TX where he has received his first round of chemo several blood transfusions and lots of pain medication. At this time Louis is unable go work due to this crippling disease. All proceeds raised will be used to pay his bills food and travel for his treatment. He is thankful for any amount.

name: Rally for Riley - Fight Leukemia !
text: Riley Sharum is 3 and began his fight against Leukemia on April 14th, 2015. This will be a 3 year battle that will require all the strength and attention his Mom, Dad and 6 yr old Brother Tyler can muster.Even with insurance, the out of pocket expenses will be staggering. Numerous chemotherapy treatments for the next 3 years and extensive home care will direclty impact Matt & Helana's ability to work and live a normal life.Please help them stay focused on this fight and not worry about the onslaught of expenses that will inevitably come.Any amount you can give will help. If you are unable to give, please share this story.At 3, Riley wants nothing more to be like his older brother - let's help give him this chance.

name: Beckett's Fight Against Leukemia
text: Beckett Dougherty is a 9 month old baby boy, my nephew, who was diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia called Infant Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia at 2 months old. Britt and Kelley Dougherty live in Swift Current, Saskatchewan and have moved to Toronto, Ontario to get the best treatment for Beckett. We are using this site to help raise money to make the transition easier and help cover the costs that come with a serious medical condition as well as uprooting to a different place. Please consider donating to this cause. You can read more about the Dougherty family at Caring Bridge

name: Mia Cano Leukemia Fund
text: Mia, our sweet and high-spirited little buddy, was recently diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). Mia is a 5-year-old cutie, with Down's Syndrome. She has always been energetic and a ball of fun. Around Halloween, 2017, Mia began experiencing severe bone aches. Fevers, a decreased appetite and weight loss began shortly thereafter. Little Mia has been sick and weak, on-and-off, since then, and has had limited abilty to walk, due to the pain she's been experiencing. Mia's parents checked her into the Children's Hospital on Friday, January 20th and yesterday (January 24th), her test results confirmed she has Leukemia. Mia has already had to undergo two surgeries this morning - one to put a port inside her chest, and the second, a cerebral poke, to determine if the leukemia has spread to her spial fluid. Given Mia's disgnosis of Down Syndrome, treatment of her Leukemia can be a bit tricky, as she may not accept the medications as well - they may prove toxic to her body. We are asking for any support you can provide to the family during this difficult time, as the last thing we want them to worry about is finances. With the cost of treatment, hospital stays, compounded by missing work, we are hoping this fund can reduce that stress! We thank you, Mia thanks you. . .# MiaSTRONG

name: Dominic LaRocca Fighting Leukemia
text: Friends of ours, Tony and Jennifer La Rocca, received news that no parent wants to hear on Sept 19th. Their son Dominic, who is 5 years old, was diagnosed with Leukemia and has now been admitted to the hospital. From what we’ve been told, he will be there for a few weeks and is having a procedure on Monday with chemo being started immediately.Like so many, we want to help them in this time of need, so I have decided to start a gofund me account for them for anyone who wants to help. Tony and Jennifer are extremely grateful to have so many family and friends wanting to help out and send care packages to help Dominic, his twin brother Vincent, and their older brother Cameron, cope with this journey. However, by their request, if you would like to help please consider donating the money you would have spent on the care package. They are by no means asking for donations, but with everything going on: they just bought a house, they live 30 minutes for the hospital and drive back and forth, and they are supposed to be moving into their new house next weekend, anything helps. They have already started to receive a lot of gifts and don’t want to receive gifts that will not be used or potentially tossed or given away, due to so much going on.As you know medical bills can and will pile up, so if you are wanting to help in any way, this would be a great way to show support or even just sending a kind message letting them know that they are in your thoughts and you will pray for Dominic’s quick recovery.Again, they are not asking for you to donate, but want this to be a way for you to contribute if you want to help. If you would still like to send a care package for the boys (Dominic & Vincent -5, Cameron 11) please contact me and I will give you their new address. Thank you,Kathy Cole

name: Help for Leukemia
text: Hello everybody, I created this account for my dear friend Jillian whose been in the hospital for the last week. She just recently found out the devastating news of being diagnosed with Myeloid Leukemia at the age of 24. This is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow. She is going to need a minimum of 4 weeks of drug therapy in the hospital, which is going to be very expensive. Jillian is a hard working, compassionate, driven, young woman, who needs our support during this difficult time. Any donation to help support the funding of her hospital stay and drug therapy would be greatly appreciated.

name: Battle Leukemia with Bjorn
text: Our little 2 year old viking grandson is doing battle with a terrible foe...B cell Acute Lymphblastic Leukemia. After 3 months of chemotherapy and treatment at Mary Bridge Childrens Hospital were unsuccessful, he was chosen to take part in the CAR-T 100 day clinical trial at Seattle Childrens Hospital.  Our daughter and son in law will have to be with him for the duration to help him manage as his treatment proceeds. We are fundraising to help cover insurance deductibles ($5200) and to cover bills and living costs for the family for all the time away from work.Any donation is greatly appreciated, including sharing this page if you can't afford a cash donation.With your help we can battle alongside Bjorn and slay the dragon.

name: Help Alex Fight Leukemia
text: Back in late 2015, I was diagnosed with Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS). I went down to UCSF to have the diagnosis confirmed in the beginning of 2016. They said the cure to MDS is a bone marrow transplant. Instead of going through with the risky procedure (15% chance it could be fatal), I asked if it would be safe to wait a year so I could do a few exciting things before the procedure. The doctor said I should be fine given the diagnosis. Within that year I planned a trip to Disney Land, got engaged, moved to Oregon,and went on a cruise with my family. Positive stuff. Unfortunately, more negatives happened than positives.I got so sick I was bed ridden and had to cancel the trip to Disney Land, my fiance left me the day our trip was actually planned for, then was hospitalized the next day due to a giant blood clot that had formed in my right leg. While in the hospital for this enormous clot, they found that pieces had broken off and gotten to my lungs. Thankfully the clots weren't big enough to kill me, but it raised some concern with the doctors. Not having the technology to break this clot up, the hospital had to fly me to a bigger hospital in Portland, OR. While in Portland, they were thankfully able to MOSTLY deal with the clot. (I'm still currently taking medication to try and deal with it fully. Hopefully only one more month to go.) While in the hospital, I was also diagnosed with Crohn's Disease (which explained my stomach issues, but we'll come back to this).I was discharged two weeks later and picked up by my loving mother, and my brother (and my bone marrow donor). I decided to stay in Oregon a little longer and was able to stay with some friends. They, and a few others, helped me clean my stuff out of my, now old, apartment and move it to their garage for a temporary holding. My doctors didn't want me to work anymore, so I lost my job and cannot work until the clot is all gone.About a week after getting home, I received a call from the Portland Doctor saying I may not have Crohn's and might have been misdiagnosed. Yay! No..I may have an even more rare disease called Behcets. I still have yet to get the final diagnosis on that, though I finally have an appointment to find that one out.So, since I've been home, I've been constantly dealing with doctor appointments, setting up the transplant, and getting everything together financially.Moving forward on the MDS stuff. I went down to UCSF to get the ball rolling. They did some blood work and told me a bit more about the procedure. I'm not sure if the chances changed, but they told me now there is a 10% of failure (instead of 15% :D). They also found something called Blasts on my cells, calling for a biopsy. So we did a Bone Marrow Biopsy, as I posted about last week, and we finally got the results. I was called today and told that I have Acute Leukemia. I'll have to start Chemo as soon as possible to fight that before we can start the Bone Marrow Transplant (which requires a different kind of Chemo Therapy). Do to the Chemo, I'm having to contact a Fertility Clinic so I can ensure that I can have future children of my own..and the prices aren't pretty. Thankfully my family and close friends have been supportive through the whole thing. Not to mention the family members willing to put their lives on hold to be my caregivers through the procedure. Thank you all for being there for me, and continuing to do so through this little adventure.

name: Hillary's Fight Against Leukemia
text:
Hello!My name is Hillary LeBlanc, and i'm a 25 year old Nurse. I was recently diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer, ALL, (Acute B-cell Lymphoblastic Leukemia. On diagnosis, over 80% of my bone marrow cells were cancerous. I will need to receive heavy chemotherapy, transfusions, and radiation over the next 2 years, and will be unable to work. My wonderful boyfriend John created a video of my story.....

                                      How can you help?No donation is too small and no kind word is unheard. I turned to gofundme.com because the physical, emotional and significant financial burden of cancer has hit my family and I significantly hard. These donations will help cover unpaid medical bills, life-savinging medical treatments, transportation to and from hospitals, and simple everyday expenses.I want to thank everyone for all the support and kindess during the last few weeks. Please share this link to your page to help my family and I reach our goal. Thank you in advance for all the donations and love.-Hillary & John.

name: Erin's Fight against leukemia fund
text: My name is Jamie, I am the very proud Aunt of a spirited, beautiful, funny, three and a half year old named, Erin Elizabeth. Erin has a been the light in my life  and countless others since her birth. She loves her family, her friends, going to the park, playing  games with her dad, helping her mommy and most of all, playing, "mommy", to her many baby dolls. On, October 19,2016, our entire family was devastated when Erin was diagnosed with, Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Erin's mom, my sister, has been a stay at home mom since the arrival of Erin's brother, Ryan, two months ago.  My brother-in-law, Brad, works in his family  business. This small, loving, happy family, has not only been devastated by Erin's medical diagnosis, but incurred thousands of dollars in medical costs, and childcare for their infant to allow them to be with Erin during her hospital stay for treatment. I am hoping to raise five thousand dollars to alleviate some of the financial strain that this crisis has put on my sister and brother- in -law. They are wonderful, kind, generous, good hearted people who are overwhelmed and devastated by the heartache of their daughters battle against Leukimia,and financial  hardship of paying for her treatment. Whatever is given is a blessing and I am eternally grateful for any help my sister and her family receive. I wish only to allow Brad and Christen the ability to focus solely on Erin and the hard road ahead. Donations will help them be slightly less concerned with how to finance Erin care. Thank you in advance from the bottom of my heart! Erin's biggest fan,  Her Aunt JamieFIGHT LIKE A GIRL ERIN#prayforerinelizabeth#fightlikeagirlerin

name: Ashton stein's leukemia fund
text: Our beloved son Ashton stein was diagnosed with blood cancer on Monday January 2,2017. My life has fallen apart completely. He will be starting a very long road tomorrow on January 4,2017 starting his chemo. my wife and I will be traveling back and forth because our daughter is not aloud to be here as his care is intense . our lives have stopped and we accept that because he is more important than anything else. Please help as he has a long road ahead of him and with his condition and cancer type he will need chemo for the next 2 and a half years at one time a week. To my friends and family and everyone please pass this post around as help, love, and prayers are needed. God bless

name: Abjit's Leukemia Surgery
text:
Four months ago I received the news that my 14-year-old little brother was diagnosed with Leukemia. I know that not everyone has been through this, but for the ones that have, I'm sure you will agree with me saying that till now you still feel that you are just stuck in a bad dream...or at least hoping it's just that. A really bad dream. 


Sadly, it wasn't. Next thing you know, he was in the hospital with tubes and needles 24/7. I should say now, that I live in Gainesville, FL and at that time my brother was still in Peru. I hopped in the first available flight. On my way there, all I could think about is seeing him, hugging him and telling him how much I love him, but he was in such extensive care that the only way for me to get inside was with a mask, a hospital robe, and tons of foam alcohol. Even with all that, I had to stay at least 1 meter away. 


Days, weeks and months passed. We noticed he got a little better, but the doctor would always tell us not to put our hopes up, because the type of Leukemia he has(Acute Leukemia T-Cells) is an aggressive one. The odds were and still are against him. I was already back to the US by then, trying to seek help from everywhere and anywhere, but nothing. It was so bad that even the hospital from the school I go to (Shands UF Health) closed its door on my face. They didn't even bother to at least orient me where to seek help. 


From back home things seemed to be getting better, at least that is what I was told. Then one day, all of a sudden, my dad called me from the airport letting me know that they were on their way to Houston. Abjit had a paralysis and they didn’t know what to do, so they decided to go to my uncle's place and take him to closest hospital. Luckily for us that place was MD Anderson (the best for cancer in the world). They accepted him there and right away they discovered that the leukemia cells went all the way to his brain. Apparently, the hospital in Peru didn't provide him with the right amount of medicine and chemotherapy he needed.  



We wanted to try taking him to St. Jude (a charity hospital which already declined him once) but Abjit didn't want to. When he talked to the doctors and nurses at Anderson, he felt so secure that he started feeling much better emotionally. After so many months, we saw him smiling and laughing again. His hopes high rocketed with them. So, even if we wanted to take him somewhere else, we couldn’t because of his delicate condition. Any stress or worry would put him in a coma. That is why we decided to keep him there and start looking for different ways to get money. 


It's been a over a month. He is now feeling better. Doctors said that he will be ready for a bone marrow transplant pretty soon. They might even do the radiotherapy (for his facial paralysis), the transplant and ...all the treatments he needs at the same time. That is really great news for us, because it means that there is hope he would get better. But the truth is that we didn't expect all this to be so expensive. The money just flew away from our pockets to their bank accounts. 


I love my brother with all my heart and I will do everything for him, but today he needs more than that. Our hands are tied and GoFundMe is our last hope to provide the best possible treatment for him. He needs your help... Bills are to the roof and anything can help. The transplant will occur on august, and after that he will be in extensive care. He has to do it when the doctor says so, otherwise his health can worsen.Please share this with everyone you know. Its our last hope and a last chance for him to be able to live a happy childhood, and get the life he deserves. 


Please share this as much as you can and remember that help, big or small, is highly appreciated. We would always be grateful to you.

name: Emmah's Fight Against Leukemia
text: My 11 year old niece Emmah is a kind, thoughtful, spunky, funny girl who was just a few weeks away from finishing 5th grade when she and her family received devastating news. After having her examined for a seemingly simple sore throat, Emmah was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  She was immediately taken to Mott’s Children’s Hospital at U of M where treatment began within a very short time. Emmah has already had two rounds of chemotherapy and is remaining strong through it all, even somehow making all of those around her laugh while starting the fight of her life. Emmah will have to remain hospitalized for the next few weeks while the beginning chemo treatments are given. She is receiving the very best care possible here, but it will be a long road for her treatment, recovery and care.Over the next two years, Emmah will have to receive several more rounds of chemo as well as be in and out of the hospital for any treatment issues that may arise. She’ll have to miss her first year of middle school because the risk to her health is too great to be around large groups of people. There are several obstacles to overcome, but if anyone can do this, I know in my heart that Emmah will. From the moment Emmah was diagnosed, her parents, my brother Jason and his wife Tamarah, have never left her side. Tammy has taken a medical leave from work to care for Emmah and Jason has been able to take time off of work to be at the hospital as well. As anyone could imagine, this vigilance takes a toll on this family, both emotionally and financially. I am setting up this GoFundMe page for Emmah’s parents in hopes to relieve some of the stress of immediate expenses and bills so they can focus completely on their daughter’s health and treatment. Emmah has an older sister, Vedah, that is not allowed to stay overnight with Emmah so there is a lot of travel between home and the hospital as well.  We know this journey isn’t going to be easy, but we also know that Emmah is a fighter and she will beat this disease with the same bravery and strength that she has shown us all so far. We have already received such an outpouring of love and support that has taken this family by surprise and Jason and Tammy are so appreciative of it. Thank you for taking the time to read this. Any amount of support and prayers truly means the world to our family as Emmah brings such light into our lives.

name: Love for Alohilani - Rare Leukemia
text: Alohilani is an energetic, beautiful, soft spoken little girl who loves to sing, draw, and play volleyball in her spare time. One afternoon while Alohi and her father were playing, he noticed a rather large lump on her outer right thigh. Initially we thought it was just a muscle spasm. The lump rapidly grew to the size of a large egg which physically deformed her limb. We immediately took her in to the doctors, where they preformed a biopsy and found that the unknown mass in Alohi’s leg was cancerous. On November 19th, 2013 at the age of 7, Alohilani was diagnosed with Blastic Plasmacytoid Dentritic Cell Leukemia. Previously known as the Natural Killer Cell Leukemia. An aggressive rare cancer to adults, and extremely rare in children.     Her oncologist stated, she is the first child to be diagnosed and treated in the state of Hawaii. Their is little information known about this type of leukemia and no established treatment. A team of specialist, locally and nationally, formed, agreed and supported a treatment plan for Alohi. Doctors predicted that she had a 70% chance of reaching remission. Immediately, a Port-A-Cath was implanted in her upper chest and treatment was started. She began taking numerous types of pills, to intravenous chemotherapy and even multiple spinal taps. During the course of her treatment Alohi has also gone through multiple blood and platelet transfusions.     At the young age of 8, Alohi had endured an immense amount of pain, experiencing many awful days of weakness, chills, high fever, nausea, vomiting and difficulty breathing. Thus making it impossible for her to attend school. However, she has had a few exceptional days of fun with friends and family which we cherish, but they seem to be so few and far between. Remission was achieved and gave everyone in our ohana a brief moment of relief. Unfortunately, on Thursday, August 13th, 2015, after 21 months of treatment, we took her in for a routine test and results revealed Alohilani had suffered a relapse. The leukemia had returned and traveled to her brain fluids causing her to have very painful headaches.     The doctor’s let us know that if a new treatment plan wasn’t implemented soon, Alohi would pass away in just one month. A very tough decision was made to continue treatment for Alohi. The second round of treatment would require a much stronger dosage of chemo, and for the first time Alohilani would undergo radiation. This would all lead to a bone marrow transplant, with the hope of finding a donor match. This time around doctors predict a 30% chance of survival for Alohi. Alohilani, now 9 years old, understands and accepts her difficult situation. She keeps herself busy by reading, writing, and drawing. Alohi and her family humbly ask for your prayers and support through these challenging times. ALL funds gathered will help pay for her medical care and quality of life. #TEAMALOHI                                                                 Sincerely,                                                       Alohilani and family

name: Daniel Camara Amaral-Leukemia Fight
text: Our sweet sweet Daniel has been through so much in his life, and has always been a fighter. Not to mention his Mom, Maria. She has been by his side the entire time fighting each day with his previous brain surgeries, shunt replacement and just every day life for Daniel. This week, we recieved some news that he has been diagonosed with ALL pre-B Leukemia. Daniel and family have a long road ahead for recovery. Daniel will be in the hospital for at least the next month, again with Mom Maria right by his side. After that, therapy will continue for 3 years roughly 2x a week for hospital visits.  This gofund me page is set up to help the family with their financial responsibilites, as there will be no going to work for Mom,  and be sure that Daniel can get the best care possible during this difficult time.

name: Gabriella, Leukemia Superhero!
text: Out of the BlueGabriella "Gabs" Kovach is six years old. She loves the movie "Coraline" and has seen it "like a zillion times." She dresses up like Rapunzel (while singing "In Summer" by Olaf from Frozen), and likes to meet new friends at school and at church. She loves dogs and knows that when she gets one she's naming it Sunshine. And when she grows up, Gabs wants to be a Construction Worker so she can give people homes.Gabs is like SO many other six-year-olds in our country: endless energy, eyes full of wonder, an impossibly big smile, and a beautiful hunger for all that life is beginning to reveal. In short, she's coming into her own in big and powerful ways...and she was just diagnosed with leukemia. The FactsLike any parents who get this news, Jennifer and Jon were initially devastated, overwhelmed, and lost. Where do you begin to process cancer in a child? How do you make sense of something that wasn't even on the radar the day before? The unknowns seemed endless and visions of Gabriella's future, and their shared futures, instantly broke, morphed or halted. As tests came in and results were compiled, the facts started to arrive:1. The Good News: Of the two most common kinds of childhood leukemia, Gabs has the better one. It's called Pre-B (ALL) Leukemia. The 5-year survival rate for children with this kind of leukemia has greatly increased and is now 85% with proper treatment!Shaving Dad's head...Mom is next!2. The Challenging News: The cause of Gabriella 's leukemia, however, is a rare mutation called iAMP21. Found in only 2% of leukemia patients globally, iAMP21 is a mutation of her 21st chromosome, which somehow causes her chromosome to produce cancer in the form of leukemia. It means that an aggressive, intense, and longer (usually 2-3 more months) treatment of chemotherapy is necessary. In more relatable terms, it means that: her body will be more exhausted; her immune system will be more fragile; her hair will be gone longer; and her energy, spunk, and sass will be needed more than ever! Gabs will be fighting a tough and persistent battle for the next three years. The Financial RealityThough we are beyond grateful for the hopeful prognosis, the financial reality of this literally life-saving treatment is staggering. In 2009, the average cost of pediatric hospital visits alone for children with leukemia was $55,900*. Add to this the incidental expenses that pile up: missed work for both parents, mileage to and from the hospital, adaptive equipment, and the ongoing expenses of six children and it quickly becomes overwhelming! In an effort to begin to tackle these expenses, our goal for this GoFundMe is $25,000. Your gift will make this possible.The Uncles brought the Rennaissance Festival to Gabs!Strong and Courageous - Birth of a Superhero!Times of change and struggle have a way of bringing out our strength and courage.  Armed with the superpowers of faith, humor, love and kindness, Gabs WILL overcome leukemia. Thank You for Making a Difference! Please Give. That thing that we ALL fear will happen to our child has happened to our child, but we are united and committed to giving Gabs the most incredible chance at life! Treatment is already underway so your gift today would be greatly appreciated. Whether you give $10 or $1,000, YOU make a difference for Gabs and for our family.    We understand that there are many things in life you give your money to, but know that this gift will DIRECTLY change the life of a child. We are all connected - every one of us - and what we do for one we do for all of us. Thank you for helping Gabs get well again, and for letting her share her heart, smile, and courage with the world for many years to come. God has blessed us in so many ways. Thank you for your continued prayers, friendship and support. We love you. The Kovach and Saiz FamiliesPlease share this campaign with friends and family on Facebook! Together, we will reach our goal. :)Visit our CaringBridge page for updates and photos from Gabriella's journey: https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/hopeforgabs/journal* Warner, E., Kirchhoff, A., Nam, G., & Fluchel, M. (2014). Financial Burden of Pediatric Cancer for Patients and Their Families. Journal of Oncology Practice.

name: Miriam Janeth's Leukemia Treatment
text: "So do not fear, for i am with you; do not be dismayed, for i am your God. I will strengthen you and help you; i will uphold you with my righteous right hand. "Isaiah 41:10Hello family members, friends, and community,      My name is Maria Tercero and  today has been the worst day of my life.  On September 6, 2017, my mom was diagnosed with actue leukemia.  Acute Leukemia is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow, acute meaning that it is a rapid and fast acting.      She has been transferred to UCSF medical center to commence chemotherapy right away. This all happened at once and we do not know how or where we will come up with the money to pay for it. That is why I am asking for any type of donation because I know it will go a long way. I would also like to ask from you all that you keep me, my mother, and my family in your prayers.      Our family is small and my mom is my rock. She has been a hard working single mother all of my life. She supports her community and is a member of our church. This unexpected news has put a large stress on our family. Throughout this time we ask for your help. Your donation will help pay for everyday needs that will not be as easily accesible, treatment, and further medical bills. These donations will help relieve some of the emotional and financial struggles she will be going through. It will surround her with continued strength and navigate through this difficult path. We appreciate your help.        We are staying positive and know that God is here with us during this hardship. He is our Savior, our doctor, our everything and he will never leave us. This is in His hand and we are fully trusting in Him. GOD IS GOOD ALL THE TIME! GOD BLESS YOU!! ____________________________________________________________"No temas, porque yo estoy contigo; no desmayes, porque yo soy tu Dios que te esfuerzo; siempre te ayudaré, siempre te sustentaré con la diestra de mi justicia."Isaías 41:10Hola miembros de la familia, amigos y comunidad,       Mi nombre es María Tercero y hoy ha sido el peor día de mi vida. El 6 de Septiembre de 2017, mi madre fue diagnosticada con leucemia. Leucemia aguda es un tipo de cáncer de la sangre y la médula ósea, aguda que significa que es una acción rápida.      Ella ha sido transferida al centro médico de UCSF para comenzar la quimioterapia de inmediato. Todo esto sucedió de una vez y no sabemos cómo o dónde vamos a conseguir el dinero para pagar por ello. Es por eso que estoy pidiendo cualquier tipo de donación porque sé que recorrerá un largo camino. También quisiera pedirles a todos ustedes que me mantengan a  mi madre y mi familia en sus oraciones.     Nuestra familia es pequeña y mi mamá es mi roca. Ella ha sido una madre soltera trabajadora toda mi vida. Ella apoya a su comunidad y es miembro de nuestra iglesia. Esta noticia inesperada ha puesto un gran énfasis en nuestra familia. A lo largo de este tiempo le pedimos su ayuda. Su donación le ayudará a pagar las necesidades cotidianas que no serán tan fácilmente accesibles, el tratamiento y otras facturas médicas. Estas donaciones ayudarán a aliviar algunas de las luchas emocionales y financieras que ella atravesará. La rodeará con fuerza continua y navegará a través de este camino difícil. Apreciamos su ayuda.        Nos mantenemos positivos y sabemos que Dios está aquí con nosotros durante esta dificultad. Él es nuestro Salvador, nuestro médico, nuestro todo y El nunca nos dejará. Esto está en Su manos y estamos totalmente confiando en Él.¡DIOS ES BUENO TODO EL TIEMPO!¡¡DIOS TE BENDIGA!!
